item.title: Rescuing Yourself From Bad Link Building
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
DISCLAIMER: This blog post contains a bunch of hilarious and awkward stock photos because I love them so very much. For all you out there interested in doing well online, the only way to guarantee long term success in search is to create a good product, reach out to the appropriate audience, and engage with a community that will be interested in what you have to offer. That's it. It's simple, it's time consuming, and it's not something you can pay someone a couple hundred bucks to do for you. With that said, many small business owners have tried to rank well with cheap and unsustainable tactics. Several years ago an effective way to rank higher in search was to pay an SEO company very little money to spam the Internet with links to your site. They'd create blogs like this, write crappy articles, and link to you. Boom. Google thought, hey, you must be popular since so many people link to your site. Poor Google was like a kid in middle-school, assuming that the guy with the coolest clothes was automatically worth the popularity. But then Google went through puberty, got a little bit of life experience, and realized that popularity has to be earned. You have to create something that real people care about in order for Google to take you seriously. The authority of those fake links (i.e. links created by an SEO company and not by a person who actually respects you) began to crumble, and sites that were doing well in search began to plummet. If you're one of those people, if you're a small business owner who had effective, if slightly unethical, SEOs generating thousands of low-quality links for you and you find yourself slipping in search, here are some tips for rescuing yourself from bad link building.

Disavow Your Bad Links

Google doesn't want you to suffer if you're willing to change your evil link-building ways. So they've created the disavow tool, which allows you to tell them which links you don't want them to look at any more. They prefer for you to ask the webmaster of the site with the bad link to remove you first, but since most of these sites are cloaked in anonymity, it's nearly impossible to do. In fact, you may not even know what your old SEO did. But you can get an idea. Make sure you have access to your Webmaster Tools. In the traffic section of your dashboard, you can view incoming links to your site. When we go through the disavow process for a new client, we download the entire list of incoming links, then we carefully try to find out why the site is being penalized in search. Go through these links one by one. How is the link placed? Is it in an article that's unrelated to your product? Is it part of a long list of links that don't seem to be related or relevant to the rest of the content of the site? Often your link will be in a blog post that is so poorly written that it'll become clear to you that even if your SEO company was based in the U.S. or the U.K., they outsourced link building abroad. Curious what bad links actually look like? Check out this blog post: Um, what? I feel bad for Mark Gray, the Australian photographer who hired this SEO firm to build links for him. Mr. Gray, please add this link to your disavow list. For more information on how to disavow links, check out Google's instructions. If you don't feel comfortable using this "advanced feature" contact us and we can talk about working with you to disavow.

Now Build Good Links

Now that you've disavowed those hundreds or thousands of links, you'll need to get some good, high quality links. There are many ways to do this, and I recommend checking out my post Offsite SEO in Five Hours a Week to get some more ideas. But for the sake of not making you click around too much, here are a few ideas for building good links. And technically you can't really "build" links. What it comes down to is creating something interesting, interacting with the appropriate people, and being willing to give a little.

Create Something Interesting

Your product or service is probably pretty interesting to you, but that alone may not get attention. I like to use Commerce Kitchen as an example here. We are a Denver web development and internet marketing shop. Great, right? But it's not a unique service in Colorado. Denver is a big tech hub, and while our approach is what makes us stand apart, we've had to showcase ourselves by creating something different and interesting. Recently we built a very simple web application that takes quotes from director and writer Joss Whedon, who has a very excitable cult following, and turned them into an ipsum generator. Because many of us at Commerce Kitchen are huge Joss Whedon fans, it was a fun project for us. And, guess what? It got us almost 300 real links that we didn't have to ask anyone for. Those links will never be penalized by Google because they come from real people sharing a real product. If you're reading this blog post, there's a good chance you're not a web developer, so you're not going to be able to build an app like Whedon Ipsum (though you could hire someone like us to!). But I'm sure there is something creative and interesting that your team could put together if you can't yet afford to hire an ethical internet marketing firm.

Interact With Influencers

Even if you've created something great, no one will know about it unless you share it with the right people. When we created Whedon Ipsum, we tweeted it and tagged Whedonesque in the tweet, because we know they're influential. How did we know that? We did our research. However, don't assume that you should tag every influential person in every tweet that you post. Please don't do that. Instead, begin by interacting with people who inspire you in your community and industry. Build trust with them by starring their tweets, responding to their blog posts, and being a good online friend to them. For more details on how to do this, check out my blog post on interacting with bloggers. Your goal should be to build your community and make connections. It's an extension of networking, something that all business owners should do. If you've built trust with your online community, then they're more willing to share your blogs, post about your upcoming events, or tell their followers about the fun or interesting things you've created.

Be Willing to Give

Finally, to get good links you've got to be willing to give. Sponsor charitable events, throw online fundraisers, give away your product for free, or give regularly to your favorite nonprofit. This is good for the world and good for your business. Currently Commerce Kitchen is running an Office Dogs to Watch contest, and we're donating $10 per entry to Freedom Service Dogs. Admittedly we haven't gotten a ton of links for this project (maybe four or five), but giving to an organization that we like is just as important to us as getting links back to our site. As far as giving away your product or service for free, this can be a great way to get good links to your site. Find out who is writing online reviews for products like yours and send them a free sample. Or, give away your service as an online contest. Commerce Kitchen gave away free SEO setups to Denver-area organizations in exchange for a link on a blog post explaining what we do. Most of the websites we helped were pretty small, and the value of the links wasn't huge, but it was a nice gesture for our friends and community, and it got us some authentic links.
To summarize this post, in order to rescue yourself from bad link building, you need to first disavow the bad links, then you need to begin to build good links by creating a business that people want to link to and building a community that will support you. It's time consuming and it's not instantaneous. But Google will never penalize you for it, and they're links that will last. While some SEO firms remove the links they've built for you as soon as you're not longer working with them, this type of link building is long lasting. And it makes the internet a better place. We're always looking for organizations who want to be and do better on the Web. If that's you, contact us and we'll examine with you how your business can do better online.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bad Links: Rescue Yourself!
Did you hire an SEO company who built you links that you're now being penalized for? Rescue yourself from bad links!
Bad Links: Rescue Yourself!

item.title: Site Launches in Q1, 2013!
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Well, the first quarter of 2013 has come and gone, and I'd like to briefly showcase some of the sites we've launched so far this year because we're pretty proud of them. We have web developers on staff who are experts in Ruby on Rails, PHP, and WordPress, and all the sites and apps we build are customized to our clients' needs and scope. Take a look at these websites and web apps, and tell us what you think!

Ruby on Rails Apps & Websites

For larger-scale websites and custom web applications, we usually build in Ruby on Rails. Ruby on Rails is great for agile development, and, as many of you probably know, has become the preferred language and platform in the startup community. Commerce Kitchen has been building in Ruby on Rails for the past five years or so. Here are the Rails sites we've launched in 2013.

Transwest

In February we launched phase one of Transwest's new website. Transwest is a Colorado-based organization that sells and services heavy and medium duty trucks, RVs, and trailers. This app feeds real-time inventory from SalesForce into the website as well as lead processing from the website into SalesForce, on an organizational level.

Translease

Translease offers financing for truckers and fleets. While they're related to Transwest, their services are available for all organizations and businesses who need that transportation-related financing.

Landesa Landwise Library

We've been working with Landesa for well over a year now to build their library of free legal resources regarding women's land rights around the world. This year we redesigned the library's home page and added some great pagination features. Additionally, we got the app / library ready to present in front of the World Bank tomorrow. Hooray for Landesa and good luck tomorrow!

WordPress Websites

Ah, WordPress. It's one of the friendliest content management systems (CMS) around, and we take pride in ensuring that our Wordpress sites are highly usable for our clients. This empowers our clients to make regular site updates, change navigation, and add images. In other words, we want our clients, regardless of their web or tech skills, to be able to make most changes to their site on their own once it's launched. Here are some of the WordPress sites we've launched in 2013.

Hack4Colorado

Our WordPress team donated this site to Hack4Colorado, an event that brings developers together for one weekend to create apps that provide solutions for government needs. The event takes place May 31 through June 2 at Galvanize. We encourage all you Colorado tech types to check it out!

Siera

Siera provides workplace training and consulting, with extensive experience in libraries. We absolutely love the team at Siera, and it was a pleasure working with them to build this mobile friendly site.

Swallow Hill Music

Swallow Hill Music is Colorado's most-loved folk music center, offering music classes and incredible concerts. We rebuilt Swallow Hill's innards to create an easy way for them to manage their incredibly complex content, and to make the site mobile responsive. We gave them the power to make daily updates to nearly all aspects of their site.

Seattle Mortgage Planners

We've been so lucky to have Jim Hoge from Seattle Mortgage Planners as a web and internet marketing client, and this year we rebuilt his site from the ground up. Entirely mobile responsive, the Seattle Mortgage Planners' site is clean, clear, and conversion rates have already shot up dramatically in the week since we launched.

Set For Life Insurance

Set For Life Insurance is a life and disability insurance broker based in the Denver area. The owner of Set For Life is pretty much the most interesting and funny insurance broker you could ever meet. We are crazy about her. We rebuilt the website to clean up and update the infrastructure. Though we did not add a custom design layer (design was done by our amazing UX friends at Slice of Lime), we did reprogram the entire site to make it easier to manage, less bulky, and more SEO friendly.
We're working on several more Ruby on Rails and Wordpress projects right now, and keep a look out for our Q2 update this summer! If your organization needs a new website, whether it's a full-blown custom Rails app or a smaller Wordpress site, give us a call or email us today. We'd love to chat.

item.title: Do LinkedIn Ads Work?
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: UPDATE: Over the course of several months, we've gotten one click from our LinkedIn ads. While this means that we're not really paying anything, we're not getting traffic from the ads either. However, we are getting more referral traffic from our LinkedIn company page, so it's possible that people are looking at our ad and instead of clicking on it they're viewing our profile, then visiting our website from there. Our conclusion on whether or not LinkedIn ads work: not exactly, but they haven't been a drain on resources either. Hi everyone. Welcome to our journey with LinkedIn ads. Today I created our first ad campaign with LinkedIn, and each week I'll write an update on the effectiveness, cost, and visibility of our ad campaigns. We like to be completely transparent about what we do and share with other businesses our process. This keeps things interesting, teaches everyone a little something, and helps all of us do a bit better online. Today I launched two ads, targeting C-levels and directors at businesses in Canada and the United States. Kind of broad, huh? I don't know about you, but those images look terrible on my retina display. The size of the images used in LinkedIn ads and Twitter avatars tends to appear really grainy and awful on my screen. I'm using the same headline on both of our ads: Be and Do Better Online. We're experimenting with this tagline. It unites our desires for other businesses with our superhero theme. All ads are currently going to our homepage because I am doing broad targeting rather than specific web development or marketing targeting. We like to pride ourselves on integrating SEO knowledge with web dev, so I wanted to go for that idea with these ads. I've set our budget at a mere $20 per day, with a CPC (cost per click) of $2.01. LinkedIn sent me a coupon for $50, so that was why we were finally enticed to try. See? Discounts and coupons really work! I'll update you all weekly on how our LinkedIn ads are performing, what kind of traffic we're getting from them, how they're converting, and how much they cost.

item.title: Ruby Gems: What Are They?
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded: *Post by heroling Jessica. Commerce Kitchen is a fully integrated web shop. We do Rails development, CMS (Content Management System) manipulation, inbound marketing and SEO, and we can even provide IT support from our friends at Lark. Because of this, we have a lot of lingo and buzzwords zipping around, some of which we don’t all understand. I found myself speaking ‘developer talk’ last week among some marketing folks and realized we needed a connection. The topic of the conversation was custom CMSs for Rails apps compared to some CMS gems we had researched a few months back. The question from the marketing team was: what is a gem? Ruby Guides describes it fairly well, labeling it a ‘software package’ that you can bring into your application and manipulate on your system. Gems provide awesome tools to add to your toolbox, and there are many out there. You need to be careful about which gems you choose though; even if a gem may do all the things you are looking for, when was the last time it was updated? What systems is it running on? Is there good documentation from the developer? Once you have done your due diligence, you can choose that particular (or many) gems to install on your system, requiring it in your gemfile and doing a bundle install. Mind you, you will need to have bundler installed first in order for this to work properly (you can do this by typing `gem install bundler` in your command line). Making this connection was interesting because when we were discussing what a gem was, one of my co-workers made the comparison to a WordPress plugin. With a plugin on WordPress, you can find additional functionality to your blog, e.g. wp-touch which allows you to install the plugin and have a mobile-friendly theme ready to go. You can do this by either downloading the file and uploading into WordPress and activating it, or you can use the Wordpress UI with a simple search. Now, this is definitely not an apples-to-apples comparison, as Wordpress plugins give you a really nice UI to work with for easy integration. Rubygems extend what you can do in Ruby and can provide nice abstractions for dealing with complex tasks, but you still have to integrate with them in the code itself. Another comparison is Excel Macros. If you are an advanced Excel user, you may want to add functionality to use across your projects and spreadsheets, but without repeating steps each time so things stay DRY. You can accomplish this by encapsulating the functionality you need into repeatable macros that manipulate your data. This is similar to a Ruby Gem as you are working with the code to extend the capabilities of Excel, but you still have tell Excel where and when to apply the macro. See how much fun technology can be? We can find ourselves geeking out in one fashion or another all the time, whether it be a developer, a marketer, and ITer or just a plain nerd. Hope this helps clarify some things for you all. If you’re in Colorado, stay warm with this wet spring snow!

item.title: Turning Professional Humiliation on Its Head
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
*Post by heroling Elaine.

Turning Professional Humiliation on Its Head

I bombed my first technical interview. It might be the most humiliating professional thing to happen to me. Actually, it might be the most humiliating thing to happen to me, ever. I had just finished an 11-week intensive course to learn Ruby and Ruby on Rails. I was looking for my first coding job, and the company knew my newbie status. However, I myself did not fully understand my newbie status. After all, I'd already had a career -- I'm 36. I've managed teams, brokered deals, sat at the table of some really important meetings and I'm good at what I do-- in advertising. I've earned my stripes-- in advertising. I was a total noob as a programmer. And so there I was, Little Miss Accomplished, completely freaking out -- sweaty palms, elevated heart rate, and not a clue as to how to answer the two Sr. Developers' question about Active Record. And the worst part of it all -- I knew the answer. I definitely learned the answer in class. I definitely used the answer on a regular basis. But the answer was stuck somewhere between my emotional state of panic and fear. And so, I hung up the phone. And cried. And sure enough, a little while later, I got the call: they loved me. I was a great cultural fit. However, my technical skills were not where they needed to be, so they passed on hiring me. I didn't blame them. I would have passed me over too. Technical Interviews are no joke. And they are a very real way that companies hire developers. So what should a newbie do? Well, here is what I did -- I went out and talked to Hiring Managers and Sr. Developers. Found out what they were looking for, and learned their tips and tricks for acing a technical interview and how NOT TO PANIC. And now, I'm sharing that knowledge with other women in technology through LadyCoders Boulder. On May 4 - 5th at Google Boulder, LadyCoders Boulder is holding a Bootcamp. On the first day, Spotify is coming out to demonstrate their technical interview process with their lead recruiter and a Sr. Developer. I plan to have whiteboards for all attendees, and we are going to do this! The seminar is over two days because while technical interviews are the holy grail for getting the job -- there are so many other aspects to tech careers too. We plan to cover them all -- resumes, LinkedIn, negotiating a raise, starting a business, networking effectively and my personal favorite -- building confidence and risk. Also, this is not just for ladies, everyone truly is welcome. And yes, I did get a job coding. You can find me at Commerce Kitchen slaying Rails applications with my fellow Super Heros.

item.title: Google Tag Manager Is For More Than Just Marketers
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Google's Universal Analytics platform launched to the whole wide world of analytics users today! The beta version launched to a select few back in October 2012...sadly, I was not one of them. Maybe next time... In my research of this new functionality and some troubleshooting on how we could apply Universal Analytics across our clients' sites, I once again stumbled across Google Tag Manager. I'd seen this last platform year, but since I'm a reasonably tech savvy marketer who can write limited HTML and edit template files, I figured I didn't need to use it. Plus, I have a team of really smart programmers at my disposal at CK, who can drop in unlimited snippets of javascript in a millisecond, so I don't have the same constraints as a marketer in a large corporation that is constantly fighting with IT to get their tags added over a 3-month release cycle. So why this change of heart? Why am I now waxing poetic about Google Tag Manager? Because it doesn't matter who you are -- Tag Manager makes your life easier as a marketer, as a programmer and as a business!

Who Needs Google Tag Manager?

Marketers

  1. Complete control No need to corral devs to help you add tags. Want to start tracking something new? As long as you know what you want to track, you can do so in under 2 minutes.
  2. Centralized management Much like an MCC for Adwords, or the Analytics Account List that displays all of the properties and profiles you manage, Google Tag Manager centralizes all of the tracking codes that you have running on every website into once nice, neat little package.

Programmers

  1. Cleaner code Even on the simplest e-commerce sites, you have at least 4 to 5 sets of Google tracking code -- a snippet for Google Analytics, another for a specific conversion event, and as many Adwords conversion tracking codes as you have conversion opportunities (buy a product, request more information, contact us, etc.). That's a lot of snippets cluttering up the code base. With Google Tag Manager now you just need to enter 1 (one!) snippet under the opening body tag and you are done. All "tags" for analytics, event tracking, adwords, and more are handled by the business through the UI without messing with your code. Plus, if the business folks ever do get in hot water, you have a complete revision history in the interface, allowing you to isolate the problem and fix it quickly, and easily.
  2. Fewer stalkers No one likes being stalked by me -- let's just put that out there front and center. Screw chat, sending polite emails or leaving someone a voicemail. If I need something done, like RIGHT NOW, I'll wait at your desk until you have time to talk to me and help solve the problem. Not necessarily the most PC approach, but very effective. So devs rejoice! There's now one fewer reason for me to stalk you.

Businesses

  1. Greater efficiency No more marketing teams chasing developers, and developers stopping work on other revenue-generating products to add some simple javascript. Tag Manager gives your staff the tools they need to do their jobs, and will free up time spent in cross-functional meetings (now rendered unnecessary).
  2. Look like a rockstar Not only will you be able to manage your client's web presences and marketing efforts more closely, but you'll also look like a rockstar when your clients have questions. No need to search through the code to see what's running where, or log into Adwords, Analytics and any third-party tracking companies' interfaces to get an answer. You can see it all in the one interface. Any quicker response times equals happier clients and more time to focus on business development.

Get Started

Here's some great information from Google on how to migrate your sites to Google Tag Manager. And for all of you advanced users, has a great reference post on how to use macros to track analytics events with GTM. We just started porting client sites to Google Tag Manager today, but will check back in and provide you the low down as we do more complicated implementations using macros.

Difference Between Tag Manager and UTM Tags

Now you know why you have to start using Google Tag Manager, note one important thing: Tag Manager does NOT manage your campaign-level UTM tags. You still need to create those, and keep track of them however you have in the past. Maybe an integrated tagging platform that combines implementation of web tags and management of custom campaign tags will be phase 2, Google?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Google Tag Manager for Marketers, Programmers, and Businesses
Google's Universal Analytics platform launched to the whole wide world of analytics users today, and after learning all about we kind of a crush.

item.title: Interview with Superhero Brian Gryth of OpenColorado
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
CK superhero Jamie Hollier interviewed Brian Gryth from OpenColorado about his work with the state of Colorado. Here's what he has to say.

So what does OpenColorado do?

OpenColorado is an organization founded with the idea that government is on the cusp of a transformation that can lead to significant positive change. That change aims to create a govt that is easy-to-use, simple, and beautiful with compelling resources and tools. OpenColorado supports that work with two core missions: 1) Enable open access to government information (eg crime, health, GIS, and transit data). 2) Host, organize, and partner with others to educate governments and citizens on how to create more transparent, participatory, and collaborative communities. Much of the inspiration and mission of OpenColorado is influenced by the Govt. 2.0 movement and the work of Tim O'Reilly specifically. OpenColorado is a little different from some of the other groups working in this area as we are one of the oldest community data catalogs in the world. Additionally, whereas many are state-driven collections, ours is different in that it is community driven.

What resources are available through OpenColorado?

Right now, OpenColorado is home to a federated catalog that hosts data sets that are primarily from municipal governments. Data.OpenColorado.gov is where all the data is collected and it currently is just shy of 700 sets of data. This collection helps to make this information more findable and allows municipalities to create a repository and catalog of their data. At the moment, most of the information on the site is related to GIS data, but other types are being added all the time. We are also often engaged with Hackathons in the community. So far, we’ve run one of our own in 2012 and have been involved in others with Denver Startup Week. We were recently just involved with a hackathon run by the city of Longmont that 14 year old, Jackson Roberts won for his app "Longmont Events." One of the hackathons that is coming up that we are a sponsor for is the Hack4Colorado event that will be held the weekend of May 31st and that coincides with the National Day of Civic Hacking.

What are some of the reasons that you are involved in hackathons?

The reason hackathons are of benefit is because data is nice, but it has to be applied to make it relevant for most of the public. The hackathons allow us to take open data and make it into web, mobile, and other applications in order to increase the relevance of our data. The best way we have found to turn that data into tools is through hackathons. However, that is not to say that just a 48 hour work time will get you to a good, complete tool, but it gets you started and it exposes people to the possibilities of this data. A hackathon is also a good proof of concept for different models of civic engagement. This illustrates to those involved, developers, designers, etc. that they can impact civic engagement and increase community involvement in different ways with the skills they already have. For example, many developers may not like door knocking or community meetings. However, they still care and they can make a big difference by working with software to build tools that connect the government to the people and vice versa.

How did you get involved in OpenColorado and the open government movement?

First, I was always interested in technology, but having my daughter a few years ago really opened my eyes to how technology could change her life. Based on that realization and my interest in that, I became aware of the the Govt. 2.0 movement. Then, during a project at my day job at the Secretary of State’s office, I was working on a session for an event and was able to bring in leaders from the Govt 2.0 world for that session. In 2010, another OpenColorado founder, Sean Hudson, went to CityCamp in Chicago and was advised by Tim O'Reilly to implement Sean's idea to create a community data and idea sharing platform In June of 2010, Sean, myself, and the other founders Michele Hovet and Scott Primeau launched the first irritation of what would become OpenColorado. And the rest is history.

Are you a developer? What is your background?

I have a background in political science and I am a lawyer. At my Secretary of State job, I mostly I do management consulting. For OpenColorado I handle most of our business development, evangelizing, and partner development. Being a non-tech person in a tech field, I have always found it interesting and challenging. I can understand the non-tech person’s perspective which means I am skilled at helping to understand the challenges and pitfalls from a user’s perspective. Also, in any space, you need a balance of tech and non tech people to balance things out and create the right tools and solutions. Tech is dependent on the business side of the work as well and I bring that skill set to our work. In a way, I feel like that is what government has been missing, the business side of managing technology. That is not to say that government should be run as a business, but that more understanding and relations between political science, government, business, etc. will make technology and government more effective. Also, I love where I am right now. Being in a tech space is exciting and it is where a lot of the cool stuff is happening and where everything is moving, especially for civics since it allows you to provide more services for less costs. In the civic technology space it is really just getting started, we are in on the ground floor at the beginning. This is the start of something important and impactful and will change the way people will live.

item.title: The Love Affair With Big Data
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
This year at SXSWi (South by Southwest Interactive), a tech festival that brings together marketers, entrepreneurs, startups, designers, and programmers, Big Data was everywhere. Panelists discussed harnessing data; Nate Silver presented on his methods for gathering Big Data and making predictions accordingly; startups are producing apps to help companies organize and act on Big Data. Everybody's hot for numbers. I get that. We need information, data, to support our processes, to guide us into making intelligent decisions for our organizations. But the artist, the Humanities nerd, the right-side-of-the-brainer, as well as the realist in me cringes at the trendiness of and seemingly blind allegiance to Big Data. This week the New York Times published an article about film studios applying Big Data to screenplays. A statistician created an equation to determine what plot elements will fail at the box office and which ones will succeed. For example, if you summon a demon with a Ouija board, it's not as likely to do as well as if you are the target of a demon's wrath. Huh. Film studios rely on this data to choose which screenplays to buy and which ones to discard. While using data to determine how studios spend their money seems like a safe bet, I can't help but feel like there is going to be an incredible loss of creativity, absence of risk, and pop-cultural stagnation. And I think there's something missing here. Interestingly enough, television is moving away from the deeply-flawed Nielsen ratings in exchange for aggregating insane amounts of data to understand their successes. However, TV networks are also more willing to take risks right now, relying on social media-based crowd-sourced marketing to do its thing. Shows with cult followings, such as Arrested Development, were canceled due to poor Nielsen ratings. Netflix, as opposed to a traditional television network, is capitalizing on the cult following and by reviving the show after a several-year hiatus, it will probably make a killing. Television is no longer just on a television. Shows have generated enormous audiences of viewers who do not engage with television in the way that they used to.
I'm a great example of this. I am 33-years-old, and I haven't had cable or network television ever in my adult life. Yet I spend at least twenty minutes a day watching TV shows through iTunes, Netflix, Hulu, or the networks' own apps on my iPhone or laptop. In fact, the only television show I've watched when it aired in the past few years was this year's Oscars, and Seth McFarlane's performance was worse than most of the comedy open-mic nights I've been to, so I doubt I'll waste my time with that again. So what's missing from the way the film studios use Big Data? Everything that comes after the box office. The truth that innovation can result in passionate fans, even if the movie doesn't best GI Joe Two (cringe) at the box office. Having a cult hit is the gift that keeps on giving. Creating interesting and unique content is a risk, but as all business people and artists know, creativity and risk are what change the world. Think different, right Steve Jobs? What does all this have to do with Internet Marketing, my department here at Commerce Kitchen? Well, Big Data is useless if you're not looking at what comes next. I'm lucky to have more number-driven people on my team here, but I don't think numbers can or should dictate how we engender passionate communities. Let's understand what has worked and what hasn't worked in the past, and let's allow that to inform our decisions. But let's not stifle our creativity based on an equation of what normally works. There have been plenty of demons summoned in successful films in the past, and there will be again in the future. And in fact, Paranormal Activity, today's demon franchise of choice, was a surprise hit. Likewise, when I do keyword research I don't just look at the highest volume search terms; instead, I look at which search terms convert well, which ones are the most relevant, which ones make sense within the context and within the ethical SEO strategies we're committed to, and what the intent of the searcher is. In other words, I look beyond the numbers and into the habitus, the thought processes, and the emotions of the actual people behind the numbers. This is where my experience in the Humanities comes in handy. Big Data helps us quantify an existing ethos, but it doesn't necessarily help us predict the next one. In being adventurous and taking risks, creative content, whether it's film, television, literature, or even marketing, not only responds to the cultural milieu, but it helps create it, too. After I began writing this post, an article was published last week that explains why Big Data isn't really big data at all; it's simply what we've begun to call data analysis. The article makes some excellent points about the dangers of falling for Big Data without understanding its limitations:
Biases in how data are collected, a lack of context, gaps in what’s gathered, artifacts of how data are processed and the overall cognitive biases that lead even the best researchers to see patterns where there are none mean that “we may be getting drawn into particular kinds of algorithmic illusions,” said MIT Media Lab visiting scholar Kate Crawford. In other words, even if you have big data, it’s not something that Joe in the IT department can tackle—it may require someone with a PhD, or the equivalent amount of experience. And when they’re done, their answer to your problem might be that you don’t need “big data” at all.
We shouldn't abandon data and data analysis, but we should be more realistic about its possibilities and pitfalls. I'd like to see our love affair with Big Data evolve into something else: an orgy that includes numbers, calculations, emotions, creativity, spontaneity, and risk.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Marketers and startups are all hot for Big Data, but there's something that the algorithm is missing: the human piece.
The Love Affair With Big Data
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/05/love-affair-with-big-data/

item.title: An Intro to Sprites in Adobe Illustrator
item.dc:creator: Goodtimes
item.content:encoded:
For my first Lightning Talk at Commerce Kitchen, I presented how to use some essential tools in Adobe Illustrator and how to setup a sprite, the right way. I thought this would be a good introduction to Illustrator because not only did my co-workers get to learn some of the basics of the program, but it also gave them some insight on the workflows within the software. The other main goals for this presentation was to show everyone some real nifty pro-tips inside Illustrator.

What is a Sprite?

Sprites have a somewhat long history and do different things depending on the platform. In terms of the web, they are simply used to decrease the number of requests to the browser, which speeds up load time for a website. Instead of loading in ten different image files of the same sized icons, why not put all those icons on one image and then display only certain parts of that image as needed? This is exactly the function a sprite serves, in essence it is one large image tiled with lots of different images. Then by using CSS background-positioning, height and width, we can hide and display only certain areas of that image as desired. One of the most common uses for a sprite is a button: static (regular display), hover (mouse over state) and active (clicking). However, when creating these sprites in Photoshop or Illustrator, many designers lazily eyeball the spaces in between the buttons. Even though those spaces aren’t being displayed, it makes it a pain for the developer if they are not completely pixel perfect. By that I mean, exactly 10px vertically spaced from each other. Illustrator and Photoshop have many super handy tools when it comes to making these sprites pixel perfect. Some of the different tools I highlighted in this presentation are the Align Tools, Guides, and Measuring Tools. The other key aspect to this presentation was to go over how to correctly set up the document and save images out for the web.

item.title: Why We're Platform Agnostic
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: I've written a lot about why we like Ruby on Rails and the benefits of WordPress. But I don't think I've ever taken the time to explain why Commerce Kitchen is a platform agnostic development shop, and why we want our developers to have the ability to learn new programming languages, even if their first language isn't something we often build in. First, let me define what that means. Historically the phrase platform agnostic has been used synonymously with "cross platform" to describe software that works on various operating systems and devices, rather than software that only works on, say, a Mac. Another example of this is a videogame that is available on the Xbox, Playstation, and Wii, rather than just on one machine. However, when we use the term platform agnostic to describe ourselves, we're referring to our belief that our clients have different needs according to their service or product, and while one platform or code base might work for one client, it might not work for another. We have the skills to build in the platform that will best suit your business. Because consulting is such a central part of the way we operate, we take the time to dive into our clients' needs before recommending a platform. Your business might be best served with a Ruby on Rails application. Your e-commerce site might do better on Magento. Or maybe a mobile-first WordPress site is exactly what your organization needs. Some development companies are one-trick ponies, and they do that one trick impeccably. However, if you go to those web shops they aren't going to tell you if your site needs a platform other than the one they build in. Instead, they'll push you toward the one solution they offer, even if it doesn't actually meet your needs. That way of operating does a disservice to the web, even if it does a great service to their bottom line. We want to set our clients up for success, taking their strong businesses and great ideas and making them real online in a way that's practical, interesting, and converts well. This handsome man pictured on the right is one of our developers. While we originally hired him on as a PHP developer, he's also amazing at Ruby on Rails. What luck! A brilliant guy who likes goats and can quickly excel at a new programming language. As I've mentioned in the past, Ruby on Rails is incredibly popular right now with startups, but there is always the chance that another language and platform will come along to take its place. For us this is exciting because it gives us the opportunity to constantly learn and grow as a company, and it provides our clients and potential clients with more flexibility. Plus, I get to throw in my SEO two cents in all of our builds to make sure they're optimized for search from the ground up. And as anyone who's familiar with SEO knows, that too changes as search engine algorithms weigh certain features over others. To sum up, Commerce Kitchen calls ourselves platform agnostic because we believe that there isn't one platform that can cover everybody's needs equally. We choose one that makes sense for you, and if it's not something that we do, then we are happy to recommend someone else who can. We just want your site to work well.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Platform Agnostic | Why We Build in Many Platforms
Commerce Kitchen believes that different goals and needs require different web solutions. We are platform agnostic. We know & recommend different languages.

field_51acf05ad0fec

item.title: Gluecon 2013
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded: Conferences are the name of the game around here at CK. I had the opportunity to attend Gluecon this year, alongside Elaine Marino, another heroling at Commerce Kitchen. A bit of background on what exactly Gluecon is. No, it has nothing to do with Elmer’s glue. Eric Norlin is the organizer and puts on two conferences a year here in the Denver area (Broomfield to be exact): Gluecon is in the spring, and Defrag is in the fall, and he does an absolutely phenomenal job. There is some crossover between the two in relation to attendees, but there is also a big difference. While Defrag takes more of a business approach, focusing on the implementation of APIs on a corporate level, development tools for marketers and more, Gluecon is for the super nerds, covering topics such as Cloud, Mobile, API’s, Big Data, Node.js and Hadoop from a development perspective. This year’s agenda was filled with amazing speakers, and I was thoroughly impressed. “Glue is a case study of what a conference is supposed to be.” Gluecon typically starts with a hackathon on Tuesday night, then leads into a two day long conference on Wednesday and Thursday, where at the end of it all, your brain will be either mush or exploding with ideas and inspiration after hearing all these amazing people speak. Plus, the conference is structured so that you can go up to any speaker afterwards and have a solid conversation with them and make a great connection from it all. I know I have personally made some great friends from this conference specifically and I am sure I’m not the only one. At this year’s conference, I enjoyed: “Confessions of a Tech CEO Who Still Loves to Code Everyday”, from Lew Cirne, CEO of New Relic. He talked about how he is still able to do what he loves because the team he’s put into place helps balance his plate of to-dos. Because of this, he is able to take one weekend a month to code and contribute to his team. His talk was inspirational to many, showing developers and managers that it is possible to do both. Being a good speaker probably helps with this as well. “Creating Sustainable Documentation with Jekyll”, from Brandon West, Developer Evangelist at SendGrid. He discussed how important documentation is, as well as how to keep it sustainable. Hint, this is NOT done in Wordpress! “Start Small & Go Big: Getting the Most from Google Compute Engine”, from Joe Beda at Google “The Pros and Cons of Choosing Go” from Brady Catherman at Apcera Overall the conference was a huge success this year and bonus, I saw a total of 19 women (double from last year)! I am looking forward to Defrag later on this fall; it should be another winner! If you have any questions or just want to chat, hit me up on twitter: @jessicag

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: CK's heroling Jessica discusses highlights of Gluecon, 2013 and what makes the conference so rewarding.
Gluecon 2013

item.title: Google's Quantum Computer & Paranoia
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen is, quite naturally, obsessed with the singularity Our CEO Tynan delved into some good old-fashioned paranoid speculation regarding Google's new quantum computer. How quickly will it gain intelligence? Tynan makes an educated guess. As our superhero fire-siren Leslie pointed out, Google's use of quantum computers might be a reason for pause, but what about Lockheed Martin's? The giant weapons manufacturer acquired a quantum computer over two years ago. While Google's quantum computer may speed up my Gmail connection, what will Lockheed's do? Anyone? Matthew Broderick, where are you? Popular culture has its share of evil fictional computers, and there's something about a fleshless consciousness that both excites and terrifies us. HAL 9000, voted one of the best film villains of all time, is almost spookier than the evil robots who look like humans, maybe because we can't see the malice in his face but have to infer the extent of his evilness from the calmness in his voice and his one winking red eye. Of course we can't help but get a big old evil crush on Battlestar Galactica's human-shaped cylons, complete with bio-engineered flesh and blood. And Agent Smith from the Matrix series was a charming and formidably villainous computer-generated human form. Despite our fantasies of battling artificial intelligence and coming out on top, we've already lost. As I've mentioned before, we are all cyborgs. Fortunately there's still human thought behind the algorithms and technologies that shape our lives, but how many of us are contributing to that and how many of us are allowing ourselves to be swallowed up by it? Maybe I'm cynical because, as an SEO, I spend so much time working to understand an algorithm better, praising it as it becomes more human-like but also criticizing it when it acts like the kind of human whose behaviors and assumptions I disagree with. Sometimes I try to imagine what I would do if something disastrous happened and the internet shut down completely. Sure, I'd be out of a job, but even more importantly, how would I know how to care for a wound? How would I get directions to the nearest clinic? Who would I make 140 character pithy observations to, if not my Twitter followers? Who would validate the hilarity of my child's interpretations of the world if Facebook were gone? Side note: I planted a tomato plant this year, and I am proud to say that I haven't had to use the internet once to find out how to pour water onto the soil.
I asked some of our other staff members to present their views of the singularity to balance out Tynan's gentle, um, anxiety. Here's what they had to say: I love Kevin and Goodtimes / Aaron's responses for their pure denial, but I also think we have some pretty insightful and interesting ideas about the singularity. Do you believe?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Google's Quantum Computer and the Singularity
We think about the singularity a lot here at Commerce Kitchen, and Google's recent acquisition of a quantum computer has once again got us thinking.
field_51acf04ed0feb
field_51acf05ad0fec

item.title: Bandwagons and Rankings and Conversions, Oh My
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Your competitors are ranking higher than you in search. So what do you do? You go to their website, you cringe at the stockphotos, you criticize it as confusing and out of date, then you ask your web team to emulate it exactly. Because if they're ranking number one, they must also be raking in the bucks. No, no, no no. First of all, rankings do not equate with conversions. Let me say that again:

RANKINGS DO NOT EQUATE WITH CONVERSIONS

Assuming you've done careful keyword research and have a good reason for going after those keyphrases, rankings can be important. But believing that your competitor is doing better than you online is not based on facts. For one, you don't have direct access to their analytics, unless you've got a spy reporting to you from the backend. You don't know how long people are staying on the site, where they're clicking, how they feel about what they see, or how often they're converting. And a reminder:

RANKINGS DO NOT EQUATE WITH CONVERSIONS

Clients often ask us to make changes to websites based a knee-jerk reaction to what their competitor is doing. However, our years of conversion optimization experience informs us that what your competitors are doing sometimes, well, sucks. (What's happening on this site? Why is it so terrible?) This isn't always the case. We see beautiful and well thought-out sites all the time, and if we think someone has a great design idea, then we don't see a problem in paying homage when it's due. A good website does the following:
  • It does well in search
  • It causes people to perform an action, e.g. to call you, email you, buy your product, etc.
  • It allows people to do what they need to do as easily as possible
  • It engenders trust and confidence
Have you ever walked into a store and immediately felt uncomfortable? Either the salespeople are too aggressive, the layout of the store is confusing and you can't find what you're looking for, or maybe it just smells weird.
Websites are like that too. Rather than allowing your competitors to dictate your design, let user experience experts work with you to decide what people respond to well, and then implement that on your site. You should be concerned with earning your potential clients' trust and making your existing network happy, not obsessed with one-upping your competitors.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Bandwagons, Rankings, and Conversions | Ranking Aren't Everything
Just because your competitors are doing better than you in search doesn't mean you should copy their web design. Please, please don't.
field_51acf04ed0feb
field_51acf05ad0fec
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/06/rankings-arent-everything/

item.title: Introducing Our Reed College Interns!
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
This summer we're hosting two interns from Reed College for an inbound marketing / linkbait internship. Our COO, Michelle Drumm, graduated from Reed College back in 1995, and we're excited to connect with the Reed community. Without too much ado, I'd like to introduce our Reed College interns.

Sofia Wright

Sofi is a mathematics major scheduled to graduate in 2014. We're excited to have Sofi's mad math and compsci skills contribute to developing infographics and fun freebies. When she's not doing math stuff, she's 1/2 of an identical twinship,  she likes cosplay (yay!) and making costumes, and has participated and led service learning projects in Ecuador.

Rebecca Richman

Rebecca is an anthropology major at Reed, who's planning on graduating at the end of 2013. Rebecca has the Humanities brains that are incredibly valuable for marketing, especially in terms of researching and understanding communities. Rebecca has acted as the Ping Pong Room manager at Reed, so we're looking forward to seeing what she does with our ping pong table. Watch out, Lark IT, we're sicking our interns on you!
Sofi and Rebecca are busy researching how to create successful linkbait, and they're already generating some awesome ideas together. If you come by Wine Friday soon, please say hi to these two and challenge them to ping pong.

item.title: Linkbait Interns Reflect, Week 1
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hello! We are the Reed College interns! We're here for nine weeks and we'll be documenting our Commerce Kitchen experience via blog. Join us on our adventure! (Sofi, left, evil look, is that type of hero who's always in danger of going to the dark side!)  

Sofi Says:

This experience marks many firsts for me. First time visiting Denver. First summer living away from home. First paid internship. First experience working in marketing. And here, my first blog entry; it only makes sense to talk about my first impressions.

Impressions of Denver:

Lots of trees. And cars. A four-lane one-way street? That’s crazy! It’s youthful. And active. People who like to socialize. And drink beer. And get outside. I’m going to like living here.

Impressions of the Work:

I had never heard of linkbait before taking this job. Or inbound marketing. But in just a week I have already learned a ton! It’s a way more elaborate process than I could have imagined: from researching the client and their audience before generating ideas for the linkbait to securing some prominent “linkerati” before the project even goes live, and then tracking the success of the linkbait after it is launched. And I’ll be doing this all in the next few weeks! Whew!

Impressions of Commerce Kitchen:

Awesome workspace (there are Star Wars and Firefly posters on the walls; need I say more?). Likewise, awesome people; with nerdy and diverse interests, they treat each other like family, and they have fun doing their work. They have been incredibly welcoming and I am ecstatic to be joining this team for the next couple months! (Proof of awesome workspace.  Stay hydrated and use the Force!)  

Rebecca Says:

Coming to Denver

I’m Rebecca! The Anthro major and not-so-ping-pong-y Ping Pong Room manager intern (Sorry guys! Lark IT might still have us beat)! My ping pong skills aside, I’m very happy to be here! This week has been a bit of a whirlwind, but by that virtue, exciting. In a little over a week, I have flown from LA to this hot, beer-drinking metropolis that is Denver, set up a condo, had furniture delivered and worked a full week here at Commerce Kitchen. I’m having a lot of fun and everyone is so nice!

About the Work

I’m struck by the difference between theory and practice in SEO; understanding it is one thing and doing it is totally another. Despite this challenge, it makes it all that much more exciting when you get that piece of information you’re looking for! Or find out where to get it, or find out that it doesn’t exist or find out that place you’re looking is wrong. Either way it’s progress. We spent this week researching SEO and how it may or may not be dead, as well as linkbait and some strategies on how to make and deploy it. We’ve also begun researching target markets. This is the hard stuff, it seems. We’ll get the hang of it. Hopefully, we’ll be churning out some good stuff soon!

Stay tuned for the next installment of: THE SUPER INTERNS!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: field_51acf04ed0feb
field_51acf05ad0fec
Reed Interns Move to Denver to Learn SEO and Develop Linkbait
CK's Reed College linkbait interns reflect on coming to Denver, their work environment, beer and SEO.

item.title: Linkbait Internship: Tracking and Metrics
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hi! It's Rebecca.This week, I'll be writing a reflective post. Next week, you'll get Sofi! Enjoy!

Life at Commerce Kitchen:

Metrics!

[caption id="attachment_3695" align="alignleft" width="300"] I love it when data is clearly presented![/caption] This week, Sofi and I have been researching methods of tracking linkbait. You can find your market and create your content, but if you can’t see the effect it has had, there isn’t much of a point and you won’t learn anything about your content or your audience. Monitoring efforts is important in deploying anything, but it is particularly important for SEO as it constitutes one of the main means of reaching your market. Thunder SEO presents this nice overview of the types of links linkbait can get and various tools to track them. But your infographic or other linkbait is responsible for a lot more than links. Though its primary and eponymous purpose is links, as this article suggests, linkbait also plays a part in views and conversions. Tracking just for links and content reposts misses a crucial aspect of linkbait.

Our Plans:

For our project, we are going to use Google Analytics to track any traffic to the Commerce Kitchen site as well as monitor Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest for shares, views, and the amount of conversation surrounding what we post (see what Avinash has to say about the Facebook TAT metric). We don’t know how much traction we'll get with any of these metrics, but by careful tracking we'll establish a baseline and go from there!

Life in Denver:

At home:

We’ve pretty much settled in now. We’re walking different ways to work and finding good places to eat. Just last night we got take-out from Taki Sushi and watched a Japanese movie Sofi picked out called “Kamikaze Girls”. It’s a humorous and heartfelt about two very different girls and their adventures together; I highly recommend it!

Out and About:

[caption id="" align="alignright" width="300"] The Byers Evans House![/caption] We also went out to Pints Pub with an intern at the Byers-Evans House Museum. Lydia told us her impressions of Denver as a native and the best places to go and where to do things. Hopefully, we can go visit the museum soon; It’s over 100 years old and more than 10,000 square feet! Wow!

Denver at Large:

One thing that I noticed earlier but have recently really experienced is how easy it is to get around in Denver and how well placed everything is! The buses come frequently and there are so many libraries. There is the main branch and a ton of side braches everywhere. They get requests in so quickly too. What an easy place to live in! I love LA, but getting anywhere is a pain and things take so long. I’m Looking forward to another seven weeks in this lovely city.   Next time on the adventures of the SUPER INTERNS: SOFI’s Super Scintillating Segment!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Our Linkbait Interns Discuss Metrics
Linkbait is designed to get people interested in your website. Our intern Rebecca discusses what she's learned about tracking it.

item.title: Introduction to Image Formats on the Web
item.dc:creator: Goodtimes
item.content:encoded:
As a designer at Commerce Kitchen, I get a lot of requests from clients and coworkers for images, logos, icons, you name it. No problem there, I'm happy to oblige, however simply asking me "Hey, can you send me that logo?" is only half of the information I actually need to complete the task. First of all, what is the use of the image, web or simply delivering assets to a client? Let's assume it's for the web, then what is the correct file format? If it's a photograph, chances are a JPG is the best option. If it's an icon a PNG makes more sense. What color is the background it's going to be used on? Are there other icons because a sprite might make more sense. All of these questions are things I consider when exporting out an image from Photoshop or Illustrator. This why it is incredibly important for everyone on the team to know exactly how images work on the web. Throughout the rest of this post I will highlight the most important and popular image formats to use on the web.

Raster Vs. Vector

It always surprises me how few people know the difference between the two of these. A raster image is one that is made up of a set number of pixels on a grid call "resolution" or PPI (pixels per inch), each assigned with a different color value. A vector graphic, such as an EPS or a AI file are made up of shapes and paths on a mathematical plane. In other words, its making an image using math, therefore, there are no pixels with specific color values, only shapes and paths with a set fill and/or stroke. This allows it to be resized without ever losing quality. In the image below you can see the difference between resizing a vector graphic opposed to resizing a raster graphic.

Lossy Vs. Lossless

This is very straight forward. Lossless means there is no compression on the image. On the web a PNG-24 is actually the only lossless image available. However, other files that are lossless are PSD, TIFF and RAW. Lossy means that the image is being compressed, which great for the web because load time is a very important aspect of web design, especially when creating responsive websites. On the web, lossy formats are GIF's, PNG-8's and JPG's.

GIF

GIF stands for Graphics Interchange Format and it is a raster image format introduced by CompuServe (remember them?) in 1987. According to Wikipedia, Steve Wilhite, the creator of the GIF format, intended the pronunciation to deliberately echo the American peanut butter brand, Jif, and CompuServe employees would often say "Choosy developers choose GIF", spoofing this brand's television commercials. These days PNG-8's are much higher quality and actually smaller, therefore GIF's serve only one purpose now, as seen below.

JPEG

JPEG stands for Joint Photographic Experts Group, named after the committee that developed it in 1986. It was created because photographers were frustrated with large files and GIFS couldn't deliver the kind of quality they were looking for. JPEG's offer super high quality images at a seriously reduced file size. when using photographs on the web, the JPEG is your go-to image format. Also there are three types of JPEG's, baseline, optimized and progressive. Progressive is actually slightly larger than optimized but the way the web browser reads the image actually allows it to have a much faster load time. To read more about them check out this post.

PNG-8 & PNG-24

First of all, I could probably write a whole blog post just about PNG's. Nevertheless, it stands for Portable Network Graphics, created as a powerful alternative to the GIF because of the Unisys Patent on LZW compression that emerged in the mid 1990s. Like I mentioned before, PNG-24 is lossless and is also the only image format available on the web that has true alpha transparency. This means that you can have an image as a block level element (otherwise know as a rectangle) with areas of the image with little or no color information. These are great ways to overlay images on a background or if you don't know what the background color is it will always look good because of the alpha transparency in the anti-aliased pixels. A PNG-8 has pseudo transparency. You can either have a pixel with no color information, or 100% color information, there is no in between like you do get with a PNG-24. However, PNG-8's are much smaller typically a good to use if you know what the background is. Instead of using true alpha transparency, PNG-8's try to fake it by changing the color of the anti-alised pixels with the background color that you provide. The background color you set for the PNG-8 is called a matte, which comes from an old photography lingo. However, if the matte is not properly set you will end up with some super ugly anti-aliasing as you can see in the image below. The second image is a PNG-24 which means it has true transparency and will always look good no matter the background color. [caption id="attachment_3658" align="alignleft" width="300"] This was exported out as a PNG-8 with a black matte, hence why it looks so bad![/caption] [caption id="attachment_3658" align="alignleft" width="300"] This was exported out as a PNG-24 so no matter what the background is it will always look good.[/caption]

SVG

Last but certainly not least, are SVG's which stands for Scalable Vector Graphics. These are super cool, however, browser support for them is not good, if you are looking at this on Internet Explorer 8 or below, then you are not going to see any image below. (Sorry IE users...) These are super rad images because they are vector graphics which means that no matter what size it is it will always be 100% perfect quality. Don't believe me, zoom in a bunch on your browser and I can guarantee it will still look perfect. The only difference between an EPS or AI file and an SVG is that the SVG is written in such a way that it can be read by a browser. In fact you can open it up with a text editor, which actually opens a lot of doors when it comes to manipulating the image with CSS or JS. However, like I mentioned before, it is made up of shapes and paths, so a photograph can never be a vector graphic unless every single pixel was actually a shape, which is made up of four points and a fill color. Why don't people do that? Because they would be entirely too large and it just simply isn't worth the time to convert it to that. However, if you are just putting up images of superheroes it might be perfect solution. Nevertheless, browser support is still lacking so there is very little desire to actually use them on the web. Overall this is a very basic introduction to different kinds of image formats available on the web. As you can see it is far more complex that most people imagine. In the time where we are building for many different browsers on many different devices, images can be one of the biggest factors to speeding up (or slowing down) your website. I hope this post will inspire you to do more research about image formats and how to correctly use them on the web.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: image formants on web
Intro to Image Formants on Web
An introduction to image formats on the web, including the differences between raster and vector, lossy and lossless, and the beloved GIF.
image-formats-on-the-internet

item.title: Linkbait Internship: Planning and Brainstorming
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hey, Sofi here. Over our first two weeks Rebecca and I researched linkbait and metrics, learning the ropes of SEO and internet marketing. But this week our time has finally come ... to TAKE ACTION!

Action at Commerce Kitchen:

Brainstorming Linkbait

Our first linkbait clients are... ourselves! Commerce Kitchen. I spent Monday and Tuesday researching CK's audience – studying our Twitter and Facebook following and scanning the local startup network on Built in Denver. On Wednesday, Rebecca and I met with CK marketing heroines Leslie, Natalie and Jen for a brainstorming session. [caption id="attachment_3741" align="alignright" width="300"] A whiteboard is an essential tool for brainstorming.[/caption] It was an intensive process: once we had thrown some linkbait ideas on the whiteboard, we examined each one-by-one. What audience is this idea appealing to? Is there a better way to reach this group? How can we make this unique to CK? And so we weeded out the problematic ideas and improved upon the stronger ones. Our process followed many of the steps from this useful guide. We settled on the best idea to pursue, and Rebecca and I are already marching forward with it. I think we want to keep the idea under wraps until the linkbait is launched, but it's going to be fun, so stay posted!

Learning To Code

As an exciting bonus this last week, in our free time from linkbaiting Rebecca and I have started to learn some coding from CK's web dev superhero Aaron. He showed us some basic Unix last Friday and over the weekend we attended his workshop on HTML and CSS.  We learned a lot in just a single day, and I would recommend that anyone serious about learning or advancing their web development knowledge check out DevCamp.us's future workshops.

Action in Denver:

Adventures this Last Week

In addition to learning some HTML last weekend, Rebecca and I attended the Japanese Cherry Blossom Festival downtown, where we browsed vendors' stands, ate good food, saw a lot of interesting people, from musicians to cosplayers, and even saw a shiba inu! Did anyone else make it there? Later in the week I went for a jog in Washington Park, and I've never seen so many people doing active things in one place: people running, walking, playing volleyball (and at this altitude!). I have decided that Denverites must be  some of the most in-shape people in the country.

Future Plans

A few CK team members have assumed the duty of making sure Rebecca and I are doing cool things while we're here, so we've started a list that will keep us busy for the next few weeks. Let us know your favorite things to do in Denver and we will check them out! Next week on the adventures of the Super Interns: Rebecca will regale readers with her riveting reflections!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Our Linkbait Interns Discuss the Brainstorming Process
Commerce Kitchen interns embark on the brainstorming process for developing online marketing linkbait, to improve SEO and appeal to a target audience.

item.title: How to Use Pinterest for Business
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Ah, Pinterest. The Internet’s answer to hoarding. Pinterest is filled with an array of extremely diverse boards, ranging anywhere from the quintessential food board, to the continuously growing “dream closet”, to a board used exclusively for someone’s undying obsession with David Tennant (and there are a lot of those). It is a beautiful social media platform, and I love it. While its consumers may not be as demographically diverse as those on Facebook and Twitter, Pinterest has the capability to encourage interaction between a consumer and a brand, in ways that other social media platforms cannot. Based on a June 2013 study, people prefer to interact with brands on Pinterest. Yes, that’s right. I’m saying it… Don’t underestimate Pinterest. Why, you may ask? It has been my experience, having worked extensively on both personal and business accounts, that Pinterest takes time. It can sometimes take days, weeks, or even months for one “pin” to get any interaction from users. And yet, a pin that you forgot about from six or seven weeks ago has almost the same impact as a pin from six or seven minutes ago. In a world of instant gratification, Pinterest is in a league of its own. It is the time lord of social media. Don’t underestimate the underdog. Did you hear that? Yes, I’m talking to you; the business so focused on having a Facebook presence that it overlooks the other social media portals. While Facebook does bring its own return on investment (ROI) to the table, it fails to keep a post going after a day or so. Pinterest keeps a pin alive and well, safely protected by aptly named boards under their associated categories. Here are my tips for any business account looking to build their Pinterest influence: Looks aren’t everything, but they help. Sounds shallow, right? But like I said earlier, Pinterest is a place of image hoarders. It’s important to pin or repin things that your followers (and potential followers) would want on their own boards. Eye-catching images for your pins are not required, but they’re recommended if you want those pins to have long, healthy Pinterest lives. Check the pins, and check ‘em twice. Just like any social media platform, it is crucial that you check what you’re sharing with your audience. There are multiple possibilities for bad pins. The pin’s source could no longer exist, or the attached link has been reported as suspicious, or the link could lead to something that doesn’t even relate to what you thought the pin was about. In short, be careful what you repin. Know your audience, but keep an open mind. Your customers might be from your specific region, so your company’s account should pertain to that area, but to a certain degree. Pinterest (at the risk of sounding cliché) is a place for explorers. Users want to repin things about places or topics that they’re interested in, but they may not be from that area or know much about it. So remember to make your boards friendly for everyone to explore. Keep your boards well-rounded. Okay, so maybe your business account doesn’t necessarily need a “Women’s Fashion” board, but this goes back to the previous point: your audience isn’t set in stone on Pinterest. You can attract some pretty diverse consumers to your profile if you hook them with a board that’s a little fun or whimsical, such as a humor board or an animal lovers board. Self-promotion silence may be golden. Pinterest is a great place to introduce a larger audience to your business. However, unless your business is product-based (like a clothing boutique or food service that you can provide images for) I recommend keeping self-promotion limited. Those pins tend to not get as much interaction from users. Pinterest is a great social media platform, and I personally hope it continues to grow. Although things have simmered down a bit since its initial boom in 2011, it’s still growing, just a little bit slower. Like I said, Pinterest takes time. Happy pinning!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: pinterest for business
How to Use Pinterest for Business
Commerce Kitchen's social media expert Jen Martinez discusses how to use Pinterest for business.

item.title: Linkbait internship- More Preparation for Linkbait!
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Intern reflection: More Linkbait Launch Prep!

  Hello everyone! It's Rebecca!

Work at CK:

This week’s been a short one, but very busy! Us interns are hard at work prepping for our linkbait launch. Thanks to the help and creative powers of a lot of people this linkbait has really grown into more of a project! It’s grown past getting eyes via simple Internet links and now has a real-world component. We are going to have our own website for this series of events we’re planning, too. I personally am very excited. Our own website! Cool! Today we also made buttons down at Lowbrow! We met some really cool artists!

Denver:

[caption id="" align="alignright" width="189"] Neat![/caption] Has been really hot lately. We haven’t really done too much exploring yet. We often go to the library branch closest to us to get books or movies. This past weekend, we went out to tea at the Brown Palace. The tea was great and the building was incredible! The stained glass ceiling was a sight to see!
See you guys next week! Happy 4th!!
