item.title: Linkbait Interns: Web Design and Startup Outreach
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hello, Sofi speaking. This week at work has been rather intense, for two reasons: 1) it's the final week before our marketing project launch (Yay! ...and yikes!), and 2) our master marketing mentor Leslie was away from the office, doing awesome things at MozCon, so Rebecca and I took on a bit more executive responsibility than we have had experience with previously.

Preparing for Linkbait Launch

Just a recap: the marketing project Rebecca and I are working on is an event that will engage the startup community, but has an online-linkbait component as well. The main tasks we tackled this week were assisting with the web design for this linkbait project, reaching out to startups that we wish to engage, and making the final preparations for this week's Wine Friday, which was the "beta test" for this marketing project.

Web Design

Rebecca and I decided the best way to present our project online would be in its own webpage, so we enlisted the service of CK web designer Good Times to make us an awesome site. To help him understand what we wanted in the site, we did two things. First, I sketched some wireframes of what the structure of the front page might look like – what features do we want on this site? What overall appearance are we going for? And the big question, what do we want a viewer to do once they land on this page, and is this design going to achieve that end? Secondly, we looked up reference images to give GT some idea of what we imagined for the event logo. I compiled a collection of interesting fonts as well as cute cartoon pictures (I borrowed from this nice collection of cute monster pics). The results so far are looking great! [caption id="attachment_3828" align="alignleft" width="300"] Business networking in Denver[/caption]

Outreach and Business Networking

This week we also began our outreach plan, contacting local startups that CK thinks are awesome and wants to work with. Rebecca and I got to interact more with one of these startups, FluentStream, at the unveiling party for their own project, a list of ten Denver startups with awesome offices (naturally, Commerce Kitchen made the list!). We had a lot of fun with the FluentStream team.

Things I'm Learning as an Intern

Over halfway through my nine weeks here, I was reflecting this week on all the unexpected things I have been learning as an intern at CK - many things about linkbait and online marketing, but also a number of unrelated skills and tidbits that I would never have guessed I'd be acquiring when I started this internship. For instance, last week Rebecca and I learned to work a button pin maker. Just this week, I have learned and developed some unexpected skills:
  • How to sketch a wireframe for a web page.
  • How to network with startups at a happy hour event.
  • How to play beer pong (as part of business networking!).
  • How to work more independently from supervision.
  • How to take and give criticism (invaluable know-how given by CK hero Jaimie at this week's lightning talk).
  • How to mix cocktails (this is for work, for reals – I have the best job).
I would honestly recommend that everyone be a marketing intern at some point in their lives – there are so many valuable things to be learned. Readers be warned. . . linkbait is coming.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Web design and startup outreach for marketing linkbait
Commerce Kitchen linkbait interns prepare for the launch of their marketing project; this process includes web design and outreach to local Denver startups.

item.title: Online Conversions
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
If you have an active website, you probably know what you'd like people to do once they get there. Maybe you want them to buy something from you, or you want them to send you their contact information or sign up for a newsletter. And it's in your best interest to track these online conversions as much as possible so you know where your good traffic comes from, and so you can develop a plan for increasing this good traffic.

Tips for Tracking Online Conversions

Make sure that you've set up goal URLs in Google Analytics. These URLs should be the web page that your viewers go to after completing a task that you want them to do. So, if they fill out a form to sign up for a newsletter, the "thank you" page should be one of your goal URLs. Or if they buy a product from you, the page that they go to after they check out should also be a goal URL. As far as I can tell there is no limit to the number of goal URLs you can set up in Analytics. You can have a goal URL for newsletter signup, a goal URL for when they contact you, a goal URL for when they download a PDF, and /or goal URLs for each product you sell. Once you've set up goal URLs in Analytics, you can even assign a value to those goals. This is easy to do if you're selling a product, but it's much harder if you're not. How much is it worth to have someone sign up for your newsletter? While Google Analytics doesn't provide an equation for how to assign value to an item that isn't e-commerce related, they do discuss how to treat your site as though it were an e-commerce site, even if it's not. But have no fear! Our favorite Analytics genius, Avinash, has written a wonderful blog post on how to come up with a dollar number value for your conversions that don't have an actual dollar amount attached to them. It involves some good communications with the other departments of your business, and you've got to be committed to following up on those conversions to make them actually worth something. After you have your goal URLs identified, you can create a custom dashboard in Analytics to show you immediately what your online conversions look like. If you haven't set up a custom dashboard for yourself in Google Analytics, I highly recommend it.

In this image above, I've got an overview of my goal completions open. Then, I click on Add to Dashboard, choose an existing dashboard or create a new one, and voila. Now I see goal completions right away when I log on to my Google Analytics profile. For goal completions you can see both the number of conversions and the number of conversions by goal URL. I added both to my dashboard.

Another cool thing you can do is click on the little pencil icon next to the title of the section (e.g. "Goal Completions by Goal Completion Location"). Then, you can change the appearance of your widget to look like a pie chart if you want. I love pie.

You can make the widgets look however you understand data best. Some people prefer graphs, tables, charts. You get to pick.

Making the Most of Online Conversions Data

Once you've been tracking your online conversions for some time, you should make sure you do something with that information. If you're getting a ton of converting leads from Yelp, then you consider investing in Yelp advertising to get even more people to your Yelp profile. Conversely, if you're spending a ton of money trying to optimize your site for a keyword that doesn't even convert, then stop doing that! Ranking number one for a phrase that doesn't convert is a waste of resources. Look at what works and make that even better. One of the most important things to remember about SEO is that ranking well should always be secondary to conversions. I harp on this all the time, but I still want to make that clear. If you're ranking for terms that don't convert, your rankings mean nothing. Work on ranking better for the things that convert well. Understand the intention of people searching, and if your site matches their intention you can make magic. If it doesn't, then you're paying for AdWords clicks or SEO that's completely irrelevant. Be smart about where you're spending your marketing money. Optimize your site for conversions, while you're optimizing it for Google. If you'd like to talk about how we can help you understand where your converting traffic is coming from, contact Natalie or Leslie and we can come up with a marketing plan that targets your highest converting audience.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Online Conversions
Learn about how and why you should track your online conversions in Google Analytics, and how you can make the most of that data.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/07/online-conversions/

item.title: Can't Add a Facebook Page Admin?
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: You guys. I just spent a very long time feeling frustrated (like, Hulk frustrated) that I couldn't add any admins to a Facebook page that was created without a personal account. Facebook kept telling me I didn't have permission to add anyone, no matter how many fans of that page I tried to add. Sound familiar? If you've tried the following and it hasn't worked, this trick may work for you: You've tried to add a new admin by name, after they've liked the page. Nothing. You've tried to add the new admin by the email address associated with their Facebook account? Nothing but a sad red error message. Read on. Here's what I did. There's no guarantee this will work for you, but it worked for me, like magic. When I was logged in as the business page, I added a new admin with an email address that was not associated with a Facebook account. Then I logged out of Facebook and I went to the admin confirmation email for the new email address, I clicked on the confirmation, and I set up a new personal account. Then, I went to the business page that I was requesting admin privileges for and "liked" it. Then! I searched for my personal profile (the one that's really me, not this new one, obviously) and added myself as a friend of my new personal account. I logged out from the new personal account and logged back in as the business page, and for some amazing reason it let me add the new personal profile as an admin. It autofilled the form when I typed in the name. It was beautiful. After that I logged out as the business, logged in as myself (my old self), accepted my new profile's friend request, logged out as myself, logged back in as the new profile, went to the business page as the new profile (not the business account) and I was able to add myself. Keeping up? Facebook doesn't like for users to have more than one personal account, so after adding myself as a manager / admin I deleted the new profile as an admin, then deleted that new account altogether. It shouldn't have taken that long, but I tried every trick out there to add new admins to that page. I've managed dozens of Facebook pages and never seen a glitch like this, so I think it's a once-in-a-blue-moon thing.  If you're struggling for hours, like I did, try this trick and let me know if it works for you, too.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Can't Add a Facebook Page Admin?
If you can't add an admin for a Facebook business page created without a personal account, check out this hack.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/07/cant-add-a-facebook-page-admin/

item.title: A crazy week for launching linkbait!
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hello everyone! It’s Rebecca! You thought last week was a whirlwind; this one was possibly even crazier! We’ve entirely switched directions! Our linkbait was supposed to launch on Monday, but now we’re on a totally different project! I’ll give you guys a play by play.

Monday:

Monday was intense! We were all stressed out trying to get the webpage for our launch internet-worthy. We were working closely with the Wonder Twins™ Aaron and Alex. We were putting on the graphic final touches, moving around text components as well as checking and improving functionality. It was supposed to launch Monday afternoon, but that didn’t really happen. Tuesday for sure.

Tuesday:

I was out of the office all day at a doctor's appointment. This made anything going on at the office very hectic to keep on top of. Between texts and emails during breaks, I frantically tried to keep in contact with Sofi and up to date with all of the office happenings. I had marginal success. Despite improvements to the website, we did not launch. Also, near the doctor’s office I found an Andrés!! I was so psyched! I thought I was dreaming! I didn’t think they existed outside of Kansas City. Turns out they don’t. Denver is the only other place there is one! Needless to say I bought some cake. It is such good cake. If you’re in Denver, go get some now. I’m serious. You won’t regret it.

Wednesday:

Despite everyone’s hard work on Tuesday, our website did not launch. We were certain we’d get it up today as it was pretty much done. Boy, were our expectations blown out of the water. We met with some partners about their potential involvement with our project and after talking with Leslie about certain possible avenues for our project, she decided to take it to the main stage, as it were. Because of all the interest shown and a possible collaboration with the Colorado Technology Association, Leslie decided to take it off our hands so she could work her marketing magic with it. [caption id="attachment_3947" align="alignleft" width="300"] Us[/caption] After this we were caught a little bit like deer in headlights. We had just had the project we were working on suddenly re-delegated. We fumbled around a little bit, unsure of what to do. I’m glad we could create and idea that has such big possibilities! But what now?  

Thursday:

Today we started research on our new linkbait project. Back to square one and flitting about the internet looking for information. We’ve decided to keep this linkbait to a small, one off project that won’t spiral out of control like our last campaign. I think we’ll be able to finish this one. And, more importantly, track its success and reception.

Friday:

Aaaaaahh. So much still to do today! We are aiming for finalizing research and method on our newest linkbait project so we can start executing early next week, launching shortly after that! [caption id="attachment_3942" align="alignleft" width="300"] For real, go get some cake.[/caption] Though this week has been hectic, it's not upsetting in the least. One must always be prepared for rapid changes and about faces in any industry, especially marketing. This is a good opportunity to practice such. Even more than that, It's exciting! You never know what will happen next! See you next week!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Shifting Linkbait Strategies to Better Align with Marketing Needs
This was a super busy week for the linkbait interns. We went from almost launching a new site to having a plan for a new project laid out in a few days!

item.title: Linkbait Interns Make an Infographic
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Sofi speaking. After finishing our part on the Commerce Kitchen marketing project last week, our next project was to create linkbait for one of CK's clients. And so we revisit our old friend: the linkbait process!

The Linkbait Process, Revisited

We have adapted our process from this in-depth guide to creating linkbait.

Initial Steps

1. Research our client: We looked at our client's history and mission. From their webpage, what message do they want to send about their business? From their Facebook, Twitter and blog entries, how are they trying to reach their audience? We got to know a Seattle company that promotes itself as a local expert, celebrating the Seattle area and culture. [caption id="attachment_3990" align="alignleft" width="300"] THIS. IS. SEATTLE![/caption] 2. Research their audience: Who are Seattle-ites? What do they value? What would they pay attention to online? We gathered that Seattle residents value outdoor recreation, healthy lifestyles and good coffee; they are proud of their unique neighborhoods and plentiful farmers' markets. 3. Brainstorm: Bringing together the brains of our entire marketing team, we produced a variety of linkbait ideas, from a review of famous houses to a contest of weird foods in Seattle. We decided to create an infographic on a fitness-related field. 4. Fine-tune the research: We narrowed down our project possibilities considerably with the brainstorm. Now it's back to the computers to determine what's most feasible, in light of the statistics and info we can find, and what would make for the most interesting infographic. 5. Metrics: Can't forget this step! We studied our client's Facebook and Twitter stats and decided on some reasonable goals for the numbers – in terms of links, views, likes and shares – that we hope to see for our infographic once it's launched.

The Infographic

[caption id="" align="alignright" width="204"] Adobe Kuler Samples[/caption] After considerable research, thought, and discussion, we decided to create an infographic about cycling in Seattle. (Who doesn't love biking? At least Seattle-ites do: Bicycling Magazine named Seattle 4th most bicycle-friendly city in the nation!). This would appeal to our client's active local audience by highlighting unique features of Seattle as a biking city. Through more internet research we uncovered an array of noteworthy statistics, unusual facts, and recommended biking routes and shops. Next we needed to decide how to present this in a manner that was clear, visually pleasing, and tonally appropriate. Again we enlisted the help of CK's design expert Good Times. He pointed us to Adobe Kuler, a useful site for creating and sharing color schemes. Rebecca and I chose some colors, sketched some designs for the layout, compiled some reference pictures, then handed it over to Good Times to work his magic.

The Next Steps

Aggressively pursue our outreach targets. Nail down our social-media promotion plan. Set up analytics to track the project's success. And then launch!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Marketing Interns Use the Linkbait Process and Create an Infographic
Commerce Kitchen marketing interns review the linkbait process; they research, brainstorm, and design an infographic on biking in Seattle.

item.title: 5 Things Arrested Development Taught Me About Business
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
1. Don't Be Afraid To Make A Mistake

While GOB was the least competent Bluth Company president, he wasn't afraid to make a mistake. Or, like, fifty of them a day. While I know better than to be a complete idiot like GOB, it is helpful to know that we can take risks and not beat ourselves up over it. Entrepreneurs are always writing about risk taking because risks help our creativity grow and can often be exactly what a business needs to take the next step.

2. There's Always Money in the Banana Stand

Sometimes we focus on getting the Really Big Business and forget about the little stuff that has sustained us all along. When the contract to build 22 homes gets cut back, we forget about the banana stand. Sometimes the small things add up; this could be cutting back on little expenses, or it could also be about building smaller business alongside the bigger stuff. Whatever you do, don't burn (the bridges to) the smaller things. Nobody's got that kind of insurance.

3. Don't Use All Your Resources On Things That Don't Matter

We're all guilty of spending money where we shouldn't. I am lazy about buying groceries, so I'll spend too much money on Chipotle quesadillas for my daughter. Likewise, in business we often spend our money in the wrong place. A physical location may be important for your business, but if most of your business is done online, then your website is even more important. You can have a nice space that isn't on the top floor of an expensive office building in Newport Beach. Cut back where you can, and spend your money where it makes sense.

4. Tony Wonder Is Doing It Better

Tony Wonder pulled off some incredible tricks, err, illusions. GOB was infinitely jealous and impressed by Tony Wonder. His envy peaked with Wonder's appearance on the cover of Poof after he baked himself into a loaf of bread to feed the troops. GOB was going to boil himself into a chowder to feed and entertain the firemen. SAME IDEA! Whatever idea you have, someone else has had it and they've probably pulled it off pretty damn well. That doesn't mean you shouldn't try. Your idea may be different enough (bread vs. chowder), or it may even be better. Just because there are Tony Wonders out there doesn't mean you should abandon all your good ideas.

5. Admit When You've Made a Huge Mistake

And finally, tying back to the first lesson from Arrested Development, admitting when you've made a mistake is crucial. Admit to your staff, your partners, and yourself that you've made a mistake and work to correct it. While I wouldn't recommend getting a shiv stuck in your belly to help you out of a bind, showing a bit of humility and asking for help can be incredibly good for you and your business.
I'm a certified Arrested Development junkie--though I'm still not too sure about season 4--and I while could probably come up with a dozen more business lessons from the Bluth Company (don't do business with Brits? don't give seals the taste for mammal blood?), the ones above are actually relatively applicable to our world. What lessons from Arrested Development would you add to this list?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Things Arrested Development Has Taught Me About Business
1. Don't be afraid to make a mistake. 2. There's always money in the banana stand...In my obsession with Arrested Development I've learned a thing or two.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/08/lessons-from-arrested-development/

item.title: Linkbait Interns: Infographic Outreach!
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Promotion, Promotion, Promotion

  Hello! This is Rebecca!This week we have been busy working on outreach and promoting our infographic. We first investigated places and people that might host or share our infographic. To do this, we took a sort of indirect method. Other than looking at just people who write bike blogs, we looked into Seattle tourism (bicycle and other), shops in the Seattle area that might be bike shops or otherwise biker friendly. We got advice from a nice guide about promoting an infographic from Tasty Placement. Another thing we have found out in this process is that you might want to be creative and think outside the box when it comes down to who you reach out to as well. If a blog is associated with a large company or association,  the blog or website’s media/ publicity contact might be very busy or otherwise uninterested in helping you in your infographic goals. We found that emailing someone “lower down” with more immediate access to your desired venue (and perhaps less competition for their time), such as the blog manager, might be more effective. Jeremy also offers excellent advice on coming across right when approaching bloggers.

 Other News:

  A week ago I played a pretty good game of extreme Ping-Pong. There is no point tracking and all surfaces are fine for the ball to hit; floors, ceilings, walls, lamps, Kevin- anything goes! [caption id="" align="alignright" width="300"] Hand painted ceiling of Dushanbe[/caption] This weekend we went to hang out with Russ in Boulder and do a bunch of exciting things. We visited Dushanbe teahouse, went to an amazing performance at the International Ariel Dance Festival and went white-water tubing! This week our last week! It’s sad times for us interns, as we will soon be leaving commerce kitchen! I don’t know what to say. It’s gone so fast; it barely feels like a month, let alone nine weeks. I’ll miss everybody so much! This Friday: Final joint segment!

item.title: Be Like Joey: How to Use Twitter for Business, As Taught By My Favorite Friend.
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Yes, I am referring to Joey Tribbiani: the ladies man, the sandwich man, and everybody’s favorite Friend. Okay, well he’s my favorite friend. Unfortunately, Twitter wasn’t around when Joey was busy being amazing, ordering the Joey Special (a.k.a.: two pizzas), and selling Ichiban (“Lipstick for men!”). Nevertheless, we can learn a lot from Mr. Tribbiani. Here are five things that Joey taught me about using Twitter for business.

1. “How you doin’?” is the perfect pickup line.

Not only does it express interest in the audience, but the audience, more often than not—I’m looking at you, Elle Macpherson—also responds extremely well by expressing mutual interest. Joey had a winning smile and killer confidence. Your Twitter account doesn’t need to be smiling all of the time, but be aggressive with your audience and communicate your intentions effectively.

2. Be lovable.

No one wants to retweet something that a robot wrote. Have some personality. Joey did lots of winking in his day. You don’t have to use emoticons in every tweet, but it’s important to show some emotion in there so your audience can feel connected with you.

3. Be the friend.

In my opinion, Joey was the best friend in the group because he had the biggest heart. Truthfully, the only reason I grew to love Chandler was because Joey loved him so much. Hey, they were bracelet buddies! So take a note from Joey: care about your business and/or product, and your audience will too.

4. Have an Estelle.

Estelle was Joey’s agent, and even though sometimes Phoebe did her job better (See “The One with the Metaphorical Tunnel”), Estelle was the one that helped Joey out the most. How else would he have gotten the role of Dr. Drake Ramoray on Days of Our Lives? But back to my point, it’s important to have someone on your team doing the work for you, who knows your business well and knows how to express your mission in 140 characters.

5. When in doubt, eat a sandwich.

I think the only thing that Joey loved more than women was a good sandwich. Just like Joey, you should stick to what you care about. If there’s a specific idea or cause you want to endorse, take it and run with it. And don’t let anyone else eat it—I mean steal it! However you choose to use Twitter for your business, represent yourself truthfully and have some fun with it. Otherwise, your Twitter presence isn’t you, and this entire article is a moo point. You know, a cow’s opinion.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: twitter for business
5 Things Joey from Friends Taught Me about Twitter | Commerce Kitchen
"Joey doesn't share food!" But he will share these tips on how you can use Twitter for business in the best way possible.

item.title: Linkbait Interns Say Goodbye
item.dc:creator: heroling
item.content:encoded:
Hi! This is Rebecca and Sofi. This last week we launched our final linkbait project, an infographic about biking in Seattle for CK’s client Seattle Mortgage Planners. It looks great, so you should check it out! We've had an amazing nine weeks at Commerce Kitchen, but our internship has come to an end so the time has sadly come to write our final blog post.

Rebecca Says:

This week was a very busy one! We finished our infographic, emailed outreach targets and posted on social media. Despite an apparent time crunch, we did well. People responded to our emails and we got it out there. It was so great that people responded- they sound very excited too! I’m sure it will only grow in the coming weeks. That will be our final challenge, keeping up with our metrics despite going into the school year. This has definitely been an educational experience, and not just in linkbait or SEO, though those are certainly lessons that are useful even beyond the field of SEO. This was, while not my first time “living alone,” it was definitely that moreso than my previous experiences. It is always great to live in a new town- you learn a lot about how that place works and what the people are like. Being a part of Commerce Kitchen was amazing too. It was a chance to see how a small startup is run and managed. I also got to meet a ton of great people. You guys rock! Granted, my employment history is not incredibly long, but out of all the places I’ve ever worked, you guys are the most fun. It was great spending nine weeks with you!

Sofi Says:

Nine weeks here, and we have finally launched a linkbait! We certainly hit a lot of bumps along the way, but it has been a fun ride, marked with unforgettable experiences and many things learned. I'm really excited about how the biking infographic turned out. It looks fantastic (Goodtimes did a really nice job with the design), the content is interesting and we’ve been doing some extensive outreach, so hopefully it will take off. In additon to this project, in our time here we also set the groundwork for two other linkbait projects: a networking campaign for Commerce Kitchen (which we spent some significant time on earlier in our internship) and a historical piece around horses for another of CK’s clients. I said in my first blog post that this internship marked many firsts for me, and consequently it has been a great learning experience. In addition to the oodles I learned about linkbait and online marketing, I learned some of the ropes of living on my own, holding the responsibility of a full time job, and working on a professional team. The CK team was awesome, and I want to thank them for the experience; for being so welcoming, for encouraging us to see Denver, for teaching us about SEO and marketing and various related fields, and giving all kind of guidance, assistance and support in executing our crazy linkbait ideas. Thank you! You guys are super!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Marketing Interns Reflect on Linkbait Experience, Say Goodbye
Commerce Kitchen's summer interns finish up their linkbait projects and reflect on their experience learning about SEO and online marketing.

item.title: LoneStar Ruby
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded: I've always felt that conferences were in general just tax deductible corporate sponsored mini vacations. However, wanting a mini vacation myself and taking advantage of Commerce Kitchen's generous conference policies, I decided to attend LoneStarRuby this July. I won't lie, the biggest reason I wanted to go was simply the fact that it was hosted in Austin, Texas which I've heard nothing but legendary stories about for at least a decade (all of which turned out to be pretty spot-on). On the flight home, I began gathering my notes from the conference and contrary to my prejudiced conceptions of conferences, I realized that I actually got a lot out of the three days I spent there. Mostly I learned that with conferences, all the benefits are proportional to the effort you put into them. They're great opportunities to network, learn about topics that you might normally not have any initial interest in, stay abreast of the latest happenings in your field, and most importantly they get you out of the firehouse. There were a multitude of presentations, one of my favorite discussions was by the folks @ HashRocket, on the value of pairing. We pair program here at Commerce Kitchen, but at times we slip out of good pairing routines and we developers go rogue from time to time. This session reinforced the value of pairing and got me a lot more enthusiastic about pairing with my fellow dev heroes. I won't go into a whole thing about the benefits of pairing, but if you haven't looked into it, you definitely should, it's a huge force as of late in the coding world. Another interesting discussion was from Steve Klabnic about creative coding. It was a pretty unorthodox talk basically telling developers to break all good coding conventions and code creatively. Essentially, forget commenting, have fun, write overly clever totally unreadable code, don't be afraid, and just use code as a creative outlet. (Just don't do it at work :-) ) This was an interesting take on developing; he gave a good deal of background on 'why the lucky stiff', who was an incredible developer/artist that used code as one of his mediums. This idea of creative developing as an art form is something I'd never previously considered. Since that point, I've looked at code I've been writing with a different perspective and it's overall made me enjoy developing more. This was surely educational conference, one that I learned a variety of new things that I wouldn't normally take the time to research about. One of the biggest takeaways, is that I'm fairly new to Ruby (~6 months) and I'm not alone, at least half the attendees had been working with RoR for less than a year. This gave more credence to the fact that RoR is not fading away into a sea of sexier hyper fast multithreaded server side frameworks; it's a mature platform that's gaining support in droves. The Ruby community is incredible and although the language itself is amazingly robust, it'd be nothing without the shared efforts of all the open source devs that contribute so much to it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Ruby on Rails Developer Discusses the LoneStar Ruby Conference
Kevin has been programming for quite a long time, but he's relatively new to Ruby on Rails. He attended the LoneStar Ruby Conf this summer, and loved it.
lonestar-ruby

item.title: Soaring with Meteor.JS
item.dc:creator: aaron
item.content:encoded:
Meteor.js is a JavaScript framework that enables rapid application development. It handles everything from templates, databases and business logic, all packaged and ready to deploy. While it's still in preview (version 0.6.5 as of now), they recently received $11.2 M in funding and have already developed a relatively mature framework. Out of the box, Meteor utilizes MongoDB for databases, Node.js for the server, Handlebars.js for templating, the Meteor class for awesomeness, and vanilla JavaScript for everything else. These tools make Meteor unique because it enables reactivity with two way databinding, synchronization with hot-code-pushes, responsiveness with latency compensation, and functions with vanilla JavaScript from end-to-end. There may be two audiences reading this, so I'll describe each of my favorite Meteor.js features with this in mind.

Two Way Data-Binding in Meteor.js:

Devs: If something changes in the database, the browser immediately knows about it. If something changes in the browser, the database immediately knows about that. There's no need for HTML5 data-attributes or ng-whatever to create reactivity. Instead, simply define Handlebar helper methods and make something happen with Meteor's built in event listeners. Users: You can expect your information to be processed quickly and efficiently. Check out how reactive this Meteor build color picker is!

Hot Code Pushes:

Devs: When one user changes a value stored in the database, all browsers viewing the site immediately receive the updated value without refreshing their entire page. This saves precious bandwidth by avoiding expensive HTTP requests. User: When using a properly configured Meteor app, you can navigate from one page to the next and elements like the main navigation, footer, and sidebar will remain. Super fast user experience and page speeds FTW!

Latency Compensation:

Devs: When users post new data, the browser stores that data in a local storage and renders it in the browser before sending the request to the database for authentication. So the user can see results with zero latency, Meteor first assumes the value posted is correct. If the value is rejected, it is removed from the screen and never stored in the Database (and consequently never rendered on other screens via Hot Code Pushes). Users: Unless you do something you’re not supposed to, the site will react to your actions immediately. These are just a few of my favorite Meteor.js features. If you're interested in learning more, check out the robust Meteor.js documentation or come talk shop at DevCamp.us.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meteor.js: Rapid Application Development
Meteor.js is a rapid application development JavaScript framework, and Commerce Kitchen's Aaron has a big crush on it.
meteor-js

item.title: Agile Software Development: Why We Do It
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
In the world of Software Development, stories reign. They are essential to the process because they represent the customer's idea translated into a more technical language for developers to build upon. Building and deploying software is a complicated business. Historically, the industry has a rather poor success rate delivering working software, much less something the customer actually wanted. People's perceptions often differ even on simple things, so it's easy to imagine the gap that exists between technical programmers and a business customer when it comes to the complex matter of expressing that idea in a language that enables warm bits of silicon to bring it to life on a display. Bridging that gap is a difficult job that requires a skilled, master communicator, mind reader, savant, who possesses leadership, levity and unwavering drive. Someone who will ask the tough questions and yet encourage both the customer and developers. When this job is done well, the bridge is a superhighway for informative ideas that establish a collaborative team and create great apps. When its falls short of superhero abilities, the result is something akin to a tattered footbridge made of old, weathered rope. Agile was established by a group of software developers on a quest to solve a common industry premise of the time: THERE MUST BE A BETTER WAY TO WRITE GOOD SOFTWARE FOR OUR CUSTOMERS. What they created for us was the concise and subtly powerful Manifesto for Agile Software Development.
We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it. Through this work we have come to value: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools Working software over comprehensive documentation Customer collaboration over contract negotiation Responding to change over following a plan That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more.
Agile is flexible. It's an adaptive, modern construct for developing software that the customer wants. It doesn't prescribe a certain process, but it does work well with other practices like iterative development, incremental development, Scrum and more. Agile is what you make it. If you value the principles in the Manifesto, you are Agile, your customer is engaged in the regular process of scheduling and refining stories, and receiving working software that delivers on those stories. So why build agile software? Important stuff changes all the time -- make that work for your customer. If you're interested in learning more about Commerce Kitchen's development philosophy or to find out how we can help you build the software you've been wanting, contact Tynan.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Agile Software Development
Agile software development is flexible. It's an adaptive, modern construct for developing software that the customer wants.

item.title: Scrum for Marketing?
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: Last week I attended a two-day Scrum product owner certification course. Not only is Scrum a strange word to say (scum meets scrape?), but it's a challenging concept to translate into what I do, which is marketing. [caption id="attachment_4398" align="alignleft" width="207"] Our marketing team, being super agile.[/caption] We've written about agile software development and Scrum before, but let me tell you about it again before I explain how Scrum works for marketing, too. Originally, a group of software developers created Scrum to more realistically manage projects. Traditional "waterfall" project management was based on the premise that you can accurately predict what an end product (i.e. software) will look like, how long it will take to build, and how much it will cost, before you actually build it. This is never the case. Software development can be unpredictable! WHAT?! During the course of building software, many unknowns become apparent. Some of the features that the stakeholders believe are pertinent in the beginning reveal themselves to be irrelevant. Likewise, there will be new features that emerge that are crucial elements to making the software function to meet the users' needs. Scrum takes all of this into consideration, and the goal is to create a high-quality "shippable product" as quickly as possible, but this means that stakeholders must reconsider what is essential and what is superfluous. Apparently only 36% of software features are actually used. This means that the organizations and people who manage software projects are wasting about 64% of their developers' time and their clients' money. Good Scrum project management ranks software features according to significance. If there's enough money for every tiny feature, then great. But a good Scrum team will only build the best software, and that doesn't equate to the software with the most features (sometimes simplicity is better). So how can I use scrum for marketing? I've been asking myself this question for the past few months, and during the training last week I was mentally translating everything our instructor said about Scrum into marketing terms. First of all, marketing doesn't really have a product comparable to software. We focus on goals (increased conversions, brand visibility and recognition) and we use a variety of means to get there. Sure, we'll design an infographic and distribute it, and in some ways this counts as a shippable product, but it doesn't have quite the same purpose as software. Also, our work is never done. We can't just execute a marketing campaign and call it good. We have to continually create new campaigns and measure their success. But wait! The more I think about the more I realize I just need to change the word "shippable product" into "implementation" and voila. It kind of works. Hear me out. Sometimes we get requests for very specific marketing tasks that may or may not actually work toward a business' goal of getting more conversions. For example, some people come to us with a really, really bad website. Either they had it built too cheaply, it's way out of date, or it wasn't designed with actual user experience in mind. We know that no matter how hard we work to move it up in the rankings, how great their AdWords ad content is, or how much money they pump into Pinterest, people are not going to trust them, and they will lose a significant chunk of business based on their crappy website. Scrum project management would consider their marketing goals, analyze their user base, and make recommendations and changes accordingly. For a client with a bad website, the first step would be to recommend a rebuild, not to raise the daily AdWords budget. We look at what has the potential to be effective and, budget allowing, we prioritize those "features." The top priority would be to build a new marketing website that considers everyone's goals (users, stakeholders, client). The next priority would be to set up appropriate tracking of these goals in Analytics, analyze what channels have converted best in the past, consider what channels may convert better now, and begin implementing a marketing plan accordingly. But you know what? What works today may not work tomorrow. That's just marketing. Websites become obsolete in three years or less. A new social network releases an amazingly effective advertising package. Suddenly nobody cares about cat memes (unlikely, I know). [caption id="attachment_4396" align="alignleft" width="300"] Selfie with our kanban board.[/caption] Agile project management is really the only way to manage ongoing marketing projects. Good marketing is inherently agile, constantly adapting and responding to change, and making the most out of situations we can't always anticipate. While I can't directly plop the technicalities of Scrum for software development onto Scrum for marketing, I do see how the premise applies equally, if not more so, to marketing. Plus, we're kind of in love with our kanban board.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Scrum for Marketing
Can principles of scrum be applied to marketing? Since marketing is inherently agile, yes.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2013/10/scrum-for-marketing/

item.title: Colorado's Most Experienced Agile Developer: Russ!
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: I am hesitant to publish this post because we don't want anyone else to snag Russ. On the other hand Russ is so awesome that I want to brag, and the White House should've probably hired him to build the health care exchange website. Russ took fifteen minutes out of his day to talk with me about his experience as a software engineer and the interesting life he leads (music composer! tracker of space junk!). How long have you been working with computers? Since they were really big and noisy. I didn't toy around with them because they weren't toys then! I chose to take up computers in the early 1980s and went back to school for computer science. I went to school the first time around for music, for performing and teaching trumpet. I also played the bass, flute, and clarinet. But I got interested in computers and decided to give it a whirl. After I finished my computer science degree I was teaching for a while, then I got sucked into Department of Defense work down in Colorado Springs. What kind of work were you doing with the DoD? I was working on astro stuff. Basically we were tracking space junk. This was back in the Ronnie Reagan years, so strategic defense was huge. I got into a team that supported software developers designing systems and doing testing. This was in 1983, so pre agile development. There were 250 programmers working on this system, and we had these massive printers that would spit out, literally spit out across the room, thousands of pages of code. Those trees never had a chance! We'd go through these pages of code to analyze it and fix it. Sounds exhausting! So, I've heard a rumor around the office that you worked under Steve Jobs for a while. Can you confirm or deny? I was an independent consultant involved with NeXT before it was released. Then we worked on an updated version of HyperCard, an old Mac app. This was basically creating a programming language for non-programmers. As a NeXT consultant, I worked bringing large, networked applications to many Fortune 100+ companies. The excellent object-oriented foundation in NeXT Software (now Mac OS X) provided a huge time-to-market advantage by dramatically reducing software development time for any given project. It was a relatively small community, and I felt honored to get the nod from Apple to fill-in for a member of their online store team as they approached an important delivery. With NeXT, networking was built in, and things were moving incredibly fast. Networked computers were worth a lot more than an isolated single computer. So we were doing object-oriented development, building products and systems that would be released quickly. There's object-oriented programming, which is what we do with our Ruby and Rails applications. What is the other way of programming? Well, there’s procedural programming and object-oriented programming. In procedural programming things happen in a sequential manner and the data and processes are separate. In object-oriented programming the data and the processes that work on that data form an object. Things happen by having the objects interact. So basically, you have a functioning piece that gathers knowledge over time and it's well encapsulated. With encapsulation, the behavior of an object is kept in a sandbox. It does one thing, and when that one thing needs to be enhanced, changed or isn't quite right, you go to that one object to change its behavior. You add tests for the new behavior and the object now works in a new or different way, and the tests prove it does its one job as expected. The code is isolated so it’s much easier to fix or enhance. This was before Ruby, obviously. So what language were you programming in? Objective-C was sort of the quintessential object-oriented programming language. This is what NeXT--and what is now OSX--are built in. Over the past 30 years what other types of projects have you worked on? After leaving the world of space I worked on commodity trading systems and on database management projects. We created a system that provided data to travel agencies. Then I worked on a system to index legal documents. Today Google has indexed the world, but in 1986 it wasn't so easy. We were dealing with a massive amount of large textual data, and we were developing an indexing system similar to what Google uses to retrieve data quickly. A short list of other memorable efforts includes: Apple - first expansion of the online store. GE Capital - world wide computer leasing. CPP Wind Engineering - atmospheric modeling. SHL SystemHouse - commodities trading. Frequent Flyers Productions - motion driven, interactive audio playback system for live dance performance. Aetna/USHealthcare - online enrollment system. I'm a musician too, but I'm not terribly mathematically minded. I know some people approach music from the math perspective whereas for others it's more of an expression of creativity. Where do you fit in? Some people are really excellent at reproducing a piece of music. They can execute it with extreme precision, and it's beautiful. It's perfect. But they have to be told what to do; there has to be a piece of music they can read, memorize, perform. They're not able to express themselves creatively with music, even though they can play their instrument impeccably. I was obsessive about music for a long time. I was constantly composing music and arranging it, so I think I approach it from both angles. It seems like programming could be like that too. You can reproduce code perfectly if someone tells you exactly what needs to be done. But if you need to create something from scratch you have to use the creative half of your brain to envision what that will look like. Exactly. When I first started programming my mentor was also an artist, and I complained that programming wasn't an art form because you're just working with two digits. But it is an art form. There are so many tools that we can use to make art. And there are so many types of art. There's commercial art, art for self expression, etc. Well, and in music it might not be two digits, but typically you're working within the 12 "digit" chromatic scale. So there are still limitations. Do you miss music? I used to think that I'd go back to music after doing the computer thing for a while, but I really love this too. It's not the same as standing in front of sixty people and performing something you've worked on for months, but it's rewarding in a different way. You've brought some amazing skills and experience to the Commerce Kitchen development team, especially when it comes to testing and agile software development. How would you describe your strengths as it relates to others here at CK? Well, in agile teams you're expected to do more than just one thing. Teams aren't necessarily role-based; for example, there's no database guy. While my strengths are definitely on the backend, I believe that UX (user experience) is incredibly important and a nice way to keep things encapsulated. Clients are looking at each iteration and accepting it, so you're always on the same page. You start with a big idea and reduce it into smaller chunks, then each one becomes viable on its own along the way. All of our developers write really solid code and they have great ideas. Having tons of experience is fun, though sometimes I feel old! I've been working in Rails since 2007, but since I've been doing object-oriented development for such a long time I think I bring some good insight. And the younger devs always keep me learning. Overall working at CK is as good as it gets! My criteria for taking a job has been working in Ruby and Rails, having interesting projects, and working with good people. We are so glad to have you here!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Colorado's Most Experienced Agile Software Developer: Russ!
Russ is Commerce Kitchen's most experienced software engineer. He's been doing agile software development for decades and is an incredible Ruby developer.
colorados-best-ruby-dev

item.title: Bad News, Guys: The Hashtag Ain’t Going Anywhere
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: By now, if you’re on the Internet and haven’t seen a hashtag [#] followed by a word, phrase, or sometimes even a full sentence, then I’m afraid you’re doing the Internet wrong. The hashtag on social media goes all the way back to ancient times, when marketers used them for targeting audiences about specific topics, particularly on Twitter. During its evolution, the hashtag has gone from a footnote in social media strategy to a thorn in your average social media Scrooge (a.k.a. a cyncic)’s side. And now, at the end of 2013, the hashtag has been embraced by even the most unlikely of platforms: Facebook. In short, the hashtag is kind of a big deal. As a lover of the hashtag and everything it represents (#ilovehashtags), I can say this without shame:  When Facebook enabled hashtags, about 5 months ago, it was like the heavens opened up. I’ve been on both sides of the hashtag. I’ve been that person who uses hashtags on Twitter, Instagram, and yes, even Facebook before it hopped on the hashtag bandwagon – yes, I am one of those people. And I’ve also been that social media marketer, who shamelessly uses the hashtag to find her [or his] people. But Jen, what do you mean by your “people?” When you’re in the marketing business, you get acquainted with buzzwords or phrases like “audience” and “building community.” When I say that I’m trying to “find my people,” I mean that I’m trying to engage anyone and everyone that currently does, possibly might, or potentially will have interest in a company and its product or service. This is basically what Avinash Kaushik discussed at MozCon this year in his talk “Simplifying Complexity: Three Ideas for Higher ROI.” As one member of a kick-butt Internet marketing team here at Commerce Kitchen, I’m often having discussions with the other CK’ers about how to build community for our clients. A question that was raised lately was “How do you find your people without using hashtags?” The answer? If you’re not a big brand that everyone already loves or not using paid search or social ads, then it seems like hashtags are your best bet. Yes, they can be obnoxious and unnecessary at times, but at the end of the day, if it helps you find your people, then what else matters?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: hashtag
Bad News, Guys: The Hashtag Ain’t Going Anywhere | Commerce Kitchen
Whether or not you use it, the hashtag is here to stay (for now).

item.title: Curse You, Internet Hoaxes!
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Hey Internet, I have a bone to pick with you. All of you.  What's the deal with Internet hoaxes? They completely baffle me; I have so many questions. How did they begin? Why do people start them? Why are we so fascinated by them? Are they designed to trick the most gullible of us users? Okay, so the answer to that last one is obviously a big, fat YES, but what about my other questions? I had to do some digging. How did Internet hoaxes begin? The earliest of all media-driven hoaxes is most likely Kremvax from 1984, which convinced everyone on Usenet that the Soviet Union was joining the network. This was a earth-shattering news, since everyone assumed that the Soviet Union's security laws restricted such activity. This rumor was later debunked, but when Moscow joined us on the Internet in 1990, they adopted "Kremvax" as their domain name, in honor of the hoax. Those Russians have quite a sense of humor. After Kremvax, there was the "Drunk Driving on the Internet" Senate bill in 1994, The Kidney Thieves of New Orleans email chain in 1997, and (in movie form) The Blair Witch Project in 1999. Even before the Y2K "scare," people were going nuts for these weird hoaxes on the Internet. Why do people start them? This is a question that has endless possible answers: for Internet fame, for fun and giggles, out of boredom. In my opinion, I think it goes back to school yard politics: some kids just like to start rumors and watch everyone else squirm. Why are we so fascinated by them? It depends on the hoax. This year's hoaxes certainly reflected the times we live in. We were fascinated by the "Dear Santa" letter written in crayon with an link to Amazon.com, showing that kids in 2013 are tech-savvy. And then we found out that the letter was a fake. What else happened in this year's hoaxes? A 'Bachelor' producer got into a fight with a fellow passenger on an airplane. A drunk guy was eaten by a python in India. Tom Cruise died in a car accident in Australia. A girl caught fire after attempting to twerk. Clearly, 2013 was the year of the hoax, but out of everything in our media-driven world that could have defined the past twelve months, why, oh why, did it have to be hoaxes? This topic is something that will continue to fascinate me. So, in case you were wondering how to keep track of every single Internet hoax that happens in the new year, I'm working on a little side project for Commerce Kitchen. I'm currently building a Tumblr around Internet hoaxes. *gasp!* Yes, I'm still baffled by the popularity of hoaxes, but if you can't beat 'em, join 'em. Stay tuned for some hoax-tracking hilarity in 2014!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: internet hoaxes
Curse You, Internet Hoaxes! | Commerce Kitchen
Dear World, I have a bone to pick with you. What's the deal with Internet hoaxes? I need some serious clarification here. Love, Jen

item.title: Technology & Charitable Giving: A Match Made in Internet Heaven
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: 'Tis the season to give. And you know what? I love giving. Sure, I'm a broke college graduate with oodles and oodles of student loans to pay off, but even my massive debt can't bother me when I think about all of the awesome ways to give made possible through technology. At least once per week, you can hear me say "I love technology." Every week I hear or read about something in technology that makes me want to do a little happy dance. The charitable side of technology and the Internet is no exception. Of course, volunteering is the optimal way to get instant gratification when you're in the giving mood. However, dedicating your time isn't always an option for some people, especially for those of us guilty of saying, "Sorry I didn't call you back/come to your birthday party/notice you had a baby; I've just been so busy lately." When I find something that I'm really passionate about, I want to tell anyone and everyone about it. The same goes for charities and organizations. Charitable giving has taken its own shape in the 21st century, and I want to tell you all about it. Sevenly. I could talk about Sevenly forever. It's one of those things that I am so glad exists in our scary, heartless world. To quote their site, "Every week Sevenly (and its customers) teams up with a charity, helping raise funds and awareness for 7 full days." The way that I explain Sevenly to people is "consumer-ized and merchandized giving." They design cool t-shirts and sweatshirts for each week's charity. I bought this elephant shirt last March to donate to the Invisible Girl Project. GiveWell. I first heard about GiveWell at a Passion Projects talk at Github HQ in San Francisco in November, and it's been on my mind ever since. GiveWell helps you plan your annual charitable giving, based on in-depth research of programs from around the world. In short, they make sure that you're giving your money to a charity that will use your donation appropriately - and not just for restocking their office supplies. CrowdRise. I have to hand it to Edward Norton: I really did not appreciate him at all before I found out about CrowdRise, of which he is one of the founders. CrowdRise is about discovering causes that you're really passionate about (sounds like something I should enjoy, right?) and throwing money in that general direction. The tagline in their site header is "If you don't give back no one will like you." Talk about sassy copywriting. These are only a few of the many ways that you can give back, so pick one and go. We live in the 21st century, for Pete's sake! Give. You'll feel better about everything.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: charitable giving
Techology & Charitable Giving: A Match Made in Internet Heaven
Do you know how much I love giving? I love giving so much that I decided to write a whole blog post about it. 'Tis the season for charitable giving.
technology-made-charitable

item.title: Kick A$$ Marketing Strategy
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Want to quash your competition and look like a rock star to your CMO? Develop and implement a kick-ass marketing strategy, and you will be on the path to world domination.

Lay Your Foundation

Before your formulate your marketing strategy it's important to do prep work and understand as much as you can about your the current landscape.

Scrutinize the Competition

Who are they? What are they doing? Where have they been successful and where have they failed? Is there an opportunity for you to mimic their successes or capitalize on their failures?

Understand Your Audience

What do you know about your target audience? Is the demographic and psychographic segmentation that you paid pretty penny for still valid? If not, reassess. How many customers do you have in each stage of the sales cycle? How's brand recall? Has your product development team incorporated audience feedback into your latest updates, or ignored consumer requests? Where are you most engaged with your audience? Where would you like to engage your audience?

Set Measurable Goals

Given the competition and your target audience, what are your goals? These must be SMART, and in alignment with what you can actually hope to achieve. For each marketing strategy, you really should only have 2 to 3 goals, max! If you have additional measurements that will help determine success or qualitative objectives, these should live at the KPI level.

Know Thyself

Self reflection is the step that is most frequently missed in prep work because it requires you to think about what your organization can actually achieve and execute against. Do you have buy in from senior management? Do you have dedicated resources e.g. enough staff, access to data, etc. to effectively work against your goals? If not, scale back the scope of your goals. Alternately, postpone your marketing campaign until such time that you do have the resources. Better to parse your goals and make incremental progress, than to shoot for the moon and come up short.

Ask questions.

If you don't know the answer, find out. Don't know where to find the answer? Start with your analysts – they are generally the ones with the best understanding of your company's existing tools and data sets, and they may be able to point you in the right direction.

Don't have any questions?

What are you doing in marketing?! You should always be questioning as the landscape is always changing! This is more than just a SWOT analysis, folks. Once you've answered enough questions that you could pitch the idea to your boss' boss, in layman's terms, you are ready to move on to marketing strategy.

Craft Your Marketing Strategy

You know your audience. You know how to differentiate from your competitors. You have the tools you need to be successful. And most importantly, you know what you need to achieve. So now, here's your chance to get your creative juices flowing. Creating a compelling marketing strategy requires a connecting with your audience in a meaningful way and adding value.

Build Community

To make your strategy sustainable you need to built a relationship with your audience, and the best way to do that is to build communities using relevant content – content marketing. Marketing is now equal parts, if not more, pull than push. And while lots of folks have said it's all content, content, content, that's not strictly true. It's the right content, delivered at the right time that adds value. Social media is one of the best community building platforms and ways to engage your audience, but you don't have to think about this as an online only approach. Community building can happen through events, and through direct marketing of all types that encourages collaboration and sharing. For more details on community building, check out this great, albeit long, guide for learning the fundamentals.

Position the Benefits

All of your planning and a community building approach will be for naught if you don't also position your campaign with benefit-oriented statements. You need to sell your audience on "why" they should care. At the end of the day, it's about them, and NOT you. A lesson you should have already learned when community building, but it bears repeating. Them NOT you.

Mix Up Your Tactics

Pick your tactics based on your audience. If you have highly fragmented audience segments, you may need completely different strategies with completely different marketing mixes to engage with them. In a simple example, you could engage with tech-savvy young people on social media and via email using infographics and compelling, sharable content, while engaging with tech-averse older folks using in-person demonstrations and TV spots that drive them to stores. While micro-targeting and micro-positioning for one specific channel may at times be helpful, do not become overly reliant on any one particular channel. Consider a balance of both inbound and outbound marketing channels. Here's a great graphic from Moz: A multi-channel marketing strategy will ensure you engage your customers in a variety of ways, and, when done right, will allow you leverage one channel in support of another.

Test

The only way to know what's working and what isn't is to test, and use data to develop meaningful insights and refine your marketing strategy. Test your copy. Test your design. Test your channel. Test your timing. Test your segmentation. Test your marketing investment. While our intuition as marketers can sometimes be right, it can also be wrong, leaving money on the table and minimizing long-term success. Success is not about a single conversion, nor is about a single campaign. It's about incremental changes across campaigns that result in the highest lifetime value of a customer possible. Avinash has a great visual that details a ladder of digital metrics that your organization should care about. Make it your priority to use your campaign level goals and your marketing strategy to move your organization forward. Not only will your company look better, but you'll also become the marketing rock star you set out to be.

Go forth and strategize, friends.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Create a Kick Ass Marketing Strategy - What You Need to Know
Craft a successful marketing strategy by understanding your audience, knowing your internal limitations, building community and more!

item.title: A Lesson in Inbound Linking: Why You Mad, Bro?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Recently - and by that I mean today,so I just need to rant - I had a weird experience on one of our client's social media profiles. Let me start from the beginning... The back story. This client had been asking me to promote content on their social media profiles, as well as on their site blog, that focused on one specific topic. Let's call this Topic B. So that's what I did. My social media strategy for that client became much broader, promoting content that was similar to what I had already been doing (Let's call these Topics A & C), in addition to using more content that was related to Topic B. Today, I found this pretty cool blog written by someone (Let's call them Bitter Blogger) who has had personal experience with Topic B. This was a particularly cool blog because she wrote about Topics C and B! Sounds like a perfect match for the kind of content that I needed to promote, right? Yes! And the blog was definitely something that my client's followers would enjoy, right? Yes! So of course I linked to it. I wrote up a quick blog post about Bitter Blogger, their story, and I linked back to their site. I composed a tweet using a link to my blog post, tagged Bitter Blogger's handle in the tweet, and I was done! It was prime content creation for a client. Exactly the kind of Friday morning that I enjoy. The confrontation. Alas, Bitter Blogger didn't think that what I did was prime content creation. In fact, Bitter Blogger was really offended. They said that I (my client, technically) had not asked permission to link to their site, and that it looked like they were endorsing my client. I was agog. I was aghast. Why had Bitter Blogger written me off so fast? (Yes, I just paraphrased Les Misérables.) Technically, I was doing them a favor, right? It was outbound linking for my client, and inbound linking for this blogger. This is good SEO. I was going to be driving users to her site. Surely, they were mistaken, right? Wrong. Bitter Blogger was incredibly peeved. They turned several of their Twitter followers against my client, making me out to be the bad guy. I finally had to wave a white flag of surrender. I deleted the offending blog post and tweet, and issued an apology tweet to Bitter Blogger. Forgive me, but when someone links to your site, isn't that an amazing, wonderful, awesome thing?! It's what we Internet marketers DREAM OF! To get noticed! To get recognized! To be seen by a larger audience! Yet, it seems like Bitter Blogger doesn't know anything about inbound linking. How sad for Bitter Blogger! Because inbound (and outbound) linking is awesome! It's the superfood of Internet marketing! It what makes my small but exciting world go 'round! The conclusion. If you're a blogger, it's kind of important to know how the Internet works. To know that someone doesn't need to "ask permission" to link to your blog. To know that inbound linking will help drive more users to your site. To know that it's simply not nice to chew someone out when you're completely in the wrong.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: inbound linking
A Lesson in Inbound Linking: Why You Mad, Bro? | Commerce Kitchen
Forgive me, but when someone links to your site, isn't that an amazing, wonderful, awesome thing? Yeah, that's what I thought. Sigh. Inbound linking.

item.title: Sass Hack Denver Update
item.dc:creator: aaron
item.content:encoded: Last month Eric Meyer and I started the first Sass user group in Denver. We soft launched with a quick site that Eric whipped up, sent out tweets, and made it happen with a great turn out. Based on that small success, we've set up a new home for Sass Hack Denver on Meetup.com, where we currently have 57 members. We hope to provide a project and people focused event, so we'll kick off with lightning talks before diving into a short, live challenge. This Tuesday, January 14th, our second meetup features a lightning talk by Jim Hanifen, who will discuss how he and MapMyFitness use Sass for inherited templates that allow branding across several different sites. There will be beer and pizza and consequently plenty of socializing. If you're into that sort of thing or want to learn more about Sass, then be sure to stop by!
