item.title: Athletes, Ads & Puppies - It's All Good Press
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
“There is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.” - Oliver Wilde, The Picture of Dorian Gray
If the Richard Sherman outburst at the end of the NFC Championship Game taught us anything, it's that this sentiment is alive and well. Forbes chalked up the response to the "crazy" we want to see in our athletes. Sports Illustrated dug into additional footage to put the response the context. And #richardsherman has been used thousands, if not millions, of times in the last week and a half. All of the press is building up the intensity and excitement of Sunday's NJ showdown. The same can be said for the ads. We no longer wait for Super Bowl Sunday to watch the ads. Agencies and brands alike "leak" their insanely expensive ads to build buzz and capture the spotlight for as long as possible. AdAge thinks that Doritos won the pre-game brand battle for web dominance. And while by the number of views, that may be true, the heart warming and sappy Puppy Love has been blowing up my social feeds. You're welcome. And while I am a sucker for cute animals in commercials (I counted at least 4 so far), I really can't wait to see Arnold in all of his spandex glory and my Denver Broncos kick the shit out of the Seattle Seahawks. #trashtalking #PFM So athletes, here's to playing hard, and saying whatever crazy things pop out of your mouth in the heat of the moment. Your agent may hate you, but you just made your PR person's life a whole lot easier. Brands, here's to going viral with your million dollar ads and teasing just enough content to keep us interested (and envious of your budgets). And here's to puppies, because puppies always need press. Check back tomorrow, for Jen's great take on the evolution of social media at the Super Bowl.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: athletes-ads-puppies-super-bowl
Super Bowl Athletes, Ads and Puppies - It's All Good Press
Trash talking athletes, viral TV commercial "leaks", and puppies build up our excitement for the Super Bowl. Positive or negative, it's all good press.

item.title: Do You RDD?
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.content:encoded: Even though I'm still learning the process, I'm a believer in the Agile way to develop software. The trickier part for me is how to incorporate it into my workflow. I'm always anxious to start programming first without really diving into the details and this typically gets me into trouble. I'll either have to completely rewrite some code because I missed something or I've created a bottleneck for other developers working on the project. So, how do I break these bad habits and save my sanity and honor? Test driven development (TDD) is one process that I can use to help me avoid these headaches. But I still have that inclination to skip this step and start working on the production code. Lately, it's been one of my biggest challenges in altering my workflow. And it lead me to ask for advice from my team and search Google for some solutions. That's when I read Tom Preston-Werner's post on ReadMe driven development (RDD) and it resonated with me. It is such a common sense approach to help give you clarity BEFORE starting to program. Write down what you need to do in plain English before you write a test or a line of code! The very simple and novel idea to iterate over the problem and possible solutions in your head before programming is the step I was missing. If I can't describe accurately what is needed, how can I expect to program it? What steps do you take to improve your workflow and development process?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: rdd
Do You RDD? |ReadMe Driven Development
I've found that RDD (ReadMe driven development) has helped me better adopt agile software development.

item.title: Matt Cutts' Musical Chairs
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
If you're new to the world of search engine optimization, then you've probably never heard of Matt Cutts. Matt is the head of Google's webspam team, and he's in a constant dance / battle with SEO firms who are trying to outwit Google's algorithm. Some SEOs would disagree with my choice of the word "outwit." However, this is exactly how Google sees it. The algorithm is theoretically designed to find the best of the best. It's supposed to present to you, the person searching for something on Google, the most relevant results. Google determines relevance based on its algorithm, and the algorithm is always changing. Some websites that are not actually the most relevant will appear close to the top of the search results because they've managed to outwit the algorithm. Of course Google's definition of relevance is a topic of debate and doesn't come without ethical and philosophical implications. Some algorithm updates have shoved small businesses off the first few pages of search while pushing big brands to the top. Google has tried to mitigate this by placing local search results above universal organic search results and by having anyone who's logged into Google receive personalized search results. They're implementing a rotating carousel for local search, enabling users to see a variety of local businesses that they wouldn't have seen before. Over the years SEOs have tried every cheap trick they can to outwit the algorithm, and to me this is like playing a really bad game of musical chairs. Musical chairs was fun and innocent, and when the music stopped if you were the one left without a chair then you'd wait until the next round began. However, with this version of musical chairs, now when the music stops the floor collapses underneath you. You've spent thousands of dollars on an SEO strategy that not only doesn't work any more, but that also actually penalizes you. You may have outwitted the algorithm for a while, but now Matt Cutts is on to you. And you're going to be punished. Here are some of the chairs that Google has pulled out of the game over the past few years: Footer links: A favorite of web designers, developers, and SEOs, Google no longer gives any weight to links placed in the footer of a website, or other site-wide links. Many Wordpress themes and plug-ins have their creators' links attached to them, and while this isn't inherently spammy, Google no longer uses this as a signal. Guest blogging: Guest blogging was once thought of as an ethical SEO tactic to generate relevant content, drive people to your site, network, and build links. A bunch of really bad SEOs started doing an excessive amount of guest blogging, paying people to include their irrelevant and poorly-written blogs on their sites, and now Google no longer sees guest blogging as a true signal of a site's authority or relevance. Link exchanges: One of the oldest and cheapest tricks in the book, Google hasn't been interested in link exchanges for a while. The gist is this: I'll scratch your back if you scratch mine. I'll link to you, website that I don't know anything about, if you'll link to me. Google says nope.

Keyword (over)optimization: Google has claimed that it penalizes sites that are over-optimized for keywords. And we really want that to be true. However, sites like this one are still ranking number one for competitive keyphrases by over-optimizing the crap out of their site. That page is a nightmare of keyword variation. Sure, they rank number one, but it seems to me that they're all about the tricks and not about the content. If your site has performed consistently over the past few years, then congratulations. There will always be fluctuations in how you perform in search, and focusing too much on organic rankings will make you crazy. Plus, it won't actually bring you the business you need if your site isn't built to convert those visitors, and if your product or business model doesn't have inherent value in its own right. If you're still playing SEO musical chairs, then it's only a matter of time until you lose. Create a marketing strategy that will work no matter what Google's algorithm does.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Matt Cutts' Musical Chairs
Trying to outwit Google's algorithm is like playing a bad game of musical chairs that will cost you time, money, and credibility.
matt cutts
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/matt-cutts-musical-chairs/

item.title: Gold Medal Apps from the Outside-in
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
pro·pri·o·cep·tion (prō′prē-ō-sĕp′shən) n 1. The unconscious perception of movement and spatial orientation arising from stimuli within the body itself. 2. The ability to sense the position, location, orientation and movement of the body and its parts. Take a moment and consider the level of awareness necessary to successfully execute the maneuver above. An acute awareness of everything in the environment and your position in it develops over time by repetition of analysis, planning and practice. Starting simple and working up to, then beyond the comfort zone to achieve those first few successful landings. Soon, you realize the trick flows more naturally more consistently when your focus is more comprehensive and less about the gyrating aerial maneuver. Developing a keen awareness of everything in the environment from the top of the run, through the approach, takeoff, maneuver and landing is key to successful execution. Without a doubt, pro athletes practice the techniques of their sport a great deal. Many also use visualization to practice and prepare. They visualize themselves on the course, aware of and interacting with every small thing about the course, the day, the weather, the event, their perfect performance and their presence on the awards podium. They've gone through the process countless times so they can adapt to variations of the day and perform with confidence and clarity. As agile developers, we too practice our techniques a great deal, and that should include visualization. Using a wireframe, sketch or other model of the UI to repeatedly discuss, define, and refine behavior that occurs when the user presses a control on a page builds a keen awareness of the application in each team member. This iterative, outside-in approach has many benefits for the team at both levels, client and product owner, and product owner and dev team. Some of these benefits are:
  • The vocabulary of the business domain is used in daily discussions and is intentionally transferred into the code, improving communication and long term comprehension by current and future team members.
  • Features and stories are defined, evolve and get accepted or rejected by what is presented in the UI. The business value of each feature remains clear, and unnecessary code does not develop.
  • By keeping feature and story discussions ahead of implementation, the dev team is able to encapsulate behavior into related and loosely coupled modules, establish effective APIs and create object hierarchies with very little backtracking.
  • With a planned and maintained modular architecture, the team gains the ability to quickly adapt to changes and pivot without major losses in time or sections of the code base.
  • The application's object hierarchy is well organized and efficient reducing redundant code.
  • Refactoring and code extraction goals are achieved faster because of the high degree of modularity.
  • Tests remain more useful because behaviors are well encapsulated and cross module movement of code is reduced.
  • Prototyping efforts can be utilized more effectively because they can be quickly connected to existing UI and infrastructure code, providing a faster evaluation time and more realistic estimate of implementation.
Did you notice some recurring themes? Discuss, encapsulate, communicate, (re)organize and iterate appear often. Communication is an invaluable skill in building software with a team. It requires the repeated exchange of a tremendous amount of detailed information, so it's no wonder that mis-communication is often responsible for project shortcomings and failures. By repeatedly discussing features and stories, analyzing them, breaking them down and rebuilding them in conversation, the team members are repeatedly implementing features without writing much application code. They are visualizing and verbalizing solutions, much like the athlete practicing a new trick one step at a time, adding difficulty in a less hazardous environment. Implementation ideas have been refactored, regrouped, merged and moved around in the architecture with great ease, saving many frustrating and costly hours of development time – which usually means it doesn't get done at all and your code base degrades. Like the athlete who has reached a confident awareness of all fundamentals in the trick, it's time to add difficulty, the characteristics that make the application unique for the customer (our judge). As developers, our fundamentals are the application's API, object hierarchy, and functional dependencies. We have modeled/visualized them countless times and we have confidence in how to use them to interact with other application code to implement the difficult stories. Add a bit of code at a time (test first). Back up and rework if necessary (refactor), you're in a safe and encapsulated environment. Iterate and visualize completely (constant integration) from the top of the course, approach, takeoff, maneuver, landing, and most certainly, the tallest podium in the winner's circle.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Gold Medal Apps from the Outside-in | Agile Developers Need Practice
As agile developers, we practice our techniques a great deal, just like gold medalists. So, how can we apply Olympic strategies to software development?
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/featuredimage.jpeg

item.title: On the "Problem" of Women in Tech
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen’s ownership team is primarily women (3 out of 4 of us). We do our best to encourage women in tech spheres. We support Lady Coders and Women Who Code when we can. We try our best to interview at least one woman every time we have an open position. We understand that diverse teams are almost always more productive and more creative and we really want that goodness baked into our company. At the same time, all of our developers are men. We’ve had lady devs, and we’ve extended job offers to others. But the fact of the matter is that currently our dev team is not just male dominated; it’s all men. Seriously. What gives? I know a lot of people think this is a cop out, but hiring awesome developers is freaking hard, and hiring women developers is even harder. Inexplicably, between 1985 and 2010, the percentage of comp sci grads that were women dropped from 37% to just 18%. SAT-taking teen girls reported a 20% interest in an engineering/tech field in 2001.In 2006, that number dropped to 12%. The list goes on and on. I was going to make some fancy graphs to convey some of the data in a meaningful way, but really, this about sums it up: There are tons of theories as to why women don’t pursue careers in tech at the same rate that men do, and many of them are backed by lots of data and great research. Others are anecdotal and appalling. We can blame education. We can blame obnoxious dudes. We can even blame the work itself - Harvey Mudd’s president, Maria Klawe, summed it up this way: “We’ve done lots of research on why young women don’t choose tech careers and number one is they think it’s not interesting.” And it’s that last one that really sticks in my craw. Not interesting? I think we have a perception problem here, people. I’ll admit to being the nerd kid that got sent off to computer camp when everyone else was learning archery and horseback riding (I already knew how to do both of those!), but come on. Not interesting?! Last year, I talked with Katie Weiss of the Boulder Chapter of Women Who Code, and she had this to say:
"We tell girls who may have good math/science scores in school to go into business or liberal arts because they can communicate, write, talk to people – even though they may also have a high aptitude for something like programming; and we tell men to go into science/engineering fields if they show the slightest aptitude for it. It’s like we’re pushed out of computer science programs because people think our skills are more needed elsewhere, but we really need those skills here, too."
Programmers aren’t 100% anti-social sweaty dudes coding in their mom’s basement while swilling Mountain Dew (not that there’s anything wrong with that). Coding is a creative endeavor, and code isn’t written for computers - it’s written for the people that use computers. But a job in programming isn’t even all about the code. As Katie suggests, we need people people who are also great coders. If we just funnel the socially awkward into tech careers, we’re really screwing ourselves over! And please know - I’m not saying that men are socially awkward and women are socially amazing. But I think Katie’s right in that we have a bias in how we coach young people. If you’re a little dorky and a boy, maybe you should program. If you’re a little socially awkward and a girl - we don’t know what to do with you. Sorry! A while ago I had an interesting conversation with an aspiring developer - a guy who had spent most of his time post-graduation from an elite liberal arts college as an elementary school teacher. I want this guy to learn how to code. A lot. Know why? Because he has people skills. He has worked with the General Public - with parents and their children, for crying out loud. He’s got a service orientation, knows how to talk with and persuade people, he’s charming, and he’s used to coming up with unique solutions to peculiar and hard problems. And as an employer of developers, that’s what I want. I want someone who can code beautifully not even though they’re clever and creative and people-oriented, but precisely because they are those things. Did you catch that? I think a career in elementary education is a suitable stepping-stone for a career in tech. I’m a former librarian and I used that career as a jumping off point for a career in tech. The skills required in both fields - teaching and librarianship, both women-dominated fields - are the skills I’m desperate to find in good coders. If women aren’t coming to tech because they think the work isn’t interesting, then we’re not doing a great job of explaining tech career options to young women. The things that make a career in business or teaching appealing to women can apply equally to a career in technology. Problem solving. Communicating. Educating. Sharing. Check, check, check and check. Coders just happen to do that all in addition to writing code. Just like librarians do all that in addition to hanging out around books all day. The CK ownership team has a DU, Wesleyan and Reed College education; we’ve got Art History, Music, American Lit, and Religious Studies backgrounds. We’ve all worked in service industries, and we’re all people people (though some of us are more extroverted than others!). Our team is made up of bartenders and biologists, musicians and teachers, historians and artists, and, admittedly, the occasional born-and-bred computer geek. [caption id="attachment_4961" align="aligncenter" width="625"] Commerce Kitchen's owners, looking surly.[/caption] I’ve worked in libraries, universities, bookstores, naturopathic medical colleges, and even a bar of dubious repute. And you know what? This is hands down the most interesting place I’ve ever worked - in part because of the nature of the work, and in part because of the motley crew we employ. [caption id="attachment_4972" align="alignleft" width="196"] Me, as a freshman at Reed.[/caption] This weekend, I’ll be facilitating a panel discussion on “Women in Tech” at my alma mater, Reed College, for an event put on by the “Center For Life After Reed” (a department that would be called Career Services at any other college). Reed students and alums (a.k.a. Reedies) tend to skew heavily academic (the tiny campus has produced 31 Rhodes Scholars - the second highest number for a liberal arts college), and the event, Reed Working Weekend, is an attempt to give Reedies a glimpse of what non-academic careers look like. Part of my goal is to make sure that these exceptionally bright women know that if they choose a career in technology, they won’t be forsaking that beautiful and intense liberal arts education; they’ll just be using it in a different way than maybe they’d planned.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: On the "Problem" of Women in Tech
As a tech company that's 75% female owned, even Commerce Kitchen has trouble hiring female programmers.
women in tech
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/women-in-tech/

item.title: Live StyleGuides and Why They Rule
item.dc:creator: aaron
item.content:encoded:
A live styleguide is designed and built in the browser. Coded with the big three – HTML, CSS and JS – it hosts all of the things, from buttons to forms to calls-to-action. Checkout our latest styleguide for Go Code Colorado to get an idea of how one looks. A live styelguide offers more than just looking freakin' spiffy, so let's review some of the other benefits that come with it.

Don't Repeat Yourself

Have you ever designed a button on the homepage and later code an almost identical button on the contact form? Starting your design process with a styleguide forces us to anticipate repeating patterns and solve for them all at once. Having all buttons in the same place helps us recognize these patterns early and stay consistent in our presentation.

Reusability and Independence

When every element on your site must coexist on the same page, it forces us to think through how we chose to write code. At first I was surprised to discover how much of my CSS depended on inherited styles in the cascade. Hey, that testimonial section looks great on the homepage, but oh, rats, look... Now it needs to be in the sidebar and, oh, that broke it. Building elements in a standardized environment helps us write reusable and decoupled code.

The Promise of Java

With a styleguide, we can build each component once and call on it when needed throughout the site. Implementing this will vary depending on the framework you use, but we haven't had much trouble making it work for us. Here's a screeny of a recent Wordpress homepage that uses a styleguide. (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻ That's 7 lines of code! If we need to change the markup for featured posts, we only change them in our styleguide and that change happens site-wide, as every instance of every component references itself in the styleguide. It kinda feels like class inheritance in OOP, doesn't it?

Measure twice, cut once

A live styleguide provides a central repository for everything. We always test individual pages, but it's really nice to have one place to review how components are rendering on different screens and devices. When other developers come a long, they can quickly review how everything is styled and marked up, perform minor surgery, confirm everything looks well and be on their way.

Save Time or Get Rich Quick

The typical web development workflow demands sketches, wireframes, mockups, and code and in that order. Mockups can take up around one third of a project's time and budget only to be passed on to developers, referenced for a few weeks, then archived forever. Instead of wasting resources, our project workflow favors using the right tool for the task at hand. Sometimes it's easier to articulate a feature on the marker board, while other times it's appropriate to prototype an animation in CSS, but we always try to get into the code and onto the browser as soon as possible. Then we design and developed where the components will live forever: online.

Subject to Scrutiny

We've experienced some success with this part of our process, but we will certainly iterate on it and other aspects of our workflow in the months to come. Have you ever used a live styleguide? What makes your workflow unique?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: live styleguides
Live StyleGuides and Why They Rule | Commerce Kitchen
A live styleguide provides a central repository for everything. But why else are they awesome? Let one of our great front-end devs, Aaron explain it to you.

item.title: Facebook, 10 Years, and the Nostalgia Train
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Oh Facebook, thou art a wondrous anomaly. Who would've thought ten years ago that Jesse Eisenberg - sorry, I mean Mark Zuckerberg - would create a social media platform that has 1.23 BILLION MONTHLY USERS?! That number is huge. Do you know 1.23 billion people? I don't. But Marky Mark Zuckerberg does. Admittedly, Facebook has come a long, long way since its creation in that Harvard dorm room. From dropping "The" from "The Facebook," to the disappearance of stickers and flair walls (RIP), and then redesign after redesign after redesign, we have reached 2014's Facebook, complete with your Timeline and a customizable (!!!) News Feed. So after 10 years, what do we get? A Look Back. Mark and the Facebook team gave all 1.23 billion of us these tailor-made videos, showing us our histories on the site. The year we joined. Photos we uploaded when we were younger and more naïve. Our big moments (a.k.a.: our most-liked statuses). Random photos we had forgotten. With "A Look Back," Facebook is almost as naïve as we were when we uploaded those terrible photos during high school. Did they not hear of little apps called Statigram and Flipagram, both of which became extremely popular for Instagram users at the end of 2013? Statigram collected all of your top moments (a.k.a.: most-liked photos) from throughout the year and turned them into a shareable video on Instagram. Statigram critics disliked its one-shot-is-all-you-have nature, so Flipagram's flexibility was appealing. Flipagram allowed you to collect all of your favorite photos from Instagram, Facebook or your camera roll, and create a short video montage of your year. Do either of these concepts sound familiar? These trips down memory lane that Facebook handed to each of us this week aren't exactly original. In fact, they're so unoriginal I bet it took them all of five minutes to come up with the Look Back concept. Nostalgia is so popular right now that it makes A Look Back seem like an off-the-cuff idea. Essentially, Facebook hopped aboard the Nostalgia Train. Toot toot. But guess what? It doesn't even matter, because what Facebook lacked in originality they made up for in heart. It was nostalgia suckers like me that ate up "A Look Back" with a giant, Facebook-loving spoon. I cried during my montage, okay? However, my favorite part of Facebook's celebration of 10 Years was the Ten Stories campaign. The stories chosen focused on how the decade-old social media platform has helped connect people from all over the world. One of these stories happened to be about one of my favorite companies, Sevenly, and its recent partnership with Mercy Ships, so I - of course - fell in love with Ten Stories. So what does this 10-year mark mean for Facebook and its users? Let's not forget that while Facebook aged 10 years, so did all of its users. And not only are Facebook's users getting older, but more people from older generations are signing up for Facebook profiles as well. Furthermore, many critics are saying that the youngest social media-using generation is turning away from Facebook, and moving towards Twitter and Instagram. (But at the same time, some around the web say that teens aren't leaving Facebook, so who are we supposed to believe??) And how will this age change affect your business profiles on Facebook? If you're targeting a younger audience, then maybe Facebook won't be your best option to find your people. Or maybe it will, depending on who you ask. Twitter and Instagram continue to grow, and let's not forget about Pinterest! I'm just excited to see what social media's going to look like in another ten years.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Facebook, 10 Years, and the Nostalgia Train | Commerce Kitchen
facebook
Oh Facebook, thou art a wondrous anomaly. So after ten years of the social media giant's reign over the web, what do we get?
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/flairwall.jpg

item.title: Improving eCommerce with Social Media
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded: If there is anything web-related that I am obsessed with, it's eCommerce. In my 10+ years of programming, I've feel like I've been involved in every aspect of the web. It started with Flash, then migrated towards front-end Javascript/CSS before landing on PHP, and now Ruby. Between all that my computer became littered with pieces of C++, Java, and even .NET (ugh!). I would have never expected that my calling however would make itself known the day I was introduced to Magento, the open source eCommerce framework. As I progressed slowly through the immense volume of code that compromises Magento, I became slowly entangled in ideas of how to make it easier and faster for customers to shop. Enter social media. In my many discussions with friends, family, and co-workers about eCommerce sites, the one topic that comes up time and time again is how much of a hassle it is to complete the online shopping process. You have to register and log in, navigate through a rats nest of categories and sub-categories, or even worse: search for something that you may not even know the name of. Once you have what you need, you may have points to redeem, coupons to use, and don't forget the dreaded checkout page... "What's your billing information? What's your shipping information? How are you going to pay for all of this? How much do you want to pay to get your items faster? Where did you hear about us?" So, how can social media make this all better? For starters, skip the registration. Facebook, Google+, and Twitter all offer up their own variations of a login button. In return for logging in with a social media service, each will return a specific set of information such as the users email or name. In some cases, the service will even allow you to request additional information from the user. Facebook, for example, offers up loads of additional options to request of the user, everything from their "Liked" books to their friend's birthdays. Using this information to generate the users account on your eCommerce site allows users bypass the entire registration process without you losing out on the information needed during registration. You could even take it a step further depending on the content within your store. Selling books online? Collect the users favorite books list and use it to find more personalized recommended items in your store. Everyone has their opinions around social media and privacy, all with what I feel are valid points. That being said, I always disliked how there is such a negative connotation surrounding what information social media sites collect. It's never a matter of what they collect as much as it is what they do with it. It's not enough for the social media giants to continually spout "We don't do anything malicious with your information." Rather, I feel like it's up to us as innovative developers and programmers to show what can be done with the information they collect, and build things that make users lives easier. Consider the following. If Facebook collected your address and phone number, an eCommerce website customer who chose to login with Facebook could have their billing and shipping information auto populated during the checkout process. A huge advantage when you take into account the fact that approximately 67% of shopping carts are abandoned, many during the checkout process. The idea is simple: the less a customer has to do, the less stressed they are, the faster they can move through the checkout, and the less time they have to second guess their purchase. Incentives, anyone? Every social media site worth their salt today releases plugins that you can easily build upon to incentivize your customers during their shopping experience. It's the difference between "Like this item, because we want you to. Pretty please?" and "Like this item and get free overnight shipping on your order!" Which would you prefer see? It seems as though most companies are missing the potential of social media when it comes to eCommerce. Almost every site you visit these days will have social media on some level. More often than not however it amounts to nothing more than a couple buttons to share, +1, or tweet. Where's the incentive? Why should I click on any of those buttons if I don't really care that much about it? The potential for social media to improve the experiences of users on an eCommerce site, or any site for that matter, is unparalleled. Social media has gifted us nearly unlimited resources, all that's left is to build on it. As a wise man once said, "If you build it, they will come." (Ethereal voice in the movie Field of Dreams.)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Improving eCommerce with Social Media
Improving eCommerce with Social Media | Commerce Kitchen
On many eCommerce sites, checkout processes are too lengthy for users to complete. Here's how one of our newer devs, Eric, thinks social media can help.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/shutterstock_101189113.jpg

item.title: Resources for Women In Tech
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
This weekend Michelle and I will be mentoring and presenting at Reed College's Working Weekend on women in tech. Here's the handout we'll be giving to students on resources for women interested in pursing a career in tech. Please note that these resources are for students located in Portland, Oregon, and skew toward that region.

Resources for Women in Dev

If you’re interested in becoming a software or web developer, seek out mentors, learn as much as you can, and join others who are also learning. You can do this in female-centered environments or not. Some feel safer and more confident in women-only spaces in tech, others are fine reaching out to men for mentorship. No matter how you choose to approach a career in tech, don’t be afraid or self-conscious about asking all the questions you have, failing often and learning from your mistakes, trying things out for yourself, and getting help when you need it. You will not be a perfect dev right out of the gate. No one is. Men and women alike have a learning curve and the more you practice the better you’ll get.   Also, it is absolutely crucial for your career to network. Meet women and men actively working in the technology sector by joining meetups, becoming members of tech organizations, and seeking advice. This will ingratiate you to the community, create more job opportunities for you, and potentially get you some new friends! Here are some resources that focus on helping women learn to code and supporting them in their job search in tech. Passion Projects (online) Women speakers in tech with presentations available to watch online. Code Scouts (Portland) Empowers women to become programmers. They have a mentorship program using existing dev training resources, like Treehouse (see below for more details). PyLadies (Portland) A meetup for female python developers and those who want to learn. Code N Splode (Portland) A networking group for women and genderqueer identifying people in the tech industry or interested in getting into tech. Women in software engineering on Github The Ada Initiative A resource that supports women in technology by hosting conferences and camps, advocating for gender diversity in tech, and teaching men how to be better allies. WITI - Portland Chapter Networking opportunities for women working in the technology sector. Women 2.0 Conferences, job board, videos, and other resources for women in tech. Geek Feminism A website that discusses issues that women face in geek communities, “including science and technology, gaming, SF fandom, and more.” National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT) Advocacy for getting more women into technology, as well as resources to help women and girls. DevChix Support and resources for women in software and web development. Not incredibly up to date, but their archives might be a good resource.

Women in Tech on Social Media

While LinkedIn is a great way to make your professional presence known, Twitter is the platform of choice for most devs. Follow, interact with, and get to know other women in technology on Twitter. Here are some places to start. Huffington Post’s list Information Management’s list EndGadget’s list  Mashable’s list

Training Programs

Code schools are popping up across the United States as demand for software devs explodes. Some of these programs have courses just for women or offer scholarships to women, which we’ve indicated below. While these programs exist across the world, we’ve listed the ones in Portland, Seattle, and northern California. We’ve also included code schools in Denver and Boulder to try to convince you to come to Colorado, where Commerce Kitchen is. Prosper IT (Portland) 10-week program Call for pricing .NET programming only Epicodus (Portland) 4-month program $4500-5000 Javascript, Ruby, PostgreSQL, Active Record, Ruby on Rails, APIs, AJAX, Ember.js, HTML and CSS, jQuery Code Fellows (Seattle) $500 and up per class Foundations of computer science classes, plus bootcamps in Rails, iOS, Javascript, Python, and UX. Coding Dojo (Seattle) 12-week course, 50-70 hours per week in class $9850 HTML, CSS, JavaScript, PHP, MySQL, OOP, MVC, Ruby on Rails, and more Rails Bridge (Seattle, Denver, and other locations across the world) Free Workshops in Rails, with some specifically for women. Hackbright Academy (San Francisco) For women only 10-week program $15,000, with $3000 refundable after getting a job from someone in their network Python focused, with HTML5, Javascript, SQL, and CSS, plus methodologies like paired programming, interview skills Dev Bootcamp (San Francisco) 9-week program $12,200 - women get a $500 scholarship or a potential Levo Scholarship, offering women $2500 off tuition Ruby on Rails, HTML5 and CSS, Javascript, agile development, SASS, HAML, AJAX, jQuery, Coffescript Hack Reactor (San Francisco) 12-week program $17,780 Javascript App Academy (San Francisco and NYC) 12-week program "App Academy does not charge any tuition. Instead, you pay us a placement fee only if you find a job as a developer after the program. In that case, the fee is 18% of your first year salary, payable over the first 6 months after you start working." Git, PostgreSQL, Ruby, Rails, HTML5, jQuery, Backbonejs Apprentice.io (San Francisco) 3-month apprenticeship Pays $500 a week Must have intermediate knowledge of Ruby on Rails to apply Ruby on Rails, jQuery, Backbone.js, HTML5, SCSS, git, Unix, and agile software development. Zipfian Academy (San Francisco with some online classes) 12-week program $16,000 with a $4,000 reimbursement if you get a job through their hiring program. Focused on “data science” and requires a background in quantitative thinking. General Assembly (San Francisco, online, and other locations across the world) One-day classes and workshops to 12-week courses Free workshops, $85 one-day classes, $550 three-day bootcamps, $12,000 12-week classes Ruby on Rails, APIs, javascript, jQuery, AJAX, sys admin, front end and UX, business, marketing GSchool (Denver and Boulder) 24-week program $20,000 with a three-year payment plan available "As long as you will work in the US, participate in 75% of our "matchmaking" activities and graduate from the program, we'll help you get a job with a software development team in the Colorado region — or we'll refund your tuition." CSS, HTML5, Javascript, Ruby, Rails, SQL, source control, test driven development, pair programming, deployment, scaling, presentations, leading group discussions DaVinci Coders (Boulder) 11-week program (not full time) $5000 - $6000 Ruby on Rails, HTML, CSS, and jQuery refactorU (Boulder) 10-week program $12,500 - 10% discount for women Python focused, with HTML5, CSS, jQuery, MongoDB, JSON, Javascript, Node JS, Websocket Lynda (online) $25 - $37.50 a month membership Basic online courses, videos, and tutorials for software and web development. Courses wouldn't prepare you for a job but would give a great introduction into the field. Treehouse (online) $25 - $49 a month membership Online courses in HTML, CSS, Design, JavaScript, Ruby, PHP, WordPress, iOS, Android, Development Tools, Business Georgia Institute of Technology’s Online M.S. in Computer Science $6,600 for an entire master's degree Requires undergraduate degree in computer science, math, or related degrees, with a GPA of 3.0 or above. Computational Perception & Robotics, Databases & Software Engineering, High-Performance Computing, Interactive Intelligence, Machine Learning, Networking, Social Computing, Systems Cool graphic of Rosie the Riveter from Tech Cocktail's list of organizations for women in technology.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Resources for Women in Tech
Resources for women in tech: support, mentorship, code schools, social media networking, and more, focused on the West Coast & Denver/Boulder.
Resources for Women in Tech
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/resources-for-women-tech-portland/

item.title: Building Business in Colorado
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
If you didn't know, you may have guessed that Colorado is hot, hot, hot for startups right now. But how do we keep more of our businesses growing, partnering and as competitive as possible? Enter Go Code Colorado.

What is Go Code Colorado?

Go Code Colorado is an apps challenge designed to make public data more accessible and user-friendly. Teams of developers and entrepreneurs across the state will compete to solve business problems and grow our economy, by building apps that will help Colorado companies thrive. That's right – teams will build apps using public data that actually help Colorado businesses be more successful by addressing common challenges such as:
  • Where should I build or expand my business?
  • Who's my competition and how can I take market share from them?
  • What kind of funding is right for me and how do I secure it?
  • How can I hire qualified new grads, or where can I find research on industry factors affecting my business?
  • With whom should I partner to grow my business?
Plus, teams will have a chance to work with industry leaders and earn cash awards to build businesses around their new apps.

For the love of Colorado

If the competition, access to amazing folks and incentives weren't enough reasons to get involved, how about for the love of Colorado!? We all started or moved our businesses here because we love Colorado – the quality of life, the smart people, the mountains, the sunshine, the laid-back culture, the beer, and much, much more. To keep our state thriving with some of the best-performing cities and high-tech startups around, we need to keep innovating and supporting each other. By building apps using new public data sets (or data that was really difficult to access before), Go Code Colorado will make existing Colorado businesses stronger and more competitive on a national level, and create new business ventures.

How is CK involved?

We've helped Colorado's Secretary of State's office build the Go Code Colorado brand and website, and are currently reaching out to businesses across the state and marketing the challenge to spread the word. This initiative is near and dear to our heart because we think Colorado is one of the best places in the U.S. to do business, and we want to work with and support business growth in our state. Because as we all get better...stronger...faster (well, really, bigger...smarter...more innovative), we're raising the global bar on tech. Let's all work together to build apps, build business and build Colorado.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Building Business in Colorado: Go Code Colorado Civic Apps Challenge
Go Code Colorado will help build high-tech startups and solve challenges for existing businesses in our state, keeping Colorado's economy growing strongly.
business in colorado

item.title: The Value of a Crappy Job
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
This past weekend I was at Reed College in Portland, Oregon for their annual Working Weekend event. The event is designed to let students know what life will be like after college; panelists (mostly Reed alumni) discuss career paths, give advice, and provide one-on-one mentoring. Even though I'm not a Reed graduate, my background is similar to many of those students: I graduated with a B.A. in Religious Studies, with minors in English and Philosophy, and an M.A. in Religious Studies. I love learning for learning's sake, thinking for thinking's sake, and solving strange problems just for fun. You might call us nerds. That's cool. On Saturday evening I participated in a mentoring version of speed dating. Students read my online profile and signed up to speak with me for ten-minute increments. After the ten minutes was up someone blew a whistle and the students rushed on to their next mentor. I met with some really smart, interesting, and creative students, many of whom were overflowing with angst. I'm not talking about a Bright Eyes sort of teen angst (is Bright Eyes still around? I feel old). I'm talking about the Greek root of angst:  ἄγχω, which means "strangle." This is a real, deep, overpowering anxiety that these students have about finding a career as soon as they graduate in May. On one level I can understand this. A Reed education is about $57,000 a year, including room and board, and these students and their parents want to see an incredibly fast ROI. They want this expensive education to result in a prestigious job that will become a solid career and make them simultaneously happy and financially successful for the rest of their lives. Who doesn't want that? One thing that I kept telling the students I spoke with is that the idea of finding your career right after college graduation is both unrealistic and probably a little bit stupid. Well, the idea isn't stupid, but actually doing it is a little bit stupid, and here's why.

Crappy Jobs Are Good For You

I hereby define a crappy job as follows: a crappy job is a job that doesn't pay very well, that demands a lot, that is physically or mentally monotonous, that doesn't have much opportunity for growth, and that you've probably taken because you're desperate for income. Here's what you'll learn from a crappy job.

How to be nice to people

From the time I was 15 until I was 27 I worked many service industry type jobs. I'd been babysitting for cash since I was twelve, but my first job, with an actual W4, was when I was 15 working for a moving company that was hired to pack up and move the main library in my town. The month I turned sixteen I started working at a coffee shop, then as a cashier for a grocery store, where I worked until I was nineteen. Through and after college I worked as a barista, a waitress, a caterer, and I did landscaping and odd jobs for temp agencies, until I eventually started working in desk jobs. In most of these jobs I had to learn how to be nice to people. There were so many times when rude and caffeine-deprived customers would come up to the counter where I was making lattes, and demand their drink without so much as a hello. I'd say "how are you today?" They'd reply "give me a large coffee." No please. No thank you. Just GIMME. I hated that. I hated being treated poorly, and I hated that I was seen as a means to an end (the end being coffee) rather than a human being. But I learned how to be nice even when I was getting very little in return. This is how the world works. In our personal relationships we can choose our friends. I wouldn't want to be friends with someone who doesn't care about my well being. Unfortunately we can't hold everyone else to those same standards. We can't expect every person we encounter to be kind to us, but if we've got some integrity then we'll figure out how to be nice anyway. It doesn't hurt anyone, and it's a skill that's incredibly valuable.

How to deal with conflict

The horrifying / wonderful thing about working in the service industry is that you will have to deal with conflict, some of it stemming from completely irrational places. You'll experience conflict with customers who are dissatisfied with something that you may or may not have any control over. Your boss didn't order enough sesame bagels, and the irate customer--whom you identify only by the moniker "Triple Americano" because that's what he orders every day--is throwing a fit and blaming you for the fact that now he won't eat until dinner. So what do you do? You figure it out. You deal with the conflict. It sucks, but you do it. You may end up picking up a co-worker's slack when she comes in hungover for the third time that week, and you'll need to figure out how to deal with that (tell your boss? work it out between you? begin slacking yourself?). Conflict is ubiquitous, but in a crappy job it can be even more difficult to manage. It can seem unfair, tedious, and ridiculous. But you have to deal with it. And in dealing with this everyday conflict you'll learn how to be a better person.

How to be reliable

Not only does a crappy job teach you how to be reliable, it teaches you why to be reliable. If your coworker shows up and he's still out of his mind on drugs from the night before (this happened to me many, many times), you're usually pretty pissed. Serving customers, keeping things clean and organized, and making sure everything is in the right place is even more difficult when the person who was supposed to help you do that can't even read a clock because he's so high (yes, this also happened to me). Your co-workers rely on you. This is different in a service industry job or a labor job because it's not work that can be made up on the weekend or after hours. If you don't show up for your shift, or if you show up for your shift unable to do the work, then your coworkers suffer. A lot. Also, if you miss too many shifts you'll get fired. Pure and simple. Crappy jobs teach you the value of being reliable because you know what it feels like when you can't count on someone else. You know how it makes everyone else's job more difficult, and you also know that not being reliable means that you won't have a job.

How to have compassion

This is a big one for college educated, upper-middle-class millennials to embrace. If you've never worked a crappy job then you have no idea what the world is like for most people out there. This entire blog post is written from a privileged perspective. I'm writing under the presumption that a crappy job is a brief stopover on your way to a better career--one that pays well above minimum wage, one that allows you upward mobility, one that will create a stable life for you and your (future) family. There's been quite a bit of research lately that reaffirms the value of a college education. Despite the crippling effects of student loans, people without a college education earn only 62% of what college graduates earn. For college graduates a crappy job is a stepping stone. For others a crappy job is often a longterm reality. From 2003 to 2005 I worked for a national organization that worked to mobilize low-income families across the United States to make their neighborhoods better. Its employees were a mix of recent college graduates with a passion for philanthropy and people who had lived in those communities their whole lives and were deeply invested in making them better. I remember at an annual conference for the organization a woman spoke out against "playing in the ghetto." She felt that these young college graduates were simply tourists in impoverished neighborhoods, and they would never understand what it meant to be part of her community. This is true. If your crappy job is just something you do until you get a "real" job, you'll never really get it. However, living paycheck to paycheck, struggling to make ends meet, and working your ass off day after day for very little reward will make you more compassionate. You'll think twice before stiffing someone on a tip. You'll remember to say please when you order your $5 espresso drink. And you'll know that no one deserves to be treated as inferior to anyone else, regardless of their occupation.

I Like to Hire People With Crappy Jobs on Their Resumes

If the only work experience you have is with internships for companies just like mine, then I don't want to hire you. First of all, internships are (or should be) an extension of your education, not an alternative to actual work. I'm not saying that some internships aren't work, but instead of fetching coffee for a couple executives or updating a company's Yelp profile, I want to know that you've worked hard. Having crappy job experience shows me that you've learned how to be nice to people even if you despise them, that you've worked on ways to deal with conflict, that you've had to be reliable in the face of tedium, and that you know enough to be compassionate. These are skills that can be learned in places other than crappy jobs, but it's the crappy jobs that give you context. People who've had crappy jobs don't have the same sense of entitlement as those who haven't. If you believe that you should never have to have a crappy job because you're somehow above that, then you could use a dose of humility. Instead of moving back in to your parents' basement when your dream job as a creative director at an ad agency doesn't work out right out of college, apply at a coffee shop. See if a department store is hiring. Paint houses. Do landscaping. But work. Get a real job, even if it's crappy. Support yourself on that for a while. Keep building up skills and experience in whatever it is you'd like to do for a career. Teach yourself to code after work. Take free classes in design. Begin writing blogs. Don't stop learning, but don't stop working either. If you're afraid an employer won't be interested in someone who spent a year and a half waiting tables at a gross suburban chain restaurant, then you're wrong. Every bit of work experience counts. Every job counts. Especially the crappy ones.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: The Value of a Crappy Job
One of the most frequent responses I give to anxious college seniors is that they should get a crappy job. Here's why.
crappy job
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/crappy-jobs-are-good-for-you/

item.title: Social Media and The Trader Joe's Deviation
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Disclaimer: I previously lived in California, where Trader Joe's are a dime a dozen. Therefore, my previous experiences with TJ's come from the West coast stores and their West coast customers. I loathe Trader Joe's. Their parking lots are instruments of torture. Their air conditioning systems reek of herbal remedies and condescension. Their clerks wear tacky Hawaiian shirts un-ironically. Their shoppers behave like ravenous wolves fighting over a fresh, lightly-seasoned rotisserie chicken. And yet, I'm utterly fascinated by the brand. Trader Joe's does not use social media. In fact, it seems like the only online presence that they have is their aggressively island-themed website. The brand's quirky personality shines through in website's content and in their recently-released iPhone app. But other than those two mediums, Internet users have little access to this old-school brand. So why doesn't Trader Joe's have social media accounts? In light of the company's secretive nature, it's anybody's guess at this point. In my opinion, it comes down to the fact that without a social media manager at the helm of a Facebook page or Twitter account, the brand's message doesn't get lost in translation online. Either that, or they just like being an old-fashioned brand in the 21st century. Why are they so successful?? Because their shoppers are a large and vast cult, that's why. You can argue that their success comes from the over 3,000 preservative-free products they sell under their own label, or because they introduce a dozen new items each week, or because their staff is super duper cheery like animated characters on Red Bull. It's none of the above. It's because their cult members are truly obsessed with the brand and what it represents: a unique, in-store shopping experience from a brand that supports a healthy, organic lifestyle. Anybody who has blindly walked into a Trader Joe's (after miraculously finding a spot in one of those pain-inducing parking lots) for the first time knows that the store, while small in size, is overwhelming in nature. You feel like you've just stumbled into a Jimmy Buffet song. You immediately have a hankering for something organic and free of artificial coloring. You realize you've never had almond butter, and consider why it took you so long to hear about it. You wonder why more people don't wear Hawaiian shirts. And then you walk out, $150 poorer, unsure about what just happened and how it has changed your life. The Trader Joe's Deviation. Trader Joe's already holds the souls of millions of U.S. citizens in the palm of their hands. Just imagine the kind of social media strategies they could be using to further tighten their grasp on those ravenous wolves I talked about earlier. You can see how I (a social media manager for multiple brands and companies) get easily frustrated by what I have begun to call "The Trader Joe's Deviation." They've deviated from norm, and yet it really works for them. While I could mock and critique Trader Joe's and their business tactics until the cows come home, I must admit that they're not the only big-name brand to forgo social media. Apple, Malboro, and Viagra all abstain from using social media in any official capacity. Does it work for them? Sure. Do I recommend it? No. No one's safe. For a long time, it seemed like Colorado would narrowly escape the intoxicating grasp of Trader Joe's and its huge, bewitched fan base. Alas, you can't always get what you want. Joe will start infecting local grocery shoppers come Friday the 14th, when three stores open their doors. And if you can believe it, I'll be visiting one of them on opening day, because apparently I'm a masochist.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Social Media and The Trader Joe's Deviation | Commerce Kitchen
trader joe's
Trader Joe's does not use social media. So how are they so successful without it? Enter the Trader Joe's Deviation.
