item.title: Deeper Analytics Analysis with Google Tag Manager
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
With several new developers, marketing folks and front-end designers coming on to Commerce Kitchen in the last year, our business has grown pretty dramatically. Which means larger projects, more dev projects, more marketing retainers and more analytics consulting.

The Old Way: Analytics Tracking in the Source Code

And while the crack team here at CK has great javascript and analysis chops, many of us are used to implementing analytics tags the good old fashioned way: modifying the source code. And as we dig deeper into marketing effectiveness and UX optimization, our analytics installations keep getting more complex: passing hidden variables, tracking untold quantities of onsite events, working with third parties on cross domain tracking, and adding AdWords and third party tags to conversion pages. Long story, short: keeping track of all of the tags on each site is becoming cumbersome and inefficient. Enter Google Tag Manager.

The New Way: Analytics Tracking and So Much More

Back in April, I waxed poetic about the benefits of GTM platform for marketers, developers and businesses, but we hadn't really done much with it. Other than play around, and set up our own sites. Fast forward to 2014. Many of our clients are launching really amazing, robust apps that need transparency to micro conversions and nuanced understanding of interactions with their apps. And while we have some great clients on GTM, we really need to bite the bullet and port ALL of our clients over.

Why We Love Thee GTM

  1. One and Done

    By placing the GTM script in the header one time, we're done. And we don't have to worry about updating individual tags when we rebuild sections of a site, or build out new pages. Plus we can see all of the tags and rules in one place. That gives us a clear picture of what's going on across a site, and allows us to duplicate best practices easily across accounts.

  2. Testing on the Live Site

    No need to worry about implementing on dev and stage platforms before pushing live. All testing can be done quickly and efficiently on the production site using the Debugger Console.

  3. Extensible Macros

    With some javascript wizardry and hard work at the outset, we can create macros that can be replicated across multiple accounts to allow for infinite manipulation of specific parameters and tags.

  4. RegEx

    Or Regular Expressions for the uninitiated. By using RegEx we can keep our tags and rules cleaner and easier to understand (and manipulate).
Simply put, Google Tag Manager is necessary and amazing for anyone trying to manage and implement more complicated tracking on multiple analytics account. It has raised the bar and pretty soon everyone will need to start using this awesome tool (or get left behind). While our love for GTM knows no bounds, in honor of Valentine Day's, we'll leave you with this little gem: Roses are red, RegEx is sweet. Implement Google Tag Manager, so you don't get beat.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Deeper Analytics Analysis with Macros in Google Tag Manager
Google Tag Manager is a great way to manage tags for multiple accounts. Using macros and RegEx, the possibilities for onsite tracking are limitless.

item.title: Why Designers Should Know Code: Part One
item.dc:creator: Goodtimes
item.content:encoded:
When I was hired at Commerce Kitchen I was fresh out of college with a shiny BFA with an emphasis in Digital Design. For the most part, I learned mostly visual design practices in college, but I was taught very basic HTML and CSS. I had no idea what I had gotten myself into when I got an internship at Commerce Kitchen, but I quickly learned that the world I had been in was much different than what I was about to experience. I had spent the last four years of college being closely surrounded by design enthusiasts, and when I arrived at Commerce Kitchen I was surrounded by not only design enthusiasts, but web development enthusiasts. At our weekly wine friday events I would have the opportunity to hear them converse in a language I could understand, but knew nothing about. For a long time they thought I was really quiet, but really I just had no freaking idea what any of them were talking about so I was just living by one of Lincoln’s quotes. “It is better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to speak out and remove all doubt.” Over time I learned a ton just from eavesdropping and eventually getting tossed into the big scary world of code. Quickly realizing that it isn’t that scary and the benefits of learning front-end development have been insanely beneficial for my ability to create successful web designs. This series is really a list of five things that I have been working on and continue to work to make myself a better web designer. Before I start, I want to define two things I just mentioned. A Successful Web Design: This means that it meets the requirements and expectations from the client, the interaction is enjoyable and easy for both the user and the administrator, and meets the requirements of the budgets established internally. A web design does not need to be beautiful to be successful. If you don’t believe me then either you’ve never been on Reddit or you’re smoking way too much Helvetica. Better: This means that you can start to exceed the expectations of the client and the user, make your developers happy by making designs that are easily translatable into reusable patterns and do all of this in an even shorter period of time.

Part 1: The impact of design decisions

When designing a homepage I am dictating a ton of decisions that should mostly be carried on throughout the website globally. Granted, a homepage often does and to my opinion should, have special styles associated with it. But that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t be thinking about reusable patterns. When I mean reusable patterns I mean, does a paragraph look the same on the homepage as it does on an internal page? If so, why? If you can’t provide a solid sound reason, then you’re not creating reusable patterns. This will slow down and eventually frustrate your developers. And thus the birth of jokes about designers. “Hey look at this dumb-dumb, they’re using both Arial and Helvetica!” The only way to learn how to make reusable patterns is to learn how the developers will be coding your designs. Every time I bust out that Type tool in Photoshop, change the font, font weight, tracking and leading, I’m literally forcing the developer to write more code. If I make two headlines look completely different in my mock up and semantically it makes sense for both of them to be an H3, I just created duplicate work and diminished the reusability of any styles I just established. Furthermore, I’ve proceeded to make my design less consistent, providing a potential for a poor user experience. At this point the developer has a decision to make. Spend the extra time to satisfy what you had specced out in the design, even though to them it doesn’t make sense when creating DRY, sementatic and reusable code. Or they can just pretend like they never saw that and do it the way they think it makes sense. Unfortunately you will never have any idea what it means to them to create DRY, semantic, and reusable code unless you have a solid understanding of what those are. And the only way to learn that is to actually learn how to do at least basic HTML and CSS by using it. And beyond that having an understanding of how the backend is working too can be incredibly beneficial. I’m not saying you should go out and learn Ruby or PHP, but to understand how it works. And if you’re using something like Wordpress or Drupal, they’re easier to understand than you might think. Point being, learn some code designers! It will only make your designs more consistent, which in the long run will save you and your developers both time. And after the project is finished everyone will want to give you a big hug! Stay tuned for part two!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: designers-should-know-code-part1
designers should know code
Why Designers Should Know Code: Part One
Designers should know code. One of our amazing front-end developers, Alex, will tell you why.

item.title: Three Common Mistakes People Make with WordPress
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Natalie and I are gearing up to head off to Austin, TX for South by Southwest Interactive (no - this does not mean we'll be catching that insanely hip band you used to love, until they made it big at SXSW. The music event is the following week!), and in thinking about the trip ahead, I remembered that last year I spent some time chatting up the guys at the WordPress booth. I've been building in WP since the 1.x days (3.8 is current, and it's been 10 years in the making!), and in so doing, I have probably made every mistake in the WP book at least once, so I think I can speak with some authority on the topic of WP mistakes. WordPress, a top of the line content management system, now accounts for almost 20% of the websites on the web (HOLY CATS! TWENTY PERCENT OF THE WHOLE WEB?! That's a lot of cats.), and so any web designer worth her salt has probably encountered it a time or two. Some of us love building with it and use it for jobs large and small. At Commerce Kitchen, it has become our go-to platform for marketing/brochure websites for a variety of reasons. It's flexible. It's a lot easier to use for a non-techy content administrator than its primary competitors (I'm looking at you, Drupal). And it's more than enough for about 50% of the sites we see, without being overkill. One of my former colleagues who loves Drupal admitted that using Drupal on most websites she used it on was like using an orbital laser to kill a housefly. When Drupal is too big and Squarespace is too small, WordPress is almost always just right. Because of its popularity and sheer awesomeness, WordPress is also often a gateway drug for web development. It's the hook that grabs a lot of people, and because it seems easy, they start hacking away, and before you know it... Utter. Chaos. And. Pain. For everyone. Not just the developer, but her clients as well. So, without further ado, below are my candidates for top 3 WP mistakes that you can easily avoid.

Mistake One: Forgetting about your user until it's too late. No - the other user.

A lot of devs/designers new to WP will often hack the native/core functionality instead of creating custom functionality. This is great if you're working on a site for yourself or a site that you intend to maintain (forever!), but it doesn't work out so well when you have to hand the site off to a client. At CK, we work off the mantra that websites are for use - by visitors and site admins equally. If you're using WP Posts (a specific content type reserved for the blog) to create a text blurb on the homepage, or if you're using Pages (again, a specific content type) to list events, you're doing it wrong. Or at least, you're not doing it as right as you can be.If you're not afraid of cutting and pasting some PHP, take some time to explore Custom Post Type UI and Advanced Custom Fields. These are two colossal workhorses of the WP plugin world that will allow you to easily create the right post types with just the right fields to get the job done. Custom Post Type UI allows you to easily create new post types (beyond the native Pages and Posts - so you can create an Events post type), and ACF allows you to assign unique fields to all content types ("home page text blurb" can be a field that only shows up when editing a page called Home). So with the two together, you can create a new post type and assign unique fields. A few hours spent in the documentation of ACF, and you'll be plugging these new fields into templates like a pro, rather than trying to get blood from the Post/Category hackery stone. Your content administrators shouldn't have to remember some arcane, non-intuitive sequence of steps, categories, etc to make magic happen on their site. You should spend as much time working through site admin tasks as you do site visitor tasks, and build with both users in mind.

Mistake Two: Using ALL THE PLUGINS. Because, PLUGINS!

The WP community is amazing. It's filled with some of the most talented problem solvers ever and these fine people write elegant solutions to common and complicated problems, and release that code back to the WP community in the form of Plugins - little chunks of code that extend the functionality of WP to do something more wonderful than it does out of the box (think, event management, ecommerce tools, etc). Because of this, it's easy to make WP do amazing things without knowing a lot of PHP yourself.  It's truly a gift. That same community, though, has its equal share of bad ideas and wonky, undocumented code. At CK, we'll use a plugin if we deem it trustworthy, which is a voodoo-y combination of number of downloads (must be high in relation to the time since release), star ratings (number of them as well as high star value), the support forum has to be great, the documentation not awful, and latest update within the past year if possible. As a rule, use as few plugins as you can, and rely on the ones that have strong support. A tangle of plugins (especially unsupported/un-updated ones) leads to a mess of ridiculous proportions, and can often mean that a site cannot be updated to the newest version of core without breaking. That's great news for spammers, and really, really crappy news for you and your client. Instead of grabbing the first plugin you find, try to push the limits of your knowledge to build the functionality you need yourself. This is easy for things like writing a simple home page alert blurb, but may not be feasible for something like finding a way to do faceted searching or geolocation. Know your limits, but try to push them, too.

Mistake Three: Hardcoding your templates - because hey!? Who wants a content management system anyway?

This is my personal pet peeve. This relates to number one above, but is a little more specific. If Kelly, the admin assistant and only person in the company who's not afraid of breaking the internet, is assigned to maintain the website through the WP admin interface, but he has to call you every week to edit something you've hard coded into a template, then you've just delivered a really bloated static HTML site masquerading as a CMS. Kelly should be able to edit pretty much every word he can see on the website through the WP admin panel, without using FTP, without diving into the template files (page.php etc), and without calling you. The beauty of a well-done WP site is creating ease of content management for your users. It's not all about ease of development for yourself. Remember your client's needs, and build with that first in your mind at all costs. When I was in college, an amazing professor told me that one of her thesis advisees - a senior - had just come to her to apologize for how horrible her freshman year papers had been. The prof just looked at her and said:
"Would you rather look back on the work you were capable of four years ago and think 'Hey - that's pretty good'? Or would you rather look back and think 'Wow - I've come a long way'?"
I am mortified when I think of how many really bad websites I churned out in the dark days of WordPress 1.x, but I'm delighted to say I've learned from my mistakes.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Three Common Mistakes People Make with WordPress
Avoid these common WordPress mistakes and you'll be on your way to better WP builds in no time. Okay, maybe a little bit of time.
wordpress
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/three-common-mistakes-people-make-wordpress/

item.title: Writing a Blog Post in One Hour
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
There has been some talk on the Internet lately about how to properly write a blog post in an hour or less. It is possible, but let's face it: unfortunately, not everyone is a writer. Our superheroes have been blogging up a storm in the past month. They're doing a great job, but I wanted to help them out with some tips on how to get it done as quick and efficiently as possible. And to demonstrate, I'm going to write this blog post in under an hour. Everyone, myself included, has that moment of panic when they sit down to write a blog post. "What am I going to write about???" But it's like The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy says, "DON'T PANIC."

Getting started.

First and foremost, you have to close all unnecessary (and distracting!) browser windows. Facebook. Twitter. Reddit. That one article from The Onion that you stopped reading an hour ago. You might even close Gmail, if you're feeling worrisome about emails from clients disturbing you in the next hour. Next, put on some crazy, epic music. For me, I listen to movie scores and classical tracks. Something about Hans Zimmer just puts me in the right mindset for writing one badass blog post. Truthfully, Hans was a big help whenever I wrote weekly papers in college. Finally, it's time to come up with a topic. I hate the word "brainstorm," but it's the only word that correctly explains what you're doing here. Ask yourself some questions: 1. What is everyone else writing about? This is what RSS feeds are for. I use Feedly to keep myself in the Internet marketing and social media loops. Sometimes a simple headline from HootSuite gives me an idea. 2. Did you do something cool lately? Here at Commerce Kitchen, we encourage our superheroes to show their strengths in other areas of the community. Whether it be through a hackathon, a tech conference, or a simple meetup, telling the story of a new and exciting event is a great way for novice writers to start blogging. 3. Did something uncool happen while you were working on something recently? Once in a while, you have a not-so-cool experience on the job. You might be hesitant to write about it, but one of the awesome things about blogging is that it provides you and/or your company with a platform for transparency. I speak from experience. Right about here in the process, you should have a pretty good idea of what you want to write about. And right about here, it's time to get down to business. So - and I really can't emphasize this enough - DO YOUR RESEARCH. Whether you love it or hate it, research is the backbone for a good blog post. Check your facts and check 'em twice. And, for the love of Gandalf, do not cite Wikipedia or I will hunt you down and make you watch Justin Bieber music videos. [I just hit the 30 minute mark. 491 words written. But will I finish on time??]

Writing time.

You've picked a topic! And now, for the super scary part: facing that horrifyingly intimidating blank page. That blinking cursor is like a ticking time bomb. You ask yourself, "How in the world do I begin writing this infernal thing?" Honestly, I'm not a fan of the outline. Sure, it helps you collect and organize your thoughts, but, in the past, it's done me more harm than good. To each their own, of course. If it works for you, then outline to your heart's content. "So what should my blog post look like?"  Follow these tips: - Take advantage of headings. - Make lists. - Use emphasis when necessary. - Keep paragraphs short. - Images are great to break up longer blog posts. - Total word count should land somewhere between 300 and 1,000 words. During the writing process, it's important to stay focused. If you're like me, then you're 40 minutes in to a James Newton Howard binge-listening session. The difficult thing now is keeping those outside distractions to a minimum. Noise-cancelling headphones ought to do the trick. [45 minutes in. Almost there!] Edit as you go. Pause to collect your thoughts after every paragraph or so. Go back and reread what you've already written. You may be reminded of a point you wanted to make or a detail that you left out. And, as always, proofread, proofread, PROOFREAD. Hitting the wall. Hell hath no fury like a blogger with writer's block. It's unavoidable. It's going to happen eventually, whether it be 5 minutes in or 50 minutes in. For me, I just chant "Go, go, go, go!" in my head. You're in a sprint to the finish, all you have to do is hop over the wall. Stay consistent throughout your writing. This is where editing as you go comes into play. Make sure that you maintain the same voice from beginning to end. Suddenly changing your writing style halfway through will make your readers wonder if you were knocked in the head with a baseball bat mid-blog. [5 minutes left. Will I make it?]

Final steps.

If you've been editing as you went along, then you should have minimal writing adjustments to make while you're wrapping up. Add those images. Use those headers. Emphasize important points. Optimize the post for SEO. Proofread one more time. Then hit "Publish!" You just created one rad blog post, now it's time to share it with the world.  Post it on Facebook. Tweet it out to your followers. Make everyone read it. You wrote it! Be proud of it! I'm proud of you! And guess what? I finished in under an hour. 926 words. Here's my Freckle timer to prove it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Writing a Blog Post in One Hour
Writing a Blog Post in One Hour | Commerce Kitchen
Jen loves blogging. She loves it so much, she's going to tell you how writing a blog post in one hour is as easy as pie.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/unsplash-kitsune-3.jpg

item.title: Who Are You, The User?
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: Welcome to Natalie's Thoughts About Stuff. This blog post is my written thoughts on a topic I often mull over but that I don't have an answer to. I'd love to hear what you think. I spend a lot of time thinking about The User. How will The User respond to a design? How will The User interface with an application? I even think about The User in terms of parking garages, corporate office parks, malls, freeways, the layout of my house, the soda machine at Noodles & Company, the way my breakfast burrito is wrapped. I think "this is not User friendly." Or "this was definitely designed with The User in mind." And sometimes it dawns on me that there is no such thing as The User as a predetermined form that we are striving to make everything compatible for. The User is created, it's re-created, disassembled, re-assembled, manipulated, advocated for, educated, re-educated, and invented. I am not The User. You are not The User. We become The User through the process above, by responding to our environment. Let's think about it like this: the world does not consider The User. We're born, we live, and we die in a world that functions with or without us. And we're only able to make it through our lives because we adapt to and manipulate our environments. To say that something is designed with The User in mind--whether it's software, a website, or the layout of the building--is only to say that it is designed for The User Of Now. The User of Yesterday is dead and the User of Tomorrow is being created by innovators as we speak. Is the iPhone User Friendly, or did Apple train The User to believe so? Humans are incredibly adaptable. We've managed to survive and thrive in the tropics and in the arctic. Are the tropics User Friendly? Is the arctic? Those are stupid questions. It doesn't matter. We adapt. We make them User Friendly because we know how to use. We have to use to survive. I'm not advocating for giving up on UX/UI. Not at all. I think it's one of the most fascinating and rewarding aspects of, well, everything. But if we act on the belief that we're trying to get closer to what The User wants, that we're trying to achieve the pinnacle of usability, as though there really ever is such a thing, then we might be relinquishing opportunities for innovation. I'm not talking about user testing. User testing will show you what someone is capable of understanding today, not what you can slowly train them to understand and expect. How can we let The User experience something unexpected without frustrating him or her to the point of abandonment? How can we trust that human beings are always adapting and willing to look at their experiences differently but create in a way that allows them to do so naturally? Is it a slow progress or can it be done suddenly?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Who Is The User?
Here I go, waxing philosophical about The User.
the user
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/02/who-is-the-user/

item.title: The Internet of Things Aims to Misbehave
item.dc:creator: tszvetecz
item.content:encoded:
Tynan here. I've stared into the dark abyss of your future, and I've seen how the Internet of Things will change your life. I know you were holding out for that hover board, but what you actually end up with is fifteen more hours of free time a week and hundreds of thousands of dollars in cost savings from reduced utility bills, medical bills and the new business you're going to bring in for your company. You have it all in six years. Here's how it goes down: after Volvo puts one hundred self-driving cars in Gothenburg, Sweden in 2017, the rest of the developed world quickly follows suit on the heels of incontrovertible data that self-driving cars save millions of dollars in government emergency services, insurance claims and medical bills. By 2019, your new self-driving car has opened up three hours of your work day by not only allowing you to do other things during your commute, but also getting you to your destination faster as it interacts real-time with city traffic lights, construction notification sensors and real-time networked accident beacons. Like the six million dollar man, the Internet of Things is going to make you smarter, better, faster. In this post, I'm going to show you how you will have more time, your overhead costs will plummet, and you will make thousands of dollars from releasing new products and services. In order to understand those implications, we must first understand what the Internet of Things actually is. The Internet of Things (IoT) has become a popular term to throw around in everyone's favorite game of buzzword bingo. The term was originally coined in a 2009 presentation by a SAP research engineer named Stephan Haller. He defined the Internet of Things as "a world where physical objects are seamlessly integrated into the information network, and where the physical objects can become active participants in business processes.” The information-technology research and advisory firm Gartner has predicted that by 2020, 30 billion mobile phones, tablets, computers, and wearable technology devices will be in use. That means all of them will bridge the physical world of your business and home life with the virtual within six years. Contrast that with 2009, when there were only 2.5 billion connected devices. But Jerry Maguire wants you to show him the money, so here it is: Gartner projects the Internet of Things will add $1.9 trillion to the economy by 2020.

The Internet of Things Will Give You More Time In Three Important Ways:

  1. I alluded to your daily commute earlier. Whether or not you actually spring for that self-driving car, the interconnectivity of mobile devices, your car and the road will reduce travel time. Your commute will be safer, and you will run errands and get to work meetings in record time. Average time-savings: 15 hours/week
  2. Certainly through your smartphone, and likely extended through RFID chips implanted in your skin, you will be able to pay for things quickly, have your favorite coffee order prepared and paid-for before you arrive at the cafe, and have your house front door open automatically for you while you truck in kids and groceries. Average time-savings: 5 hours/week
  3. You will know where absolutely everything is. This will include everything from computer gear to inventory, to pets and even contact lenses. You will also know the state of everything you own that requires maintenance, allowing your devices that require more power, refills or replacement to notify you (and your Amazon shopping cart) that attention is needed. Orders can be placed with a simple acknowledgment, drastically reducing the amount of time you spend at physical stores. Average time-savings: 3 hours/week

The Internet of Things Will Trim Your Overhead:

If you've been living under a rock for the last two years, or simply been watching CNN or Fox News, you haven't learned your next buzzword bingo vocabulary word: The Smart Grid. Smart Grid technologies use meters, sensors and other digital tools to control the flow of energy and can integrate alternative sources of power, such as solar and wind. The Smart Grid will optimize the energy use at your home and your work, saving hundreds or even thousands of dollars a year in utility costs.
  • Average personal cost savings: $150/month
  • Average business cost savings: $1,500/month

The Internet of Things Will Make You Money From New Products and Services

As stated earlier, the IoT will unleash $1.9 trillion into the economy. You will win, because you will be ready to leverage that business opportunity. Keep in mind that the IoT will introduce complexity, as there will be a variety of operating systems that IoT integrates with and is powered by. The days of Windows powering everything in your business have already come to an end, but this trend will only magnify in the next six years.
  1. You will have to support iOS, Android and many new operating systems that will be introduced into the market place. As a result, more training and support will be needed for company employees. This opens up an incredible maintenance and training opportunity for IT specialists.
  2. You will cash in on Remote Management. The IoT will allow remote management over all sorts of physical hardware, including Android cameras and set-top boxes, among others. More Remote Management allows for more scalability, reduced commute time and quicker resolution of issues.

The Internet of Things and the Chamber of Choices

What will you do with your newly acquired time? Increase your cognitive surplus? If you read one hour a day related to your professional field, you'll become an industry leading expert in seven years. Or will you start a new hobby? Have a regular breakfast with your kids and spouse? With more time, more savings and more income potential, your future is wide open. Perhaps it should be channeled into the hover board R&D budget you've always dreamed of.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:5286;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:2;s:13:"restored_time";i:1393277543;}
internet of things

item.title: The Latest from Tech Marketing 360
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
After a whirlwind couple of weeks, Tech Marketing 360 is behind me, and I am energized for our upcoming tech marketing projects. So now it's time for the conference good, bad and ugly, peppered with my favorite paraphrased soundbites from the week.

The Good

Location. Location. Location.

It doesn't get any prettier or more relaxing than Dana Point, California. With sunshine two out of the three days, and a nice ocean breeze, it was great to just take it all in and sit in the sun between sessions. The casino night on Wednesday left me $250 richer, so that's always a plus. And come on, who doesn't love to play craps and blackjack after a long day of sessions!?

Better balance between actionable analytics and good marketing.

Over the last few years, many of us have begun to live and breathe analytics. We have more input sources than ever -- onsite analytics, social reporting, CRM data, survey data, crowdsourcing data. And while I love the power and insight that come with measurable metrics (yea attribution! yea pivot tables!), it's important to remember the inherent limitations of and assumptions present within the data. In his session on The Voice of the Customer, Erik Koto reiterated that people have a terrible reporting bias. Which makes data integration from multiple sources oh so important. The pendulum has swung pretty far afield with marketers trying to measure EVERYTHING. And while I am 100% on board for measuring what you can to drive deeper insight and better iterations, our industry, as a whole, has increased the pressure for return, and taken some of the art out of a good marketing campaign. Several speakers including Romi Mahajan of KKM Group, focused their sessions on getting back to marketing fundamentals by focusing on the power of a good idea, the art of a compelling campaign, and the increased potential for success with a "holistic marketing" approach. That said, other speakers like Jon Miller from Marketo, revealed key metrics that marketers SHOULD know to be able to justify their holistic marketing approach. He found that 44% of marketers don't know how a 10% increase in budget would impact business profit. Yikes!

Don't use technology just because you can.

Perhaps one of my favorite takeaways from the conference, I am so GLAD that people are no longer asking "What are you doing on Twitter?" or "Are you on X [sub in any social media, crowdsourcing or blogging platform]?" Instead, marketers are getting back to the basics of "good idea + solid strategy" before choosing the channels through which they can make their story come to life. Digital channels are just that - channels. Simply being on the same channels as your competitors (or even being one step ahead of your competitors) will not ensure brand success without the right message to the right audience using the right approach. As Brad Brooks so eloquently stated, "Messaging strategy, context and segmentation 101 are keys to relationship marketing. No longer spray and pray."

Leveraging real-world "things".

John Gagon from Bing had a great presentation on the real-world impacts on onsite conversion rates and profitability in the hospitality industry. By leveraging local events data, he was able to predict high demand, low supply times for increasing paid marketing spends to drive business profitability. The next day Rob Fugetta from Zuberance gave a compelling 5-step plan for leveraging and mobilizing brand advocates--something we can all do a better job of. He encouraged marketers to act as facilitators between prospects and brand advocates, rather than driving or dictating those conversations, to mobilize "the best sales force you never have to pay for."

The Bad

Endless company pitches. Enough already.

One my of my favorite things about the Online Marketing Summit (OMS) when it was hosted in San Diego was the policy of minimal self-promotion. We were all there to swap best practices and lessons learned in an education-first environment. If a speaker got on stage and started talking about himself or his business instead of the topic at hand, attendees were actively encouraged to boo until the self-promotion stopped. Unfortunately the OMS buyout by UBM Tech, has turned Tech Marketing 360 into more of your standard conference in which speakers get on the docket purely to pitch their products or toot their own horns. A necessary evil, I guess, but the shift leaves me somewhat cold and disappointed that the conference has shifted from education-first.

Misalignment between presentation titles and content.

While I found the networking at TM360 great (lots of smart, passionate marketers), the presentations themselves were a bit flat. Of the 10+ sessions that I attended, at least three had NOTHING to do with the presentation titles and descriptions. I really wanted to hear from speakers on how to get the cross-channel experience right, or gain insights on actionable social metrics. No dice. Even though the speakers missed the boat, my fellow attendees and I had some dynamic conversations around how we would have addressed the topic and swapped war stories / best practices on our own post-session. Marketing collaboration is alive and well.

The Ugly

Some really poor presenters. They were just painful.

Painful for the attendees, and undoubtedly painful for the presenters. A standout was a one-person presentation of four different personas on stage. Without supporting slides. Without a compelling way to differentiate the personas. Without a tie to the title and description of the presentation. Another gem was a famous company whose presenter talked so fast and made no sense that the entire audience sat for three to four minutes before someone came up with any sort of reasonable question to ask about the keynote. These presentations were spectacularly ugly, but thankfully not the norm for the conference. And they definitely reinforced the lesson that you must have you marketing message down before presenting to marketers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tech Marketing 360 | Analytics & Marketing Conference
The good, bad and ugly on analytics, relationship marketing, marketing strategy and digital channels from Tech Marketing 360 in sunny Dana Point, CA.
tech marketing 360

item.title: Looking Forward to SXSWi 2014
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: The countdown has begun. Michelle and I will be headed to SXSW Interactive (SXSWi) in just over a week, and if it's anything like it was last year it'll be five full days of fascinating and overwhelming talks and panels that will help my business brain and creative brain. Looking through the schedule I'm noticing a lot of similar talks as last year. Data is big. UX is big. Wearable tech is big. My goal is simple: to attend talks that will help me develop new skills and knowledge to make Commerce Kitchen better. Some of the talks will do that. Some of them will be duds. There will be parties and tacos and rabid startups with names that end in .ly or "ify" spreading their swag across Austin. Unfortunately I was unable to get my startup idea up and running for SXSW, but Get Rid of Your Swag.ly is still a great idea and would inundate Austin-area thrift stores and homeless shelters with a ridiculous number of free startup t-shirts. Image courtesy of Alfie Photography / Shutterstock.com

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Looking Forward to SXSWi 2014
I'll be attending SXSWi again this year, and I'm looking forward to walking away with an achingly overflowing brain.
sxswi

item.title: How My 'Useless' Degree Gave Me The Best Job Ever
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: It's hard to believe it when I say it, but it's already been over a year since I started working for Commerce Kitchen. Last January, I was still a student at the University of Denver. I was writing my honors thesis. My only other work experiences prior to becoming Commerce Kitchen's social media management intern were a brief stint at Jamba Juice and some sporadic seasonal work at Nordstrom for four years. It's been nine months since I graduated, and I've been working full-time (intern, no more!) for CK since then. So how did I get this job? It's rather simple, actually: I'm persuasive, and I owe it all to my Bachelor's degree in history. Of course, there were nay-sayers: the people who doubted I could get a "real" job after graduation. It comes with the territory of getting a degree in what is so lovingly called the "Liberal Arts." The self-doubt, the questioning, the uncertainty, all of that is a package deal when you sign your name away to your desired field of study. Why did I get a 'useless' degree then? I have a pretty simple answer to that, too. I wanted to study something that I truly enjoyed for four years, rather than suffer in a competitive business school that I knew I wouldn't succeed in. Was it a reckless decision? Maybe. Do I regret it? Absolutely not. Being CK's social media manager means that I spend a fair share of my days writing. And because of my 'useless' history degree, I'm a kick-ass writer. I don't want to be humble about it; I earned and paid for [and am still paying for] it! What about my minors? Surely I studied some form of business while I was in school, right? Wrong! I double minored in Communications and Sociology, and man, was that fun. I learned public speaking and amazing argumentative skills. I stayed far, far away from any classes at the business school, and I'm so thankful that I did. And I'm not the only one! Four out of the four Commerce Kitchen partners did not get their Bachelors' degrees in business. Natalie worked on Religious Studies. Michelle focused on English. Jamie studied Art History. And Tynan jammed out with a Music degree. A few of them went on to study some form of business later in their lives, and I think personally that's the right way to do it. Enjoy your college years. You only get to do it once. Spend time at grad school suffering in that competitive business school. I love the job that my 'useless' degree gave me. Commerce Kitchen is a great place to work. It's fun, it's innovative, and I really enjoy the work that we do here.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How My 'Useless' Degree Gave Me The Best Job Ever
How did I get this job? It's rather simple, actually: I'm persuasive, and I owe it all to my Bachelor's degree in history.

item.title: You've Got Innovation All Wrong
item.dc:creator: tszvetecz
item.content:encoded:
In business mythology, there is one word that conjures so much fear, reverence and delusions of grandeur. One word dreams all dreams, masters men, devours women, pillages venture capital firms and topples empires. It is the soliloquy of a nation. That word is innovation. And, like generations of leaders before you, you've got innovation all wrong. You've got it wrong because you think innovation is creating something new. It's supposed to be a radical idea -- originating from off-the-wall thinking that's the purview of the artistic and the mentally insane. In this post, we're going to discover why that is incorrect, and we're going to discover how innovation has not only blanketed you, but also been within your grasp over and over again, for your entire life. In his book, The Nature of Technology, Brian Arthur explains: "To invent something is to find it in what previously exists." Innovation is simply mixing old ideas. It is remixing things in your life or company that already exist.

Winning a Nobel Prize Can't Be That Hard

In 1993, the Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Kary Mullis for developing the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It has become a cornerstone for the biotechnology era, allowing DNA sequences to be replicated efficiently and accurately. He describes the process of innovating as jarring and suspiciously easy. He was simply putting together common concepts other people already developed. In his Nobel Award Speech, he said, "Somehow, I thought, it had to be an illusion... It was too easy... There was not a single unknown in the scheme. Every step involved had been done already." As one explores the greatest innovations of our time, a common narrative emerges that tells us the components of an innovation are not novel. It is in combining them that their impact becomes remarkable. Look at the web, arguably the greatest innovation in four generations. It is made of the TCP/IP data transmission protocol, and a simple markup language called HTML that creates a framework for laying out content. Finally, it is a basic piece of software that can render that HTML to the user, called a browser. These elements were basic. They were not innovative. They were mundane. But put them together, and the world would never be the same.

The Old School Is The New School

The building blocks for your future innovations are already here. Progress isn't something that you achieve, it is something that accumulates. The limiting factor for your company's growth, then, is the ability to think through all of the combinations and find the really great ones. Don't think of the next new thing, put some old things together in new ways. Your life will never be the same.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: innovation
You've Got Innovation All Wrong | Commerce Kitchen
One word dreams all dreams, masters men, devours women, pillages venture capital firms and topples empires. It is the soliloquy of a nation: innovation.

item.title: Getting Kids Into Code
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Whether or not you believe there's a developer shortage (many people do and many people don't), one thing is clear: tech jobs will only continue to grow as other industries shrink. I've got a four-year-old daughter, and I want to help give her the brains she might need to get a job in tech someday, if she chooses. I was an artsy kid, into music, literature, and the performing arts, and while I'm incredibly happy with the way my career has turned out, I do wish that I'd had a little more math exposure so that if I wanted to do something slightly more technological I would have had the groundwork to do so. For parents like me, who want to expose their kids to programming, here are some resources to get you started.  

Kids Ruby

Free Kids Ruby teaches children real Ruby code and shows them the immediate output. They're currently working on building lessons and classes, but for now it's relatively self guided. It seems especially valuable for younger kids, who can see very basic results from writing code. Kids Ruby has paired up with other kids programming events and seems to be expanding.  

iD Tech Camps

Online subscription $179 a year; Summer camps from $799 Starting at age seven, kids can attend day or overnight (age 10+) summer camps in 28 states to learn basic game design, programming, robotics, and web design, among other areas. iD also has an online program with tutorials, forums, workshops, and an online arcade.  

Digital Media Academy

$725+ Digital Media Academy's camps, held on a dozen college campuses across the country, are for children age 6 to 18. Areas include programming and app development, game design and development, UX and design, robotics and engineering, and more.    

Code.org

Free

Built for K-12, Code.org is a nonprofit dedicated to getting more computer science education in public schools and to encourage more women and underrepresented people of color to get into programming. There are tutorials online to help your children learn to code with puzzles and games. One cool feature of code.org is a tutorial to help you learn how to code without a computer.  

Code Now

Free

Code Now is dedicated to getting more women and minorities into tech. It's a free program for high school students in Washington D.C., San Francisco, and New York City. Students must apply and be accepted into the program. Students learn how to build a Twitter app and an encryption engine in Ruby, and as many as 1/3 of the students who go through the Code Now program end up majoring in Computer Science in college.  

Play-i

$59+ These programmable robots, made for children 5 and up, teach children programming and robotics through an easy interface. Younger children learn visual programming that incorporates stories and music. Older children learn to write code for iOS or Android using the Play-i API. There are currently two robot models available, and the company is completely sold out but taking pre-orders for December 2014.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Teaching Kids Code and Getting Your Children Into Tech
Since my daughter was born four years ago I've been gathering resources to help her learn to code. Here are some of my favs.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/03/getting-kids-into-code/

item.title: Lies, Damned Lies, and Browser Statistics
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
Mark Twain has a famous quote: "There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies, and statistics." He attributes this to Benjamin Disraeli, but Wikipedia doubts that. As a developer who does a lot of front-end work, I want to know what browsers people are using. The gold standard is the browser statistics for each individual site via Google Analytics, but there are a few sites that offer a glimpse at the global usage patterns. The most well-known is a company called NetMarketShare, and they annoy me because they are the most often quoted, and their numbers never match the stats on the individual sites I work on. More specifically, they always showed more Internet Explorer users than I was seeing on any individual sites - and showing way more Internet Explorer 6 (IE6 for short) users than Internet Explorer 7 users, which makes no sense at all, because 7 is more than 6! Here's the top 10 browsers according to NetMarketShare for February 2014: For a long time, I was confused about NetMarketShare numbers , and then I found this gem buried in their FAQ (http://www.netmarketshare.com/faq.aspx#Country) "The Net Market Share data is weighted by country". Why does this matter? Because China is fond of Internet Explorer for historical reasons. China, as you might imagine, has a lot of people in it, but numbers on Internet usage are not as good as they could be. Despite the strides China has made in modernizing, there are still a substantial number of people who can only access the Internet from cafes, if at all. When that changes, it tends to be a mobile phone, which is going to be running Android Chrome or iPhone Safari. Why the fondness for Internet Explorer in China? A brief history lesson (stay with me here, I promise this is going somewhere): Back in the 1990s, the United States government, in its infinite wisdom, considered good encryption so important that they classified it as a munitions (no really, I couldn't make that up!).  SSL was in the same category as surface-to-air missiles as far as the US Government was concerned. People in the United States got the good encryption, and people everywhere else in the world got the watered-down versions widely believed to be breakable by the NSA and other similar agencies around the world. So the government in China decided to make their own version of SSL - the secure connection your bank uses that cannot be seen by prying eyes. This version of SSL was only available in Internet Explorer 6. Web users were reluctant to upgrade because their banks did not work with Firefox or other browsers. Finally, with the advent of smartphones, people started to realize that upgrading was really needed, and the switch to newer browsers happened. Fast forward to now, and SSL restrictions have also been relaxed for most countries. Now, in 2014, most people in China have upgraded - but many of them still use Internet Explorer 8 (IE8), which is a 6 year old browser. IE6 in February 2014 is still at an absurdly wrong 4.65% - even though the Microsoft site urging people to stop using IE6 shows the United states share at 0.2%. Last month, IE6 was at 2.45% - that kind of large change seems indicative of weighting being the wrong approach. So NetMarketShare shows IE8 as their first browser, with 21.25% of market share. NetMarketShare still shows all versions of Internet Explorer at 58.19% in February 2014. Here's the thing - none of the websites I work on have nearly 60% market share for Internet Explorer. The average is more like 30 - 40%, as more and more people use their iPads and iPhones, and as Google Chrome steadily increases its market share. The reason why the number for all version of Internet Explorer bothers me is that NetMarketShare gets many more articles written about it. The executives, the CIO types, can look at the numbers and conclude that Internet Explorer support is the most important thing, when on most sites, 60% - 70% of the users are using another browser like iPad Safari or Firefox. It's like NetMarketShare is living in a time warp when Internet Explorer was the dominant browser. There is another site called StatCounter that has a rather different picture: StatCounter shows all versions of Internet Explorer at 22.61%, and Chrome at a whopping 43.85%. However, this is comparing applies to oranges, since StatCounter counts page hits rather than unique visitors. Since Google Chrome is the favorite of most web developers and techies, it makes sense that there would be more hits from Chrome, since they tend to be on the web more often. Even with the big difference in methods, StatCounter is closer to what I see on the sites I work on when I look at the Google Analytics stats. Even sites with Internet Explorer as the most popular browser usually have that browser with less than 50% of the browser share. (Note that in the graphs, in order to make the comparison more even, I have compared desktop browser stats only). Firefox seems to be slowly losing market share to Chrome according to both sources. The upshot is that checking a site in a wide variety of browsers, including mobile browsers like iPad, iPhone, and Android browsers is more worth doing than ever. Some sites show over 40% mobile usage. This is why we here at CommerceKitchen focus a lot of time on those browsers while still checking Internet Explorer back to IE8. It's a better bang for your buck (or ROI for you business types) to spend time building a responsive design that will work well in Safari iPad and Google Chrome for Android because usage of these is growing rapidly going forward, and Internet Explorer usage is slowly declining, despite what the misleading statistics at NetMarketShare claim. Update:  For a while, NetMarketShare had this gem on their home page (since removed):

"NetMarketShare has recently shown a large drop in Windows XP share from September to October. This drop was primarily caused by a major change in the network of sites we have in China. A group of large Chinese publishers with a very large number of visitors per day had audiences heavily skewed towards Windows XP (nearly 100% XP). In researching the nature of the sites, we determined they were not appropriate for our network. We removed those publishers ourselves, which caused the shift since Chinese traffic is weighted higher due to lower coverage. The current data set is more accurate than in the past due to this.

We are researching ways to prevent outlying sites from causing this problem in the future. "

Since Windows XP can only run IE8, this has had the effect of making IE11 their top browser instead of IE8, which is a bit closer to reality for most sites.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Lies, Damned Lies! And Browser Statistics
Mark Twain has a famous quote: "There are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies, and statistics." As a developer, I want to know what browsers people are using.
browser statistics

item.title: GitHub Releases Another Editor Into the World
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.content:encoded:
The text editor is arguably the most important tool a developer uses during their job. It's the virtual hammer from our tool box. It needs to be reliable and efficient, so we can complete the job quickly and without worry. Last week, GitHub announced the public release of a new text editor called Atom. It's something that their developers have been working on for over six years. Their goal was and is to create an editor that can be used easily by beginners and adopted by veteran developers and one that is hackable. My first thought when hearing this news was met with sarcasm, "Great, another one." But I quickly began to wonder what the people at GitHub were building. It must have something different to offer.
  • Are they going to incorporate Git features into the editor?
  • Could I commit a change directly from Atom?
  • What do they mean by hackable?
  • Ultimately, how is this editor different from my preferred editor, Sublime Text?
I gave Atom a try after getting an invite and decided to share some of my observations. I encourage you to share your experience with this tool, especially the dev super heroes. If you are running Windows or Linux you'll have to wait for your release. Which doesn't seem like a smart idea and is contrary to the spirit of an open community. We have developers at Commerce Kitchen running Linux and it's unfortunate that they can't try it and provide feedback.

Fool me twice, then shame on you!

[caption id="attachment_5438" align="alignright" width="300"] Failed on first start.[/caption] On first run I get this message, "Atom quit unexpectedly." Not the sort of first impression you want from your trusty text editor. But it's a beta. So... I run it a second time. When it opens, the application looks almost exactly like Sublime Text. That isn't a bad critique. I use Sublime and I'm familiar with how to use it. And I happily discovered that Atom's keyboard shortcuts are similar to Sublime which would make transitioning easy. The commonly used Command Palette, File Switching, and File Search commands all used shortcuts similar to Sublime.

What about Git?

The second observation was the Git integration. The editor keeps track of files untracked and modified by color coding them. However, I didn't see a color change when adding a change to the repository from the terminal. That would be nice. You can navigate pretty quickly to previous or next Git differences within a file. Line changes are also marked with a color indicator to help you identify them when you have hundreds of lines of code to scan. And one last note, you can see what branch you are working on and the number of commits done in the bottom of the status bar. I was expecting to see features like this and it would be nice to see more. What if you could add or make a commit from the editor? And an informative view of the git log would be an added bonus. Maybe this is where the ability to hack the editor comes into play?

It's a web application!

Atom is built on web technology. It uses the Chromium architecture for it's engine while using Node.js for file system access and customization. This means that if you are fluent in javascript, you should be able to design features that will interact with the native code. And since it's built on a browser window, they have included Chromium's Developer Tools to help developers create. Which lead me to wonder about the licensing and if it was open source.

Atom is both open and closed source

The president of GitHub said they are still working on how to structure the licensing and how it all works. And there is already plenty of discussion on Hacker News interpreting what the implications or concerns might be. For some people this is a deal breaker and they stick with VIM or another free editor.

UI for Package Control

[caption id="attachment_5446" align="alignright" width="300"] Atom's Package Manager[/caption] Atom has a nice interface for managing the packages and themes you'd like to install. This is a big improvement over Sublime because you don't have to mess around with configuration files.

Sublime, I still love you.

Besides having fancy coloring for Git tracking or similar shortcuts to Sublime, I don't have much interest in switching editors. This is especially true while the application is in beta and bugs are being worked out. Atom also doesn't have the number or variety of extensions or packages available that Sublime does. I've found a number of useful Git specific packages that Atom doesn't provide. Finally, I am skeptical of Chromium being able to provide the performance and reliability needed in an editor. How do you see Atom fitting in the crowded space of text editors?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: GitHub Releases Another Editor Into the World | Commerce Kitchen
The text editor is arguably the most important tool a developer uses during their job. It's the virtual hammer from our tool box. It needs to be reliable.

item.title: Code With Confidence: Use TDD
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded: Life in today's technological world is often full of complex situations, tightly booked schedules, timers, alarms, flashing lights, bleeping beeps and an emphatic sense that there simply isn't enough time. As software developers, we're constantly faced with decisions about performance vs. maintenance vs. timely delivery vs. modularity vs. readability, and on and on. There are consequences to our decisions in every line of code we write, but somehow, we manage to get through the day, produce working applications and even receive praise from clients and coworkers. No really, it does happen. With computers getting faster and faster, people getting slightly faster and time remaining constant but out of control, what can we do to stay on track with our demanding software production schedules?  One tool in the developer's quiver is tests. Tests serve as milestones in functionality. Barriers to regression. Insight into behavior, and they even work well as documentation. When you do Test Driven Development with thoughtful test descriptions, these expressive english statements become the next level of good planning and documentation detail below a Readme Driven Development approach as referenced by Alex Kirsch in his post "Do You RDD?" last month. Test Driven Development (TDD) is an enlightening and worthy process, but as a comprehensive immediate goal, it can seem like the illusive holy grail to developers that have minimal spare time as it is. Changing their familiar process into something new, possibly upside down, and requiring them to learn new language techniques is a lot to ask, but the rewards are more than worth the effort. Code confidence, headless web development, improved code use, excellent code coverage, low resistance to refactoring and terrific pivot capabilities make effective development teams, spritely managers and satisfied clients. Let's say you're convinced. You've decided to make the move toward TDD. You've checked into the test support mechanics of the language your app is written in and you're ready. Where do you start? After all, when considering the broader scope of testing an application, the vastness of everything that can go right and go wrong is a larger problem than the application itself, right? Much like the novelist staring at a blank page, you're staring at an empty test class wondering where, how, and eventually why. Get a grip already! At one point, the application didn't exist either. Gather your wits and just do it. As in, just start. Begin with unit tests. Choose a class and make a test for every method in the class. That will take some time, so begin with the important methods, or the easy methods. Start with the classes that interest you the most. Those are only a few of many ways to narrow the choices and the workload of starting. Most importantly, find something that resonates with you and start. The learning curve will flatten, you'll be thinking about tests first, and soon be wondering if it's possible to get the rest of life in control by applying a TDD approach.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: tdd
Code With Confidence: Use TDD | Commerce Kitchen
As software developers, we're constantly faced with decisions about performance vs. maintenance vs. timely delivery vs. modularity vs. readability, & so on.

item.title: Meet Eric, the Trebuchet-building Magento Mage
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Eric is awesome. I sat down to chat with him about his dev experience, his fascination with Facebook, and that trebuchet he built when he was 13 years old! If you need further proof of his awesomeness after this, then behold his knowledge of pi.

How long have you been a developer and what kind of experiences have you had since you started?

It’s been 15 years. I got started doing Flash, just as a hobby. I remember in junior high we took a class in Flash and everybody else was messing with the animations. I kind of slowly figured out that you can write code for flash and I thought that was the coolest thing ever; that you could do so much more than just make something move. I loved messing with it, I loved playing with it, and I ended up on actionscript.org helping other people, answering lots of questions, and asking lots of questions, and started getting freelance work when I was 13 or 14, from people all over the world.

So what was your first dev job? I believe it was for a guy in New Zealand, who I never met, but we corresponded through email. He wanted a music player for a site. I was so naive at that point in time that when he asked me how much I wanted for it - I was 13 years old - I said “$100?” and he said “Yeah, sure.” I think it ended up being some 30 or 35 hours of work. I didn’t care; at the time, I wasn’t thinking about money.

You talk a lot about Facebook as your expertise on the social media side of dev work, so when did you start working with it?

That would be more of a recent development, in the last couple years. We had a client that wanted the feature where you could log in using Facebook, and - at the time - I was still pretty new to Magento, so I didn’t know exactly how to go about doing it. I messed with it for a couple of weeks and finally got it working. I started just reading about logging in with Facebook, and I ended up on the Facebook page for developers. There’s so much stuff on there. As I was clicking around, I started to see all of these other things that you can do with Facebook, and I slowly got to thinking that there’s so much that you can do to integrate that with eCommerce, just to make everything easier. It’s still going, and I keep adding stuff to it every single day.

It’s really refreshing to have someone who sees the value of social media from the development side of things.

Yeah, and one of the reasons I really like Facebook is because they have an absolutely kick-ass API. It is awesome. I’ve dealt with so many APIs and software development kits and all that kind of nonsense before, and there are a few that are good, but normally they don’t go to the degree that Facebook goes to. Facebook, it’s intuitive. A lot of the stuff that I’ve figured out was just by guessing, because Facebook just makes it that way that you think that if you made a cURL request to some URL that you’d expect to get X, Y, and Z back. They made it in such a way that, if you guess, you’ll probably hit on something that will get you what you need.

To kind of go back to your dev experience, what’s something that people do when they program code that annoys you the most?

Documentation would be one. Put some comments in your code. Tell me what exactly is going on. You’re not the only person that’s going to be writing that code, or looking at that code at some point in time. I also think that helps you develop, yourself, because if you have stuff written down you can just look at a glance, and know exactly what someone’s doing.

Yeah, that definitely helps. So you’ve been working here for three months, what’s something you’ve learned from your fellow CK’ers so far?

When I first came here, I think it was Shelly who told me that “If you’re ever stuck on something, you should just talk to other people, and a lot of the times it’s not them that help you, it’s the fact that you are talking, because you’ll think of it yourself.” As you start saying exactly what your problem is, you realize, “Oh I forgot to do X, Y, Z.” That’s not to say that the people here aren’t helpful, because they are. When I first started Ruby, Aaron, the front-end guy who rarely touches code, was actually helping me with Ruby, which I really love. I love that everybody is so well-rounded here. There’s nobody who’s just CSS, or just PHP. Everybody knows a little bit about something, but they all have their specialties, and it’s really cool.

You touched on eCommerce earlier. What kind of projects have you worked on in the past?

I’ve done a lot of very serious customizations. I wrote a module for Magento that integrated with UPS, that would make API calls to UPS to fetch estimated delivery dates, which is not natively in Magento. UPS, their API is definitely not as cool as Facebook’s, but it’s pretty interesting to see what kind of information UPS will return. It was fun going through that because UPS would ask “Where is the package coming from? Where is the package going? How many packages, and how big are they, and what is the weight of the package?” Taking all of that information, you send it to UPS, and UPS would give you back this enormous XML document. If they chose this shipping method, they would get their package by this date and time. Things like that were really fun to play with.

Switching gears a bit, we all have our little quirks and nerd-isms here at Commerce Kitchen, but you are bringing it to a whole other, three-dimensional level. Rubik’s cube… when did you solve your first one? It’s no easy feat, and I hear that you can solve it blind-folded.

No, I can’t do it blind-folded. I solved my first one not too long ago, late last year, I finally figured it out. I have an infatuation with little toys like that. I love puzzles, and I love Rubik’s cubes. Little things like that that keep your brain going is really fun to me. But that took a long time to figure out. There are some times when I can do it in less than ten minutes, which is a far cry from the record-holder. Sometimes I can’t even do it in an hour. And speaking of little toys, what’s the deal with the trebuchet? Tell me that story. I have no idea why I did that. I was really young, probably 12 or 13 at the time. I must have just read about a trebuchet or see it on TV, and I thought, “There’s no reason why I can’t build that.” First I mocked it up, with the lengths of all of the pieces of wood that I needed and how they would need to go together. I built it four times before it was successful. With the first one, I put it in the middle of street, and immediately it ripped itself apart. I built it again, reinforced it, and took it out. It was okay, but it still fell apart. So I did it again, reinforced it, and the third round worked, but it wasn’t ideal because I was using things like PVC pipe to hold the counter-weight on there. There was little problems with it sticking in places, so I gave my mom $20 and said “Can you please go to Home Depot and get me 1 ¼ inch steel pipe?” I don’t think she knew what was going on at that point in time, but she went and got me a pipe, and I cut it by hand so it would fit, and I just built that thing up and I finally got it to the point that I was doing ⅛ of a mile throws with full cans of soda. I kept adding to it. I cut my wagon apart, and took the wheels and put them on the counter-weighted side of the trebuchet. The whole idea was that I could lift the other side and just move it around with a finger, which I could. I could roll that thing all the way down the street. It had like 80 pounds of counter-weight on it. After the trebuchet, I built a quarter-pipe, and I couldn’t even ride a skateboard. We're really excited to have Eric on the Commerce Kitchen team. Keep an eye out for his superhero, which we'll be revealing soon!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Meet Eric, the Trebuchet-building Magento Mage | Commerce Kitchen
We're really excited to have Eric on the Commerce Kitchen team. Keep an eye out for his superhero, which we'll be revealing soon!

item.title: Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Front-End Development
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded: I am finding myself beyond exhausted today, and the enormous Red Bull on my desk is a testament to that. I walked out to my car to find out that it had somehow traveled back in time 1 hour, which is weird since only DeLoreans are supposed to be able to do that. It's as if the world is playing a very bizarre trick on me, but I digress. So why am I so tired, aside from daylight savings time? In a nutshell: design. In the land of web development there are 3 kinds of people: Front-end developers, back-end programmers, and IT. However, for the purposes of this blog post. I'm going to exclude IT. Not that they don't matter; it's quite the contrary. They matter a great deal and I'm sure everyone can agree on that. Yet, they are incredibly confusing. I'm starting to wonder if my go-to response to anything an IT person says to me shouldn't be, "I have no idea what you just said... but I like you." When one first enters the realm of web development, they gravitate towards either front-end development or programming. Both are radically different from one another, and yet they depend on each other to be successful. Front-end developers are the artists of the dev world. They are the ones who make sure what you see is appealing to the eyes, easy to navigate, and overall define the "feel" of the website. Front-end devs are awesome! Programmers are the engineers behind it all. They are the ones who make sure that when you click on that fancy, flashy button, that you arrive on a page that loads content, images, documents, and so on. I've primarily considered myself a programmer, mainly because - when it comes to front-end development - I am the most indecisive person ever. Sure I can do front-end development, but it helps if I actually know what I'm doing from the beginning. Whenever I sit and try and decide how I want something to look, I draw nothing but blanks. I'm good at Scrabble, but I'm bad at development. Over the weekend I was working on a side project of mine and needed to build out a mini cart view. It needed to show an image, quantity (with buttons to increment/decrement), the selected items options (color, size, etc), and a delete button for each product in the cart. I got the general idea down, list format, one product per "row" seemed to do the trick. Didn't really make much sense any other way. Now for the nitty gritty, I have ~350 pixels width to lay out the remaining buttons. Delete button on the right side? Quantity box in the middle? Product info below everything else? The next hour was spent moving buttons, input boxes, and div's around. No matter what I did however, I wasn't completely happy with it. There was always something that seemed just a bit "off" about the layout, I couldn't quite put my finger on it. I was frustrated to say the least, and I think it has everything to do with the fact that I think like I programmer. Anyone is creative, including (maybe especially) programmers, but artistic creativity is something else entirely, and something I really wish I had. I would rather do just about anything else before front-end development... and so I did. The next 4 hours were spent doing anything and everything not design related, among them: - Watering plants - Neglecting dishes - Reorganizing record collection - Cleaning - Further dish neglection - BuzzFeed (10 minutes somehow always turns into 2 hours, but I now know that my spirit animal is a hedgehog, yay!) - Aimlessly walking around So how do I overcome this immense hurdle of non-creative thinking? Well, the obvious answer would be "ask a front-end developer." True, and I do. While that may be the most obvious answer it's not necessarily the best. After all, if you're constantly looking for input from those who know it best, you're never going to figure it out for yourself. What I've learned is that sometimes the best thing to do is to forget worrying about the design and instead focus on how it will function. Jump out of the Bob Ross shoes of design and in to the users shoes. Take a step back and think, "If I were using this site and had never seen it before, where would I be looking for                ." With that in mind, several answers reveal themselves, and it all boils down to priorities. Important features should be big and/or stand out. Less important features should be smaller, and possibly even tucked away out of sight until they are needed. Back in the mini cart, with priorities in mind, I now know that the delete button doesn't necessarily need to be so dominant. If something is in an online shopping cart, then chances are the customer knows about it and don't need to see a very obvious delete button, so the button can be fairly small. If the customer really wishes to remove it, they'll find the button. From there I moved on to the quantity box and increment/decrement buttons. This is almost the same as the delete button, in that it's not a huge priority, but it is just slightly more important than the delete button. Think about it, when is the last time you were shopping online and actually bought more than one of an item? A coffee table? Probably just one. A pint glass? Chances are the quantity was more than one for that purchase. Who buys just one glass? Keep in mind that this is a mini cart, so the customer has already been through a product page where they define the quantity they want. The quantity box here is more of a convenience, for those who maybe moved too fast through the product page or change their minds last minute. Now all that's left are the image and the product details. The image I would consider low priority since it serves no other purpose than to visualize what the item is. There didn't need to be a lot of detail, only needs to answer, "What am I looking at?" Based on that, I made the image average size, 50 x 50 pixels. Remember, I'm working in an area 350 pixels wide not counting padding, margins, etc. This leaves me with plenty of room for the most important piece of all, the product info. So just by looking at a task from the perspective of usability rather than looks I was able to extract priorities in this order: Product Info > Quantity > Delete Button > Image This in turn helped me design what I needed to. At the very least, I've successfully come up with an ideal size for each of the components which has helped me lay out where each will go on the page. Of course this doesn't necessarily aid in the issue of theming and color picking, but like most people I have my own solutions to that problem as well. (If you read this and happen to spot a man holding his laptop screen next to paint swatches at a Denver area Home Depot, come say hi!) Are you a back-end programmer that also struggles with front-end development? What parts in particular do you struggle with? What methods do you utilize to make a job easier?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love Front-End Development
front-end development
Are you a back-end programmer that struggles with front-end development? Eric has had his fair share of troubles, but he learned to love the front-end.

item.title: 7 Signs You Went to the DSTILL Showcase Last Night
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5590" align="alignright" width="247"] Kevin & Leslie at the DSTILL Showcase![/caption] Five of our superheroes attended the DSTILL Showcase at the McNichols Building in Civic Center Park last night. While it was a great event filled with lots of drinking, the struggle was real this morning. Here are seven distinct signs that last night definitely happened. 1. You haven't mixed that much alcohol in one night since grad night in college, so waking up this morning felt like Han Solo being released from the carbonite. Five snoozed alarms later, you finally drag yourself out of bed to chug a glass of water, followed by a shot of espresso and a cup of coffee. 2. You find one (or maybe more, if you're super cool) of those little DSTILL tasting glasses sitting on your kitchen counter, and suddenly you remember your favorite pour of the night and the ten-minute conversation you had with the rep from that distillery. Let's be honest, there were so many great distilleries represented last night. Each of us had our favorites. That Sno Gin from J & L Distilling Company was my personal favorite. 3. While you're getting ready for work, you find yourself mulling over the crowd from last night, and you're trying to figure out why you didn't know more people there. I don't know what I was expecting, but I did not know a single person outside of our little Commerce Kitchen group.
