At more than one point last night, I found myself thinking, "Who are all of these people?" 4. While you're eating your [hangover] breakfast, you have a vision of that amazing little sandwich that you snagged from the Argyll booth in the snack section. You little piece of heaven: I have no idea what was between your baguette slices (I think I found apricot jam at one point?), but hot damn, you were freaking delicious. 5. Right before you leave for work, you dig your hand into your purse or jacket pocket and pull out ten or more business cards, postcards, coasters, and brochures from the distilleries that you just had to remember for later. What am I supposed to do with all of these now??? 6. You forgot you left your car at the lightrail station/your office and took an Uber home, so you have to figure out how in the world you're going to get to work today, meanwhile cursing the DSTILL gods for scheduling the Showcase on a THURSDAY. Ugh. Is there a struggle bus that I can catch to work? 7. When you finally get to work, you discover that it's Pi Day, and that there is no greater hangover food than pie on this difficult morning. Mmm, pie.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: dstill
7 Signs You Went to the DSTILL Showcase Last Night | Commerce Kitchen
While the DSTILL Showcase was a great event, the struggle was real this morning. Here are 7 distinct signs that last night definitely happened.

item.title: Another SXSWi And Wow My Brain Hurts
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
This year marked my second South By Southwest Interactive experience, and now that a few days have passed since the conference ended I think I can begin to express some of the information that I learned. My brain is recovering from an information hangover. As always, there were some great panels and presentations and some that were mediocre. Rather than painstakingly combing through every talk I went to, I'll pull out some highlights of the week.

Marketing is Science

One of the more compelling talks I went to was on the data behind marketing language. Guy Krief from Persado discussed the vast research his firm has done on what type of language gets people to click or convert. As many marketers know, there are three parts to a message: the action, the description, and the emotion. Action is the CTA, the actual thing you want someone to do: buy this, like this, friend us, etc. The description gives you the basic details: our green yoga pants fit underweight Boston Terriers. Then there's the emotion, which can be both positive and negative. Negative emotion (like "hurry!") gets people to click but not to convert. Positive emotion (like "this is awesome!) gets people to convert. This is true across the globe with one exception: Latin America. The data shows that for some reason negative emotion works for conversions in Latin America. Emotion is almost always good for reeling people in, except in the case of email subject lines. For email subject lines description is the best way to get a higher open rate, and in fact, emotion can trigger spam filters. Persado has been able to gather this data only for messages that have a direct action that they can measure. For example, this can't be applied to building brand awareness, creating billboards, etc. But they've been able to develop a science out of marketing messaging to increase ROI dramatically.

George Takei's optimism gives me hope

Oh George Takei. He is funny, witty, relevant, articulate, insightful, and passionate. He spent years in a Japanese internment camp in the United States when he was a child, and even though he endured unjust imprisonment and discrimination, he still holds so much hope for this country. [caption id="attachment_5626" align="alignright" width="128"] Bocman1973 / Shutterstock.com[/caption] Takei's insights into Edward Snowden echoed something I've been thinking for a while: why did he flee to China and Russia, of all places? Takei remarked that Martin Luther King Jr. broke unjust laws and willingly went to prison for them, and from prison was able to transform the system. Snowden instead fled to two countries whose surveillance states and records on human rights may be worse than the one Snowden is speaking out against. Takei's biggest question to Snowden: What is your game plan? Takei spoke about his success on Facebook as well, and reaffirmed an argument I always make: it takes time and strategy to build your fan base in a meaningful way. Takei created his Facebook presence with the end-goal of promoting a play he had created. The play wasn't debuting for over a year after he started Facebook. This means that he was spending a lot of time nurturing a community long before he promoted his product.

Neil deGrasse Tyson has made me a better parent

Neil deGrasse Tyson. The guy is amazing. I jotted down about ten brilliant one-liners from him, but my favorite of his points were about parenting. Let your kids experiment. Let them break stuff and bang on pots and pans, and learn about the world by exploring it. Nurture their curiosity constantly. This is what builds scientists. He had a wonderful story about his daughter and the tooth fairy. He didn't want to lie to his daughter, so when she asked him he said "I've heard that when you put your tooth under the pillow you might get money." His daughter and her friends began to suspect that their parents were behind the tooth fairy. So they came up with a hypothesis and a method for proving the hypothesis. When the next child in the group lost a tooth she didn't tell her parents about it and put it under her pillow that night. The tooth fairy didn't come. Now the children had a conclusion. But because they all wanted the money they kept believing any way (and told their parents each time they lost a tooth). Tyson made me feel better about letting my daughter explore and make noise and make mistakes. And now I have some better ideas on how to address the magical experiences of childhood without lying to my daughter.

Not everyone is obsessed with exit strategy

One of the more surprising and interesting events I attended was a meetup for "slowpreneurs." Slowpreneur is a term that Denver local Mario Lurig uses to describe entrepreneurs who aren't in it for the insanely fast lifestyle and exit strategy. His creed is this:
I want to be patient. I want to grow within my means. I don’t want to incur debt. I will hold back the charging bull. I will continue to live my life. I will learn every day. I will let go of the reins when it’s ready. I will not be greedy. I will succeed.
At the meetup there were more than thirty entrepreneurs from all over the world (with a disproportionate number of Swedes, oddly), who were either tired of working 100 hours a week or who wanted to leave their current positions to start something new, but they wanted to do it in a way that wouldn't force them to sacrifice what they love about their lives. I really appreciate this movement. I want to spend time with my daughter, make time to write and play music, go on vacations where I can turn my phone off for a few days, and feel good about this one singular life I have. Making sure a business runs smoothly is crucial, but that doesn't necessarily mean you can't have a full life outside of work. As the meetup attested, there are lots of entrepreneurial minded people out there whose love is greater than work.

Culture is ping pong. Culture is not ping pong.

Culture. Along with the words pivot, disrupt, and acquire, culture was another ubiquitous term at SXSW this year. I attended a couple talks on culture and I was sadly disappointed. However, there was an afternoon workshop that I really wanted to go to on creating a company culture "beyond ping pong." Unfortunately I was put on the waitlist and never got in. So why am I writing about it, you ask? Because I think we need to take our discussion of culture deeper. Ping pong tables and professional office chefs are amazing, but those things don't get to the heart of what it means to work in a place with diverse interests, skill sets, and personalities. I heard the CEO of a startup talk about how when people come into the office they hear the music playing and they know what a cool place it is. That made me cringe. What about people who want silence from time to time? People who need a little space to concentrate? Culture isn't about playing ping pong or listening to music, it's about feeling like who you are matters to your company. Let's talk more about that.

Conclusion?

SXSWi is good but it's exhausting. I'll have to consider next year whether or not I have the strength to make it through five days of over-stimulation for a third year. I think I can make it. And I am seriously considering submitting a panel idea or two.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: another-sxswi-wow-brain-hurts
I Went to SXSWi 2014 and My Brain Still Hurts
SXSWi is always an overwhelming experience, with some wonderful talks and some mediocre talks, all of which get my brain churning.
sxswi
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/03/sxswi-2014-highlights/

item.title: Your Business is Science Fiction
item.dc:creator: tszvetecz
item.content:encoded:
Speaking candidly, the latest drop from the Silicon Flatirons Conference Series, entitled "SciFi and Entrepreneurship - Is Resistance Futile?", was an opportunity to meet William Hertling in person. William Hertling is a software engineer at Hewlett Packard by day, and by night is the author of the independently published Avogadro trilogy, a near-term science fiction revelation that explores the emergence of the world's first artificial intelligence. The intimacy of the conference, one of the great breaths of fresh air that is unique to Silicon Flatirons, did not disappoint. However, it was its candor that really set this event apart. The conference presented three star-studded sessions with panelists who ranged from MIT Media Lab instructors, to disruptive technology innovators, to VC legends, to Science Fiction authors and even to a former assistant director of the FBI. Their mission: to explore the convergence of science fiction and entrepreneurship. During the kick-off fireside chat between Mr. Hertling and Brad Feld (notable Venture Capitalist and managing director of the Foundry Group), Mr. Hertling keenly observed that science fiction and entrepreneurship diverged on a key point: the goal of science fiction was to maximize risk to its characters -- to build tension, whereas the goal of entrepreneurship was to minimize risk in order to maximize return on investment.

The Roots of Our Inspiration: Unshackling Our Creativity

Listening to the insights of the various panelists, the feedback loop between science fiction and entrepreneurship easily became apparent. William Hertling commented that we're chasing the future as defined by Star Trek. Look at the technologies that came out of that ground-breaking narrative we are desperately trying to bring to life: tricorders, faster than light travel, vision for the blind, artificial intelligence and "tea, earl grey, hot". Mr. Feld skillfully articulated that the power of science fiction is the power to create one's own world -- to shape one's future. Mr. Feld alluded to two realities: one where your future is imposed upon you, and one where you create your own future. Successful science fiction, as in successful entrepreneurship, is the result of the latter mode of thinking. To underscore the significance of the interplay between science fiction and real-world innovation, one panelist observed that China has been struggling to get its engineers to exercise a comparable level of creativity to US engineers, and after further research, it was revealed that US engineer's exposure to science fiction from an early age led to their heightened levels of creativity. This underscored Mr. Hertling's Star Trek observation.

Temple of the Nerds

Having identified the roots of technological innovation, Dan Novy of MIT's Media Lab described the process of creating the 'science of imaginary solutions.' This is a field of study known as 'Pataphysics. As an example of 'Pataphysics (and as an example of the coolest job ever), Dan challenges his MIT students by having them read an influential science fiction book, like Neuromancer. He then asks them to create a technology described in the book that does not yet exist. Being MIT students, they do just that. Every day, Dan bears witness to what can be innovated on the backs of science fiction visionaries. This real-world experience gives him some interesting perspective on other current technology trends. Where science fiction writers are good at story telling, Dan observes that technologists are equally good at story telling, to the extent that they fabricate entire realities. Notably, he observed that one of the great "nerd-topias" that currently pervades our collective psyche, second only to the "singularity" (in which humans and machine converge to form an immortal, cloud-based consciousness), is the Big Data idea that if you collect enough data, patterns will magically appear that give you prescient and predictive insight into your business's future. Needless to say, to Dan Novy, Big Data is the biggest unrealized story of all.

The Final Frontier of Entrepreneurship

The depth of ideas and discussions explored by all the panelists from this event are too numerous to articulate in one blog post, but William Hertling struck a chord that echoed through the entire conference. He observed that, starting out as a writer, he read just enough to be inspired. Through the likes of William Gibson, Charles Stross and Walter Jon Williams, he developed an understanding of the field, but was generally at liberty to explore the theme of the emergence of artificial intelligence in his own way. It was only after his first book, Avogadro Corp, was released that fans and peers inundated him with stories from other authors that explored the same topic. Mr. Hertling wryly noted that he had read enough science fiction to be inspired, but not enough to feel that the field had been too thoroughly explored. Otherwise, he would have felt he had nothing new to contribute to it. He observed that the same must be true of successful entrepreneurs. Mr. Hertling unintentionally drew the thin line between a world deprived of his genius and a world transformed by it. How many entrepreneurs are at this very moment losing their footing. How many are allowing unbarred inspiration to turn into the premature psychological defeat that comes from believing they have nothing new to contribute? At that moment, true to his art form as a writer, he created the tension that maximized the risk to his character. It was all too easy to see how he could have been dissuaded from the great contribution to the world that has defined our contemporary understanding of the disruptive (and inevitable) impact of artificial intelligence. Where Mr. Hertling originally observed that the goal of entrepreneurship was exactly the opposite -- to minimize tension and minimize risk, it became irrefutably clear that science fiction and entrepreneurship had exactly the same goal: to be inspired, and to create something new. Risk be damned.

Recommended Reading

  • Star Trek: The Next Generation (all seasons)
  • Avogadro Corp: The Singularity is Closer Than It Appears by William Hertling
  • A.I. Apocalypse by William Hertling
  • The Last Firewall by William Hertling
  • The Circle by Dave Eggers

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Your Business Is Science Fiction
Commerce Kitchen's CEO Tynan went to a Silicon Flatirons event last week that activated his flux capacitor.

item.title: Why I Like Developing in Linux
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded:
I've been using Linux for 5 years or so. When I started my first development job, my boss gave me an Apple laptop to do development, then over Christmas, it faded and died. So I needed another computer ASAP. Not having enough money for an Apple, I decided to get a cheap PC laptop (during all the Christmas specials) and put Linux on it. I budgeted a full day to migrate everything over and get my development environment running. (This was a huge mistake, it took over a week.) Linux is a totally different animal from both Windows and Mac, and takes some getting used to, be prepared for a STEEP learning curve. But as they say, once you go Linux, you never go back.

Security

Security is one of Linux's biggest advantages over it's counterparts, from a hacker standpoint, writing Linux desktop targeted viruses is silly, as it only makes up 1% of desktop OS's. I'll spare you the details of Linux's security achievements, but it's safe to say that you'll have very little to worry about in the realm of viruses if you run any flavor of Linux.

Price/Hardware

Most flavors of Linux are free, which is pretty affordable. There's been arguments forever about the cost of ownership of Linux being higher than that of it's closed source counterparts (windows), but there are lots of studies that prove otherwise. Another nice feature is that you can use affordable PC hardware, but not be tied to Windows, which opens up your options considerably.

OpenSource

OpenSource development is an ideology I believe in strongly, it helps secure us from secret NSA backdoors, gives the entire developer community the ability to make additions and makes development time infinitely shorter by allowing devs to build off others scaffolding. Where would social media be without user contributed content? Well, OpenSource software is much the same way.

LightWeight

Linux is generally lightweight, you can run a full Ubuntu (most popular desktop linux flavor) install off a USB stick! I've done it before and it's great, essentially you can carry your computer with you almost anywhere in your pocket. There are incredibly lightweight distros that can run on 10+ year old hardware, Arch Linux, Slackware, Puppy Linux, etc…

Mad Respect

Lets not forget that people have mad respect for Linux users. It takes some effort to overcoming the learning curve of Linux, and those who understand this will give you props right off the bat for making the change.

Software Repository

One of my favorite features of Linux is it's software repositories. Need Firefox? Open up a command terminal, type one short line and viola, the latest Firefox specific for your OS is installed and ready to go. Most software is already in a software repository that's been tested on your specific distro, no downloads, no finding the install file, no trying to determine what OS you're running and it all just works like magic. When it's time to uninstall, it's just one quick easy command. You'll never miss the Windows registry, I promise.

Matches the production environment

As a developer, there's inevitable issues that arise when you deploy your code that worked perfectly on you local machine to the production server. However, if you're running Linux, this takes you one step closer to having the same environment as production (if you're deploying to a Linux server). It also gives developers a little more insight into the inner workings of the servers that they're deploying too.

Customization

For those of you who like to tweak their machines, Linux provides you with endless possibilities. Ubuntu alone has 8 different official flavors, and a whole host of non-official ones. That's only one distribution of Linux, there are literally hundreds. And yet with all of its great features, I still have several issues with Linux. 

Configuration

Linux is awesome, but it's not always smooth going though, there's issues that arise that I think Windows users don't have to deal with as often. For example when you buy a laptop with Windows pre-installed, you're pretty confident all the hardware will work out of the box, and sometimes after you install Linux, you'll have to do some tweaking to get things working. Though the amount of custom configuration seems to be getting less and less every year.

Games

This has been the biggest hindrance to Linux adoption, it's limited use by the gaming community. Though it's still a problem and if you're a gamer, you'll still probably want to at least dual boot so you can continue to play your favorite games. Steam is available for Linux now, which is a HUGE win for both the gamer and penguin communities.

Is Linux right for you?

Linux is a great OS, but it requires a little configuration work. If you're not super tech savy, it may not be the OS for you, though every release gets more user friendly. If you're looking for something that's lightweight, secure and ultra customizable, it's definitely worth the effort. I've recently been using Kubuntu, and it's GUI is beautiful, polished and clean. Enjoy the adventure of learning a new OS.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: linux
Why I Like Developing in Linux | Commerce Kitchen
Kevin's been working with Linux for about five years now. Here are his thoughts about its positives, its negatives, and everything in between.

item.title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Culture
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
A few months ago, during a trip to Portland to talk to the brilliant minds at Reed College, I took some time to catch up with some old college friends over dinner. There was wine and whiskey, there was fantastic food, there was a crazy ice storm going on (Come on, PDX. Ice??! Really?), and there was a lot of catching up. I hadn’t been to Portland in years. My host and a great friend for many years was Luke Kanies, who, after being a mostly surly and occasionally charming - and always crazy smart - college kid, grew up to be the fancy-pants founder and CEO of Puppet Labs. That sometimes still surprises me, but it’s a true story. So, with someone whose success has been so great sitting at the table with me, I couldn’t help but talk a little about a question we’ve been chewing on for a while at Commerce Kitchen.

What, really, is “culture” in the workplace? What’s a good one? What’s a bad one?

Natalie mentioned in a recent blog post about South By Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) that there’s a weird obsession with ping pong tables in tech companies and that the presence of one somehow means you’ve done culture right. We have one in our beloved firehouse, but it’s almost never used. Are we failing at culture?! We don’t have a company chef prepping  fresh, farm-to-table meals for our staff every day - or, really, ever. Not once in 11 years. Are we failing at culture? We are killing it with the kegerator and we have 2 office dogs and 2 office pigs. We are obviously winning at culture. Right? When I was talking about this with Luke, he said something to the effect of “You know, when we talk about culture, we can be talking about 2 different things. Do we wear the same kind of shoes? Or do we work the same way? I don’t give a s*** about your shoes. I want to know that we can work together.” *** Note: Luke may or may not have used expletives. He did, after all, have his twin daughters and another child within earshot. But I did mention he can be surly, right? I know him well enough to say this with certainty: He does not give a s*** about your shoes. Incidentally, in the CK ownership team’s home closets, there are, at last count, 12 pairs of Fluevogs. I’m sorry.

What is culture if it's not about shoes?

[caption id="attachment_5733" align="aligncenter" width="625"] Fluevogs one, two, and three.[/caption] I’ve been reading a few books on culture and hiring lately (and so can you!), and I’ve been deliberately seeking out books that don't focus on tech. When I read Natalie’s comment that she cringed when someone on a SXSWi panel said “We have music playing, so you know it’s a cool place to work,” I nodded my head and thought “That only works if we like the same music.” Sort of like “That only works if we like the same shoes.” To be fair, some of the culture focused talks I went to at SXSWi mentioned that creating a diversity of working environments within the company space was valuable. A loud and raucous idea-sharing space. A quiet space for solitary, focused-thought work. A small conference room kind of space for teams to work together on collaborative stuff. So there was a nod to different working styles - but creating tons of different kinds of spaces is hard to do if you’re in a small space to begin with, as a lot of smaller companies are. The folks talking had worked on the Google and Yahoo campuses, so they had plenty of space to work with. What surprised me at SXSWi was that almost all of the talks on culture focused around environmental factors and tangible things. A lot of which, to paraphrase Luke, is more about shoes than work. Who wouldn’t want a personal chef? Who wouldn’t want to cuddle with tiny pigs on lunch breaks? Why not have a Donkey Kong console next to the kegerator?

Culture runs deeper than your kegerator

[caption id="attachment_5681" align="alignleft" width="225"] Peaches, CK Canine Cultural Ambassador[/caption] The books I’ve been reading really speak to something that rings more true for me and the rest of the CK exec team as we’re trying to really nail this culture thing: It’s more about your work ethic, your expectation of excellence and how you can best get there, whether or not you foster a service orientation, and the extent to which you want to honor people’s lives outside of work. Gaining consensus around those points, and many others like them, is the really hard work. By comparison, making sure the kegs are flowing with tasty brews and that there are quality ping pong balls on hand is child's play. Building that consistency of vision and mission requires some serious reflection and introspection. It requires communication to the point that you think you're over-communicating. It requires constant vigilance and attention. I don't think we've nailed this culture thing 100% at Commerce Kitchen, but we are working toward it every day. And if I ever do tell you that I think we've got it 100% figured out and are doing it perfectly, make sure you tell me that, in that moment, I'm failing at culture.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What We Talk About When We Talk About Culture
We've got a ping pong table, a kegerator, office dogs, and even office pigs. But that's not really what culture is.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/03/talk-talk-culture/

item.title: Go Code Colorado: Inside the Events
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Were you at the Go Code Colorado Kick-Off Event last night? If not, you missed a great party and some amazing speakers. The highlights of the evening for me were:

Bipartisan Collaboration

Hearing Ken Lund, Executive Director of OEDIT, speak about Go Code Colorado's mission to innovate and collaborate, we were all able to reflect on and get excited about this weekend's events, and the future for app development using public data. He emphasized that collaboration is occurring not just during app development, but also behind the scenes in government to make events like Go Code Colorado a success. Democrat, Republican, young, old, entrepreneur or established business, we are all coming together to build Colorado's economy. What a powerful message. Later in the evening we heard from Secretary of State Scott Gessler, who focused on the business challenges that our Colorado companies are facing, and the big reason that his team has worked so tirelessly on the events – to build business in Colorado. This year's events will be the first, in what hopes to be an annual challenge to build Colorado. Secretary Gessler also bridged party lines to thank the Governor's office, SIPA, and OEDIT and for their collaboration and support to make Go Code Colorado a success. It's great to see the leaders of this initiative put Colorado first. They are truly embodying Go Code Colorado's mission to build apps, build business and build Colorado.

Real Colorado Business Stories

While I've worked on Go Code Colorado for the last four months, the Challenge Statements that our event is trying to solve were admirable, but never really came alive for me until we heard from business owners last night.

Site Location

Heather Alcott from Glaze focused on the need for a better analysis tool to determine business site location based on pedestrian traffic, tax incentives, and available parking through the day or night.

Access to Capital

Jeff Macco from Seedpaths discussed the importance of infusing business with "smart money" at the right times to maximize business growth. He would love to see an app that gives businesses a rundown of available capital types that are best for their specific businesses.

Higher Education Resources

Carol Carlson from Gates wants to ensure that educated Colorado talent stays in Colorado, by connecting those students with business partners that desperately need their skills.

Competitive Landscape

Brian Freeman from Grower's Organic shared his business growth and the unexpected hurdles he faced when moving into the transportation businesses to further distribute his products. Wouldn't it have been great to have an app that provides insight into the opportunities and challenges of tangential industries, or one that can help find strategic alliances?

Business Partners

Finally, John Land LeCoq from Fishpond shared his vision for moving much of his outsourced manufacturing back to Colorado, if only he could find the right business partners that align with his business mission of sustainability. I think we all left more jazzed that ever to start building apps on Friday to address some of these challenges! Get involved by signing up for a Challenge Weekend.

The Band

Katie Glassman + Snapshot. Need I say more? They were fabulous and kept folks entertained right up until the end. A good two-thirds of our 180+ attendees stuck around for networking (we had some really great talent and kick ass businesses present) and some good ole fashioned Western swing music.

Behind-the-Scenes Teamwork

Putting on a large event series like Go Code Colorado takes a lot of work, and a lot of people. Collaboration to the nth degree. Am I sensing a theme? It was wonderful to experience the nexus of that hard work, which couldn't have been possible without:

Planning

Four months of planning, to be exact. And that doesn't count the time that the Secretary of State's team put in to get the challenge off the ground to begin with. With five Challenge Weekend events, and one Final Competition ahead of us, our motley crew of CK staffers, politicians, government agencies, vendors, and partner companies has laid the foundation for an amazing competition that gets folks collaborating, innovating and driving change in Colorado. Now it's time to hit the road for Challenge Weekend in Boulder, Colorado Springs, Denver, Durango, and Fort Collins.

Production Management

While you may not consciously notice them while you are there, they solidify and spread the brand message. Tons of backend work that pays off tenfold. No event would be successful without the little details that bring it all together. Banners, posters, table tents, name badges, t-shirts, and more.

Event Coordination

The most visible of the behind-the-scenes efforts, but one of the least understood. Successful event coordination is like leading a project that has already missed its deadlines and gone infinitely out of scope. There are marketing materials to put up, registration tables to man, A/V to coordinate, sound checks to run, logistical issues to solve, table spreads to set up, volunteers to direct, people to corral, and more. And that's just the foundation necessary to ensure an event runs smoothly; you must also build excitement, get people engaged and throw a memorable party. But all told, I wouldn't change it for the world, because it's FUN when you are working with great people. I can't say enough about the wonderful business partners we've been able to collaborate with on Go Code Colorado – Engine7, History Colorado Center, Denware and more. And really, Elaine Marino, you are the bees knees, so thank you. With good people, it all comes together.

Marketing and Advertising

With marketing and advertising dollars unavailable for use until the last possible minute, we had a pretty crazy scramble to get word out about Go Code Colorado. PR was already moving along thanks to the continued efforts of our business partners to spread the word in their respective regions, and the Secretary of State's marcomm team. Paid search, social media and display advertising managed to net us 112,000+ impressions to a very targeted developer and startup audience in under a week. And five days of underwriting:15 spots plus a great interview from Secretary Gessler on Colorado Public Radio's Colorado Matters, helped drive word-of-mouth and support in the business community. Thankfully our work paid off, and we sold out the Kick-Off Event three days prior to launch. I am so proud of our team's collaborating and execution, and can't wait to move on to the Challenge Weekend events tomorrow.

Enthusiasm

I know the post is getting long, but I want to leave you with one word: enthusiasm. Businesses, developers, entrepreneurs, marketers, spectators, and pretty much anyone that's heard about Go Code Colorado are enthusiastic and unbelievably excited about the challenge. Let's keep our momentum going to do great things for Colorado. Get involved and make a difference. I can't wait to hear more next week about the great ideas our 10 finalists will have for app development in Colorado.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Go Code Colorado Public Data Challenge | Kick-Off Event a Success
Businesses, developers, and government launched Go Code Colorado with compelling speakers, a great party and momentum leading into Challenge Weekend.

item.title: As Twitter Turns 8, What's Next for the Blue Bird?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Twitter launched eight years ago. On this semi-momentous occasion for the social media platform, I started thinking about how it has changed since the beginning, what it's doing now, and what's next for this little birdie that could.

What's Changed?

Just like its big and intimidating step-brother, Facebook (Yes, I used the F-word in a blog post about Twitter - get used to it!), Twitter has changed since it was born. It hasn't gone through quite as many interface-lifts as Zuckerberg and his team of minions, but Twitter has updated itself enough to stay current. One of my personal favorites was when they activated the header photo. It has given Commerce Kitchen the chance to show off our super cool Firehouse.

Not only have interface updates been a slow-moving process, the growth of users on Twitter has also been a long time coming. Twitter has less than half of registered users compared to Facebook. While Facebook has had massive growth spurts in the past six years - getting about 1 billion new users since 2008 - it took Twitter that same amount of time to obtain about 500 million registered users. Mobile has made a huge impact on Twitter's growth. 60% of users access Twitter from their mobile devices. It probably doesn't hurt that the app for iPhone is freaking awesome. I love it so much. I love it more than the desktop interface.

What's Twitter Doing Now?

For starters, they're taking a page from the Book of Face and making their 8th birthday about nostalgia. They've created a simple tool to help you find your FIRST. TWEET. EVER. That's right, you get to see how embarrassing you were in 2008. The folks at Twitter did us a favor and gave us some amazing examples: I played with the First Tweet tool and discovered what Natalie's life was like in 2011. Ironically, Twitter is currently aging just like Facebook is! Twitter's fastest-growing age demographic is 55-64 year olds, while Facebook's is 45-54 year olds. What does this mean? It means that (*gasp!*) older generations are getting online, and it's GREAT. Although it hasn't happened yet, when my middle-aged mother doesn't have to ask me for computer help, I can die happy. On the business side of things,  Twitter is becoming a place of solace for social media marketers. In theory, Facebook is the perfect place for small businesses to nurture current client relationships and have access to potential clients. However, with the changes that have been made to the Newsfeed in the past several years, as well as the most recent decision to MURDER ORGANIC REACH, Facebook is becoming a marketing graveyard. Unless you want to pay for your own followers to see your content, the chances of people organically viewing your posts are slim to none. Meanwhile, brands on Twitter don't have to pay up to have their tweets seen. Of course, there is a lot to be said about what kinds of relationships are best nurtured on Twitter versus Facebook. Twitter's good for B2B, Facebook's good for B2C. In my opinion, recent changes on Twitter (ex: automatically viewable images on the Twitter feed) are making it a more friendly space for brands to exist.

What's Next?

I'm waiting for the day when desktop browser Twitter has a simple switch-accounts button, like the one they have on the mobile app. Why did I wrap a square around the Accounts button three times? Because it saves my life on a daily basis. I manage four Twitter accounts - in addition to my personal account - and switching between them in desktop browser Twitter is currently not as simple of a task as it should be. Why, Twitter??? Why isn't this a priority to-do item on your list of desktop browser updates? I nearly claw my eyes out every time I think about this. Another thing I'm hoping Twitter will fix soon: the photo uploader. I've been having some major issues with it lately. While I'm uploading an image to a tweet on desktop browser, it starts to mess with other things I have open, like Spotify or YouTube. The sound gets sketchy and the pages get slower, so I simply wait for the insanity to end.

Let me gaze into my crystal ball...

A question that I've been asked a lot lately is "What's the future of social media?" I could speculate about the longevity of Facebook's triumph over its lesser competitors until kingdom come, but I don't want to do that. Facebook - I know I speak of it as if it's a human with a brain and an ego the size of Jupiter - is not the end-all, be-all to social media. Myspace was the beginning. Facebook was the revolution. The solution has yet to be discovered. With all of its recent changes regarding the Newsfeed and Pages' organic reach, Facebook is practically handing the brand-friendly, user-preferred social media torch to Twitter. The question is, will Twitter drop it on the exchange?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: As Twitter Turns 8, What's Next for the Blue Bird? | Commerce Kitchen
twitter
On this semi-momentous occasion, I started thinking about how Twitter has changed, what it's doing now, and what's next for this little birdie that could.

item.title: 5 Mistakes Businesses Make On Twitter
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
To follow up on Jen's recent post about Twitter's eight-year anniversary, I thought I'd compile a short list of mistakes that businesses regularly make on Twitter. Twitter is one of those platforms that everyone thinks they should be on, but that few people take advantage of in a way that can actually benefit their business. Here are mistakes you might be making and ways to improve your Twitter activity.

1. Pushing from Facebook

Because you can automatically push your Facebook posts to Twitter using the Facebook app, tons of businesses do this, thinking it gives them an active Twitter presence without having to do any extra work. However, there are two big reasons this doesn't work in your favor. For one, your Facebook audience expects different things from you than your Twitter audience does. A post, link, image, or comment that someone likes on Facebook may not be interesting to a Twitter audience, which seeks quicker and easier-to-digest bits of information. The average Twitter user's feed fills up and refreshes often, so your tweet will quickly get pushed off the page. It's true that Facebook's algorithm is changing so that business pages get less visibility, but generally a Facebook post may stick around a bit longer than a tweet. The second reason pushing your Facebook posts to Twitter doesn't work is that Twitter will truncate your post. People expect you to take the character count seriously when posting on Twitter. After all, that's what makes Twitter unique. You have 140 characters to say something, so make it count. I don't mean to pick on the Arvada Center; they put on some great shows and are an amazing organization. But here's an example of a Facebook post that just doesn't work as a tweet. Clicking back to Facebook to read the rest of this is the last thing I want to do:

2. Following too many or too few people

We all want followers. If a tweet is tweeted into Twitter and no one is around to hear it, does it make a sound? Well, no. One way that we get followers is by following other people first, which lets them know we're here. It can be tempting to follow everyone Twitter recommends, but this doesn't allow us to strategize, and we end up with a major imbalance of followers and followees. You can use a tool like Followerwonk to identify people who follow your competitors or other businesses that you claim an affinity with. Then, you can strategically follow certain people within those groups. And it may be obvious, but make sure you're following other organizations that you regularly do business with; follow your friends, your neighbors, nonprofits. Follow people and companies that you want to support; they need followers as much as you do. We always try to maintain a relatively even ratio of followers and followees, and every once in a while I go through the list of people I'm following to make sure they're still active on Twitter. If not, I unfollow them. If you don't follow anyone or if you follow too many people, you are less likely to get followers. There are some strange psychological games that we're required to play on social networks, but they're not any different than the social games we play in everyday life.

3. Never retweeting or retweeting too much

Twitter is a social network. This means that we're expected to participate socially. We interact, we engage. We don't broadcast our own message all the time and expect people to care (see #4 for more on this one). This is where the retweet comes into play. I recommend retweeting at least once a day. Retweet other organizations and people who are saying or doing interesting things. Retweet links to articles that are relevant to your community to show that you're interested in engaging with them on Twitter, and it also shows that you find other people as interesting as you find yourself. However, there are limits. If you retweet every time someone mentions you this can get old real fast. We don't want to see your retweets polluting our news feed, and the reason your followers followed you in the first place is because they want to know what you have to say, not what other people are saying.

Retweeting should be done, but it should be done with care and thought, rather than as a constant-- or worse yet, automated--exercise.

4. Only linking back to their own website

Brands whose tweets only to link back to their own website are a special kind of annoying. This defeats the entire purpose of a social network by turning it into a billboard. Yes, we do care about your blog and products, but no, that's not all we want to see. [caption id="attachment_5771" align="aligncenter" width="625"] Yawn.[/caption] We want to see who else you support, what you find interesting, and discover the personality of your business. If you've done your work in marketing, then you've probably already developed personas. Find people who resemble those personas and make sure that you've created a voice. There is an exception to this rule. If your business is a news site, then you don't need to worry about linking to anything but yourself. That's because you're providing an extension of your service on Twitter. Your service is news. Twitter itself is a rolling news feed. In any other case, though, I'd highly recommend curating interesting content that extends beyond your own site, services, and products.

5. Never using images

This past year, Twitter rolled out images on their feed. While some people grumbled at the change, others welcomed it. Overall, others welcomed it. Buffer did a study to measure engagement on tweets with expanded image, and they found that engagement goes up when a tweet includes an image.

Tweets that include images also show that you're active on Twitter and not just linking to your Instagram or Facebook accounts. Images add even more realtime relevance to what you're doing. If your business is hosting or attending an event, make sure to tweet an image from the event and tag relevant people and businesses within that tweet. It highlights the community aspect of social media and shows that you're active in a way that 140 characters can't.
Twitter can be a great way to support your marketing efforts, build community, stay connected, and listen to your customers' feedback. But it needs to be approached for its own unique characteristics and not as another generic social tool. We're happy to create Twitter strategies, so if you need help give us a call.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Mistakes Businesses Make On Twitter
Oh, businesses. You gotta learn how to do Twitter right. Not making these five common mistakes is a good place to start
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/03/5-mistakes-businesses-make-twitter/

item.title: I'm a Middle Adopter, and All I Got Was This Lousy $1.46 eBook Settlement!
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
In which I get a tiny eBook Credit

Amazon emailed me about an  ebook Settlement today. It was for $1.46, or two eBooks at $0.74 a piece. The eBook settlement covers April 1st, 2010 to May 21st, 2012 for most major publishers. In my case, the publisher paying out the settlement is Hachette. The two eBooks in question are Cold Fire, a nice steampunk romp by Kate Elliot which I recommend, and Hounded: The Iron Druid Chronicles, Book One by Kevin Hearne, which I was pretty "meh" about—I didn't continue the series. That's pretty representative: the vast majority of my eBook purchases since then have been science fiction and fantasy. The settlement was from antitrust lawsuits filed against those publisher alleging that they conspired with Apple to raise book prices prior to the iBook launch. The publishers of course admitted no wrongdoing but settled anyway.  Ironically, iBook purchasers have yet to receive anything since Apple is still fighting the lawsuits in court. This amusingly small settlement reminded me that I am not an early adopter.

In which I am not an early adopter of technologies

Unlike many of the techies I know, I am not an early adopter. It's a conscious choice. Why should I pay top dollar to get bleeding edge tech when I can wait a while and let the bugs get worked out and the price come down?  Lately, even I have picked up my adoption rate, and I'm not the only one:  overall, the adoption rate of new technologies is getting faster and faster.  Still, I try to be a "middle adopter" - get technology as soon as is reasonable.

Examples of when I first adopted some sort of technology:

  • First PDA: Palm III, not a Newton. Several years after its release date, so around 2000 or 2001
  • First high speed Internet at home in 2002.  I did work at an ISP for 5 years prior to that though.
  • First cell phone in 2003.
  • DVD player around 2006/2007. I showed up at a video store looking for a movie in VHS - and it was only out in DVD.
  • First HDTV in 2012.
  • First smartphone (HTC Incredible) in 2010. Dangerously close to bleeding edge until you remember the iPhone came out in 2007.
  • Facebook - I was almost bleeding edge here! I nabbed an account when you had to have a university email address in 2006. When was my first post? 2010.
  • PS3 - 2011.
  • SASS in 2012.
  • Ruby on Rails on version 3.2 (also in 2012).
  • My Macbook is white. (For those of you playing along at home: last white Macbook release: 2010.)
  • I tried Twitter in 2009, but it didn't take. In 2010, I tried it again while at An Event Apart and got hooked because the people I was following were people like Eric Meyer, Jeffrey Zeldman, and other CSS and web development gurus.
  • First Kindle in 2012. They were first released in 2007.
  • One exception: web browsers. I started using Firefox back when it was called Phoenix on version 0.5. I am a web developer after all. I switched to Google Chrome as my main development and browsing somewhere around version 10. I occasionally look at the alpha stuff like Chrome Canary. In general though, I look for version 2 or 3 of software, and look askance at 0.x versions.

How I stopped worrying and learned to love the ebook

As a long time science fiction fan and Internet user, I kept on hearing about how this year eBooks were going to take off. After a while, I started tuning it out. When the Kindle first launched, I was interested, but wanted to wait until prices came down and the technology improved. Since I got my smartphone in 2010, I was adverse to an eInk reader without touch capabilities, so I waited a few more years to 2012 to finally buy one. When I went to buy one, the book they were featuring was George R.R. Martin's A Dance with Dragons, which was good marketing on Amazon's part, since that tome weighs in at 1040 pages in hardback, which is bit much to lug with you on the light rail. I now read eBooks 98% of the time on my Nexus 7. In my favorite genre, sf/fantasy,  everything new is available, and the backlist is getting better. One of my favorite authors, Walter Jon Williams, had a great idea: he downloaded the pirated version of his backlist books, cleaned them up, and published them. I no longer have the frustrating experience of waiting weeks for a new book to possibly show up at my local Border or Barnes & Noble.  I can also read completed trilogies.  Marathoning is not just for Netflix. I read more books (about one a week) than I did before the switch to eBooks, so the switch was well worth it.  One minor drawback to eBooks is that not all of them have full color covers in them: one notable exception is the cover for Three Parts Dead, shown on my Nexus 7 in the screenshot, a brilliant second-world urban fantasy by Max Gladstone I highly recommend. Here's another thing I, as a web developer, like about eBooks. Ebook formats are just compressed bundles of HTML and CSS files with a sprinkling of XML files for flavor. This means for eBooks without DRM like all the books that major SF publisher Tor publishes, I can edit typos, change the font, or even re-do the formatting if I'm so inclined. That's a pretty geeky pastime, but it works for me.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: I'm a Middle Adopter, and I Got a Lousy eBook Settlement
In which Chad receives a $1.46 credit on Amazon. He's got some beef with this.

item.title: Branding in an Agile World
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
We all know that a great marketing strategy works best when it's built upon a solid brand. But unless we as marketers are establishing a new identity with brand guidelines, style tiles, look and feel, logos, core messaging, etc., we have a tendency to remain static. We refer back to those original guidelines and marketing hooks. We drop in a stacked logo here, and a bug-only logo there, but we don't really think about our brand. We take our brand for granted. And while we may be constantly iterating in our marketing, we have a difficult time iterating our brands.

Iterate Your Brand

Hear me out here: I am not calling for complete brand overhaul every year (which happens way too often with CMO turnover already). Overhauls should be approached with a healthy amount of research to determine the long-term value (you don't want to kill your brand recall or lose sight of your brand promise, after all). But I am calling for a customer-centric, brand iteration revolution, with a soundtrack set to OAR's That Was a Crazy Game of Poker, of course. Let's take the agile principles that have served us so well in software development and marketing, and apply them, gasp!, to brands. You may see just a few benefits from the approach:

Better Alignment with Your Content Strategies

Iterations keep you nimble. They keep you honest. They keep you transparent. And they keep you evolving in conjunction with your dialogue-driven, community-building content strategies. Because let's face it, it's a tough world out there for branded content. If your content isn't engaging your audience, your brand sure as hell better be. We have to respond to change.

Better Competitive Positioning

An evolving brand that continues to identify with its audience will be better positioned to take on whatever disruptive event competitors can throw at them because it's living and breathing change. It can adapt. Lots of small, sequential changes with continual check-ins keep you moving forward while your competitors are still scrambling to modify their scope of work with their waterfall-dependent vendors.

Better Internal Alignment

We've been seeing unprecedented levels of CMO-CIO collaboration, that's not just being driven by the CMOs to increase their technological prowess, but also by CIOs. Heck, collaboration across the C-suite is practically a prerequisite these days for getting a job. Your IT team has been applying agile principles to their development for years now. Now we're all speaking the same language and collectively working for the same end game: increased market share and brand relevance. Even though our teams may continue to have very different functions, we understand how to work better because we're playing the same game, in the same way, using the same terminology.

Better Brand Relevance

And last, but certainly not least, iterations keep your brand relevant to all stakeholders. Relevant to your audience. Relevant to your brand evangelists. Relevant to your investors. Relevant to the ever-evolving "user". Your brand needs to evolve as your stakeholders evolve, and as their needs, desires and manners of engagement evolve. Which, frankly, is at the speed of light.

What Can I Iterate?

Keep it simple. Focus on things that are easy to adapt, and easy to test. And while this post isn't about testing, always, always, always (have I put enough of them in there for you to get the message!?) test.

Benefit Statements / Competitive Differentiators

You should already know your "whys". You probably have a slew of them. And you are gathering hundreds more from your awesome community building efforts. Why not test to see what's trending up or down to increase brand resonance?

Online Visuals

In our digital world, websites, display ads, social media banners, etc. are infinitely changeable. Do you get more traction with beautiful nature photography, or lifestyle action shots? Do solid floods keep the focus on your witty, inspiring copy, or just look flat? Test what works and then slowly apply those learnings to offline efforts. Have you increased traction? Continue iterating and updating across your channels. If not, move on to the next test.

Funneling

While not strictly "brand", funneling is not only a way to prompt conversions, but also a way to tell your brand story. Have a robust audience on social that loves one particular aspect of your brand message? Start educating and bringing other messages into the fold, and see if they stick. If they do, begin introducing the audience into other channels and funnels where this message is a core tenant of your brand. Little by little, you will build more cross channel engagement, and tell a more compelling brand story across all of your micro-level audience segments. Don't think brand iterations are a good idea? Or have a better approach? Let me know! I'd love to hear your thoughts.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Agile Branding | Iterate to Increase Relevance + Competitive Advantage
Applying agile principles to your brand will keep you relevant, ahead of the competition and aligned with internal teams, plus improve content strategies.

item.title: Stop Complaining About LinkedIn. Instead, Use it Effectively.
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: I try my best to understand other peoples' perspectives in life; it kind of comes with the territory of working in Internet marketing. But for some reason, I just can't seem to grasp how folks in business and tech don't see the usefulness of LinkedIn. Too many of them aren't using LinkedIn the way(s) that they should be. These people, in my humble opinion, are the absolute worst people on LinkedIn. How can I tell if I'm a poor LinkedIn user? Let me ask you some questions... -Do you have a recent (taken within the past 5 years) photo of yourself on your profile? -Do you have a profile photo at all? -Have you written a "Summary" of yourself on your profile? -Is your listed "Current Position" congruent with your actual current position? -Have you made a new connection within the past month? If you cannot answer "yes" to at least three of these questions, then I am afraid you aren't using LinkedIn very well. I simply don't get it. What's not to love about LinkedIn? Sure, the interface isn't as pretty as Pinterest. It's not as friendly as Facebook. It's not as titillating as Twitter. However, it is EXACTLY what the social media world needs. If you can believe it, LinkedIn was actually one of the first to sit at the social media table. Founded in 2002 with some humble beginnings, LinkedIn has since grown to having 225 million registered users. Of course, that's over a decade of  v e r y   s l o w l y  acquiring users. But, truth be told, LinkedIn is designed for a certain kind of Internet user. Business ladies and gentlemen, that's you. You are exactly who LinkedIn is made for. The CEO of a startup with 20 strangers' business cards at the bottom of her purse. The marketing manager meeting 500 people in one conference weekend. The college graduate trying to maneuver his way into the business community. LinkedIn was designed to help you grow your business, grow your network, and remind you of that random person you met at the conference kick-off happy hour. Here are some things you can do to improve your usage of LinkedIn. 1. Upload an [updated] picture of yourself.  Head shots are preferred. No selfies. No blurry photos. Keep it simple. Keep it clean. Keep it classy. If you currently do not have a photo on your profile, please upload one ASAP. You look creepy. 2. Update your "Experience." This is your resume. Online. Forever. Not on CareerBuilder. It's for everyone to see. Make it good. Highlight the important stuff. Give descriptions to the positions that matter. Leave out your summer job from your high school years. 3. Make sure that each job is linked DIRECTLY to the corresponding company page on LinkedIn. When you're entering "Company Name," don't get crazy and create a completely separate company if there's already one established. That's just annoying. 4. Get connected. Easier said than done, I know. But if you're not on LinkedIn to connect with people in a business-y setting, then why are you on there? Don't try to tell me you're on there for fun, because I know that's a lie. LinkedIn is not fun. LinkedIn is useful. Learn that now and be at peace. 5. Take advantage of the new "Relationship" feature! How do I love thee, Relationship feature? Let me count the ways... Seriously though, this new addition is brilliant. It's putting CRM into LinkedIn and it's precisely what the site needed. This new addition is particularly useful for you fancy people out there with 500+ connections (or if you just have a really bad memory). To use it, visit one of your connections' profiles. You can make notes about that person, describe how you met, set reminders to get in touch, etc.  If this new feature is activated for you (it's kind of like a Facebook update), you should see this under their profile header: Obviously, I have a special place in my heart for LinkedIn. I'm pretty new to the 'business' world, and I may only have 138 LinkedIn connections, but that number continues to grow as I network and meet new people here in Denver. If I can see the value of LinkedIn, then you should too. Keep track of your contacts. Get connected with your clients. Make connections with potential clients. Use LinkedIn well, and you'll see your network expand. So for Pete's sake, take advantage of this great business and networking tool that was made just for you!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: linkedin
Stop Complaining About LinkedIn. Instead, Use it Effectively.
Jen's not sure why people don't effectively use LinkedIn. She's flustered about it, but she's got some solid tips to help.

item.title: 4 Ways Having Fun Offline Is Good For Online Marketing
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Remember when ranking well in search was 1. easy 2. effective for your business and 3. super cheap? And then came Google's algorithm updates that destroyed cheap SEO because marketers had to start acting like people again instead of algorithm-dodging robots. Ranking well can be great if your website has a strong conversion strategy in place, but as we know, ranking well isn't everything. Here are four relatively easy and inexpensive ways that I encourage all our clients to market themselves offline to help build online visibility.

1. Hosting an event is fun

Hosting an event can be easy and cheap, or it can be incredibly difficult and expensive. We've hosted both kinds of events here at Commerce Kitchen, and they've both been valuable. In early 2013 we hosted an open house for all our clients, friends, and neighbors. We got a food truck to cater, had plenty of beer and wine, and had a great turnout. Last month we hosted an event called Built in Brews that brought out tons of people from the startup community to network, shmooze, eat Illegal Pete's, and vote on their favorite cocktails. Both of those events were expensive, involving caterers, lots of drinks, and marketing materials like banners, postcards, etc. We also host weekly Wine Fridays, where we invite friends, potential employees, and clients to come drink wine with us at the end of the day. It's much less expensive, but also smaller scale than the big parties. At Wine Fridays we never have more than four or five guests at once, but it gives us the chance to talk with each of them in depth, rather than trying to network with 100 drunk startup employees. You can host something small or large, or some of each, but being a good host shows your community that you like to provide them with a place to socialize, have fun, and get to know people without there being a sales pitch involved. For each of these events there were dozens of people who checked in and posted photos on social, tweeted about us, and blogged about the event. All of these things were great for brand exposure.

2. Supporting nonprofits is fun

[caption id="attachment_5961" align="aligncenter" width="625"] Our fundraiser for the Rocky Mountain Down Syndrome Association.[/caption] A few months ago we launched a social media contest for the best photo of an office dog. We are big fans of office dogs; we have anywhere from two to four dogs hanging out at the Firehouse every day. We asked local businesses to submit photos of their dogs, and we agreed to donate $1 for every vote cast. The money went to Freedom Service Dogs, a wonderful nonprofit that trains shelter dogs to be service animals. After we made our donation, two volunteers from the organization came out to show us one of their dogs-in-training. It was so cool to see the dog in action, and the photo contest itself generated brand awareness while doing something good for the community. Next month Commerce Kitchen's staff is heading out to Zuma's Horse Rescue to volunteer. While we don't have a plan on how to harness this into a marketing effort, we don't really need one. We're excited to check out what they do and hope we can contribute. Don't be afraid or modest about talking about supporting the nonprofits that you support; these organizations need community assistance to survive, and they will almost always be happy to give you a shout back on social media or their blog.

3. Joining an alumni group is fun

If you went to college, chances are there's an alumni group in your city that you can join. Michelle and I recently hung out with some local Reed College graduates, including a former Colorado Supreme Court justice. We ate some insanely good chile rellenos and talked about life in Denver, Shakespeare, and our kids. It was a fabulously fun evening, and we made some great connections for ourselves and for Commerce Kitchen. Alumni want to help each other. The sense of camaraderie that alumni have for each other is unique. While you may have gone to college in an entirely different decade, there's still the feeling that you went through something together. While attending these events won't necessarily result in a measurable online marketing boost, connecting with others that you have something in common with will still help your business in the long-run through referrals.

4. Giving gifts is fun

I love giving gifts. I love picking out just the right thing for someone, knowing that it'll make them feel good. I feel this way about giving gifts to my friends, my daughter, and our clients. One of the CK partners bought a home last year using this Denver realtor, and as a thank you the realtor sent her a bottle of wine every month, for an entire year. Needless to say, when it was time for me to buy a house last month, I chose Red Door to help me. While the wine wasn't the only reason I chose to work with her (she is seriously awesome), it certainly helped keep her on the top of our collective Commerce Kitchen mind all year. Do this! Make sure you're always on your clients' minds. Even if you don't expect more business from that one client, referrals are incredibly powerful. You can also send fun and interesting gifts to bloggers and other influential online voices who may be likely to post about it. These shouldn't be done as bribes, obviously. Before you decide to do something like this make sure you're doing it for the good of it, even if you get nothing out of it. It's highly likely that it will benefit you in the end, but if that's your only goal then it's not worth it.
These four things are much more fun than keyword research and Adwords monitoring (I can say that, I do keyword research and Adwords monitoring every day), and they will complement your other marketing efforts.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 4 Offline Things to Do to Help Your Online Marketing
Natalie talks about four fun things CK has done that have boosted marketing efforts online. And so can you!
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/04/watson-love-power-knowledge/

item.title: Fresh Out of College? Go Work at a Start-Up
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_5927" align="alignright" width="240"] No longer an intern. No longer stressed.[/caption] About this time last year, right before I graduated from DU, I was in a state of panic. Sure, I was an intern at this great company called Commerce Kitchen (which may/may not be considered a start-up, based on who you ask), but what was I going to do after graduation? Was I still going to be an intern? Was I going to get hired on full-time? Or - the worst possibility of them all - would I have to start from scratch after moving back in with Mom & Dad in San Francisco? Thanks to all of those aching, burning questions, April and May of 2013 were probably two of the most stressful months of my entire life. I am not being dramatic here. I've had a whole year to reflect on last Spring, so I can say with utter confidence that the final two months of your college career are the absolute worst, mainly because of the uncertainty and anxiety of your future that plague your thoughts daily. The reality of the situation is that many college graduates, despite their pretty degrees and big dreams, are not ready for life in the corporate world. I certainly wasn't. Imagine this: you spend four years telling your dog it can act like a dog and run free with the other dogs. Then one day, you lock it in a room full of cats for the rest of its life. That's exactly what graduating college feels like. College simply does not properly prepare its students to join the workforce, the business world, or even the adult world. We're an immature and selfish generation. We're dreamers and cynics. We're socially liberal and fiscally conservative. We're up to our eyeballs in student loans because we were told we could go to whatever university we wanted to.

That is why the start-up world is the best place for anyone fresh out of college.

Although we are a selfish, cynical, and broke generation, we have redeeming qualities. And the start-up world is perfect for us. It's no secret: I love my job. I love this company. I love working with people who are passionate, motivated, and innovative. Not to mention, it's a really fun place to work (we have office dogs and pigs). And honestly, now that it's been ten whole months since I graduated, I can't imagine working anywhere else. And of course, a lot of that has to do with the start-up community itself. I could talk about the amazingness of Colorado start-ups over Silicon Valley/San Francisco start-ups until I'm blue in the face, but I won't do that. To keep it brief, much of what I believe about why start-ups are great for postgrads has to do with the warm, inviting nature of companies in Denver and Boulder. You have to admit it: we postgrads are depressing creatures. However, we have the means and the ability to succeed. The start-up world is exactly the place for us to begin our lives after college. Then again, maybe I spend too much time with people over the age of 25.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hey College Grads: Go Work for a Start-Up | Commerce Kitchen
Many college graduates, despite their pretty degrees and big dreams, are not ready for life in the corporate world. Jen certainly wasn't.

item.title: 45 Thoughts You Have When You Attend Built-In Brews at iTriage
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
I'm 4-for-4 with Built-In Brews right now. So when I say that last night's event at iTriage was an experience in and of itself, I mean it. These are some things that went through my mind during my time at iTriage last night.
1. Cool building. Kinda swanky. I wonder if it has any historical significance. Oh look! Check-in! 2. Wow, that was a really long elevator trip. They're only on the 5th floor, right? Maybe it felt so long because of the annoying man getting off at the 3rd floor that wanted to make awkward conversation. 3. Finally, we're here. Okay, what's happening? 4. I'm confused. Why do I have two directions to choose from? [caption id="attachment_5989" align="alignleft" width="1228"] Photo: 23rdstudios[/caption] 5. Do I want pizza or do I want beer? Decisions, decisions. 6. Beer it is. Oh man. They have kegs. Like in college. 7. I hate pouring from kegs. I always feel like an amateur. 8. WHY IS THIS BEER SO FOAMY?? HELP. 9. Don't panic. You'll just come back later after the foam goes down. 10. Looks like the iTriage peeps have matching t-shirts. 11. Their t-shirts match their hats. 12. And the cups. 13. Jeez, iTriage is fancy. Using an oscillator to measure how much beer is left in the kegerator. 14. Root beer floats?! That's awesome. [caption id="attachment_5993" align="aligncenter" width="1233"] Photo: 23rdstudios[/caption] 15. Too bad I'm lactose intolerant. A root beer float sounds really delicious right now. 16. I recognize that girl from the gSchool website. 17. I need to get away from the beer. There's a lot of body heat around me right now. 18. That's cool that they're playing movies on their TVs. 19. Wow, I haven't seem Dumb and Dumber in years. 20. Ah, that's where the pizza is. I'm starving. 21. Everywhere I look I see someone in an iTriage shirt. I think there's more of them than there are of us.  22. A photo booth! I wonder if they got the idea from Quick Left's Built-In Brews. [caption id="attachment_5997" align="aligncenter" width="1233"] Photo: 23rdstudios[/caption] 23. Oh wait, I'm back by the elevators. How did I get here? 24. IT'S A CIRCLE. I finally get it. 25. Back at the beer. Time to get some more, now that my beer has de-foamed itself. 26. Man, it's STILL foamy! 27. Uh oh, I think I over-poured. Time to eat/drink this foam mountain. 28. Why is it so hot in here?! 29. Can't they open a window or something? 30. Do they have A/C? Someone should turn on the A/C. Otherwise I might pass out. 31. MY EARS!! WHAT IS THAT SCREECHING NOISE??? 33. A fire alarm? Really? I'm not even done with my beer! 34. Is this a drill? 35. Are we actually evacuating the building? 36. If we're evacuating, then I'm taking my beer with me. 35. So many stairs. I forgot we were on the 5th floor. 36. I'm glad no one is taking this too seriously, since all 200 of us are standing on this patio. 37. Hey, look! Firemen! 38. I'm so glad I still have my beer. 39. I wonder which one of us pulled the alarm. 40. Aw, the firemen are leaving. Bye, firemen! 41. Should I go back up there? It's five flights of stairs. 42. My ears are still ringing from that deafening alarm. 43. Eh, I still have my beer. I'll hang out outside for a while since it's so nice down here. 44. I don't really want this plastic iTriage cup, but I guess I'll take it with me anyways. 45. Where's the nearest bar?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: built-in brews
45 Thoughts You Have When You Attend Built-In Brews at iTriage
Jen attended Built-In Brews at iTriage last night. Things got confusing and loud.

item.title: Something There Is That Loves a Wall
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Ah, open offices. They're the preferred layout for startups and hip companies showing off their space to potential hires. They foster creativity. They create a culture of openness and collaboration. And they make a lot of us miserable.

We've written quite a bit about culture lately, and in talks about culture, creating office spaces that people actually want to work in often arises. When Commerce Kitchen first moved into an office after deciding we wanted an option other than telecommuting, the office was a small, open room where we sat together all day. Usually it was just Tynan and me, but sometimes the other staff came in to experience our newly created office culture. Some of us wore headphones; sometimes we tried to agree on music we all liked to play on the speakers. And sometimes we'd chat about problems and ideas. Overall, it worked out ok. Then we got bigger. We quickly outgrew the little space and moved to an office next door, which was one long, open room with a conference table and a media room in the back. Our paired programmers sat side by side; some of us set up standing desks against the walls. This is when I started going crazy. The sound of the programmers talking through issues meant that I had an incredibly difficult time focusing on my tasks. I have what I call audial ADD. I don't know if that's a real thing or not, but when I am exposed to certain types of sounds--especially talking--my brain cannot focus. I can't tune it out, and then I turn into a very grumpy owl. Putting on headphones sometimes helped, but music actually decreases productivity in many cases, and I noticed this was true for me. [caption id="attachment_6048" align="alignleft" width="300"] The bullpen is much emptier than it used to be.[/caption] About a year after our second office, we moved into the Firehouse, which is a wonderful building with a very strange layout. Initially most of us worked in the bullpen. It's the biggest, most open room on the top floor of the building. We had at least seven people working out of this room, and several of our devs who do a lot of Google Hangouts chose instead to work in closed office spaces so they could hear better on calls and chats. Over the past year and a half we've had an exodus from the bullpen. What initially seemed like the most desirable room in the building now receives mixed emotions. We've found that people really love having the option of closing a door to work for a while. Collaboration is hugely important, but no one has a job that is 100% collaborative, and even if there were a job out there like that we would probably be miserable. People like to solve problems independently and it's sometimes incredibly empowering and rewarding to isolate yourself for a few hours or even a day to hammer out a project or task that you've been dealing with for a while. Just like brainstorming, which isn't actually very effective, working in constant collaboration can be draining, time consuming, and ultimately not productive. Don't get me wrong: productivity isn't the only thing that matters in business. We don't want people to be solely focused on productivity, pumping out code and creative ideas like automatons. We want people to be happy. But most of us are happier when we feel productive. We want to contribute. We want to do it well. And we want to work in space that allows us to do so. Our challenge now is to figure out how to create more spaces for independent and quiet work time without sacrificing the community feel and idea-bouncing that come from open spaces like the bullpen. As we grow we'll need more sanctuaries for those of us who need quiet and privacy, but we'll also need to give people who love working physically close to others that option as well. While we don't want to wall anyone in or wall anyone out for the sake of creating office competition and distrust, sometimes good fences make (for) good and happy workers.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Problems With Open Offices: Something There Is That Loves a Wall
Open office plans are all the rage, but sometimes they just make us miserable.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/04/problems-with-open-offices/

item.title: Your Second, Third or Fourth "New" Website
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Let's just get this out there: too many people spend too much time, money and effort building a smart, shiny, new website, just to let it die a painful Joffrey-like death. And while many of us are thankful that he's no longer inflicting his sadism on the realm, I doubt you feel the same way about your website.

Think Back to Your Original (or Most Recent) Site Build

You may have started with good intentions for your marketing website:
  • Yes, we'll have an audience-driven content strategy!
  • All of our team will blog!
  • We'll keep our homepage interesting!
  • We'll reassess keyword strategy monthly!
  • We'll use onsite analytics to inform iterations!
  • We'll adjust funnels based on conversion rates!
But unfortunately, as my mother liked to say when I was trying to get myself out of my latest childhood scrape, the road to hell is paved with good intentions. Suddenly you wake up two, three, four years later and wonder why your website is no longer working for you. And then you realize it's because you haven't done any of the things you set out to do. You relied on your website as a "thing" (that now reflects the older, outdated version of your brand) rather than a "tool" for spreading your marketing message and engaging with your audience.

What Can You Do Differently This Time Around?
