Now that you're stuck in a place you don't want to be, and your CMO is breathing down your neck to drive increased conversions and value online, you're starting over, in a similar, if not the same, place you were two, three, four years ago.

Set a Realistic Scope

Didn't blog the first time around? Unless your culture has changed and embraces content creation as a key part of serving your clients, don't try. Maybe start smaller with a plan to refresh onsite content on your driver pages monthly based on your heat mapping and analytics data. Set functional goals that can achieve and make an effort at capitalizing on those. And for goodness sake, set overall site goals so you know the value of your investment. Way too many potential clients have NO idea what they want their site to do. You have no business making that kind of investment if you don't know what you are trying to achieve (seriously, if that's you, how do you still have a marketing job!?).

Tell a Benefit-Driven Story

Your sales team is probably continually refining and evolving their elevator speeches, and reassessing the company's value proposition for each audience with whom they engage. Put that effort to work, and reflect those benefits / values on your site. As the pitch changes, so to should your website. But remember, your website is your chance to engage your audience, tell a compelling story and hopefully, start a conversation. Don't just shout at visitors. Prompt discovery and action by engaging them with the right message and benefit appeal at their pace -- not yours.

Educate Yourself

We're all busy. And it can be difficult to stay a pace with the pace of technology, especially if you were caught in a period of stasis for several years. But you owe it to your marketing department to inform yourself, and explore some of the latest opportunities in site development: responsive design, test-driven development, Sass, etc. And you need to understand the teams necessary to make your web project a success, and how they work together:
  • Brand Team - reassessing brand value, iterating on your brand, updating look and feel, etc.
  • Web Development & UX Team - building your site architecture, designing your site to improve user experience, and integrating all third party systems
  • IT Team - setting up server environments, and managing hosting and domains
  • Inbound Marketing / SEO Team - optimizing your site to maximize traffic, engagement and conversions, and mining analytics for opportunities
You don't have to know everything -- that's why you hire expert vendors that you trust -- but you do have to know how to ask probing questions to make sure you are capitalizing on your investment.

Put Good In, Get Good Out

Many times when we speak with clients, they don't know what they want their new site to do (see the goals section above), and they know they have a set budget that's driving decision making. Instead of budget driving site decisions, how about we switch to a conversation about CRM and ROI? If we can increase your incremental return by X%, and increase the lifetime value of a visitor by Y%, that should justify your investment in your website and much more. Don't build just to build. And don't buy just because you have a budget. Have a reason. Have a goal. Have a game plan. If a vendor takes your $40k to build what you want without vetting your goals and the potential business return, you are going to end up with another $40k thing and NOT a tool. And you'll be in the same place AGAIN in another couple of years. Insanity. And that arbitrary $40k is worthless if it doesn't return the money necessary to justify the expense. Better to have spent an informed $80k on an integrated team to build your site because it returns value quickly than to throw $40k away on development only. Put good in -- smart business decisions, competent vendors, clear site goals, scalable development -- and you'll get good out -- a website that engages, converts and grows with your business. Are there other steps that you would take before investing in another website? Agree or disagree?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Be Smarter About Developing a "New" Second, Third, or Fourth Website
When you address your new website build focus on four critical areas to ensure the value of your investment and continued success of your online presence.

item.title: Nootropics and Brain Health
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded:
I'm a software developer here at Commerce Kitchen, and the majority of my day I spend thinking through problems I've either created for myself or problems a client needs fixes to. In my previous forms of employment, I could roll into work hungover with carpet marks still on my face, drink some coffee, and power through the day. However, here at CK my job function is mostly dependent on my brain, which sadly, is barely satisfactory when I'm well rested and not suffering from the throes of irresponsible late night nonsense-ness. My job provides me with resources like food and shelter, which is important because being cold and hungry is no fun.  So I'm always on the hunt for things that will help to keep my brain plastic and strong, and thus hopefully staying employed.  Which is what brought me to the fun world of nootropics.

What are nootropics?

Well, a really ambiguous definition is simply, "smart drugs": they're meant to give you cognitive enhancement in a variety of areas.  There are a lot of them, and they affect different realms of cognition: memory, concentration, motivation, endurance etc…

What are they not?

NZT-48, from the movie Limitless. You're not going to make the transition from a dullard to Kim Ung-Yong by pouring a little powder in your morning smoothie.

How do they work?

Each one has different mechanisms, but in general they work with three major systems of the brain, the Cholineric, Glutamatergic and Dopaminergic/Serotonergic Systems. There is an abundance of informative sources on the web, though a good starting place that is unaffiliated with any particular vendor is the @Reddit. My experience, has been that nootropics are certainly beneficial, and highly recommended to anyone looking for a cognitive edge. I used to take Adderall when I needed a boost to solve a particularly hard issue, or work long hours to meet deadlines. Although it is effective, it does have it's share of negatives, including dependency, neurotoxicity and cost. You'll find with most noots that you don't get the buzz that amphetamine based stimulants (Ritalin/Adderall) provide, but you'll still get healthier cognitive gains including increased concentration, without the neurotoxicity. So before you go online shopping and spend hundreds of dollars on various powders and compounds, consider the 'low hanging fruit' of cognitive aids. The most crucial being good quality sleep, it's affordable and benefits your entire being, not just your brain. Go to bed early, the sleep you get from 10pm-6am is of higher quality than from 1am - 9am, and certainly better than the 1am-6am variety. This can also be helped with well timed melatonin supplements. Another easy win is routinely getting some exercise, there are numerous studies showing the cognitive benefits of getting 30 minutes of decent aerobic exercise.  Remember: blood flow is crucial to a healthy brain, and getting your heart properly pumping from time to time keeps your circulatory system in working order.

Things to keep in mind:

-Most if not all nootropics are unregulated by the FDA, so it's important to know what is actually in what you're ordering. Most good vendors should provide you with a 3rd party COA (certificate of analysis) so you'll have an idea of the purity of what you're ordering. -Research on many of these drugs is sparse at best and you'll find the internet is littered with mountains of anecdotal evidence, but do your homework before jumping into anything.  Ones that have stood the test of time and are deemed reasonably safe are Piracetam + Choline, and Caffeine + L-Theanine. -When starting a new 'stack,' take one at a time to get a feel for it's benefits, then slowly add in others, it's impossible to know which ones are working if you start them all at once. -Be careful with dosing. Many come in powder form and it's easy to miscalculate how much you're taking, triple check your measurements.

What kinds of things to do you to stay at your most productive?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Nootropics and Brain Health | Commerce Kitchen
nootropics
There are many different kinds of cognitive boosters out there, so how are nootropics different? Productivity increases, in Kevin's experience.

item.title: A Search for the Ideal Bourbon Drinker
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
I love bourbon. I love its vanilla, charred aroma. I love its smooth, caramel-oak-smoke taste. I love how its amber color catches the light in a rocks glass at twilight. I love bourbon so much that I named my tawny-colored dog after my go-to sipper, Woodford. I love to talk about bourbon (lightning talks!), and will drink a mint julep pretty much anytime, anywhere. So I was really excited when folks started talking about the first Woodford Reserve TV spot, Bookshelf, from Brown-Forman, which aired during the Mad Men season premiere. But the backlash was swift and decisive. Sexist. Weird. Narrow minded. Many of my Facebook friends sent me links to the articles, knowing my love of the stuff. And I am torn.

Am I like the woman narrating the VO?

When I see a man drinking bourbon, I expect him to be the kind who could build me a bookshelf. But not in the way that one builds a ready-made bookshelf. He will already know where the lumberyard is. He’ll get the right amount of wood without having to do math. He’ll let me use the saw, and not find it cute that I don’t know how to use the saw.

Yes, I want you to be that man

I love seeing a stylized version of you. I love coyly glancing at your hot body with your hipster-aesthetic (oh, man eye candy). I love thinking of you and "your way" as the embodiment of such sublime drink. I want you, my bourbon-drinking man, to build me hand-crafted things because you love me that much. I want you to be rustic, yet a refined doer. I want you to teach me things. *swoon*

No, I can do things on my own

I like math. Is the line offensive to me? No, but it is silly -- of course you will at least mentally use math (or have used it before if you've crafted bookshelves for countless flames in the past...let's not go there). I imagine that this line was some distilled down, and yet watered down, (bourbon's always on the brain) take on a more verbose, stronger original line that wouldn't fit in a 30 second spot. But how this line became the best synopsis and made it past creative review, I can only guess. And while I appreciate the sentiment that rather than thinking I am cute for my inability to use saw, he'll view my ignorance as a learning opportunity, I think the issue isn't that line, it's the one before it: "He'll let me use the saw." Come again? "Let me"!? What kind of attitude is that? In my married world, I own half of that saw, can use it and can build my own damn bookshelf, thank you very much.

Let's change the conversation

How about switch the order of those last lines and modify them a bit?
He'll not find it cute that I don't know how to use the saw. He'll teach me, and we'll build something great together.
You keep the aspiration. You keep the sentiment. But you transcend stereotypes, and embrace what bourbon, and drinking in general, are all about: collaboration and community. The yet-to-air Couple spot actually does this a bit better than any of the other campaign spots. It balances the vision of the ideal bourbon drinker with the collaboration and community that surrounds a drinking culture. On all of the gender-targeted spots, change the copy (and maybe the weird music), but keep the visuals. By using highly stylized stills and clips of beautiful people, you give a nod to bourbon's appeal as a speakeasy-era secret club, and maintain some of the elitism necessary to sustain a premium brand. It would be great to see not only opposite genders building their ideal bourbon-drinking love interests, but gender agnostic takes on the best parts of their favorite bourbon drinkers: best buds, grandfathers, people that light up the room, people that make you braver, stronger, better. I'd love you even more, want to drink you even more, and aspire to be that ideal even more. And while I'd love to distillers to become more inclusive and embrace the multidimensional drinkers that serve, change is difficult and slow, especially in an industry that *thinks* it has relied on one kind of drinker for the last 100 years. Whether you love the spots, or hate them, they are at least prompting conversation and still selling bourbon -- the end game even in advertising dedicated to brand building. Just my two cents, Woodford Reserve. If you ever need brand advice, I'll take payment with a lifetime supply of bourbon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Woodford Reserve's TV Spot: Search for the Ideal Bourbon Drinker
Seen the Woodford Reserve spot? Sexist, weird, narrow minded? No, a missed opportunity to discover bourbon drinking ideals that inspire and build community.
woodford reserve

item.title: *SPOILER ALERT* The 'Net is Dark and Full of Spoilers
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Note from the author: I hope you like spoiler-free pop culture references. Because this post is FULL OF 'EM.

Listen up, Internet. It's time to come to an agreement about spoilers.

For those of you that have been living under a rock, spoilers are those ginormous details from movies, tv shows, books, etc. that essentially turn an ordinary plot line into a genius piece of fiction. And the Internet is currently riddled with them.

That's right! RIDDLED.

Haven't watched Breaking Bad all the way through? TOO BAD. Some random person on your Twitter feed is going to spoil it for you.

Missed last week's episode of Scandal? Sucks for you! Your coworker is going to go on and on about the newest plot twist until she goes blue in the face.

Not caught up on The Big Bang Theory? BAZINGA. Spoilers are going to come at you from all directions of the universe!

For instance, I could talk about the huge, MAJOR event that happened on Game of Thrones on last Sunday, but I have no intention of being a total jerk, a la Joffrey, in this post. So if you haven't read the Divergent series yet, what are you supposed to do? Stay off the internet until you're done with the final page of the final book? That seems a bit dramatic. And unfair. And unnecessary. It's the Internet! Filled with information and beautiful photos and cat videos! You shouldn't have to quit the Internet just because you haven't seen Captain America: The Winter Soldier yet. You've been busy. A trip to the movie theater is a luxury your schedule just won't allow right now.

But what are we supposed to do about these spoilers? They're everywhere! And they're multiplying like Gremlins!

Internet, I propose we form a pact. A spoiler-free pact. Because let's face it: y'all are getting outta hand. You're dangerous. Your egos are writing checks your bodies can't cash. If we're going to work together to make the Internet a better place, we need to agree to keep our spoilers to a dull roar. Don't make your Facebook status about how season one of Orange is the New Black ends. Don't tweet about the [catastrophic event that was] the How I Met Your Mother series finale. Don't gChat me about the another surprising murder in House of Cards when I'm still only halfway through the first season. Photos need to be spoiler-free too. And hey, I get it. Social media rules in favor of photos, but when the photos include characters that come out of nowhere to mess with the main character of a show, I have a serious problem. What if I hadn't already watched - and finished in two days - Season 1 of Orphan Black?? This post would have dragged me into the seventh circle of spoiler hell.

So don't be the Jim Moriarty of social media. Keep your spoilers to a minimum, and we'll all be much happier.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: spoilers
*SPOILER ALERT* The 'Net is Dark and Full of Spoilers
Note from the author: I hope you like spoiler-free pop culture references. Because this post is FULL OF 'EM.

item.title: Elevated Rails in Chicago: Gearing Up for RailsConf 2014
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded: Rails systems were first established in Chicago in 1892. They have a long, colorful and productive history that is shared by millions. Ten years ago, a new system was established in Chicago, but that Rails system was a software framework. Since that time, when Rails first stepped into the spotlight, the web has not been the same. Rails was not created by the CTA, but like the trains that run on rails in Chicago, Rails is used and shared by millions. Rails was built using Ruby, a solid, object oriented language with a ten year history in 2004. It's a joy to program in Ruby, and with Rails, developing larger networked systems sharing lots of data can be accomplished in a fraction of the time required by other languages. Ruby on Rails gets you to your destination in less time and with less effort. To mark it's 10th anniversary, the annual Rails Conference will be held in the city where it began, Chicago, IL. And there will likely be some reverie, curiosities, and well-earned celebrations. It has been a while since I've been to Rails Conf, during an evolutionary year for Rails and the community. It was 2009, the year that Rails 3 was to be released. It also marked the resolution of some major internal controversies and battles between two camps of how to best proceed. This significant hurdle was not only overcome, but the community showed it's cohesive strength and maturity by merging the ideas together to make an even stronger and richer framework for the future. And here we are, in that future. The community is stronger than ever, and Rails has been operating in version 4 for nearly a year. The improvements are significant, impressive, and yet subtle. There is more maturity at work, serving an even wider range of both simple and massive applications with even more agility, networking and sophisticated data capabilities. In the week ahead, David Heinemeier Hansson (DHH), creator of Ruby on Rails, will irritate some, and inspire most. Aaron Patterson will completely bedazzle us. Yehuda Katz will awe everyone at his usual lighting pace. The sessions will intrigue, mystify and illuminate the way for our cadre of CK superhero developers with even more secure, diverse and responsive applications for clients, who realize tomorrow has already happened, and beyond next week is the right focus for today. Eric, Kevin, and I from the Commerce Kitchen dev team will be attending this year's RailsConf. Personally, I think I should've packed my lab coat so I could be recognized. Einstein didn't come either because he hates to fly in that crate (If he could talk, I'm sure he'd take the DeLorean ahead a few years and lobby for better in-flight animal treatment). If you do recognize any of us, please stop us and say hi. We're really quite approachable and love to talk tech!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: railsconf
Elevated Rails in Chicago: Gearing Up for RailsConf 2014
It's been a while since Russ attended RailsConf in Chicago, but he's really looking forward to getting some knowledge and know-how this year.

item.title: Love and Power? Elementary, My Dear Watson
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Two years after the original Star Wars was released, I was born into a home full of scifi addicts (let's not debate whether Star Wars is scifi or fantasy; for the sake of this blog post I'm going to lump it into scifi: it uses advanced technology, not yet available to us.) My sister and brother, ten and nine years older than me, had all the Star Wars toys. Some of my first memories include riding piggy back on my brother, as he pretended to be a tauntaun bouncing around the icy surface of Hoth. I wasn't immediately drawn to scifi the way the rest of my family was. When Back to the Future came out shortly before my sixth birthday, I remember whining about having to go see it at the theater. But after I got past my initial grumblings, I fell madly in love. To this day I can quote almost every line from it. After that, I watched ALL THE SCIFI, but I especially loved, and still love, those that explored philosophical and ethical dilemmas, and didn't just focus on Dudes Doing Manly Stuff But On Another Planet. Battlestar Galactica. 2001. Star Trek. Fast forward a few decades. I'm sitting at a health conference a couple weeks ago, and a representative from IBM's Watson team shows this video. Please watch this.
If that doesn't seem like a propaganda commercial shown at the beginning of EVERY SCIFI MOVIE EVER MADE to foreshadow the destruction of humankind, then I don't know what does. I think Watson is exciting. So were the cylons. Siri is fun, especially when she horribly botches my texts and responds to my questions with equivocation. HAL was charming, too. And let's not forget Google's goal to mimic human behavior. Not unlike the Terminator. But before I get on my nihilistic and ludditious soapbox about machine learning, please understand that most of my brain formation occurred in the 1980s. It was the end of the Cold War. They were making movies like War Games, Blade Runner, Terminator, Alien. Androids, robots, and cyborgs weren't often heroes, and when they were they were either helping us fight other androids/robots/cyborgs, or they were helping us fight aliens. Oddly, I'm not afraid of space exploration bringing about the wrath of aliens, but that's a topic for another blog. I would like to point out, though, that the idea of nonhuman entities mastering what we consider to be human skills has been scaring the shit out of humans for the entire course of written history.

The Ever-Present Nonhuman Human

The golem, a human-shaped piece of clay who appears in the Torah, and then becomes much more animated (pun intended) in the Talmud, is one of the earlier examples of an anthropomorphized human-like being. A golem wasn't a creature to be feared initially, because it could be controlled. If a certain word was inscribed on the golem's forehead, the mound of clay would come alive. The golem could similarly be turned back into plain old clay by removing the word. Usually a golem represented spiritual fulfillment, and/or it would defend and protect its creators. But there is at least one story of a golem going on a murderous rampage when it accidentally fell in love. The idea of statues coming to life has also persisted in literature, but industrialization definitely moved these creatures into the realm of advanced and hyperadvanced technology. The 1920 play R.U.R. deals with a robot-based economy, where cyborgs make up the bulk of labor, and humans become less important. Eventually the robots become smarter than they were before and in this newly-found intelligence they decide they want more power. And this is what it comes down to, isn't it? Love and power. We understand machine learning. We don't have too much of a problem with robots processing information, and Watson is okay as long as he(?) helps us with our health problems or somehow makes our lives easier.

Love and Power

What we're scared of with artificial intelligence is exactly what makes human existence so difficult. We fall in love and we desire power. Those two concepts don't actually seem to have much to do with intelligence. We could argue that they're remnants of our limbic brains, and if it were up to our frontal lobes we'd be more like Watson. But we also use machines for purposes of love and power. Match.com and OkCupid use algorithms to pair people up. The machine knows that if you like pomeranians, long walks on the beach, and lavender-scented pomade, then you'll probably be compatible with XYZ. If we allowed Watson to be our robotic shadchan, learning from our online behaviors, comparing us to others like us, then maybe every match he made would be perfect. Likewise, governments seeking power are ravenous for more knowledge. The CIA could (and probably does?) use Watson to read and process millions of text messages, and he'd probably be scarily accurate in predicting when and where the next terrorist attack would occur. But we're not as afraid of the power and potential for love that machines like Watson give us humans; instead, we're afraid of the machines desiring that power and love. When the cylons fall in love with humans, things get a little complicated. When Skynet craves power, it nearly destroys everyone. We can program a computer or robot to do whatever we want.
But what scares us more than anything is the idea that the computer could program itself to do whatever it wants. Learning is one thing. Desire is another. I don't think this fear is enough to stop us from trying. I think we'll try and try to create an intelligence that not only processes natural language and returns precise results to our questions, but one that gives us an emotional connection, like in Her. We want answers to our questions, we want speedy access to knowledge, but that's not enough. We're all rooting for the Tin Man to get a heart and for the Scarecrow to get a brain. Be more like us. Be better than us. And please, warn us when this happens.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Love & Power? Elementary, My Dear Watson
Is machine learning scary? Natalie argues that it's not knowledge that scares us, but the potential that knowledge will lead to love and power.
watson
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/04/watson-love-power-knowledge/

item.title: Why Good Service Matters in Tech
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
I know I keep talking about that trip I took to Portland in February, but bear with me one more time, because a conversation I had there keeps coming back to me, and it's resonating with me even more now that CK is immersed in a hiring process. Part of the gig that took me to Portland was a kind of professional speed-dating event with undergrads at my alma mater, Reed College. It was the kind of thing where college students get to have 5 minutes of your time to ask questions that will hopefully give them insight into the world of work that lay beyond the walls of the ivory tower. In preparation, I was asked to submit a brief professional profile. There were questions about my background, my post-Reed education, etc, and also one of those questions along the lines of "If you could give soon-to-be graduates one bit of advice, what would it be?" My response to that was "Get a service job and stick with it for a while. Wait tables. Sling coffee. Fill up gas tanks at the local Texaco. Work in a bookstore. Anything."

Note: Hard Work Usually Comes *Before* the Payoff

During that speed-dating event, a student scheduled 5 minutes of my time just to ask this question (and I'm not at all exaggerating, which is admittedly rare for me): "Why should I get a service job? I want a prestigious job." Quote, unquote. A 22-ish-year old student with almost no work experience, and, if I recall, a BA in fine art, had her sites set upon a "prestigious job," and didn't seem to grok that she might have to bust her a$$ in the trenches for a while to get there. After gracelessly picking my jaw up off the table, I gave her some insight into why I think it's important - among other great lessons, she might learn a little humility. But since then, the importance of a service orientation has been on my mind a lot. We're hiring. We're focusing on gelling our company culture so that even while we build the company, we can all continue to be proud of it every day. We're dealing with an influx of work that is making it more challenging to maintain the same level of service we like to offer while we staff up. These things all keep bringing me back to the value of a service orientation for a company like Commerce Kitchen, and for every one of the supersmart wondernerds that work here (and that will work here, for any of you aspiring superheroes that may be reading). And still, sometimes, it occurs to me that a lot of folks don't get why a service orientation is absolutely required to do the kind of work we do at the level we do it.

Service As Leadership

The curt truth of the matter is that most of our clients do not understand technology like we do. They need help making the right decisions for their companies, and they need guidance in understanding the stuff involved - from process to programming. If they didn't need that help, they wouldn't need us. It's easy to forget that when you're the kind of person that people might call a supersmart wondernerd. The stereotype of the over-confident and condescending tech geek is a stereotype for a reason. He's the guy that tries to fix the problem before you've explained it, whose ego overshadows your problem, and who usually leaves things worse off than he found them, but is clueless about your experience of him as horrible. After all, he fixed what he thought was your problem. I suspect you've all encountered this character. And I suspect that most of you really hope you never have to again. I hope you never have to, either.
There are *literally* billions of web dev shops all over the world (*exaggeration, maybe*) and plenty in Denver that can get the job done to some varying degree of satisfaction. But what makes Commerce Kitchen and shops like us a little bit different is that we try to do so with our eye focused on 2 things at the same time: quality craftsmanship and exceptional service. That exceptional service requires a lot of humility, a lot of patience, and a lot of question asking. These are probably not traits you associate with your last company's IT guy. This kind of approach requires us to spend a lot more time understanding problems, so that we can solve them more efficiently and completely.

Sounds Hard. Why bother?

Commerce Kitchen has invested a lot of time and effort into building strong community networks and a meaningful reputation for high performance sites and web software. We're not the most expensive shop in town by a long, long shot, but we're not an Eastern European bargain shop either. The value we deliver isn't just in beautiful code (though it is there, too), but in thoughtful attention to our clients' needs. To deliver the kind of high performance sites and software we pride ourselves on, we have to give a lot of attention to the intentions and needs both of our clients and of theirs. We need to intuit and decipher and translate on behalf of our clients. We can't do that if we're not paying very close attention. Some 80% or more of our business is from referrals. Our customers love us, so they share our names with their colleagues. If we fail to meet that same level of expectation with every client, we'll lose that momentum, and we'll lose that esteem in the community, and we'll lose those projects. That means lost opportunities. Lots of 'em.

The Golden Rule Is Not Enough

We had an all-team meeting last week. One of those meetings the announcement of which would have sent shivers down my spine when I was a cocky recent grad busting my a$$ in the trenches of a bookstore while wondering why I couldn't just have a cushy "prestigious job," but which now I find oddly inspiring - probably because I'm working, at long last, for a company that I sort of want to hug every single day. In the meeting, Tynan, our CEO, talked a lot about why he founded CK and spent some time reminding all of us about the expectation our clients have of us and that we have of each other, and why we need to strive to meet those expectations (not exceed them - just pay attention, identify them, and meet them). He brought up the Golden Rule's lesser known but smarter cousin, The Platinum Rule. The Platinum Rule states not that you should treat others as you would want to be treated, but rather that you should treat others the way THEY want to be treated. That's a pretty simple but profound twist on things and it has a pretty radical impact on how you view customer service. It requires us to seek first to understand (hey all you Seven Habits fans out there!), which allows us to approach our clients from a position of empathy and compassion as it relates to their goals and the challenges they've entrusted us to solve on their behalf. Taking the same perspective on internal customer service allows our teams to avoid a lot of the acrimonious distractions that derail a lot of teams. [caption id="attachment_6189" align="alignright" width="300"] That is actually Fabio.  The Fabio.[/caption] When I worked at that bookstore decades ago, I discovered that I freaking LOVE customer service. It was a huge surprise - I thought I was / should have been destined for great things right out of college. At first, the thought of helping one more grandmother find just the right book for her above-average granddaughter ("Oh yes! Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats is perfect - except, did he write one about dogs? She likes dogs better.") irked me. After just trying to get better at it for a bit, though, I realized the pleasure in truly connecting someone with what they needed, what they wanted, something they might enjoy, or even just taking 5 minutes out of my day to talk to another Flannery O'Connor geek. Those customers who caught me on my better service days were always more likely to come back. They each had puzzles that I could help solve, and we had only discovered that because I'd taken the time to hear where they were coming from. I didn't recommend Flannery O'Connor to someone who came in looking for a nice romance, even though some of her stories do focus on odd courtships, for example. I got to know Danielle Steele and Diana Gabaldon; I devoured Stephen King and Patricia Cornwell. I figured out the difference between history and military history and figured out how to spot enthusiasts of both.  I tried to see the entire store from their perspective, and pointed them in the direction they wanted to be pointed. I know I wasn't always perfect at it then, and I know I'm not always great at it now, but it is always what I'm shooting for, and what I want our teams to always be shooting for. Understand the client; understand their challenges; empathize with them; and give them the best solution and best experience their money can buy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Why Good Service Matters in Tech
When hiring a development team to build you a website or app, good code is crucial. But good service matters just as much.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/04/good-service-matters-tech/

item.title: Now Hiring: Master ScrumMaster
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen's team of superheroes is getting bigger, and we hope you have what it takes to help us rein it all in, future Master ScrumMaster.

Mission

Your superhero mission is to enhance the routines and best practices of Commerce Kitchen’s existing Scrum Teams, particularly in regard to focusing daily workflow, proper story breakdown and estimation, and conducting backlog grooming. You also will be expected to enhance our customers’ experience with Commerce Kitchen and communicate our core values.

How You’ll Spend Your Time

  • [~5%] Facilitation of three stand-ups per project per week
  • [~7%] Email responses and general client communication
  • [~12%] Facilitation of one backlog grooming session per project per week
  • [~12%] Facilitation of one Retrospective and Sprint Review per sprint per project
  • [~16%] Facilitation of dev team work sessions to break down stories or solve complex problems
  • [~16%] Facilitation of one Iteration Planning Meeting (IPM) per sprint per project
  • [~32%] Embedded QA work with the dev team and ongoing feedback during the course of the sprint to ensure completed stories are truly done (done is done!).
  • All of the above overseeing two to three projects at any given time.

Goals & Expectations

The company expects to achieve the following goals:
  • For each project, have no more than a 15% average divergence between the number of points committed to during the IPM and the number of points accepted at the end of the sprint
  • Improve client trust, as recognized by engaged, happy clients
  • Improve the developer experience, as recognized by their ability to understand and deliver according to expectations without over-working or over-worrying
  • Identify and track one new thing each project that each team member can be doing better
  • Manifest a relatively consistent burn-down slope during the course of a sprint
Time for travel if required: Driving time to work sessions at the Commerce Kitchen firehouse where necessary. IPMs, Special Project Reviews, and staff work sessions are preferred to be attended in person, but can be attended virtually via Google Hangout several times per month.

Tools in Use: Kanban and Pivotal Tracker

 

Competencies & Experience

Professional

  • Effective time management
  • Ability to coach and coordinate multiple diverse teams, both in-house and remote
  • Knowledge of Scrum processes, including feature scoping, story breakdown, meeting facilitation, etc.
  • Experience with Pivotal Tracker, Rally, or similar Agile project management software

Cultural

  • Love of problem solving and creative thinking
  • Strong communication (talking, listening, follow-up/resolution)
  • Efficiency
  • Adaptability
  • Ability to learn new things quickly; Intellectual curiosity
  • Ability to see three steps ahead
  • Thoroughness (anticipation)

Benefits and Compensation

We like to think that the true benefit of working at Commerce Kitchen exists in a realm far beyond the typical HR mumbo jumbo, but we suspect that the HR mumbo jumbo is important to most folks with, you know, human bodies that need to be fed, sheltered, and maintained. So here’s the quick rundown of the rights and privileges of full-time superherodom at CK:
  • Your salary Salaries are competitive, commensurate with experience, and delivered straight to your bank account twice a month.
  • Coming Soon: 401ks This new benefit is expected to roll out in Spring or Summer of 2014
  • Health Insurance We’ve got a great plan with United Health Care, and we’ll cover 80% of your dues, and 50% of those of your dependents. Insurance is available to all permanent employees working 30 hours or more a week, and we’ll get you set up shortly after your first day on the job.
  • Professional Development Budget  You’re amazing, but we want you to be amazing-er and always on top of your professional game. It’s up to you and your direct supervisor how and when you spend this cash, but so long as it makes you better at what you do for CK, we’re down to support you!
  • EcoPass Shortly after you start, we’ll snap a mugshot of you and send it off to RTD so you can ride the bus or lightrail to work (or wherever) as often as you want.
  • Flexibility of work schedule You know your team, and you know your projects and what needs to be done. Use your judgement.
  • Unlimited PTO You’ve got a great life. Live it. Use your judgement, here, though. Like above - you know your team, projects, and what needs to be done. A CK Superhero doesn’t take an unannounced 2 week vacation to ice fish in Manitoba immediately prior to a site launch. But as a CK superhero, you need to be kind to yourself.

To Apply

Send your resume, contact information for three professional references, and a cover letter to careers@commercekitchen.com.

About Commerce Kitchen

Commerce Kitchen is a collection of Internet superheroes of all kinds. Marketing masterminds, graphic design wizards, 11th level HTML & CSS masters with a native love of responsive design, top-notch programmers, and laser-focused project managers. Together we help our clients be and do better on the web. We’ve been around since 2003, and are on a solid growth trajectory. We hope to hit a very happy, healthy plateau of about 20 employees this year. If everything above sounds great to you, we’d probably love it if you were among those 20. We hope you’ll throw your hat into the ring!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: job-master-scrummaster
Now Hiring ScrumMaster in Denver
CK is hiring a master scrum master master master superhero!

item.title: 8 Ways to Make Your Website Faster
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
It turns out that most people are impatient, and don't want to wait for your website to load past 10 seconds. Many will bail after 5 seconds.  Speed is a feature. It's not just how long everything takes according to a stop watch. You need to show something as soon as possible to avoid the dreaded white screen of death. Additional images can still load, but the page should feel usable. I think of this as the first visible time.  The "everything is done" state I call the page complete time. Psychologically, it's more important that the first visible time be quick than the page complete time. Some of these methods make more sense in light of that. I will focus on the front-end changes to speed up a website, but there are also backend changes like file and memory caching, database optimization that also need to be addressed. It doesn't matter if your front end is fast if the database take 10 seconds to load one page.

1) Make your images smaller

Make your images smaller both in file size and in pixel size. This is 70% of the battle on most pages. Use fewer images if possible too. In Ruby on Rails, add a setting like this to the Paperclip gem (the default setting is a bloated 92%. What the heck, Paperclip?) 
convert_options => { :thumb => '-quality 75 -strip', :content => '-quality 75 -strip -interlace Plane'}
The "strip" option removes EXIF and color profile information, and the esoteric "-interlace Plane" produces progressive JPGS. These start out blurry, and get clearer as they load, so, they feel faster, and for most large images, they are slightly smaller. For small images, they can be larger, which is why I did not use that option for the thumbnails. Also, those thumbnail images should be 5KB - 15KBs, so unless you're on a mobile phone, you will most likely not see the progressive effect at all. These Paperclip settings will let your users upload big files and have them show up at a good file size. You can use those same settings in the command line ImageMagick commands (convert or mogrify) to optimize existing images on your server.  Don't forget your CMS images. Color wonks may object to removing color profiles, but images should all be converted to an sRGB color space if they aren't already. Photoshop Save for Web default to this correct behavior. I could explain color profiles but acronyms like CIEXYZ make my head hurt so I won't.

2) Turn on gzip compression

Turn on gzip compression for HTML,CSS, and Javascript files. This lowers their download size by 50 - 80%. Do not turn it on for PNG and JPG images, since they are already compressed. DO turn it on for SVG images, since they are XML files and compress well. This can be done for Apache, nginx, and IIS, which covers something like 90% of web servers out there. It can also be done in a WordPress plugin. The Ruby Rails asset pipeline does this by default. Here is how to do it in nginx (check first, as it may be turned already).  Add this to the http section of nginx.conf to apply it like greased lightning to your whole site 
	gzip on;
	gzip_disable "msie6";

	gzip_vary on;
	gzip_proxied any;
	gzip_comp_level 6;
	gzip_buffers 16 8k;
	gzip_http_version 1.1;
	gzip_types text/plain text/css application/json application/x-javascript text/xml application/xml application/xml+rss text/javascript;
A handy tool to check if compression is working: http://checkgzipcompression.com/

3) Combine and minify all your CSS and JavaScript

Combine all your CSS and JavaScript into one JS and and one CSS file, and minify them. The Rails asset pipeline does this by default. (Are we sensing a theme here?).  If you don't use Rails, you can still use SASS to keep all your CSS organized into partials, and then combine into one file. This saves a lot of overhead since the overhead on downloading 20 or 30 files is much higher than 2. Minifying involves re-writing CSS and JS using various shortcuts to make the file shorter, and is especially effective with JavaScript, since variables can be renamed to single character. There are different tools to make this easier like CodeKit (for Mac OS X).

4) Load the JavaScript as close to the end of the body tag as possible.

This keeps the JavaScript from blocking the page rendering. In other words, any JavaScript loaded in the head of the page, which is the old-fashioned way of doing it that many sites still do, has to download completely before the page can render. OK, the Rails asset pipeline does not actually do this for you, but it makes it pretty easy. Even if you can't combine files, this is still worth doing, but combine both those tips for best results.

5) Consider using sprites or icon fonts

This technique can be a big help if you have lots of small images in your design. A sprite is one large image with a number of smaller images placed on it. These images are then used as background images with only the right area showing. An icon font is a special font that turns a letter like "l" into a special bullet.  Tools:  http://www.spritecow.com/, http://fontello.com/ This techniques works because for many users, the overhead involved in downloading 10 small images is much slower than the overhead involved in downloading on image. This is true even if the combined image file size is a bit larger than the individual images.

6) Choose your social media gems or plug-ins wisely

Keep an eye on your Like and Twitter buttons, Twitter buttons. Make sure that if you use a plugin or gem that it uses AJAX methods whenever possible, which will let the page load and then put the button in when it's ready. Otherwise, your page will seem slow if Pinterest is having a bad day. For instance, if you have a slideshow, find a plugin that will load only the first 2-3 slides at the beginning, and then will wait to download the rest just before they are needed.  One example is Galleria, which allows you to specify how many to load, and loads two slides by default.  If you optimize your images really well, you may need to make it three so that slide is available when you need it! Talk about being a victim of your own success.

7) Watch out for huge font files

Investigate font sub-setting unless you really need to have font character for non-Western languages. I once reduced a font file from 500KB to 40KB using this method. I used FontPrep (for Mac OS X), which is free.  Each font should be less than 50KB unless you have some very specific language requirements. Since most modern browsers will not show text until custom fonts are downloaded, you want this to be done as soon as possible. If I have control of the order, I like to put the font loading in the very beginning of the CSS or HTML file.

8) Consider using a CDN for your content

A CDN is a Content Delivery Network.  Most charge money, but this might be worth looking into if you have a big site or if you have a lot of international users.  There are a couple of free CDNs with limited plans like Cloudflare. Even if you can't afford a CDN, you can use Google fonts, which uses a CDN, and load many libraries like jQuery and modernizr from Google or another CDN for some of the same effect. Google has a lot of servers all over the world, and will make these resources load faster. Even better, if a very widespread library is already pre-loaded for another site, it will not need to be loaded again for your site.

An Extra Bonus to a Zippy Site (pun intended)

If making your website so fast your users get whiplash isn't enough incentive, Google has confirmed that speed site is a factor they consider in ranking.

Tools for Checking your website

  • http://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/
  • http://tools.pingdom.com/fpt/
Or, you know, give us a call and we'll help you with it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Make Your Website Faster

Most people don't want to wait for your website to load past 10 seconds. Many will bail after 5 seconds. Here's how you can make your website faster.

item.title: What's Up, Social Media Strategies Summit: Chicago?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
If you can believe it, there's a conference dedicated to social media.

In fact, there's a lot of them. I could have gone to any of them, but I'm kind of glad that I didn't go to San Diego's Social Media Marketing World (which was actually one of my top choices), given the weird, obnoxious thing that happened there. We're not all like that, I promise. One bad apple, and all that jazz. So, as the social media manager for Commerce Kitchen and several of our extremely diverse clients, I'm going to the Social Media Strategies Summit in Chicago next week to learn what's new in the social media world. And if you want to know how/why I chose Chicago, read this post.

What I'm Looking Forward To

Oh boy, do I love learning. And I'm going to a conference where I can learn how to get better at my job. Where I can learn what other social media managers are doing for their brands. Where I can learn what the future of social media might look like. It's like my Christmas. There are several people I'm really excited to see and hear from. Michael Bepko, the Global Community Manager for Whole Foods. Jared Schultheis and Bill Gerth from Comcast. Suzanne Fanning, President of WOMMA. I'm really intrigued to hear what these individuals, as well as the rest of the speakers and panelists at the conference, are going to say about their experiences and projections for the future.

What I'm Hoping to Take Away

Facebook has not been my friend lately. In light of their recent changes, I've become more and more anti-Facebook and pro-Twitter. But now that Twitter has updated their profile pages to become more Facebook-esque, I'm becoming very confused and worried. What's going to be the status of social media in six months? A year? Two years? I'm in a haze, and I can't really figure out how I should change my strategies to evolve with the platforms' updates. In short, I need someone to tell me that there is more to Facebook strategy than paid advertising and promoted posts. Also, I really hope someone talks about LinkedIn. It's like the forgotten middle child of social media. I'd love to hear from ANYBODY about how they are integrating it into their marketing strategy.

What Doesn't Need to Happen

Don't tell me that Google+ is going to be where the social conversions come from this year. I've read about a trillion articles that told me that exact same thing six months ago. And a year ago. And almost two years ago. I'll believe it when I see it. Don't tell me that social media activity on mobile is increasing with each year. I already know that. I've adjusted my strategies to work with that data. And if someone starts singing a song about social media marketing, I'm either going to live-tweet it or walk out. It depends on how I feel in the moment. I'm flying solo at the summit, so if you are also a loner next week and you spot me there on Wednesday or Thursday, come and say hi. Everyone's a stranger until you give them a chance, man.

But seriously, please hang out with me.

I like wine and dogs and pop culture references. I have connections to little pigs. And I'm really tall, so I'm hard to miss. I'm a hoot. Or just tweet at me. That's fine too, I guess.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Social Media Strategies Summit
What's Up, Social Media Strategies Summit: Chicago?
Jen's going to the Social Media Strategies Summit in Chicago to learn what's new in the social media world. Here are her hopes and dreams for next week.

item.title: An Open Letter to Facebook's Advertising Program
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
You know what's annoying? Getting weird calls from a member of Facebook's Advertising Program. I've been screening her calls because I have no idea how she got my cell phone number, but man, is she persistent. She's called me four times in the past two and a half weeks. And then, she emailed me. Creepy sales strategy, guys. Random phone calls and weird emails? That's like, so 2010.

Fed up with Facebook, I decided to email "Amber" back on Friday. Here's what I said.

As a part of a three-person digital marketing team at Commerce Kitchen, I manage the Facebook profiles for our company, as well as for five of our clients. More specifically, we have used Facebook advertising for one client in particular, Trip30. As part of our marketing plan for Trip30, we have been managing the Facebook page since July 2013, and we started using Facebook ads almost immediately. We saw page likes increase day by day, which was exactly what we wanted. After more than 6 months of running these ads, we noticed that out of the over 6,000 page likes we had, our daily posts were being seen by less than 2% of of those 6,000. Frustrated by these numbers, we switched our ad strategy from page likes to promoted posts. We saw a dramatic increase in each post reach, which was great, but it begged the question: If we paid for those 6,000+ likes, then why should we be paying for those people to see our posts? It just doesn't make sense to us. We understand that organic likes are not profitable for Facebook. But what about likes that come from a Facebook ad designed just for that purpose? If the likes we paid for don't mean anything, then why should we pay for likes in the first place? This seems highly unethical of Facebook to take advertisers' money for likes when likes actually do very little for reach.
Trip30's social presence is really important to us right now, since our client is still developing their product to be released to the public this summer. With that in mind, we're going to continue using Facebook ads for our client until we see fit to put the client's advertising dollars elsewhere. Based on our Facebook advertising experience with Trip30, we're unlikely to pursue Facebook ads for our own business. We simply don't agree with Facebook's recent changes to the newsfeed algorithm, essentially killing post reach for us and our small business clients (many of whom do not have the funds to waste on promoted posts in addition to ads for paid likes). By our standards, it's just not very ethical. Best, Jen
Persistent as ever, Amber emailed me back 2 hours later.
Wow, that was so helpful. I feel so much better about everything now. Amber is so accommodating and insightful. I'm going to sign our company up for Facebook's Advertising Program immediately! Alas, sarcasm doesn't translate very easily online.
Just when I thought I was rid of her forever, Amber emailed me AGAIN today (Tuesday).
At this point, Amber is that creepy guy at the bar who just won't leave you alone after rejecting him several times. I just want to hang out with my friends Twitter and Pinterest, and drink my gin & tonic in peace.

TAKE A HINT, AMBER. I'm not interested. Please go away.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: facebook's advertising program
An Open Letter to Facebook's Advertising Program | Commerce Kitchen
Jen's fed up with Facebook's Advertising Program. After four telemarketer-eqsue phone calls and an email, it's time to get down to brass tax.

item.title: RailsConf 2014: DHH, TDD, and Other Musings
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded:
Last week I attended my first RailsConf ever. While there were so many things to talk about, I'm just going to highlight a few of the moments that stuck out.

One of my favorite parts of RailsConf was DHH's opening keynote. In a nutshell: "Stop putting so much emphasis on test driven development."

I feel as though I'm in a unique position having not been involved in Rails long enough to be completely consumed with writing tests, but long enough to know why they are useful. It seemed as though many rails devs at RailsConf were obsessed with writing tests. Just roaming the halls, you could here devs ranting at other devs, "You should write a test for that."

Then DHH spoke, and I felt completely free.

I'm not the only one who thinks it's ridiculous to base the entire development process around tests! I learned to program by making mistakes, and I still do, a lot. I agree with DHH that tests have their place, but don't get carried away with it. Test the things that matter, and don't fret the small stuff.

If you're writing tests for building a car, write tests that the brakes work and that the engine can turn on, but don't write a test that your car has 4 wheels. I say that for two reasons. First, the fact that your car has 4 wheels is not a mistake you should make, and second, in the unlikely event that you do screw that up, you should notice the mistake very early on.

There were, however, some not-so-good parts of RailsConf. In essence, not all who can speak, should speak. It sounds harsh, and I don't mean this to say that all of the presentation were “bad.” Quite the contrary. I believe that everyone who gave a presentation knew what they were talking about quite well. Experts in their own right. That being said, there's a huge difference between knowing something well and being able to speak eloquently about it. If you've never given a speech before, then it's probably not a wise decision to give your first on stage under bright lights with several hundred onlookers. I give you credit for trying and I do feel for you, but I can't take much away from a presentation when every other word is "um."

On the opposite end of that thought, the speakers who could speak were A-M-A-Z-I-N-G at it. My favorite talk, without question, was Sandi Metz's presentation, "All the Little Things." She was unbelievably clear, well-paced, and her slides were fantastic. She had the perfect balance between educating and entertaining, something that's critical to giving a good presentation.

[caption id="attachment_6274" align="alignright" width="231"] Squint like Mr. Whiskers.[/caption]

For a relative newcomer to Rails (though not so new to programming in general), she really had me thinking the entire time. In particular, I enjoyed her "squint test," which is almost exactly how it sounds. When writing code, take time to look at it and squint your eyes to make the code blurry. In not being able to make out the code, you'll see only 2 things:

  • The shape of it. How much indentation is happening? How nested is your code? If there is a lot of indentation going on (there are many "triangle" shapes visible), it's a sign that your code should be broken up more. Start creating smaller methods, or even breaking up the code into objects.
  • Colors (assuming you use an editor with syntax highlighting, which hopefully you do). The colors tell you how garbled your code is. If strings are red in your code and you see red all over the place when you squint, it's an example of code that will be confusing and difficult to edit. It's a sign that you should consolidate those strings into variables, or possibly even constants, and place them in a location where it makes more sense, like the top of your class.

The squint test is such a simple idea and yet brilliant at the same time. You are at that moment not worrying about the specifics of the code itself. You're only concern is how it looks, and in turn, how easy it is to understand.

I could go on and on about the lessons I took away from Sandi's presentation, but this blog would become far too lengthy. Instead, I'll leave you with as much as I can from her talk, the slides themselves.

Overall, I'd say that RailsConf was worth it. I do wish there had been more emphasis on programming related talks rather than so many business-ish topics. So many presentations on how to grow businesses and how to communicate with clients. Branding and networking is great and all, but RailsConf... know your audience. We're programmers and developers. Geeks and nerds with the collective social skills of a baked potato. There's a reason most of us choose to work in caves into the wee hours of the morning.

Would I go again?

85% yes, provided the location is as awesome as Chicago (food, huzzah!) and the speakers were screened prior to presenting and/or a safe bet to be informative and entertaining. I'll leave you with a non-poem poem/thoughts I compiled over the course of RailsConf.

The pervasive glow of white apple light has permeated every sense I have.

Hardly pressed suit jackets catch every corner of my eye. There are no irons here.

Hark! Lunch at noon thirty. Somewhere a developer's ears erect.

The awkwardness is palpable, the stench of diet mountain dew fills every corner of the promenade.

He has a Windows computer! Get him!

"Here sir, have some stickers."

Somewhere in the distance, the gentle murmur of a frustrated dev cries out. Listen .... "F#$*!"

"Is it lunch time yet?" "No, have coffee."

All the coffee, woe is me.

Divide and conquer, I'll take conference room B.

Rails. Ruby. Heroku. Node. "By your powers combined, I am Captain (Dev) Planet!"

Gratuitous use of the word “Frickin.” I understand ye, dev brother.

Feels just like home.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: railsconf 2014
RailsConf 2014: DHH, TDD, and Other Musings
Eric and a few of our Ruby on Rails developers attended RailsConf 2014 last week. This Magento Mage has some things to say about this year's conference.

item.title: How to Choose the Right Vendors
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
This coming Monday I am headed to small claims court. A terrible ending to an even worse situation with a recent contractor. I am a little bit terrified, a little bit fascinated, and a whole lot of frustrated that I've gotten here. In my preparation for court I've documented at least twelve (12!!) different times that I should have pulled the project. I know, hindsight and all, that the writing was on the wall and I should have recognized that contractor was incapable of performing the job I'd hired him to do.

Why didn't I say something!?!

Oh, but wait, I did. And like most poor saps in similar situations, I would be reassured, temporarily, that they would fix it. They would redo it and make it better better. They would listen better next time. They tell me they are the experts, and know what they are doing. Unfortunately, my friends, that's a load of horse shit. The contractors were never up to snuff, and I should have never hired them in the first place. Why, oh why, didn't I use my work brain -- the one that works with several rotating vendor partners each week, and untold more clients -- to assess their skills, strengths and weaknesses critically? Shame on me.

What I'd do differently.

First and foremost, I'd apply the thinking that I use at work to any future vendor selection, personal or professional.

Check references AND quality of work

While I'd politely call the top one or two references on their go-to lists to walk through the pros and cons of hiring the team, I'd also ask to see the work. Not in photographs. Not by trusting someone else's description, but using my own two eyes. There really is no substitute for gauging craftsmanship in person. And I'd look at not just any kind of work, but the EXACT kind of work that I need for my project. Remodeling a kitchen? Well, that basement you did is beautiful, but it doesn't show me how well you lay tile, or plumb cabinets. Put me in contact with kitchen references, please.

Understand the team

Does the vendor employ all of his workers directly? Or does he contract out work to subs? Is the person bidding the project, who's also defining the scope, the one that's going to be working on the project? Does the team seem trustworthy? Would you sit down and have a beer with those folks? While not all situations are bait-and-switch, you can frequently get into a situation in which too many team members are involved, and they aren't communicating, which leads to finger pointing, and leaves you frustrated and without a clear path forward to solve the problem. If no one can, or will, solve the problem, how can you, the client or hiring manager, come out successfully?

Put good in, get good out

More expensive does not always mean better. But usually a vendor is more expensive for a reason. And usually it's a pretty good reason -- supply and demand -- and good folks are ALWAYS in short supply. I went with one of the least expensive vendors out there, thinking I could supplement any less-than-stellar work in my free time, or work through any challenges on my own. WRONG! Good work takes time. Time costs money. Good work costs money. Simple as that.

Silver lining?

I've found out exactly what I don't want in a future contractor relationship, and have put my own practice to good use. My new, reliable, vetted by 5+ peers, "I had to wait 3 months to get on his calendar" vendor starts next week to redo my project.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Put Good In, Get Good Out: The Right Vendors Give You Right Results
Choosing the right partners can be difficult. We choose on price. Or on assumptions about quality. When really, all we need is to thoroughly vet vendors.

item.title: Everything is Sexy: A Recap of Social Media Strategies Summit Chicago 2014
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Last week, I went to Chicago for the Social Media Strategies Summit, and if you can recall, I was pretty excited before I left. And then the conference started, and everything changed.

Top 3 Sessions

Three words: Ramon De Leon. Dude knows how to grab your attention. Ramon was the second keynote speaker on Wednesday morning, and I swear I almost yelled out a "Hallelujah" during his presentation about humanizing your brand. He wants us to care more about our customers than our competitors do. He wants us to show our customers some love. And ask yourself: How did we make Mom feel? I had the pleasure of getting to chat with Ramon during a networking dinner that evening, and he's one of the most genuine people I have ever met. If you don't like Ramon, then you probably have a cold, dead heart. Another awesome presenter: Cassandra Clark. Because I'm really, really lucky, I also got to hang out with Cassandra at that same networking dinner on Wednesday night. Therefore, I knew how cool and smart she was before her session on social media metrics on Thursday morning. Main takeaway: use metrics that matter. Numbers that count steadily upward (numbers of fans, total clicks, etc.) are inferior to ratios and percentages that measure behavior. Metrics are things that you can measure, but KPIs are things that you should measure. By far, the most inspiring session from the conference was about building meaningful relationships with an audience by Cate Conroy. Not only did her content rock, but her slide deck didn't suck either. Best point from her presentation: Don't think of your audience as a bunch of "Wendys." Think of them as a bunch of "Smiths." They're like a family: they're all related, but they're individuals. The main goal is to understand who they are. Dive deeper into what your audience finds valuable, and then measure how well you provide value. Homegirl was laying down some pretty sweet knowledge on all of us unsuspecting attendees. I loved every minute of it.

Everything is Sexy (And other terrible parts of the summit)

You know what's annoying? Going to a conference where people specialize in content creation and the majority of presenters have godawful slide decks. What gives, people? Did no one take Public Speaking 101? Or How to Grab an Audience's Attention 202? Or Creating a Kickass Slide Deck 303? Text-heavy and image-light were the main themes used last week. I nearly gouged my eyes out when one slide had 10 (TEN!) sentence-long bullet points. The number of times that "sexy" was used to describe something that was (or was not) amazing would astound you. Guess what? If everything's sexy, then nothing is. The villain from The Incredibles explained this back in 2004. Enough with the "sexy," people. Learn another word! Probably one of the more unfortunate parts of the summit was its location. The Embassy Suites is nice and all, but it made for a very divided conference. The style of the atrium (where we had lunch) led to a cliche-y, high school-esque lunch hour. The three tracks in three separate rooms made you pick-and-choose which sessions you wanted to hear the most. I learned the "sit in the back of the room and if it's terrible, then leave early" trick a bit too late in the game. I sat through some horrendous sessions with mediocre content and speakers who weren't engaging.

When in Doubt, Be Snarky.

It's no secret that I'm sassy and sarcastic. So while everyone else was busy tweeting out quotes from each session (even the terrible ones), I was keeping myself entertained with social commentary.

Great Expectations

Maybe MozCon, with its engaging speakers and incredible content, has set my conference standards too high. Maybe the content from Social Media Strategies Summit: Chicago was sub-par. Maybe the speakers were sub-par. Maybe everything was sub-par. Nevertheless, I had some serious hopes and dreams for what I was going to bring back from the conference, and none of those hopes and dreams were fulfilled. No one talked about LinkedIn. No one told me that paid advertising wasn't the only solution to my Facebook problems (In fact, the "You gotta pay to play" notion was repeated many times). The majority of the sessions were on one side of the social media spectrum, and I was wishing for a much more well-rounded discussion about strategies that social media marketers are applying to their businesses. I'll probably be skipping this one next year.

Update: My Mother was Right

Deanne always justifies her 'vocal' nature with that age-old idiom "The squeaky wheel gets the grease." Well, as much as I don't enjoy saying it, my mother was right. Less than twelve hours after I published the above blog entry (and tweeted it out using #smssummit), Michael Roche from GSMI - the parent company for the Social Media Strategies Summit - reached out to me to apologize for my experience in Chicago. Actually, he did me one better than a simple apology. He offered me one free pass to whatever upcoming GSMI conference I want from now until December. And there are so many to choose from! I have to hand it to GSMI: they know how to handle customer service. After I was so underwhelmed at the SMS Summit in Chicago, they want me to give them a second chance, and they're giving me the means to do so. In fact, I'm considering submitting a speaker proposal for some of the conferences in the autumn to take a whack at these summits myself. I'll keep you posted!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Social Media Strategies Summit
Everything is Sexy: A Recap of Social Media Strategies Summit Chicago
Jen's back from her conference trip to Chicago, and she has a lot to say about the Social Media Strategies Summit.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Z08ZT5kB20KzoRboeiTxVxOM09JnJjOhCQ6dTB_Hkqk.jpg
