item.title: Now Hiring: Developer
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen is growing, and we’re looking for a web development superhero to join our team. Think you have what it takes to wear the CK cape? We really hope so!

Mission

Your superhero mission is to be a productive and efficient developer, working closely with a team of coders, designers, marketers, and project managers. You will write clean, well-documented code; create and run tests for your code; and QA your work and that of your peers, to create web-based software and websites in a variety of languages and across several platforms. You will support your team and deliver a positive and rewarding service experience to your clients.

How You’ll Spend Your Time

  • [~15%] Meeting with your team and clients to learn about projects and set/manage sprint/project expectations and deliverables
  • [~60%] Planning, coding, & testing
  • [~5%] Maintenance on existing applications/sites
  • [~20%] Internal projects
Tools in Use: Kanban and Pivotal Tracker

Competencies & Experience

Technical

Candidates with compelling combinations of the following competencies will be considered.
  • OOP (object oriented programming) experience using PHP, Java, Ruby, etc
  • Ruby on Rails for web development using PostGreSQL
  • HTML / CSS
  • Data modeling, with direct experience with database modeling tools
  • JavaScript, including working knowledge of AJAX either through direct coding or libraries such as JQuery
  • Experience working with some form of version control software such as Subversion/SVN and GIT.

Cultural

  • Love of problem solving and creative thinking
  • Strong communication (talking, listening, follow-up/resolution)
  • Efficiency
  • Adaptability
  • Ability to learn new things quickly; Intellectual curiosity
  • Ability to see three steps ahead
  • Thoroughness (anticipation)

Benefits and Compensation

We like to think that the true benefit of working at Commerce Kitchen exists in a realm far beyond the typical HR mumbo jumbo, but we suspect that the HR mumbo jumbo is important to most folks with, you know, human bodies that need to be fed, sheltered, and maintained. So here’s the quick rundown of the rights and privileges of full-time superherodom at CK:
  • Your salary Salaries are competitive, commensurate with experience, and delivered straight to your bank account twice a month.
  • Coming Soon: 401ks This new benefit is expected to roll out in Spring or Summer of 2014
  • Health Insurance We’ve got a great plan with United Health Care, and we’ll cover 80% of your dues, and 50% of those of your dependents. Insurance is available to all permanent employees working 30 hours or more a week, and we’ll get you set up shortly after your first day on the job.
  • Professional Development Budget  You’re amazing, but we want you to be amazing-er and always on top of your professional game. It’s up to you and your direct supervisor how and when you spend this cash, but so long as it makes you better at what you do for CK, we’re down to support you!
  • EcoPass Shortly after you start, we’ll snap a mugshot of you and send it off to RTD so you can ride the bus or lightrail to work (or wherever) as often as you want.
  • Flexibility of work schedule You know your team, and you know your projects and what needs to be done. Use your judgement.
  • Unlimited PTO You’ve got a great life. Live it. Use your judgement, here, though. Like above - you know your team, projects, and what needs to be done. A CK Superhero doesn’t take an unannounced 2 week vacation to ice fish in Manitoba immediately prior to a site launch. But as a CK superhero, you need to be kind to yourself.

To Apply

Send your resume, contact information for three professional references, and a cover letter to careers@commercekitchen.com.

About Commerce Kitchen

Commerce Kitchen is a collection of Internet superheroes of all kinds. Marketing masterminds, graphic design wizards, 11th level HTML & CSS masters with a native love of responsive design, top-notch programmers, and laser-focused project managers. Together we help our clients be and do better on the web. We’ve been around since 2003, and are on a solid growth trajectory. We hope to hit a very happy, healthy plateau of about 20 employees this year. If everything above sounds great to you, we’d probably love it if you were among those 20. We hope you’ll throw your hat into the ring!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Now Hiring Ruby on Rails Developer in Denver
Commerce Kitchen is hiring a developer! Do you have the superpowers we need?

item.title: Dr. Stockphoto Will See You Now
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: You may recall that I have a mild obsession with stockphotos. They pepper my blog posts ironically, like a hipster wearing a wolf t-shirt. I think they're hilarious and strange, mostly because they are almost always look so staged, so canned, and just so darn unnaturally creepy. Full disclosure: we use stockphotos. Sometimes we do it without a hint of irony. Sometimes they're the most affordable option for a website build that doesn't have a big enough budget for custom photography or illustrations, and there are some stockphotos that aren't horrible. However, healthcare is an industry that seems to have a major stockphoto problem. I see healthcare website after healthcare website with the same basic image of a row of doctors standing in a well-lit area with their arms crossed. In fact, there is a ridiculous number of stockphotos of doctors with their arms crossed. Hundreds. Maybe thousands. Behold this small sample. Why do they cross their arms so much? Does it connote sternness? Seriousness? Smarts? Skills? I don't get it. [caption id="attachment_6346" align="alignleft" width="146"] Don't piss off this Stock Doc.[/caption] I did me some Google image searching to find out if real life doctors in my city cross their arms this much? Not here. Or here. Or here. Or here. In fact, the real photos of doctors are so much better than the stock photos, even if they aren't as well-lit or smiley. The real doctors appear friendlier and more natural, and I am much more interested in learning more about them. Here's my simple advice for doctors who are building a website for their practice: don't use stock photos. Pay someone to take photos of you in action. Even headshots can be too cheesy and staged. We want to see you with patients,  not stockphoto specters of doctors standing in groups with their arms crossed. The same goes for hospitals, clinics, and health insurance providers. Spend some time thinking about the photography for your site, and please reconsider using stock photos of fake medical professionals. Even if you do use stock photos, try to look for photos that appear more natural. Add a filter that complements your website style or brand style, or choose images that don't include people. Whatever you do, just remember that there is a startling number of healthcare websites using the same tired stockphotos, and you want yours to stand out. [caption id="attachment_6347" align="aligncenter" width="1000"] I've edited the color, contrast, and brightness of this photo, but that creepy doctor model still looks like Dexter.[/caption]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Dr. Stockphoto Will See You Now
Healthcare websites use too many stockphotos of unnatural-looking doctor models crossing their arms sternly. Why?
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/05/stockphotos-healthcare-websites/

item.title: Customer Service on Digital Channels
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
We all want to be nice people, right? Our moms and dads instilled verbal etiquette -- please, thank you, yes ma'am, no ma'am . Our communities, peer groups and religious institutions shaped our view of appropriate communications and interacting with others. Tried-and-true assholes who lack the ability to be *human* aside, in a brick-and-mortar, peer-to-peer, human-to-human world we embrace our upbringing and try to approach the world with a nice demeanor. We only stray into mean or deprecating conversations in really trying or difficult situations in which we lack the ability to communicate effectively, or to reach resolution quickly. Michelle's excellent post last month on Why Good Service Matters in Tech reiterated the importance of applying etiquette, empathy and service leadership to our tech business, as an effective way to drive repeat business, to do better work, and to more efficiently solve problems. Why then do these core tenants of being a respectable human fly right out the window when super imposed on the world of electronic communication? Case in point, my recent dealings with AdAge's Small Agency Awards.

The Background

After several months working tirelessly on Go Code Colorado, we were a bit spent, but re-energized after winning Statescoop's State Innovation of the Year award. We thought that our combo of grassroots and digital outreach might be worthy of submission for Integrated Campaign of the Year. We took our time; we crafted our responses; we paid our entry fee. And then we were met with this: The 1,000 word description specified on the entry form was cut down drastically, but only after we'd paid our money and "officially" submitted our application. So what's going on?

Digital Customer Service Fail #1: Usability

No where in the instructions did the Integrated Campaign application specify word counts, so we were left to rely on the on-screen instructions, which specified 1,000 words. Following submission, we as users were left to interpret conflicting error messages. Do they want 400 or 200 words? Is our application now a waste? Can we go back and edit? Since our content was still on-screen, we immediately edited down to 400 words, and clicked Upload Campaign, assuming we'd have the chance to confirm our changes, and edit again (like we did the first time we uploaded our content). No such luck - instead the screen redirected to the contest homepage. Did our changes save? Are we now in compliance? Can we edit our content again since we still have several weeks remaining before the ever-changing (and also inconsistent - are you sensing a theme?) deadline? Even more frustrated and confused than before, we now wonder if our $250 was a waste. Especially since all of this could have been solved with:

Consistent Instructions, Repeated in Multiple Places

If we think of a website as a facilitator of a positive human interaction, we realize that things could be a whole lot easier for both parties if instructions were mirrored both in the onsite text, and on the forms themselves. Requirements would be clearer, and QA would be easier so mistakes wouldn't be published in the first place.

Clear Error Messages

If for some reason it was impossible to be consistent and repeat necessary instructions, we want error messages to be clear and concise so that users can fix their problems and format the data in a way that works for the site at large. No need for redundant systems because, as seen in this case, when the messages conflict they only create more confusion, and go against our digital customer service mantra of making an experience nice, and a site usable. Side note to self: don't hire or work with vendors that built these systems for AdAge.

Status Messages to Let Users Know What's Going On

If we have error messages letting users know something is wrong, why don't we also have status messages letting them know when something is right? A simple line of text of "Thank you for submitting your application! Your entry is complete and can no longer be edited." would have sufficed and stopped any follow up on my part in its tracks.

Digital Customer Service Fail #2: Timely Responses

After our application submission debacle, I immediately reached out on Twitter to inform AdAge that had some serious word count issues going on (and let off a little steam after writing the perfect 1,000 word entry only to scramble to edit it down). And guess what I heard? Crickets. No word. Nothing zip. Nada for ONE WEEK. So I emailed the address that they suggested I contact on their contest page. Again, nothing but my rising angst over the past four business days, as I count down until the latest deadline (tomorrow). I reached back out on Twitter early today. Still no response. So by midday, I got a bit heated. I emailed the same email as before, but added in their "Contact Us" email from their contest page footer (of course they linked to a no reply email, which promptly bounced back...argh) and the conference email. Finally, after 9 business days of waiting, I received a voicemail from their team this afternoon to help sort out the situation. We have since been playing phone tag. And one of the emails that I contacted earlier today has since directed me to a new email address without helping in any way. Two tweets, three emails to a combination of four different email addresses, and voicemail tag. Resolution is still pending. Some lessons for our advertising friends:

Ignoring a Problem Doesn't Make It Go Away

All of the above just documents my experience. I am sure the hundreds (if not thousands) of other folks submitting campaigns for the same contest went through something similar. Did my emails and tweets just slip through the cracks? Or do you ignore everyone that follows up using the emails that you've specified on your site? You wouldn't ignore a person who's talking to you in person about a problem they've had so why would you ignore someone just because they communicated with your digitally, especially if you haven't provided a phone number for follow up?

Acknowledgment Goes a Long Way to Providing Good Service

I get that the lowly intern manning the email box may be bored. Or may be overwhelmed and really busy. Or both. But a one-line note saying that you are looking into my issue and will ensure I will have a chance to modify my application before the deadline would have been more than enough to instill confidence, and provide some modicum of customer service without really even disrupting your day or workflow.

Your Reputation Can Easily Be Undone on Digital Mediums

Just because you are communicating with folks on a digital medium, you aren't off the hook for being a decent human being and providing solid customer service. Wait, not "just because"; "especially because". Everyone knows that any jerk with a Yelp, Google+ or social media account can eviscerate a brand online. And while I'd like to think my feedback was been a bit more constructive and nicely put than that, any brand should be concerned about their reputation, and the level of service that they are providing in such a public forum. Update: I received a voicemail late yesterday informing me that my entry was accepted, complete and in compliance. The AdAge spokesperson also apologized for the craziness that was going on. Thankfully, we can now all lay this one to rest.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Customer Service is Especially Important on Digital Channels
Why do the core tenants of being a nice, respectable human - etiquette, politeness and customer service - get disregarded in electronic communication?

item.title: Get Away From Your Computer
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: A couple weeks ago Commerce Kitchen took a philanthropy field trip to a horse rescue ranch, where we shoveled horse shit, stuffed bags with hay, tried to fix a baler, took rides on a tractor, and groomed horses. It was freaking awesome. Jamie, one of the CK owners, posted earlier this week about how the outing taught her how to be a better leader. I asked the rest of the staff to give me their feedback, and here's what they said. "I never thought shoveling horse shit could be so rewarding." - Kevin "I learned that we all have different leadership styles and approaches to collaboration. We need to understand each other's styles, and recognize how we can best work together to be effective with clients (or a horse :) ). And I loved the Colorado sunshine, the views, and the overall mission of Zuma's." - Leslie "Humanity has the capacity to do a lot of good, but our society erects more barriers than conduits. I would not have known or taken part in this powerful day if it weren't for CK and Philanthropy Field Trips. Step-up humans. Spaceship Earth is not a free ride." - Russ "Havana [the horse] taught me trust must be earned, and loyalty is a two-way street." - Tynan "When your poop shovel breaks, you just get another shovel!" - Jen "Something that always blows my mind is how intangible our work is and that we spend more time with our computers than we do with other living beings. So for me, my favorite part was partaking in physical tasks with tangible things (like scooping poop) and interacting with real beings (like horses and you guys!)" - Alex Like Alex, my biggest takeaway from the day was that it feels really good, like really really good, to get away from my computer and do the kind of work that uses my body, has clear goals, allows me to be outside, and gives me the chance to be close to animals. Those of us who spend eight hours a day on a computer are at much less risk than those who do physical labor. Sure, sitting is really bad for you, but we're much less likely to be crushed by machinery, inhale toxic fumes, have a horse bite off our finger (it happened several months ago at the ranch!), or lose a few toes to frostbite. Scientists, doctors, exercise freaks, and everyone else in the world has been arguing for a while now that physical activity makes you smarter, more productive, and happier. Sunshine also has amazing benefits, like reducing your risk for cardiovascular disease, keeping you healthier overall, and, of course, includes all the great ways vitamin D benefits us. When we work in front of our computers we get less exercise and less sunlight, the lack of which makes humans more miserable. Aside from the great lessons we learned that we've applied to our work (how to lead better, how to collaborate, etc.), doing something physical just felt good for our bodies, which in turn helps our minds function better. I'd encourage all business owners to get your staff off their asses every few months and volunteer somewhere that allows them to use the rest of their bodies. Volunteer at Zuma's, Habitat for Humanity, or any other number of outdoor organizations. Yes, we also rented a party bus to drive us out there while we drank bloody marys, and we had a food truck cater lunch, so it wasn't all physical labor. Incentivizing your city-slicker devs with something like that might help sweeten the deal initially, but once they're out there in the sunshine they'll love it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Get Away From Your Computer
Commerce Kitchen's staff took a day away from our computers to work on a rescue ranch for horses. The experience made us all happier people.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/05/get-away-from-your-computer/

item.title: 8 Things That Happen When You're the Youngest Person in Your Office
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
I’m 22. And no, not like the Taylor Swift song.

As a 22-year old in an office where the average age is mid-30s, it’s tough being the youngest. Of course, here at Commerce Kitchen, we have some young developers in their mid to late twenties. But even then, I’m still two years younger than the youngest developer.

So what exactly happens when you’re the youngest person in a small office? 

 

1. Your life problems ≠ your coworkers’ life problems.

Marriage? Kids? Mortgages? I’m not concerned by any of that stuff right now, but those topics are just a few of the very grown-up things that my bosses and coworkers talk about. My biggest life problem at the moment is figuring out whether or not I want to get a Dollar Shave Club membership.

2. The pop culture references that your coworkers use will make you feel inadequate.

I pride myself on being well-versed in the area of movies, television, books, etc. However, I am a mere novice compared to my coworkers. I hadn’t heard of Firefly before I set foot inside this building. I hadn’t considered reading The Lord of the Rings trilogy to be one of the top things on my to-do list for 2014. Joss Whedon? He’s just that guy that directed The Avengers, right? WRONG!

3. In order to carry a non-work conversation, you have to start speaking their language.

One of my favorite parts about working for Commerce Kitchen is how diverse everyone is outside of work. I wasn’t understanding Natalie and Michelle’s references to ‘90s TV shows, so I’m watching Buffy the Vampire Slayer and Twin Peaks for the first time in my life. Leslie loves bourbon, so she’s been slowly teaching me (and the rest of us) about it. The obscure books and movies that some of the devs talk about are incredibly random. I don’t think I’ll ever be able to catch up with all of them, but I will try.

4. If you unknowingly make yourself seem uninformed about something that everyone else knows and loves, then you will answer to many loud gasps.

I don't think I'll ever live the "... and some guy named Moby..." thing down.

5. You learn about alcohol.

Not only am I being introduced to the world of whiskey/bourbon, but I have also been opened up to so many different kinds of wines, liquors, and beers. Long gone are the days of $4 bottles of wine and a keg of Keystone Light. It only took one Wine Friday and five minutes listening to Tynan talk about this Cab or that Pinot to make a a wine convert out of me.

6. Sitting in any kind of meeting makes you feel out of your league.

What was I doing this time last year? I was an intern here, whilst finishing my senior thesis at DU. Now, I’m sitting in meetings with some of the smartest people I’ve ever met talking about things I think are way over my head, but they’re actually not. How did I get here? When did I learn about all of this stuff?!

7. Mentors.

When we're not drinking (which happens more than we make it appear), I'm constantly learning from these crazy-intelligent people. They're smart cookies. I love listening to them.

8. When said mentors show you a YouTube video from 2006, and you say "What was I doing in 2006? Oh, I was a freshman in high school," you'll receive a chorus of Aww's.

True story. That happened yesterday.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 8 Things That Happen When You're the Youngest in Your Office
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/10330878953_18b1cd12da_b.jpg
Jen's the youngest in our office. Here are some things that she has observed since she began working with us.

item.title: 3 Reasons Everyone in Your Organization Should Blog
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen has been working hard to get our entire staff to blog. As you've probably noticed, the marketing team does a lot of blogging. Leslie, Jen, and I try to blog at least once a week, and we ask everyone else in the organization to blog once a month. Here are three reasons why everyone in your organization should be blogging.

Many Voices Make a Rainbow

No one says that, right? "Many voices make a rainbow." I like to mix metaphors. That's part of my voice. When one person or one team blogs, their blogs are going to begin to sound the same. For instance, my blogs are always a mix of personal anecdotes and soundbytes of advice. That's fine, sure, but it's nice to read someone else's perspective. Some people may be more interested in delving into technical details, telling vivid stories, posting instructions, or simply recounting an event they attended. Great. Variety adds color, makes the blog more interesting, and gives your blog a wider appeal.

Expertise in the Blog Should Reflect Expertise in the Organization

Commerce Kitchen's main type of work is software development. However, if just Jen, Leslie, and I were to blog you'd think we were entirely a marketing agency. Yes, we understand the value of blogs from a marketing perspective more than our software developers do, and we'll do whatever it takes to have an active online presence. But we need our developers' expertise. We need to feature their quirky thoughts, their freakish intelligence, and all the fantastic knowledge they gain and concepts they invent every day while coding, scoping, planning projects, QAing, and all the other programmy things they do. Without Aaron's knowledge of Sass, Alex's expertise on web image formats, Eric's passion for e-commerce, Tynan's business knowledge, Michelle's culture ideas, Russ' advice on coding, and all the other insightful words coming from the rest of the staff, our blog would be pretty boring, even for me.

Your Staff's Social Networks Bring You Traffic

The final reason you should have everyone blog is that most people, after spending an hour or two writing something, want to share what they've written with their friends. They'll hopefully post a link to the blog on Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, and their friends and great-aunt Margaret will all go to your website to read the blog. I'm not saying that great-aunt Margaret will end up being a client of yours, but she may know the owner of a hotel chain in Michigan who needs a new app, and she'll refer them on to you. Likewise, your hiring pipeline will grow as more people begin following your blog. For us, we love to hire people that our devs recommend. We know that if they think they're good, then we'll think they're good as well. Your staff's friends and acquaintances may end up being your future employees.
Not everyone is a good writer, and this is often an argument you'll hear when trying to wrangle more people to write (especially the more technical members of your staff). But you most certainly have at least one person working for you who is a good writer and a good editor, and he or she can help make blog posts readable. If you continue to hear grumbles, or if your staff is having trouble with it, then refer them to Jen's post on writing a blog post in an hour.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 3 Reasons Everyone In Your Organization Should Blog
It might be tempting to have one blogger on staff, but we believe that everyone in your organization needs to contribute. Here's why.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/05/everyone-should-blog/

item.title: Bah, Humbug: Being a Decent Human in a Not-So-Decent World
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Bear with me here; I'm going to try to use as few clichés as possible. Recently, I've had several different encounters with total strangers that make me question human decency. This is the most notable of all of them.

Mr. Scrooge Goes Golfing

Since I'm trying to get back into golf, I went to a range in Littleton to hit some golf balls. I was by myself at this range, with no one hitting alongside of me, for a solid hour. Suddenly, an older fella, probably in his mid to late-sixties strode up to a hitting post a couple of spots down from me.

Out of nowhere, he bitterly called to me, "You can't hit from there!" "Why?" I asked. "Because you can't," he scoffed. "I don't understand. Why?" I asked again. "Because those are the rules!" he replied, almost mockingly. "You can't hit from back there. The ropes are up here. You have to hit from up here." "Well, I've never been here before, and I've been hitting from this spot for an hour and no one has said anything to me," I replied calmly. "Well, those are the rules!" he finished.

Livid but keeping my cool, I picked up all 100 of my golf balls that I had already emptied from my basket, took my clubs, and moved up to the ropes, seven extra spots down from Mr. Scrooge.

After about five minutes of hitting from my new spot, Ebenezer strolled over to me. "Hey, I didn't mean to be bossy back there..." He trailed off. I thought to myself, "That's not really an apology, dude." "It's fine," I replied, still somehow not losing it on this guy. "Yeah," he said with a half-hearted chuckle. And with that, it was over.

I understand that he was alerting me of the "rules" for safety purposes, but he didn't have to be a Grade A Jerk about it. There are certain ways that you can carry yourself in those kinds of situations, regardless of what role you play in it. So, in a world filled with Scrooges without time-traveling ghosts that change their lives, how is it even possible to be a decent human being?

Don't just have a heart. Have a soul.

Here at Commerce Kitchen, we've recently been talking a lot about our company values. Don't you roll your eyes at me! This is important stuff. One of my favorite parts of our core values is this thing called Generosity of Spirit.
"I am amazing, and I will share that goodness across our company and out into the community. I will help teammates when I sense they could use a hand. I will be committed to the success of our clients. I will participate in my professional communities. I will bring donuts or burritos on occasion."
Besides the donuts and burritos thing, there is something really inspiring about that whole statement. "I am amazing, and I will share that goodness across our company and out into the community." I want to wrap myself up in that sentence, with a hot cup of tea and a biscuit. Generosity of Spirit: it's like if Empathy and Humility had a baby made of pure goodness. As a company, we took a trip to a horse rescue ranch a few weeks ago, and it was game-changing for all of us. Seeing our hard work actually result in something tangible was what we needed. More importantly, I think any volunteer work - whether you're scooping horse poop or stacking cans at a food bank - is an incredibly humbling thing to dedicate yourself to. Outside of Commerce Kitchen, I do some volunteer, part-time marketing/PR work for a nonprofit organization called CESDA. I've been working with them for three months now, and I feel like a much better human now than I did before. It all goes back to that Generosity of Spirit. If you're a good person, then share that goodness with others. 

Practice what you preach.

It's one thing to talk about being a decent human being. It's another thing entirely to actually live that way. Unlike Amy Poehler, I have to try a bit harder. I blame it on spending one too many Christmas seasons (four of them in a row) in the retail industry. You really get to see the full spectrum of peoples' ability to be rude during the holidays, particularly when you're on the other side of the cash register. Yet, that experience in retail - and food service before that - has made me see people on the other side of the counter very differently. I don't know their lives. I don't know what kind of stuff they're going through. Therefore, I have absolutely no right to treat them poorly, regardless of how my day is going. It's a not-so-decent world out there. Please be a decent human being.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Being a Decent Human Being in a Not-So-Decent World
In a world filled with Scrooges without time-traveling ghosts that change their lives, how is it even possible to be a decent human being?
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/6078057491_79cb73f06f_b.jpg
In a world filled with Scrooges without time-traveling ghosts that change their lives, how is it even possible to be a decent human being?
being a decent human

item.title: Minding the Confidence Gap
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Last week, I was talking to one of our team about a talented developer who I wanted to lure away from her current job with the promise of a superhero cape and Wine Fridays. It seemed like I might have a chance - but then I got the disappointing news: Since she didn't have all of the qualifications we were looking for, she was opting not to apply.

<facepalm />

I'd just spent hours (okay, maybe not *hours*) sifting through the resumes of countless (okay - maybe not *countless*, but definitely many) Toms, Dicks, and Harrys, many of whom met just a handful of the specs in the job description. It was a total facepalm moment. That conjured up memories of a frustrating statistic I'd heard years ago, and which was recently reiterated in an insightful article in last month's The Atlantic. While trying to get more women on their management team, Hewlett-Packard did a data dive, and found this:
A review of personnel records found that women working at HP applied for a promotion only when they believed they met 100 percent of the qualifications listed for the job. Men were happy to apply when they thought they could meet 60 percent of the job requirements. 

Horseshoes, Hand Grenades, and The Average Man's Professional Plan

In short, men felt that "good enough" was, in fact, good enough; women felt that they had to be practically perfect in every way to justify taking the time of the hiring team. The Atlantic article, called "The Confidence Gap," digs deep into this phenomenon and comes up with all sorts of not awesome info. No matter how amazing and accomplished we are, we say we don't deserve it, and give the credit to others, especially (!*@#%@#* gahhh!) if the others are men. Women are plagued by the worry that someone is going to realize, any minute, that we're not freaking awesome. We shoot ourselves in the foot by not applying for top-notch jobs. When we do apply, we usually don't negotiate for better salaries; if we do negotiate, we ask for less than our male peers.

"Honest Over-Confidence"

Study after study shows that men consistently over-estimate their ability and their performance; women underestimate theirs. Almost invariably, men think that they will do better at a task than they actually will, and in retrospect, they will assess their performance as higher than a woman would. After taking a test, a man who scored 70% will say, effectively, "I killed it!!" and a woman with the same score will say "I totally bombed." If men don't meet their own expectations, they blame the task: That task was super hard, and I am awesome since I didn't fail worse than I did. Women will take that as a personal failing: I failed because I am not good enough. Worth noting is that the phenomenon is known as "honest over-confidence." Men aren't trying to fool anyone. They genuinely tend to think they're stronger/faster/better than they actually are at most things. Not to say men never doubt themselves - they just do it with less crippling fervor than women do. Lucky bastards. This probably explains why a lot of men earnestly try to fix the busted kitchen sink before finally giving in to their spouse's insistence that they call a plumber.

Confidence Matters

And the worst part of it all? Confidence matters as much as - if not more than - competence. People trust and follow people who behave confidently, regardless of whether or not they're any better at what they do than the next "guy." (Note: I tend to use "guy" as a non-gender specific term. You'll get used to it.) This probably explains why almost every woman-dominated field is still led by men - and in many cases, by men less competent than many of their subordinates (think: hospital directors, school principles, library directors). Apparently, the phenomenon of women's perennially low confidence infuriates business leaders and executives everywhere. Incredibly talented women keep their mouths closed because they feel that the louder (usually male) voices in the room deserve to be heard more than they do. We all know that teams that are gender-diverse perform better, but if a lack of confidence keeps women from taking a seat at the table, then that benefit is never realized.

Takeaways

I find this maddening - and I catch myself doing this stuff all the time. If my team makes a demanding deadline, I instinctively know it's because they're awesome and crazy talented, they worked late, they did something above and beyond. If my team fails to meet a deadline, my first instinct is to figure out how I failed. The truth of course is that our projects succeed or fail because of everything each of us brings (or fails to bring) to the table every day.

To-Dos

So knowing what I now know, and knowing that it's scientifically proven and not just a hunch, what do I need to do differently? Lots, probably, but here are a few.
  • In Hiring I need to remember that men and women with the same level of skill and experience will present themselves differently, and it's up to me and the CK team to really dive in and make sure we're hiring the right person for each job, and not just the person who tells us they're the best fit for the job.
  • In High Fiving Knowing that women will deflect credit and give it to the men on their teams (seriously - did you read that other Atlantic article?), I need to pay very close attention to how each individual staff member performs, and make sure to reward individuals as much as the team.
  • In Planning I need to work closely with my team to make sure we can, in fact, achieve what we say we can when we say we can, and that we also never sell ourselves short.
There are probably a bazillion other lessons embedded in this, too; these are just the ones I know I need to focus on right now. If you have any other dazzling insights, or, you know, ones that you think are maybe just mediocre but that everyone else will probably think are amazing (ladies, I'm looking at you!), please feel free to leave a comment!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Minding the Confidence Gap: Gender Differences in Work
The Atlantic recently highlighted studies that show how differently men and women present their own skill-sets. When we hire, we have to remember this.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/05/minding-confidence-gap/

item.title: Tech Meets Social
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Have you noticed all of the pretty amazing social events for techie Denverites happening more and more frequently? No longer are we siloed in a worksession on Sass one day, and a happy hour with coworkers the next. Instead, we're drinking beers while learning something new. Our professional and personal worlds have collided. Just like those social media futurists said they would (here's the requisite 2009 throwback). But with that convergence, we're inundated continually with new meetups and networking events to attend. We sign up for a few, and start attending them, only to see the next bright, shiny event and add that to our ever expanding social calendars. What're guys and gals to do when every free minute of every day is booked solid? Remember why we signed up in the first place:

To Get to Know Folks

Meet new people. Network. Connect with associates, coworkers, partners and friends on a personal level. Learn what makes folks tick outside of their day-to-day jobs. From Women Who Startup to Ruby-focused meetups, CKers interests run the gamut, so we're always meeting new and interesting people.

To Get Out of Your Element

Some of the most memorable events we're often uncomfortable to begin with. Maybe you know nothing about the topic. Or you don't know anyone who's attending. By the end of the night you'll know a bit more and be able to recognize friendly faces at future events. Denver Startup Week is soliciting submissions for their 2014 fall event right now. And while we'll be suggesting some of the topics that we think are important in tech -- devops, servant leadership, digital healthcare -- we'll also be suggesting a raucous Capture the Flag competition. Because we all need a little exercise, and friendly competition between startups.

To Do Some Good

We've all reminisced recently about our trip to the horse ranch, not because you need to hear about it any more, but because it really was THAT meaningful to all of us. We all feel better when we try something new and help others in the process. That's why we're super excited to be participating in Built in Colorado's homebrew competition. While the competition sounds fierce, we're hopeful that our Arch Nemesis IPA sates the crowd, and helps raise money for the Gabby Krause Foundation. Go forth, friends, and get social!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tech Meets Social: The Overlap of Personal and Professional
Social events in tech connect you to folks on a personal level, help you get out of your element and inspire the tech community at large to give back.

item.title: 3 Signs Your Blog Is Formulaic
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
As you know from my last blog post, I think it's incredibly important for everyone in your organization to blog. But it's not always easy. There are some formulas to help you out, but they often make blogs generic and unreadable. If you're feeling impatient, scroll down to my list below. After all, I'm told that blogs with numbered lists are valuable because you are impatient and lazy. Is that true? I was having some major writers block today, so I took to Hubspot's blog idea generator. The concept is cool. You type three nouns that you're interested in writing about, and Hubspot shoots out topic ideas for you to roll with. My first three nouns were marketing, business, gender. BORING! But here's what Hubspot recommended I write about: Some of those sound like reasonable, if not dull, blog topics. But number three made me giggle. Miley Cyrus always ends up in these, and a quick search shows that people don't simply laugh at the blog topic ideas that include Miley Cyrus. They actually use them. So, after enjoying the strange recommendations Hubspot made from my very basic nouns, I couldn't help but abuse the Hubspot blog post generator to get a good laugh out of my frustrating morning. Happily, when I entered Miley Cyrus as a topic idea, she was paired immediately with Miley Cyrus. Then I just got sillier. This formula for a successful blog topic may have once been compelling. But now we've all gotten so tired of seeing blog titles that look like this, we need something new. So, without further ado, here are three signs your blog is formulaic, and what you can do to make it less so.
 

1. It compares Miley Cyrus to something surprisingly incongruous.

Yes, sometimes Miley Cyrus has 10 Surprising Things In Common With ________. But more often than not she doesn't. The reason that Hubspot uses this as a recommendation is because they want you to write about something topical. Miley Cyrus and her famous twerking/hair dying/wild partying remains surprisingly interesting to a whole lot of people. According to Google Trends, she's been in the top ten search terms for entertainers for the past 60 months, and has been number one for quite some time. So what can we learn from Hubspot? Blog posts that are timely with hot search terms or news items can be incredibly successful, but make sure you have something useful and interesting to say about those topics. I don't know anything about Miley Cyrus, so I shouldn't write about her. I do know quite a bit about Arrested Development, though, and because of that I've written a (formulaic) blog about it, a blog that I loved writing and that displayed my vast and deep knowledge of the show. When season four was released on Netflix last year, that was a great opportunity for me to use my knowledge and expertise (yes, I have A.D. expertise) to capitalize on higher search volume and get people to our website. LESSON: Make your blog posts topical when you have something real to contribute or when you feel truly passionate about the subject.
 

2. It's in the form of an ordered list.

Hey look. I did it for this blog. I do it all the time. Why do so many of us create blogs with numbered lists? Every marketing writer in the history of the internet claims that blogs with numbered lists are always successful. And you know what else? Those types of blogs are easy to write. They're good for quick content generation. However, when I dive into our analytics I can see that the most successful blog posts, in terms of visits, were not numbered lists. Not one. Our most successful blog posts were written with knowledge, passion, and research. Maybe if you're a writer for BuzzFeed then 5 Reasons You Should Eat Old Leather works. But if you're writing for an actual business, then take some time to think through what matters to you and your readers. Remember, BuzzFeed doesn't actually sell a product or service. They sell ad space. LESSON: Ordered lists are overdone, but if you really have insight that can be easily chunked out into lists, then go for it. But it doesn't guarantee that your blog will do well.
 

3. It dispels common myths or misconceptions with sloppily researched rebuttals.

5 Myths About What Makes a Blog Post Successful! I could give a blog that title and use my evidence cited above, proving that ordered lists don't ever do as well as blogs that don't include ordered lists. But that would be bad research. Just because our ordered lists haven't done as well as BuzzFeed's doesn't mean they don't work for anyone. In fact, they work well for a whole lot of people. If I based my entire blog on the unproven fact that lists don't actually work, then at best I've done sloppy research, and at worst I've misled my readers into making a mistake that could cost them valuable traffic. Some people have every right to dispel myths. While I would need to do more research to effectively endorse or repudiate Michael F. Ford's work, I assume that he, as the founding director of the Xavier University’s Center for the Study of the American Dream, has every right to publish Five Myths About the American Dream. He spends his life studying it. LESSON: Don't try to debunk myths that you actually know very little about. If you feel strongly about it, do your research and have strong evidence to back it up
  My conclusion is this: in order to churn out a good amount of blog content, your blogs are going to probably be formulaic. However, this doesn't have to mean that they're always boring or uniformed and ignorant. Continue to write about what you know, what you're passionate about, and what you have time to support with evidence.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 3 Signs Your Blog Is Formulaic
See what we did there? Lists, badly informed myth-busting, and comparing Miley Cyrus to anything--these are formulaic. But formulas aren't always bad.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/05/formulaic-blogs/

item.title: Having a Passion Outside of Your Job
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
If you're like me and are trying to get better at the "networking" thing, then you probably are familiar with one particular question you get asked upon meeting someone new.

"So, what do you do?"

You get really good at answering that question after a while. It's almost automatic. You're nearly robotic with your reply. It sounds rehearsed, but it's not. You've just used the same response so many times that it becomes ingrained in your brain. When I was meeting other social media nutjobs like me at the SMS Summit in Chicago, I was really taken aback by one unexpected question: "So, what's your passion?" I was thrown for a loop. No one had ever asked me that. Well, no one that wasn't a career counselor at a university. "What's my passion?" I asked my inquirer. "Yeah, or passions," he replied. I had nothing. No practiced response. No prepared answer. "Umm... social media, I guess," I said half-heartedly. Well, that was dumb. Don't get me wrong: I really enjoy what I do. I sit on social media and surf the web for my job. Yet, I wouldn't consider it a passion of mine. More often than not, I unplug at home and stay off social media. I'm on it for the better part of my workday, so I sometimes need to compartmentalize my life in order to maintain some of my sanity. This question-answer situation happened a month ago, and it's still on my mind.

If social media isn't my passion, then what is?

Many people are willing to try to answer that for you. Billions (from my estimates) of self-help books and countless episodes of The Oprah Winfrey Show are there for you if you need them. There's even a WikiHow page about how to find your passion. And so many Thought Catalog articles about the topic of "passion." But of all of them, who is right? There are some differing opinions on doing work you love. Most of it stems from that Confucius quote that everyone and their mama knows... Realistically, we can't all have jobs that we're really passionate about. If we could, then I don't think anyone would be there to tell me, "Guac is extra!" Especially in these troubled times, having a job that you love is a luxury that many people cannot afford. Philosophical wannabes and hipster girls need to stop telling impressionable undergrads and financially conservative grads that getting a job that you love is within their reach. Some of us get lucky and land a pretty spectacular first job out of college, but that's beside the point. In my opinion, it's foolish to rely on finding a job that aligns with your passion. That's why having something outside of your job is so incredibly important. It allows you to access an outlet that is completely disconnected from your work. It gives you the chance to have childish enthusiasm about one special part of yourself. Here at Commerce Kitchen, we have a pretty vast array of after-work activities:

Leslie enjoys restoring old furniture, most likely whilst drinking some bourbon. Tynan and Jamie have a Dungeons and Dragons group that they play with. Russ and Kevin, our mountain devs, spend their off days in the winter on their skis and snowboards. Eric spends a lot of his summer days at Rockies games.

I'm still figuring out what I'm passionate about. Sometimes it's charity work. Sometimes it's golf. Sometimes it's Netflix. It really depends on the week. I'm not denouncing being passionate about your job. If you're one of those people who landed the perfect gig that aligns with what you love, then I applaud you. I'm simply stating that you are not your job. There is more to you than that thing you do every weekday from 8 AM until 5 PM. Having a passion for your job is good. Having a passion for something outside of your job is better. Go to a bunch of music festivals. Get crafty and finish all of the projects on your DIY Pinterest board. Become an activist for the latest cause that UpWorthy just promoted. Restore your dad's '57 Chevy pickup. Hang out with your kid. Try 30 breweries your before your 30th birthday. Do something great, and stick with it. Maintain that balance, that separation, and you'll be thankful you did.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Having a Passion Outside of Your Job | Commerce Kitchen
having a passion
Realistically, we can't all have jobs that we're really passionate about. If we could, then I don't think anyone would be there to tell me, "Guac is extra!"

item.title: Pinterest For Business: One Year Later
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
A year ago, I wrote a blog post about how to use Pinterest for business. In fact, it was the first blog post that wrote for Commerce Kitchen. I've written 28 blog posts since that first one, and here we are, one year later, and I still want to talk about Pinterest.

What was Pinterest like in June 2013?

 For starters, it was still kind of the new kid on the block. While the hype surrounding Pinterest had certainly calmed down since its launch in 2011, some of us weren't certain that it was going to remain a top contender in the social stratosphere. Yet, there were plenty of bloggers willing to talk about how to beef up engagement on brands' Pinterest accounts. And I was one of them. Less than a month later after I published that blog post, marketing blogs around the country were reporting that Pinterest had 70 million registered users, and 30% of them (21 million) were active on a monthly basis. It looked like Pinterest was doing great things for social referral traffic, but whether or not it was going to rescue social conversions had yet to be seen. At the time, my main takeaways for Pinterest from a business perspective were as follows:
      • Looks aren't everything, but they help.
      • Check the pins, and check 'em twice.
      • Know your audience, but keep an open mind.
      • Keep your boards well-rounded.
      • Self promotion silence may be golden.
Of course, things have changed in the past year. While I was busy writing 28 blog posts, the Pinterest team has updated things, Pinterest users are pretty savvy with the platform's interface, and the social media market has been affected by other big contenders in the social Game of Thrones.

What is Pinterest like now, in June 2014?

No one can seem to agree on the number of registered users currently on Pinterest. As of right now, official numbers haven't come out for its registered user base based on Q1 2014. Forbes has said that Pinterest finished 2013 with 34.9 million monthly users. And then there are bold, bad bloggers who are willing to state - without providing any evidence - that, as of January 2014, there were only 12 million monthly users on the site. I'd trust Forbes over some random marketing consultant any day (even though Forbes' on-site advertising is getting way out of hand). So, for argument's sake, we're sticking with Forbes' numbers on Pinterest's monthly user activity. Unsurprisingly, Pinterest's demographics haven't changed much. Women take up a vast majority of the user space on the social platform, and men haven't jumped aboard the the pinning train quite yet. Midwesterners love Pinterest, sharing more than any other region in the U.S., while folks in the Northeast aren't too active on it. In the past year, Pinterest has given us two big updates: the Explore Interests tab and Place Boards. Explore Interests is a great way to find pins that are relevant to your brand. Place Boards are great for localized brands and, of course, the travel industry. These two additions have brought Pinterest to another level, particularly for brands.

How to Use Pinterest for Business in 2014

Even though Pinterest and its users haven't changed much, it's still one year later. So let's update those five tips from last year, shall we?

Looks are everything.

Avid Pinterest users who have been on the social platform for several years don't want to pin your crappy pins. Good content gets shared. If you provide quality information in a visually appealing way, then pinners will share it. End of story.

Check the pins, but don't waste your time.

I manage four (4!) business Pinterest accounts, so unfortunately I don't have time to check every single pin to make sure that it leads to a credible source. Vague images of travel destinations and the like aren't high on my priority list. Instead, I check the sources for life hacks, recipes, and how-to's. It's all about what's important to your brand and your audience.

Know your audience, and anticipate how it might change.

For a Seattle-based client of mine, the Super Bowl was a huge source of traffic to the client's pins and boards. While the location-specific audience did not change, it opened us up to a whole group of people that we had not been reaching. From there, it only took a week or so of pinning Super Bowl-related content before the account's follower numbers increased by nearly 50%!

Keep your boards as well-rounded as you are.

Stay true to your brand. Don't promote content that is not on-target with your overall goal as a business. Besides searching for social conversions, the other main purpose of a brand's presence on any social media platform is to nurture their online community and open themselves up to future customers. Have boards that are diverse enough in topics, but not to the point that you alienate your audience.

Self-promotion silence is still golden, to an extent.

I'm a true believer in the 80/20 rule for brands on social media. Meaning that 80% of the content that you publish/promote should relate to things other than your brand, and that 20% is all of your own content. This rule is incredibly important on Pinterest, if not anywhere else. I've recently started doing a little more brand promotion on my client's pin boards. I use Canva (introduced to me by Cate Conroy at SMS Summit in Chicago) to create Pinterest-friendly images that link to my clients' on-site blog posts. This strategy has generated more site traffic from Pinterest than anything I've ever done before. However, I still limit the self-promotion. I only pin these blog posts once a week. Hopefully, from this point forward, Pinterest will only continue to grow in numbers. It's already a pretty great social platform - although its interaction with users on Twitter leaves something to be desired - so I can only imagine it can continue to succeed from here. Like I've said before, Pinterest takes time.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Pinterest For Business: One Year Later
pinterest for business
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Untitled-design-9.png
It's been a year since Jen wrote "How to Use Pinterest for Business." What's changed since then? Should you change your strategy? Maybe not quite yet.

item.title: What Small Businesses Can Learn from Netflix & Orange is the New Black
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
There once was a time when most of the TV shows that I watched featured male leads and few strong female characters. They were poorly cast and even more poorly written, filled with uncreative story lines, predictable endings, and too-likable characters.

Enter the age of Orange is the New Black.

[caption id="attachment_6664" align="aligncenter" width="747"] Netflix, Orange is the New Black[/caption] Creator Jenji Kohan and her utterly unstoppable cast have created a show that makes me laugh hysterically and cry uncontrollably. It's ugly, uncomfortable, and gets to the nitty gritty of our criminal justice system. But I'm not here to write a review of Orange is the New Black (as much as I would really, really like to). Nope, we're here to discuss what hints small businesses can take from Netflix & OITNB's success.

Make a product that the public wants and needs.

[caption id="attachment_6674" align="alignright" width="300"] Netflix, Orange is the New Black[/caption] As much as I love shows like Sherlock and How I Met Your Mother, I needed a show that would give me a female lead with gusto and gumption. OITNB is everything I needed and never knew that I wanted. With a phenomenally female-dominated cast with no-holds-barred story lines, it's a controversial program that certainly doesn't appeal to everyone. Does that hurt it? Not one bit. Why? Because those of us who love it simply can't stop talking about it. Small businesses, whether they're in the tech, tea, or tapestries, need to form their businesses around it. As much as I love my job and believe in marketing, there is simply nothing like word-of-mouth marketing from your consumers. Give them a product that they desperately need but never knew they wanted.

Make it great.

Why can't we stop talking about Orange is the New Black? Because it's badass, that's why! With its series productions, Netflix has done well for itself. For some reason, many folks wet their britches over House of Cards. The resurrection of Arrested Development continues to be a topic of discussion here at Commerce Kitchen. [caption id="attachment_6675" align="alignright" width="300"] Netflix, Orange is the New Black[/caption] However, neither Kevin Spacey's snide camera glances nor the weirdness of Hemlock Grove could surmount the buzz around OITNB. It's a fantastic show without being fantastical. It's realistic without being too relatable. In short, it's great. Many businesses set out to create great things, but lose their vision. My hope - and based on reviews so far, my expectations - for this next season is that the show has remained true to its roots. Small businesses need to do the same.

Make them want more.

Unlike regular programing on television, Netflix released the entire first season on its streaming site in one go. If you were as obsessed as I was, then you watched all thirteen episodes in two days. That was July 2013. And so began the waiting. I watched a few of the episodes from the first season again. It was a long year. Finally, one month before its season two release date, OITNB was renewed for a third season. Fans around the world rejoiced! Small businesses need to incite that kind of passion into their consumers. Make customers shiver with antici..........pation. The waiting only makes them love you (and your product) more! I think anybody who has experienced the pain of a Game of Thrones hiatus can attest to that. Now that OITNB's second season has been released on Netflix, it'll be interesting to see how Netflix customers and the show's obsessed fan base reacts to it. But for the time being, I'm aching to get home and start watching. How many small businesses can say they make their customers feel that way?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: oitnb
What Small Businesses Can Learn from Netflix & OITNB
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/orange-is-the-new-black-2.jpg
It's June 6, 2014. Do you know what that means? Netflix's Orange is the New Black is back! It's time for Jen to write an OITNB-themed blog post.

item.title: Would You Like An Appetizer With Your Software?
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.content:encoded:
A skill I'm proud to offer and benefit from, besides my ability to program or design, is my suitability for customer service. I learned the importance of achieving great service and the lasting impact bad service makes while working as a waiter at Trattoria Strada Nova. In the picture above, I'm the middle guy. It was a restaurant owned by one of my heroine's, Teri Rippeto. She's an accomplished chef and restaurateur with too many accolades and talents to count. Her seasonal farm-to-table dishes are otherworldly delicious...I'm drooling just thinking about it. (If you live in Denver, you should check out her restaurant, Potager!) Besides her passion to create healthy food in unique and inviting surroundings, she always enforced the highest standard of service. As a server, I never thought the valuable customer service skills I learned would later benefit me as a web developer. Managing my time, being attentive, communicative, and the continuous desire to learn are all skills that make a difference in providing excellent customer service.

Time Management

The ordering system used at Trattoria was top of the line back in the '90s, but as a server, you needed to manage the time you entered and sent the orders to the kitchen. Once the kitchen got an order, they would prepare it. If you didn't stagger the orders correctly, you would get dishes that would be served at different times. The experience for the customer would be a disaster if they were eating a salad and immediately following it they suddenly were served their main course. I learned how to prioritize and use time effectively from this experience. Thankfully, following the Agile software process, we have more flexibility with managing our time for a project. But the underlying message is the same. You need to know the time impact of stories. If I spend too much time on a story, that was determined to be an easy fix during an iteration meeting, I'm possibly in danger of altering what is accomplished in a sprint. I'm responsible for letting the team and client know changes that can effect the timeline.

Attentiveness

If you had a half-full glass of water at your sitting, I wasn't paying attention. As a server we were always taught to have a keen awareness for the needs of the customer and our surroundings. My job was to take care of you like you were a guest in my home. I try to use this same attentiveness to meet - and sometimes exceed - our clients needs. We work with our clients on a weekly, sometimes daily, basis. So, paying close attention to what their software needs are and how they communicate those needs can make a big impact. It pays off when you can offer suggestions or solutions that they didn't consider.

Communication

One of my strongest memories and life lessons while working at Trattoria was when I waited on the late Governor of Missouri, Mel Carnahan. The fact that I was serving a politician wasn't what made it memorable, because I had served other celebrities and musicians. But what happened after his lunch did teach me something about communication. The governor had left before I was able to ask if he needed change. When I collected the money from the table, I was shocked at how much he overpaid. I was overjoyed by this fact since this was how I made my living. But, I remember Teri pulled me over and started asking me questions gently prodding me to make sure the payment wasn't a misunderstanding or error. Finally, she got me to call the governor's secretary and inquire. The secretary replied that the governor was in a hurry and had to leave and I could keep the money. I learned it was more gratifying to clear up any confusion as quickly as possible, and you gain a loyal customer in the process. I'll think about this memory while meeting with clients to remind myself to make sure I understand their goals. Have I asked the right questions? Am I open to what they are telling me or projecting my own vision? Since we work so closely with our clients here at Commerce Kitchen, it's important to freely ask questions as they arise. We want to try and avoid any confusion and quickly make changes to plans as issues inevitably come up.

Knowledge

When a customer asked me questions about an item on a revolving food or wine menu, I needed to know what I was talking about. Teri would expect you to ask the cooks or the sommelier questions, and to experience new foods or wine by sampling them. This was my favorite time because I got to learn about sweetbreads and why decanting some wines is needed. By being informed and knowledgeable, I can provide the same level of expertise to our clients and continue to build the relationship. The application of what I know could be something as simple as doing mathematics in Postgres to cut a query time. Or have a mastery understanding of Devise for Ruby on Rails to start bending the rules to make a clients unorthodox idea come to fruition. It's an awesome feeling knowing I applied something I learned to benefit a project and can hear a client say, “That's awesome!”

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Would You Like An Appetizer With Your Software?
Alex applies his background as a waiter to his customer service expertise in software development. May he take your website edit order?
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/shutterstock_140727865.jpg

item.title: Have a Plan, Spend Wisely
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
With the tech boom in Colorado and California (heck, across the US), we're talking to lots of potential clients who have big dreams for their apps, startups, and collaborative business ventures. A sexy, shiny, transformative approach in the lifestyle industry? Check. A new app that's going to save enterprise clients millions, if not billions, in the health and human services industry? Also check. A revolutionary take on hiring and team management for businesses of all shapes and sizes? Yep, we're talking to them too. And while we've had some great conversations and are excited to be working with some new folks that have awesome business models and a vision for the future, we're regularly seeing some stumbling blocks that will prohibit us, and our clients, from being successful:

Too much money and too few plans

What's great about good looking, VC-funded startups? They have some cash to invest and grow their businesses. But all too often that means too much money and too few plans. They are looking to invest quickly and move on to the next shiny thing, without sustainable plans for getting from point A to point B. You often see this pattern emulated by folks with too much passion and too little business sense. Together they are two peas in a pod. If you are going to invest in something as brand-building, customer-facing as a website, make sure you know how you want it to work, and then spend wisely.

Too many cooks in the kitchen

It's awesome to get buy-in from all necessary stakeholders, but bringing 10+ people to a discovery meeting or a wireframe review rarely ends well. More often than not, you get watered down creative by committee, end up doubling your time in meetings, and have to schedule a follow up call to prioritize the goals of all the attendees. The most critical thing that a startup can do when working with a vendor is have a strong internal product owner. That owner will have a vision (for the product, app, website, etc.) and be able to successfully navigate political landmines , while successfully managing (or wrangling) key stakeholders. Without a strong product owner, clients can end up wasting money, and muddying the scope of a project.

Too quick or too long to launch

Why are we extremists by nature? "I have money and a general idea, so let's go, go, go!" Well, you are probably going to spend a fortune to make that deadline happen, and aren't going to get exactly what you want given your non-existent plan. And you are going to wonder why you have to reinvest in the same, hopefully improved upon, thing 6 months from now. Or, "I have a vision, but want to improve upon every single thing before I could possibly get customer feedback." Iterations are great, and making sure that a product is shippable is necessary, but an MVP is just that, a MINIMUM viable product, that can be improved upon based on actual customer feedback. Launch already. If you've done the market research to assess need, and built something to address that need, then you will be fine. If you skipped that step, well, why are you building in the first place, and why are you paying vendors to help you advertise your poor business decisions? You will bleed money, and begin to second guess anyone you've hired when the money starts to run out.

Well what do I need?

Honest feedback

Look for vendors that tell you that it may not be the right time or right kind of investment. They are not trying to shut you down, but challenge you to make purposeful decisions so that you can form a long term, sustainable relationship. That is in essence one of the fundamentals of great customer service. By pushing back, you will have better, and more open, communication, and be able to set realistic deliverables across the board.

The right folks for the job

This applies both internally and externally: a strong product owner internally, a strong project manager or scrum master externally. You also need to recognize what you or your vendor is good at, and where there are holes. Have a great business vision, a strong project lead and great backend devs? Well that's all well and good, but engage a frontend dev with UX / UI experience sooner rather than later. Go forth. Have a plan, and spend wisely!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Have a Product Launch Plan, Invest in Vendors Wisely
Big dreams for your startup? Great! But build a plan, and avoid pitfalls in your launch timing. Successful planning and good teams lead to product success.

item.title: Lightbox Prompts: The Death of Your Website (And More Dramatic Claims)
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded:
You! Yeah you, with your lightbox newsletter registration form and/or like button. With your constant need to be acknowledged and "liked." You make the web a lot less fun for at least me, and probably a couple other people who also live in a bubble of sarcasm and bitterness.

I'm looking at you:

Mashable.com Upworthy.com Entrepreneur.com Socialmediatoday.com Networkworld.com Healthtechzone.com

... and every other website that, in its own special way, made life a lot less worth it. You know who you are.

But perhaps I'm overreacting (not).

Let's break this all down. Let's pretend for a second you have a newsletter that goes out weekly to keep me informed of the latest happenings in the world of badminton. I happen to stumble across a link on the interwebs that leads me to a page on your site with a video of a totally awesome badminton play. I click on said link, page loads, and BAM! I see your lightbox pop up asking for me to sign up for your newsletter.

Congratulations, you failed at website 101. No, at this juncture in my visit to your site do I care to sign up for your newsletter. In fact, your presumptuous nature just cost you a future frequent visitor, because this is where I close your tab in my browser. I proceed to forget about badminton and decide to take up Mindball. It's way more intense of a sport anyways.

Trying to put aside all the animosity I have towards lightboxes in general, let's go over the do's and don'ts of lightboxes with newsletters and "Like" buttons.

Do

Include a close lightbox button in the upper right corner. Always.

Don't

Have the lightbox animate in from the top, right, left, or anywhere other than dead center on the page. If only I had a dollar for every time I clicked on a link I didn't want to because I was trying to click on the close button as the rectangle of chaos zipped around the page. Your website should not be a cheesy carnival game; don't add "features" that make it one.

Do

Ensure that clicking anywhere outside of the lightbox makes it disappear. More often that not when I'm expecting a lightbox I keep my mouse off to the side to click the moment I see your "nonsense box" come into view. There is a certain gratification in seeing a box go away before it can even get to 70% opactiy.

Don't

[And there may be a gray area for this claim, but] think very carefully before deciding to include your prompts on mobile devices. Take into account your audience as well as your website. Are the visitors to your site the sort of people who stay for extended periods of time or does your site offer up quick “time wasting” content like BuzzFeed? If the average length of time spent on your site is less than 10 minutes, don't include a lightbox. You're doing nothing more than interrupting what little time the visitor has to enjoy it. However, if you must, keep it simple and short. Your prompt should never take up a majority of the limited screen real estate, nor prevent the user from quickly getting back to what they really want to see.

Do

As much as possible, make sure that you are not showing the lightbox if I've already committed myself in some way to your site. If I'm signed in, then you know my email already and whether or not I am getting your newsletter. If not, leave it at that and don't prompt me because you feel that I've somehow "missed" your square of annoyance.

Don't

Prompt the user with a lightbox the moment a user visits your site.

This is where most websites fail miserably. It's just an all around bad idea to interrupt the user the moment they reach their destination. Let the user start reading and browsing for a while before your website reverts to 'toddler question mode.'

There are a few sites I've come across in recent weeks that appear to have a timer of sorts for their prompts. That's a start, but it can still be irritating if the page happens to be a news article or something similar. You can lose your concentration or maybe even the place where you left off.

Rather than using a simple timer, be a bit more cautious in your decision to prompt the user to 'Like' or sign up.

Many times, I only come to a site once to read something very specific. Those one time visits are the times I really don't want to see a prompt. If I view one page, then another, then another - using just a simple browser cookie - a site should be track that I'm engaged and interested in multiple things on the site. At that point, it makes complete sense to barrage me with your quadrilateral of insecurity since I'm more inclined to "like" or "share" what you have to offer.

Don't

Use lightboxes.

But I guess that's unrealistic.

Now go, fix your irksome boxes of wonderment so that the rest of us can browse, learn, and subscribe to your newsletter in peace.</rant>

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: lightbox
Lightbox Prompts: The Death of Your Website
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/10347464594_cbb806f238_b1.jpg
Eric has entered the seventh circle of lightbox hell. It's time for a rant about lightboxes, newsletter signups, and extremely bad UX!

item.title: Twitter > Facebook: World Cup Edition
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: It's no secret: I'm digging Twitter over Facebook lately. But I'm not going to dwell on the F-word here. Nope. This time, it's all about the little blue bird. In case you've been living under a rock, the 2014 FIFA World Cup has begun. With Brazil defeating Croatia yesterday in Match 1 (home court advantage, much?), this party is just getting started. And while I could drone on and on about how Nike is 'winning' the World Cup [or just getting weird with animation], I'm not going to do that. Nike gets enough play (muahaha, sports pun) as it is. Although some would argue it's too soon to call, Twitter is the social media winner of the 2014 World Cup. Why? They're raising the bar with user interaction and rallying support for the teams and players. It's stunning, really. Here's their #WorldCup process for those of us who tweet. When you log in to Twitter, you're prompted by this beautiful banner at the top of your Twitter Feed Page: Pretty snazzy, right? When you click, "Let's go!" - which, personally, I think should be "Vamos!" to fit Brazil's Portuguese - you land on this page: But how do I pick just one?! Alas, I had to make a decision. España it is. That choice brought me to this: Change my profile image? Never! As much as I want Spain to win, I had to keep my photo for professional purposes. Thankfully, Twitter knows what's up, and they had a "skip this step" option for every single page. I bet their bounce rates from these pages are pretty low! Next up, following the players. How cool is this?! If I wasn't such a bandwagoner, then I would probably know who all of these guys are. Next step: finding friends. You gotta hand it to Twitter: they're being realistic here and taking all of us back to our humble beginnings on their site. I haven't tried to do mass searches for any of my contacts since I joined in 2009. It's also nice to know that Twitter believes in me (and all of us) making new friends since joining. Then they did me one better: they found ones that I couldn't find. Creepy, but great nonetheless. However, at this point, I almost forgot how I had gotten here. Twitter quickly fixed that for me. Okay, so I changed my tweet a wee bit, but only because the robotically-generated one was so boring. So why does this quick process make Twitter the World Cup social network winner? Facebook, Instagram, and Pinterest haven't taken advantage of this international event like Twitter has. Granted, Twitter is probably the best platform for a hashtag revolution to take place on. Yet, there is something to be said about the way in which the World Cup is being received on Twitter. If we go back in time to 2010, when the last World Cup was taking place in South Africa, Twitter was a very different place. Numbers-wise, it had 30 million monthly users in Q1. Compare that to the whopping 255 million monthly users in Q1 2014, you can see why Twitter is making the magic happen now. Regardless of how the World Cup ends, I think Twitter is the ultimate social media winner here. Unless the other social platforms pull something out of their butts within the next few weeks, the little blue bird is taking home the trophy.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Twitter > Facebook: World Cup Edition | Commerce Kitchen
world cup
In case you've been living under a rock, the 2014 FIFA World Cup has begun. What does that mean for social media? Twitter will reign supreme.
