item.title: Usability: The Hamburglar Stack
item.dc:creator: Goodtimes
item.content:encoded:
Menu Icons – Are They Robbing You of Your Users?

When responsive design first started trending it seemed pretty straight forward to most designers and developers. "You know, fluid layouts man. Just use nice numbers, like 960." However, over time we’ve run into many other different issues, including but not limited to: screen resolutions, browser support, browser defaults, load time, and the biggest one, usability. Probably the biggest thing I’ve battled with in responsive design is menus. In the beginning, I saw a lot of designers and developers feel at loss what to do with their navigation, and often it turned out to look something like this. Obviously it isn’t beautiful, but at the time, I can see how it would look like a pretty viable solution. Nevertheless, on mobile, screen real estate is a very limited resource, and the fold, although it is becoming more and more invisible, it is still something as a designers we should all still recognize. It didn’t take any A/B testing to know that the first solution was crap, so everyone started swapping out their navigation for select menus or accordions. But then designers started seeing something that they really liked, off-canvas navigations. I mean why not? Takes up way less screen real estate, super slick, if you’re clever you can find ways to use it to reflect your brand either through look and feel and/or animation, and it gives the designer plenty of space to fit all the navigation they should need. What a great idea, to conserve space, let’s just hide a bunch of content! All the user has to do is click a magical button and the content will be revealed. Seemed like a perfect solution to me and apparently to a lot of other designers. Along side all of this flat design began to take a firm hold of the UI design world. And with that, the use of iconography increased as well. As designs became flatter and more iconographic, suddenly we had designers saying,  “Hmm, what should I put here...I know, an icon!” And recently, icon webfonts have been also become increasingly more popular, if you can use an icon, why not? And boom, the triple-bar or hamburger stack was born. And by born I mean someone somewhere decided that three lines stack on top of each other looks sort of like a list, and a list sort of looks like a menu. So this, ≡ kinda sort of is now the universal icon for a menu? Hmm...let’s back up a little bit. The triple-bar actually has no single meaning, much like an equals symbol, it’s meaning is purely contextual. In logic it means, "if and only if connective" in mathematics it has more than one meaning, and it has several other meaning based on the context it’s used in. You can read about all of them here. And here I am thinking, "Wow, it even has it’s own unicode, that must mean it’s the universal symbol for menu!" When in reality, it was never added to the web with the intended use of being an icon to symbolize a menu, that was just an arbitrary assumption that a lot of designers thought would be intuitive. Over time designers began to question the usability of a triple-bar icon to symbolize a hidden menu. I too began to question it, as I was also using it as a button for my off-canvas navigations. In my research I found many arguments against using the hamburger stack. The most startling is James Foster’s test explored the usability of menu buttons. He tested two different buttons, one a hamburger stack with a border, and another with the word MENU with a border. In Foster’s A/B test, 240,000 mobile visitors were served, roughly half were given the hamburger stack, and the other given the word MENU. Out of all the data collected, the most significant finding was that the MENU button was clicked 20% more than hamburger stack button. Foster has done many other A/B tests on this issue, but this to me is by far the most significant statistic. Granted, every website has it’s own audience and based on your audience they may be more or less familiar with iconography on the web. And Foster also goes on to say,
"I do enjoy A/B testing, but conclude what you want. I’m not an expert, nor am I advising anything, but sharing what happened on a single website."
And I agree with him, you cannot do one single A/B test on one website and apply that information to every design moving forward. And by no means am I suggesting that you move away from the hamburger stack, even though for most client projects I have. What I am suggesting is that as a designer you need to consider all your users, stop making assumptions and remember, even replacing a word with an icon could have a dramatic effect on your users interaction with your site. If you would like to read more about this very important and pressing issue, check out some of the links below.
  • Do Users Understand Mobile Menu Icons?
  • Mobile Menu AB Tested: Hamburger Not the Best Choice?
  • The Hamburger is Bad for You
  • Why and How to avoid Hamburger Menus

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: hamburger stack, usability, user experience, menu icons, ux, ui, responsive menus, responsive navigations

item.title: When Should You Fix Your 404s?
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
When we're doing a website audit, we spend some time investigating errors like 404s, broken links, and missing metadata. These are everyday, run-of-the-mill SEO issues that aren't too difficult to fix if you have the time and knowledge to fix them. Broken links should be corrected. Metadata should always be included with new pages, posts, and images. But what about 404s? Sometimes it's important to fix them. Sometimes it's not. Let's talk about why.

What Is a 404?

Great question. A 404 is what happens when you try to go to a webpage that doesn't exist. If I type in http://www.commercekitchen.com/i-love-donuts-and-monkeys, that page, sadly, doesn't exist on our site. Instead, you get this: Why is it called 404, you might ask? Well, the Internet (technically the Hypertext Transfer Protocol, or HTTP) has a series of status codes that explains what communication is happening between the client side, the HTTP side, and all the other parts that make up the Internet, like servers, etc. Responses in the 400s are Client Error responses. A 404 response means that there's nothing wrong with the server, but that the error is on the HTTP end of things. Meaning, the URL that was typed in or clicked on as a link doesn't point to anywhere. For comparison, responses in the 500s are Server Errors, responses in the 300s are redirects, responses in the 200s indicate various levels of successful communication, and responses in the 100s are informational in nature.

Where Do 404s Come From and How Do I Know If I Have Any?

There is a pack of wild hackers hunched over their desks in a dark basement somewhere, creating client side errors to torment businesses across the known universe. Or not. Yeah, not at all. Actually, 404s are created when: 1. someone types in the wrong URL 2. a page has a new URL or has moved to a new location 3. the page has been deleted entirely. You can learn about 404 issues by enabling Webmaster Tools for your website, and finding out what crawl errors exist. For a more complete list of 404s on your site, Moz's Analytics gives relatively thorough crawl diagnostics of your site, and you can discover in detail where and how often that old URL is linked.

Which 404s Should I Fix?

1. someone types in the wrong URL PROBABLY DON'T NEED TO FIX If someone has typed in the wrong URL, you rarely need to fix this. However, if people are often typing in terrifyinglysadpony.com/contact but the actual URL is terrifyinglysadpony.com/contact-us, then you may want to consider creating a 301 redirect (another HTTP code!), a.k.a. a permanent redirect, so that when people type in /contact they are automatically redirected to /contact-us. 2. a page has a new URL or has moved to a new location FIX THIS NOW If your page used to be called terrifyinglysadpony.com/why-i-write-love-letters-with-my-toes-instead-of-my-hands but you decided to shorten it to terrifyinglysadpony.com/toe-love-letters, then you'll definitely need to redirect the old URL. Also, when you're building a new website your URL structure may be entirely different than it was before. But remember that your old URLs are still floating out there in the never-dissolving abyss of Google's half-baked omniscience. Before you launch the new site, please please please PLEASE take time to figure out how you will redirect your old URLs to your new ones. We spend a lot of time thinking about this and planning for this when we build a new site, and we hope you do too. 3. the page has been deleted entirely YES, BUT WITH DIFFERENT CONDITIONS Why was the page deleted? Was it for a product that you no longer sell? Was it for a promotion you're no longer running? Or was it information that is obsolete? If the URL seems to be getting quite a bit of traffic, then ask yourself this question: why are people going there? If people are looking for a product you no longer sell, then you may want to customize that response to guide them into similar products that might interest them. The same goes for promotions. If you were selling plastic marshmallows for $1.50 each for a limited time only and the promotion is expired, then you may want the target audience for that promotion to see similar promotions. Plastic graham crackers are only $3 this week?! Perfect. I want to know that, especially because I've already purchased a plastic Hershey's bar and a plastic campfire. However, there are times when you won't want to redirect people anywhere. The page is just gone. Maybe an employee who had a page on your site quit. Maybe you're no longer associated with the plastic KOA. In cases like that, it's okay to let people know that the page is gone. And if you really want the search engines to know that the page is gone forever, then you should change the status code for that URL to a 410 response. While the 404 indicates that a page is "not found," the 410 shows the search engines and users that the page "doesn't exist." It's a subtle difference, but one that Google heeds. Here's what Google says about the difference between 404s and 410s:
[W]hen we see a 404 HTTP result code, we'll want to confirm that before dropping the URL out of our search results. Using a 410 HTTP result code can help to speed that up. In practice, the time difference is just a matter of a few days, so it's not critical to return a 410 HTTP result code for URLs that are permanently removed from your website, returning a 404 is fine for that.
Whether or not you want to use a 410 response is up to you. But if there's a page that you want out of Google's index quickly, then a 410 might speed that up a bit.

In Conclusion?

Fix your 404s if it's a page with lots of traffic, if it's an outdated URL, or if it's for an old promotion or product and you have something newer or similar to make up for it. Otherwise, you can let your 404s languish, or you can turn them in to 410s to let the search engines know they're gone for good.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: When Should You Fix Your 404s?
Sometimes it's crucial to fix your 404s by turning them into 301s. But when do you need to pay attention and why?
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/06/fix-your-404s/

item.title: Marketing to Millennials: From the Horse's Mouth
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Let's talk millennials. Millennials - the age demographic of which I land smack dab in the middle - are the subject of much conversation lately. It seems like everyone has an opinion on us. It's practically impossible to throw a rock into a herd of Baby Boomers and Gen X-ers without hitting one person who has spoken and/or written about the us. Let's break it down by each of the hot-button questions that most people seem to ask.

"Who are the millennials?"

We are nothing without our age bracket. So what birth years classify millennials? Many folks say that those of us born between 1980 and 2000 are the lucky kids in at the millennial table. Those years fluctuate depending on who is talking about us. As for me, born in '91, I'm right in the middle. There's no doubt about it: I'm a millennial. It's hard for me to think of the toddlers (those born in 2000) who just started high school as old enough to be millennials, but that's not my call to make. Most people seem to answer "Who are the millennials?" with certain adjectives. Self(ie)-obsessed, driven, tech-savvy, health-conscious, broke, self-confident, single. Paul Taylor, author of The Next America: Boomers, Millennials, and the Looming Generational Showdown, and guest on The Daily Show in March, says we're a bunch of unmarried, ethnically diverse liberals who still live our parents. Others identify us as the children of 9/11: the generation that was shaped by a morning of mourning, which at least half of us needed explanations for by parents and teachers. And there are those that see us as the kids of the Recession: the generation that was deeply affected by the 'greatest economic downturn since the Great Depression,' which has turned us into a bunch of grown-up children. It completely baffles me why people need to ask who we, the millennials, are. For the most part, those questions are coming from book-writing Baby Boomers (born between 1946 and the early 1960s) and Gen X-ers (born between the early 1960s and 1979) in marketing departments. These people are our parents. They are the generations that birthed us. Why do they feel the need to ask others - authors, talking heads, talk show hosts and their guests - who the millennials are? We are your children. And apparently we're the most interesting species on the planet right now, since no one can seem to shut up about us.

"What do millennials want?"

This is the question that all marketers who need to reach a millennial audience seem to ask. And since we're a bunch of broke, leisure time-loving, single liberals, apparently we all want Tinder accounts. [Side note: For the record, no single millennial girl wants a Tinder account. We say we're better than that, but then we sign up two weeks later because a friend-of-a-friend met her boyfriend on it.] What we want is to be student-loan free and spend the next year of our lives traveling around the world with a tall Spaniard named Eduardo. Well, that's what I  want, but unfortunately we can't have everything. Everyone wants to know how we're spending our money, and truthfully, they don't have to think too hard about it. The few extra dollars I have at the end of each month after paying by student loan, rent, utilities, cell phone, car insurance, and health insurance bills gets spent on groceries, and then sometimes dinners and drinks with friends. Sometimes I treat myself with a splurge book purchase from Amazon. Frankly, a lot of my friends that I graduated college with are having the same problems. Out of my group of ten friends at DU, five of us moved back home with mom and dad after graduation, and a few of them are still there. For those us that have left the nest, we all have pretty decent jobs that support us. However, after I've paid all of my aforementioned bills, the extra money that I do have at the end of the month does not go towards drinking gross beer. Nope. Instead, it's going towards a Dollar Shave Club membership, and maybe a tee from Sevenly. Why those two? Dollar Shave Club is saving me a boatload this year, because as a woman, shaving is really goddamn expensive. As for Sevenly, I don't feel as bad about spending $30 on a t-shirt when $7 of it goes towards a charity or organization that I want to support. Plus, the designs are pretty amazing. That's the thing about us millennials: when we find brands we love, we're extremely loyal to them. And once we've established how much we love them, we want to tell everyone about them. This isn't the first time I've mentioned Dollar Shave Club or Sevenly in a blog post. In fact, they've both been mentioned in several of my blog posts. Why do I love them so much? Because it's not just about the product. It's about the experience. Which brings me to our final question...

"How can we market to millennials?"

Unlike our parents, we don't just want to purchase a product and be done with it. I certainly don't. If I have a good first experience with a brand, then I'll be a repeat customer until they show me I was wrong to choose them. For Dollar Shave Club, I found them with a Facebook ad. That's right: a Facebook ad!  After watching the founder's video on the DSC homepage, I was impressed. I scanned the razor options and picked the middle-level, $6/month razor. Then, their checkout process was amazing. It was all on one page! That's unheard of! I'm currently waiting to receive my first shipment of razors. DSC gave me a fun, top-notch experience from beginning to end. And what have I done since then? I've told at least a dozen people about it. Give us an amazing experience, and we'll love you until you prove us wrong. Basically, our Baby Boomer and Gen-X parents told us how 'special' we are one too many times, and that unfortunately has had lasting effects on us. We all want to be made to feel special by our friends, bosses, landlords, and yes, even our brands. At the end of the day, we don't want to feel like we've been lost in the shuffle. Want to know how to market to millennials? Look at the brands we love the most, check out what they're doing right, evaluate what you're doing wrong, and pivot from there.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: marketing to millennials
Marketing to Millennials: From the Horse's Mouth
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/8331105136_7104fa9d87_b.jpg

item.title: Soylent Green is People: Trying to Mitigate Food Time Costs
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded:
Hunger is something most of us deal with on a daily basis.  She's a fickle creature: when we're supposed to eat (mornings), she's nonexistent, like my high school friends. When we're not supposed to eat (midnight), she's an overpowering force to be reckoned with.  And when we're too busy too eat, she keeps taunting us, breaking our concentration, telling us to stop what we're doing and go find some coma-inducing delights.

For most meals, I view food as purely a means of getting nourishment into my body. Obviously food has more function than just fuel, it's a common interest in which all cultures share. It's a focus of most social interactions; it comforts us, brings people together, splits people apart, and is the driving force behind some of our largest industries.  But for me, especially for breakfast and lunch it's mostly just a source of energy.

My usual day goes something like this:

I wake up, make a smoothie for breakfast and start my day.  Then around 10 AM, I'm getting hungry, so I start grazing in the various kitchens of the places I work. This grazing happens all morning until 1 or so, at which time, I'm fully famished and need a proper meal.  But I'm usually in the middle of something, and don't really want to break away from it for an hour to go hunt for some food, and then sit and eat alone in some food dispensing place.  So then there's the internal debate about whether I should just get something delivered. But the ordering process is a pain: calling, waiting, tipping... it's just as easy to go get something. So I head out and pick something up and drive back to work, usually eating in the car in the parking lot listening to NPR, or if I really want to enjoy it, I'll eat at my desk. Then afterwards, a food coma sets in, and I feel compelled to take a nap. It's silly, this whole process, and feels like a total waste of time and money.

Enter Rob Rhinehart and his Soylent project.

[caption id="attachment_6851" align="alignright" width="267"] Soylent™[/caption]

Rob's a software guy (and I think he feels the same way about food as I do), so he put together a Kickstarter campaign to basically create a simple food substitute.  This has gotten a ton of hype, for what is essentially just meal replacement shakes. He's been working on a formula that has all the essential ingredients people need without any of the junk (preservatives, high fructose corn syrup, sugars, dyes, animal fats, etc…).

When I started down this road, Soylent was still beta and wasn't shipping yet.  However, others have been working on their own recipes, so I poached some of those and made one for myself that includes all the things I want. Good quality fats in healthy ratios (Omega 3:6:9), essential minerals, quality carbohydrate sources, insoluble/soluble fiber sources, ample protein during snowboarding season, etc…

I can't tell you how much time this saves me each day.  Every time I'm feeling a bit peckish during the day, I just add my DIY Soylent mix into a meathead protein shaker bottle, add water, and voilá: instant food. Takes 30 seconds! No trash, easy cleanup, no food coma, and it's SUPER cheap.

Most people wonder what it tastes like. It definitely depends on your recipe, but after a few months of tweaking, what I've got is surely palatable.

Is it healthy?

There's been a few documentaries of people eating nothing but Soylent for months at a time and besides shedding some unwanted pounds, their blood work came back with no abnormalities. Rob claims he's been eating mostly Soylent for years, and seems to be doing fine.

You can buy Rob's stuff: they're shipping now, but it's a bit pricey. You can make your own on the cheap, but you'll need to buy all the ingredients in bulk and your kitchen is going to look like something out of Breaking Bad. However, it's really interesting to be able to have absolute control of exactly what you're putting into your body, you can tweak the recipes to fit your needs.

The web is full of productivity tips to save you oodles of time and increase your productivity, and this is just another one.  Depending how much time you spend on food, this can save you hours a day. What are you going to do with all that extra time?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/1184787591_04b09c0427_o-620x620.jpg
soylent
Soylent Green is People: Trying to Mitigate Food Time Costs
Kevin's a hungry guy, and he's discovered that Soylent keeps him nourished without compromising his health with preservatives and other additives.

item.title: Social Media Melancholia: Dealing with the Disillusionment
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Alright social media managers, let's be honest with each other. We work where we should be playing. We create content, publish that content, and manage all of it on social media profiles until we're blue in the Facebook. It's our job, and - just like any kind of marketing - it never ends. So it's time to fess up: how many of you are catching a slight case of social media melancholia?           That's what I thought. If you're one of those social media managers that still is drunk on the social media Kool-Aid (and based on my recent trip to Chicago, there are a fair amount of you out there) please leave now. I have nothing to offer you from this point on. I've been working with Commerce Kitchen for over a year and a half now, and only recently has the social media melancholia hit me. What does that mean?

Social media melancholia /sōSHəl ˈmēdēə ˌmelənˈkōlēə/ noun Disinterest in social media for personal use; disillusionment, based on overexposure to certain social media platforms. Common amongst social media managers.

Truth be told, I would delete my Facebook account if I could still manage the business pages that fall under my job responsibilities. Unfortunately, I can't break free from the tight grasp that Facebook has on me and 1.3 billion other people. In a world where Facebook plays God and Twitter is hard to look away from [especially when Germany demolishes Brazil in a 7-1 World Cup semifinal win], how can we social media managers escape? As a social media manager, from 9 AM to 5 PM Monday through Friday, my eyes are on the major platforms: Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Instagram, LinkedIn, and Google+. Once upon a time, that was my entire day. Recently, my responsibilities have changed, and my time on social media has decreased slightly. However, I still have to check on things across all platforms multiple times per day. If you're a social media manager, you probably have a similar work day and know exactly what I'm talking about. In short: there are only so many times a girl can refresh her Facebook Newsfeeds and Twitter feeds before she goes cross-eyed. The social media melancholia has slowly but surely creeped its way into my life, making me disinterested in using these platforms for personal use after-hours. So what do I do to deal with it?

Unplug and unwind.

That's right, ladies and germs. I actively limit myself to an hour of after-work social media activity. Only an hour to scroll through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, etc., and after that, I'm done. "But Jen, whyyyyyyyyy???" BECAUSE I HAVE TO, THAT'S WHY! If I don't unplug, I O.D., and it's bad. I walk into work the next day not wanting to even look at Facebook. The sight of Twitter will make me gag. Pinterest will make me cringe. Okay, sometimes I miss being active on social media for myself. Just yesterday I was wishing that I had the desire to pin pretty things all over Pinterest (it's been 2 weeks since I last pinned something), and that's what sparked the idea for this blog post. When I opened up Pinterest last night and looked at it sadly, I thought to myself, "I can't be the only one feeling like this, right?" That certainly doesn't mean I don't check in on Foursquare (because Swarm is for posers) or participate in almost every Throwback Thursday on Instagram, but it does mean that I limit my personal activity on those profiles. My tweets aren't as frequent as they once were, and my Facebook posts are even less so. I don't Instagram a picture every single day anymore, and I only pin pretty things when they really catch my eye on Pinterest. There is life outside of social media, and that's a fact that I have to remind myself every week. When the time comes, I'll return to my Pinterest account and go on a binge-pinning session. I'll greet my boards as old friends and pin things on them gladly. Until then, sometimes a girl just has to spend a four days in Calaveras Big Trees without cell or Internet service to detox from the social media melancholia. True story. That's how I spent my 4th of July weekend. Are you feeling what I'm feeling? Do you know what I'm talking about? Or am I just alone with my melancholy in a sea of social media managers on uppers?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: social media
Social Media Melancholia for Social Media Managers
Jen's been struggling with social media melancholia. What does that mean? She's getting disinterested in social media on a personal level. What's the cure?

item.title: From English to HTML: Writing Styles Matter
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_6892" align="alignright" width="300"] Closeup of map of stream names. Orange is arroyo. Using map created by David Watkins[/caption] I'm a web developer, and I have two Bachelor's degrees: one in English, one in Political Science. However, that was not the original plan. I have worked as a web developer for many years, but I feel like I learned some valuable insights in college. Even English wasn't the first major: I started with journalism, but then changed it to English. I'd like to take credit for predicting the death of journalism, but the reality was more personal.

Meeting a journalist under adverse circumstances

During my first year in college, one of my brothers who was too adventurous for his own good decided to cross the deadly ditches—called arroyos—in Albuquerque. There are a number of names for streams that are highly localized such as arroyo, rio, and the most hostile-sounding one: kill. Although they don't sound as in-your-face as "Fish Kill", after a thunderstorm, the water racing down these concrete-lined arroyos can punch a big wallop, one capable of moving trees and cars, so he was knocked down and swept down the arroyo. The other brother with him ran back to our nearby house, and we called 911. In the midst of all that, not knowing if my brother was alive or dead, a reporter from the local paper tried to interview me. I thought, "Do I want to be be like that? That seems a bit...ghoulish. I need to change my major."

Headlines still matter, even on the web

Even though I switched majors fairly early, I still learned to write in short sentences and paragraphs, to keep fancy words to a minimum, and most importantly, to write in most-important-first, details-later style—the style known as the inverted pyramid.  Making yourself write this way tends to make blog posts better. I also learned how to write headlines. Headlines for the web differ a bit from print headlines, but the basics still apply: be short, be clear, minimize words. The big difference with web headlines is that the headline must make sense out of context. I realized the headline was the most re-written part of the story, and is well worth the effort. This still applies: a well-written headline can make or break your Search Engine Optimization (SEO) for pages or open rate for email newsletters.

Switching majors to English

When I did switch my major, I ended up with with a concentration in Professional Writing, my theory being that was a useful skill since tech writing would switch to HTML. By then, I had become interested in this whole Internet thing, but my university, like many back then, wasn't quite up to speed—even though everyone had Internet access. While hanging out with the computer science types (since they had faster computer labs), I learned all about HTML. [caption id="attachment_6902" align="alignleft" width="300"] Everything was square back then.[/caption] I also used my first web browser (Mosaic), and decided it would be cool if I could work on the Internet.  Being a science fiction fan, then and now, it seemed like a way of working in the future. From my English (professional writing) background I learned as well. The focus on knowing your audience has been helpful. Professional writing classes teach you rules, such as 'Always spell out an acronym the first time you use it,' and 'Immediately use the acronym after it to help teach the reader'—hence, Cascading Style Sheets (CSS). Continuing with the know-your-audience theme—If I'm writing to a fellow software developer, I will say "The git repo was rebased and a crucial commit was lost." If I'm writing to a client, I will say, "We were re-organizing the code, and something we needed was misplaced." Both have their purposes. If I sent a more high-level sentence to a developer, they would ask, "Did you mean a rebase?" If I sent the technical jargon to a client, they would say, "Speak English please!" The main thrust behind professional or technical writing is to increase the usability of your documentation. It wasn't a big leap from that to realize that usability can really make or break an otherwise good site. I don't always use the right words for the audience; like most developers, I love jargon. But I try to look for the glazed look or the confused email that indicates I have failed to communicate effectively.

Leaving college for the dreaded "real world" (Not the MTV show)

The other thing my English degree got me was my first job out of college: at an outfit called New Mexico Technet. There were providing teacher email accounts—keep in mind this in the late 1990s. As part of that job, I was sometimes on-call for technical support. This was a real eye-opener for me, and after that I got enthused about usability in a major way, even conducting full-scale usability tests. It's one thing to read an article about seniors using the Internet: it's quite another to see one using a web browser, right clicking in the middle of a website, and saying, "I see some options on this menu, but I can't read them." Those were the grayed-out options. All those web designers with their tiny, light-gray text on white backgrounds should have to use their websites with dark sunglasses on.

The summary, more or less

And what about that Political Science degree? Well, if nothing else, I learned that sometimes the only explanation for why things happen is politics. Oh, for those of you who were wondering, my brother is alive and kicking. Firefighters tied to huge iron rungs in the arroyos for this purpose threw out a net and and pulled him out just before it went underground to the river.

Maybe I should have led with that. Where's my inverted pyramid?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: From English to HTML: Writing Styles Matter
writing styles
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/shutterstock_140141698.jpg
Chad's path to becoming a developer was not a straight one. Instead of HTML, he started writing with an English major in college. The rest is epic history.

item.title: Engage! Elucidations From Comic Con
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
I'm going to tell you a little story. Clever Connie Ryder was a mild-mannered coder at Ga-noodler.com. Ga-noodler was a modern day inter-tubes startup, destined to change the world with their app. This app used a person’s camera-equipped computer to track and correlate their daily eye movement with the phone numbers, call durations, and locations of each phone call they made last year in order to plot and color a continuously changing computer desktop wallpaper image.

Global dominance was clearly in their future.

Connie had been working very long for a couple months, trying to build a new algorithm for a motion shading color picker given a phone number and a few vectors from darting eyes and international phone codes. She was intensely focused on her third attempt. It was nearly complete, when France added new city codes. Her idea crumbled, so she had to make yet another adjustment that just didn't fit. “Those French! How can they be so irresponsible?" she thought. "Can’t they control their biological urges? Their city planning is a joke! How can they randomly divide cities into different code boundaries?” Connie snapped. She had been in a deep dive: under pressure and overly focused on a small subset of inhuman criteria for too long. Given much of today’s software driven business world, who can’t appreciate Connie’s circumstances? Many are even likely to personally identify with her situation. Me? Most definitely. I have walked, strolled, crawled, and gleefully ran down that rabbit hole many times.

Underwater Rabbit Monsters

When engaging in a interesting or challenging new problem, it usually creeps up on me. It’s often just one of several other tasks on the schedule to plan and implement. A story of complexity that quickly mushrooms and is critical to the app, which is due for release “yesterday.” And thus begins the decent: the prolonged exposure to high pressure during a deep dive. Perspective begins to warp. The ultra-focused efforts on the problem restrict judgment of all things except for the problem. Several days into the effort, the change in attitude is noticed, so an even more concentrated effort should solve the problem and end the downward spiral, right? More time focused on innate minutia. Social interaction is reduced to zero. There is no one else in this interesting but odd place, but it’s OK. The deep dive has continued for many weeks. Society is irrelevant, completely shunned until the answer is found. At this point, the answer must be nearby, continue pursuit! Wait, who said that? No matter. Dive. Dive! How has this problem remained so elusive? (Here it comes… ) Maybe a tactical change is all that’s necessary to bring the right solution into focus long enough to clearly see the right answer. Yeah, this is usually a very bad sign. Nitrogen narcosis has set-in. The deep dives are now the bigger problem and the diver doesn’t even notice. [caption id="attachment_6940" align="alignleft" width="184"] Denver Comic Con Facebook[/caption]

Decompression Chamber

One recent Clever Connie cycle was broken for me by Denver Comic Con. A large gathering of rather diverse people exercising and expanding their creativity. Since everyone at Commerce Kitchen is a superhero, we were practically escorted to the site, and what a sight it was. The creative energy of so many [mostly] humans can easily decompress any deep diver, regardless of their background. I have been a Science Fiction fan since my early years. It started with the original Start Trek (TOS) and other TV “classics” (recognized or not), which fueled my imagination with endless visions of future possibilities. Characters, situations, powers, and - of course - damsels in distress, were a weekly fare.  For a young boy that spent his early years in the middle of the mountains with fuzzy reception of two TV channels, this new life in greater Denver brought [probably] 5 channels of [occasionally] amazing visual storytelling right into our living room. It was magical. Alas, TOS went away. Many years and shattered hopes later, a new Star Trek was finally launched, Star Trek: The Next Generation (TNG). That was in 1987. A reunion of the TNG cast was a highlight event at Comic Con, and it was my entryway into an excellent weekend in the decompression chamber.

Balance is important.

Deep dives into efforts can be a fruitful practice, but keep your lifeline attached and acknowledge that it is your lifeline. Find tools to help you regularly visit the surface to keep both your physical and mental abilities sharp and clear. Engage in conversation. Go outside. Drink something other than coffee and/or sugar. Keep your body well nourished, because deep dives are stressful. I use flashy and noisy timers on my work computer to periodically tug on my line. They remind me to do something physical and get outside. That’s what I need to keep my balance. If you haven’t already, start the search for your balance. Find what really works for you so you can continue to fully engage!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:6938;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:14;s:13:"restored_time";i:1404850536;}
comic con
Engage! Elucidations From Comic Con
Russ is one of our excellent senior developers here at Commerce Kitchen, so he sometimes is immersed in a deep dive, unable to surface after a long project.
