item.title: Professional Anti-Adversarialism, or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love My Job
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_6961" align="alignright" width="300"] Me, circa December 2013.[/caption] At the end of last year, I was making myself pretty miserable with work. I love the work I do, trust and respect the people I work with, and sincerely believe that we've got about the greatest team ever assembled in one firehouse; we consistently have positive relationships with our clients. Regardless, I was often on edge, cranky, and wondering when the next fiasco was coming. I was on the defensive half the time, ready to fight my way out of whatever mess was thrown at me. I was, in short, a wreck. After losing sleep, watching my capacity for joy dwindle, and feeling overall pretty shitty for a few months, I forced myself to  dive in and figure out WTF had happened. It hadn't always been this way. I knew it didn't always have to be this way. What I didn't know is why it *was* this way. There were definitely some  crappy trigger events, but crappy things always happen at work; it's my job to creatively, gracefully move through them. Why wasn't I?

Here's what I learned:

1. Adversarialism at work is common, but it's a choice (and a bad one)

At almost every place I've worked, from bookstores to state agencies, there is some variant on the Us vs. Them phenomenon. At the bookstore, it was often The Hardworking, Over-Educated, and Underpaid Staff vs. Our Unappreciative, Ignorant Customers. In state government it was Everyone vs. Everyone Else Except The Three People You Trust And the Lady With The Chocolate. That is to say, in almost all of the places I've worked, there was an adversarial attitude towards some central component of the job. The customers we served, our colleagues in other departments, or even our closest co-workers could be the imagined enemy, the thing we approached from a position of conflict rather than one of collaboration. Interestingly, it was rare that the position of resistance and defense was focused on the work itself. [caption id="attachment_6986" align="alignleft" width="300"] Don Quixote, legendary fighter of imaginary enemies.[/caption] Commerce Kitchen is a lot more wonderful than any of those jobs were, but we have all worked in places where that dichotomy gets ingrained. Some people will stay in a place charged with adversarialism and will feed off of it, and others will keep moving, trying to find a place that resonates with their spirit of service and provides them with the ability to take joy in work they love. CK is filled with the latter type. At CK, I really have no opponent; my misery last fall, like most (first-world) human misery, lived in my brain and in my brain alone. There's no "them" - I was tilting at windmills. I was used to there being an adversarial "them," so when my energy was low I reverted to bad habits instead of rallying optimism and seeking joy in my work. I finally realized that given my position as an owner and fancy-pants person here, that I get to work with my team to create the culture I want. I get to make hiring decisions. I sometimes have to make firing decisions. I get to work with everyone in the company to help all of us try to break the habit of being on the defensive. [caption id="attachment_7011" align="alignright" width="300"] This lion is rightfully ruled by a primitive brain. You and I are not. He is also very handsome.[/caption] We are, after all, no longer on the savannah waiting to eat or be eaten; we are more than our limbic brains and we get to make important and smart decisions using that big, beautiful pre-frontal cortex we developed somewhere along the evolutionary line. Since this revelation, I've heard myself saying, and only half-jokingly, "Let's turn that frown upside down!" - and I've wanted to punch myself in the face. Hard. I can name at least one CK hero who probably wanted to punch me as well (Leslie - I'm looking at you). But I stand by it. We don't have to be miserable. We are empowered to embrace our work rather than go to war with it. And doing so is a lot more fun than fighting.  

2. Serenity. The Serenity Prayer. And sometimes, SERENITY NOW.

[caption id="attachment_7008" align="alignleft" width="250"] Buffy Summers: More of a superhero than I'll ever be.[/caption] The CK exec team recently realized in a search for our core that we're nerds. Big ol' nerds. When asked by our coach, the remarkable Diana Smith, to classify about 10 or so different personality traits that we found compelling and admirable, Natalie hit the nail on the head when she suggested "Whedonesque." The made-up word references a collective hero, Joss Whedon, creator of Buffy The Vampire Slayer. Buffy's team of quirky classmates are smart as hell, tenacious, courageous, adaptable, and humble; they know that they are stronger together than they are on their own, and in a pretty literal way, they are focused on the greater good, which they do by way of ridding the world of vampires and demons. So, you know, a pretty high bar. Calling those core values to mind in a moment of stress can really help create clarity around difficult things. (Note: if Whedonesque describes you and you are a programmer or website designer - call me! I'll buy you lunch or a cocktail and we'll talk about how amazing this company is and how amazing you are.) [caption id="attachment_6984" align="alignright" width="250"] You can't take the sky from me.[/caption] Anyway, Joss also wrote Firefly, in which a ragtag crew of space cowboys and cowgirls ride around the universe in a ship called Serenity doing good work in odd ways. So, the word serenity conjures a bunch of good stuff in the Whedonesque sense, but also, of course, there's the Serenity Prayer, which for the record, pre-dates its adoption by Alcoholic Anonymous. For those 42 people in the whole world who have never been to a 12-step meeting or been in the company of a 12-stepper, here's the prayer:
God, grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change, The courage to change the things I can, And wisdom to know the difference.
One thing that was making me crazy last year was constantly worrying about stuff I couldn't change. Work can be hard, and lot of seemingly insurmountable challenges get thrown your way. Some of those things you can change. Some of them can change you for the better. A whole lot of them can't be changed. It's hard as hell sometimes to quickly "know the difference," but I think it is something we can get better at, if we find the courage to make real change (either in ourselves or in helping others to do the same), or the serenity to let go of things that we can't impact. Of course, that isn't always easy, and so sometimes, it's a bit of a mind game with myself. I often remind myself of those core values (Whedonesque!) in order to reach serenity. I bought a punching bag for when that doesn't work. Sometimes, like Frank Costanza, I really need to remind myself LOUDLY that I need to find some serenity. I remember that I can't win battles that someone or something else is waging without me - and I don't need to try.

3. Stepping away from the worry gives me less to worry about

This may be obvious to some, but it was a revelation (if sort of a "duh!" moment) for me: If I'm not worrying about make-believe BS, then I actually have the time and energy to focus on my job, do it well, and thereby create - SURPRISE! - less BS to worry about! That's right: If I don't keep myself up all night worrying about how to improve morale, how to increase revenue, how to solve a complicated staffing challenge; if I don't focus tons of negative energy on frustrations large and small, I am more well-rested and well-prepared emotionally, mentally, and physically to actually solve those frustrations. By worrying less about my job, I can do my job better. To clarify: That doesn't mean I don't *think* about my job a lot, or spend hours working through the difficult decisions I have to make. Just that I try to not allow myself to *worry* about them as much. If I have to fire someone, for example, I'm going to have to fire them, regardless of how much I worry about it. Positioning that decision as a logical, predictable aspect of my job rather than as some unfair imposition foist upon me by the cruel, cruel world, or worrying if I'm making the right decision or even executing the termination in the most graceful way, that gives me the energy and mental acuity to make the right decision. [caption id="attachment_7000" align="alignright" width="295"] Me showing off all the new friends I'm making since I said "So long!" to trying to win non-existent or unwinnable battles.[/caption]

To sum up: work is, in fact, mostly harmless

So, long story short: I rediscovered that work can and should be fun. And if not truly fun all the time, at least mostly harmless. We should be solving puzzles, understanding ourselves and our co-workers, showing compassion when we can, and screaming SERENITY NOW when we can't, rather than spending countless hours worrying about the inevitable, trying to fix the unfixable, or trying to change the immutable. This is not to say, of course, that everything has been rainbows and kittens since my little epiphany, or that I'm doing this every day. If I don't get good sleep for whatever reason, if my crappy back pain flares up, or too many hits come too quickly, I definitely fall off the serenity wagon. But, I'm trying. I'm getting better. You know - that whole one day at a time thing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: anti-adversarialism
Professional Anti-Adversarialism | Commerce Kitchen
Michelle learned a hard lesson recently: being unhappy at work (regardless of the cause) is a choice. It's your choice. Here's how she overcame her worries.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/07/professional-anti-adversarialism-learned-stop-worrying-love-job/

item.title: Recent Changes in Google Search
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Our beloved/despised search engine, Google, is always changing. We typically give the same advice to people who live in a state of constant anxiety about Google's algorithm updates: create a site that looks good and that's well-optimized for search, then build a strong business with good community connections, interesting and meaningful content, and great customer service, and you will probably do well. Despite anyone's best efforts, a website's rankings are all over the map. Here's an example of traffic from keywords on one of our sites. As you can see, rankings went up and down dramatically over the course of the past month. Putting your faith in Google to keep you at the top of the search results without investing in good business practices is a recipe for disaster. We don't know exactly what Google will do to its algorithm. But we do know some things about the current state of search. Here they are!

The Right to Be Forgotten

Google is now required, by European law, to respond to users in Europe who want to be removed from search results. Some people praise the ruling, saying it protects an individual's right to privacy, whereas others believe it's a dangerous road to censorship. I'm torn on it. Who deserves to police public information? And what exactly is public information? A famous Harvard Law Review article written in 1890 is one of the first pieces to address privacy in an age of changing communication. The following quote applies today, when everyone is a journalist of some sort, even more so than it did 125 years ago:
The press is overstepping in every direction the obvious bounds of propriety and of decency. Gossip is no longer the resource of the idle and of the vicious, but has become a trade, which is pursued with industry as well as effrontery. To satisfy a prurient taste the details of sexual relations are spread broadcast in the columns of the daily papers. To occupy the indolent, column upon column is filled with idle gossip, which can only be procured by intrusion upon the domestic circle. The intensity and complexity of life, attendant upon advancing civilization, have rendered necessary some retreat from the world, and man, under the refining influence of culture, has become more sensitive to publicity, so that solitude and privacy have become more essential to the individual; but modern enterprise and invention have, through invasions upon his privacy, subjected him to mental pain and distress, far greater than could be inflicted by mere bodily injury. Nor is the harm wrought by such invasions confined to the suffering of those who may be the subjects of journalistic or other enterprise. In this, as in other branches of commerce, the supply creates the demand. Each crop of unseemly gossip, thus harvested, becomes the seed of more, and, in direct proportion to its circulation, results in the lowering of social standards and of morality. Even gossip apparently harmless, when widely and persistently circulated, is potent for evil. It both belittles and perverts. It belittles by inverting the relative importance of things, thus dwarfing the thoughts and aspirations of a people. When personal gossip attains the dignity of print, and crowds the space available for matters of real interest to the community, what wonder that the ignorant and thoughtless mistake its relative importance. Easy of comprehension, appealing to that weak side of human nature which is never wholly cast down by the misfortunes and frailties of our neighbors, no one can be surprised that it usurps the place of interest in brains capable of other things. Triviality destroys at once robustness of thought and delicacy of feeling. No enthusiasm can flourish, no generous impulse can survive under its blighting influence.
What are your thoughts? Does the EU's law enforce privacy, propel us toward censorship, or do something else?

Author Images Removed From Search Results

Several years ago, Google began including Google+ author images on search results for webpages that had appropriate markup. However, on June 25th, Google announced it would be removing author images and circle count (how many G+ friend an author has), to make search results cleaner. This is after years of Google trying to convince everyone to hop on board the Google+ train, assuring us that author photos increased the click-through-rate. Author names will continue to appear, which you can see in the search results for my blogs below:

 Google Isn't a Search Tool; It's Machine Learning

I've been saying this for years! Google isn't just designed to help us find the results based on a specific search, even if that's what it used to be. Google is trying to figure out our intention and guide us to the best results based on that assumed intention. Like IBM's Watson, the Google Brain is propelling us toward the singularity.

Bitcoin Currency Conversion Added to Search

Despite Bitcoin's ups and downs this year, it seems to be holding on as an increasingly acceptable form of currency. In response to this, Google has added Bitcoin currency conversion to its search. If you type "25 bitcoins to usd" into the search results you'll get this:
As always, we'll keep on monitoring Google for significant or interesting changes, and we will report back to you as they come.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Recent Changes in Google Search
In the past two months Google has removed authorship photos, implemented Bitcoin conversion in search, and allowed European users to disappear.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/07/recent-google-changes/

item.title: Vacationing: A Pragmatic Approach
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded:
Taking good vacations should be part of any software dev's repertoire (or really anybody's). This prevents burnout, renews creative juices, and just generally keeps morale high.  There are countless experts online discussing the importance of taking time away from work to be more productive at work. Progressive-thinking companies realize the value of providing their employees with generous vacation packages and understand that the benefits usually outweigh the costs.  Turnover is expensive, hiring and retaining good employees is difficult/time consuming, and happy workers make for a happy work place, which in turn benefits everyone. Commerce Kitchen is one such company, offering practically unlimited paid time-off, and genuinely encourages its employees to take advantage of it.

I've been 'professionally' taking vacations for most of the last 10 years; I've tried a whole variety of working schedules to accommodate my unquenchable wanderlust.  I've moved to various countries and worked/lived there. Then, wanting to see more of the world and having not saved a penny, I tried freelancing and traveling at the same time.  Now that I've settled down a bit (i.e. girlfriend), I'm doing the more traditional save-your-money-for-awhile-and-then-enjoy-the-fruits-of-your-labors-by-traveling thing. It all depends on your lifestyle: how much you're willing to risk to have new experiences, what kind of trips you like to take, what kinds of things you want to spend your time off doing, etc... Whatever it is that you want to do on your time off, a change of scenery is often times a wonderful thing for renewing your spirit and changing your perspective. So I'm here to help you open up your options for taking vacations. Here comes the timeshare condo pitch... Just kidding.

Airfare is expensive, so how do you pay for it?

When deciding where to go for a vacation, one of the most daunting expenses is airfare. Especially if you have your sights set on more exotic spots, tickets are more expensive. This keeps many people from seeing places that they've dreamed of seeing. If you've always wanted to see the pyramids in Egypt, that $1500-$2000 flight can be a bit of a deterrent. Well, what if I told you that with a little bit of homework, and some fiscal ninja tactics there's a good chance you won't have to PAY to fly anywhere again? I'm not just talking about domestic flights, but international trips to Istanbul, Shanghai, Manila, Barcelona, or anywhere your heart desires. It's all about the magic of credit card bonuses and making your purchases work heavily in your favor. For most of the last 10 years, I've been solely a cash guy (having gotten myself buried in credit card debt a few times, I swore them off). However, after discovering the rewards that credit card companies are willing to throw your way for a chance at your business, I've become addicted to 'the points game.' Let me give you an example. My next trip is going to be to the Middle East, and a one-way flight from Denver to Tsibili, Georgia costs ~$1200. It's not cheap; there are definitely less expensive destinations, but it doesn't matter because I'm not going to pay anything for that ticket.  I'm using airline miles, which means I must either fly often or spend loads on an airline-affiliated card, right? No. I just use generous signup bonuses.

Credit cards are your friends. No, seriously.

There are lots of credit cards out there that offer bonuses, but lets just look at one. It's the first one I picked up: the Chase Sapphire Preferred card. It's a sexy card with a heavy duty metal inlay; people always comment on it and it's kind of silly. I mostly use it to cut open boxes. They offer a 40,000 mile bonus after spending $3000 in 3 months, and no annual fee for the first year. So at first I thought, "Am I going to be able to put 3k on it in 3 months?" Absolutely! It was easy: I just put ALL of my expenses on it. I consider myself excessively frugal and was still easily able to do it. Gas, groceries, utilities, entertainment... most people have well over 1K in expenses each month.

What does 40,000 miles get you?

United Airline's MileagePlus program has a few different kinds of rewards, but if you plan ahead a bit, you can easily score super saver tickets to most any destination in the world for 30k miles one-way. By doing nothing but changing your method of payment for purchases you were going to make anyway, you've earned yourself a one way international ticket to anywhere in the world. Once you've met your bonus, sign up for another card and do it all over again. For example, the United MileagePlus Explorer Card has a 50k bonus (if you apply at a Chase branch; it's 30k if you apply online), and only a 1k spending requirement. With those two cards alone, you'll have earned enough for 3 international one-way trips to almost ANYWHERE. There are DOZENS of these cards with awesome bonuses; it's just an endless sea of miles and free trips. Maybe you don't care about international travel and are mostly into more luxurious vacations and staying in nice resort style hotels? There are lots of great hotel cards that offer great deals on hotel accommodations as well, plus you can use miles to upgrade and fly business/first class.

Traveling on a budget is possible, you just have to be smart about it.

Imagine the next trip you take, you won't have to even consider the price of the ticket, just the destination you're going to go.  It'll change the way you travel, and thus maybe change your life a little.

The key to making all this work is that you've got have at least a decent credit score and not carrying any credit card debt.  If you're paying interest on any of these purchases it really negates any of the rewards.  It's almost always better to get your credit card debt zero'd before beginning to play the points game.

There are lots of sites devoted this lucrative world of credit card bonus management. Conceptually it's simple, but with the bajillions of deals out there, it's great to have them all consolidated in one place. My favorite is The Points Guy, (who also has a really helpful beginner's guide) but there are many places that have the same information. Another great tool is Awardwallet, which lets you manage all your miles in one place.

Do it now, get started right away and before you know it, you'll be going to places you never imagined you'd be seeing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Vacationing: A Pragmatic Approach |Commerce Kitchen
Kevin's been traveling around the world sporadically over the past 10 years. How does he do it on a developer's salary? Here's a hint: credit card rewards.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/shutterstock_154580843.jpg

item.title: How Do You Wireframe?
item.dc:creator: Goodtimes
item.content:encoded:
When I was in college one of my design professors told me, “Wireframes are great, everyone agrees that they’re something that should be done in the planning process. Funny thing is, no one can agree on what they actually are supposed to look like.” Now that I’ve been making them for over two years, I think I can shed some light on the topic

What's a Wireframe?

Wireframes are essentially blue prints for your website or application. The reason they are visuals instead of written is that it’s really hard to describe in words what a particular view might look like. If I say, “the blog will have pagination.” This could mean a variety of different things. Is it going to have next and previous arrows, will it show the total number of pages, or will it just be a button a link the most recent post? Not only that, but a client might not know what you mean when you say pagination, which is essentially a language barrier. If there’s one thing that we know for sure is that everyone can agree what a square looks like.

Why Should I Make Wireframes?

The most crucial part of wireframes is that they show the backend functionality. In other words, the wireframes serves as a visual tool to get the project managers, designers, developers, and the client all on the same page. It also serves as a tool to show the client what content will need to either be created or gathered. Which is great because we all know how eager clients are to create/gather content for their new website/app!

The other most important aspect of a wireframe is that it serves as a document to be referenced by all parties. For instance, the client decides they want to add search to their website but doesn’t think they should have to pay for it. Well, just bust out those wireframes and show them that it was never included in the original scope of work. In this way, they serve as a reference document to help you and your client avoid scope creep as well as superfluous change requests.

Finally, they serve as a starting point for layout and design. It’s not to say that layout might change during the design phase. However, I tend to lean toward getting layout nailed down in the wireframe stage, as I feel that if not addressed then it’s a missed opportunity. Also, once wireframes are locked down and approved by both parties, it’s more difficult to change than it is to stay within the specifications of the wireframe.

High vs. Low Fidelity

Like my professor mentioned, there are many different ways of creating wireframes, some are drawn on a napkin, others are created with interactivity built into the wireframe. Below are three different levels of fidelity, from very low to very high. [caption id="attachment_7072" align="alignleft" width="300"] Photo Cred: Oykun Yilmaz[/caption][caption id="attachment_7074" align="alignleft" width="300"] Photo Cred: Bluroon[/caption][caption id="attachment_7073" align="alignleft" width="300"] Photo Cred: Haraldur Thorleifsson[/caption] As you can see there is a huge amount of variation in terms of how detail is in each wireframe. From hand drawn boxes representing content, to showing font choices and strict layout. Both high and low fidelity wireframes have their advantages and disadvantages, here are some things to be aware of when deciding how much detail you want to include in your wireframes

Advantages to Low Fidelity Wireframes

Low fidelity wireframes biggest advantage is they’re super fast and easy to make; so fast that you could be in a meeting with a client and start sketching ideas out on a whiteboard. They’re also a really great way to get you ideas out quickly without getting hung up on the details like font choices, colors, etc. Also, if you can convey your idea in a sloppy, low-fi wireframe, then there’s no way it will ever work in a higher fidelity wireframe. And finally, there’s more flexibility for changes in layout during the design phase.

Disadvantages to Low Fidelity Wireframes

Since low-fi wireframes lack so much detail, it’s easy for the nuances to get overlooked. Sometimes they are so low-fi that only the person who drew them understands them. And because of these nuances, it can give you the sense that you’re finished with wireframes and can move on to the design phase. Only to find out while designing that you still don’t have enough direction to start putting together a design. Also, they often lack proper annotation.

Advantages to High Fidelity Wireframes

The biggest advantage to high-fi wireframes is that they help dramatically for the back end developers. A developer should be able to look at all your wireframes and start to recognize patterns in layout, shared components, and typography. At this point, your developer may be able to warn you of potential pitfalls in development. They’re usually accompanied by well documented annotations, and it should serve as a nice starting point for design.

Disadvantages to High Fidelity Wireframes

Since they have so much more detail and include things like fonts, colors and specific layouts, it’s really easy for the client to get hung up on design details when they should really be focusing on functionality and hierarchy of the elements/components. They require more time and subsequently more money. Since they’re starting to show design, it may actually hinder the designer during the design phase because they feel like they have to follow the wireframe to the T. Furthermore, once approved by the client, it’s much harder to change things like layout or font sizes without the client asking why?

Where Should I Land?

There are two different approaches to creating successful wireframes. The first is starting with low-fi wireframes and iterate on those, then from there make higher fidelity wireframes. This approach does take more time but the idea is it should save you time in the design phase. The second is try to land somewhere in the middle. Avoid using actual type and try to keep it to boxes and lines to represent where type will go. The idea here would be to try and keep the wireframe stage pretty short, leaving you more time in the design phase to work out all the little nuances not depicted in the wireframe.

Things That Have Helped Me

First things first, draw a sitemap. These should be quick easy way to figure out user flows and serve as a list of all the wireframes that need to get created. Next, outline your wireframes into simple bulleted lists. This will help you figure out all the components you want to include in your wireframe, the order (hierarchy) you want them to appear in. For instance:

Resources Template
  • Page Title
  • Resource
    • Resource Title
    • Description
    • Download Button (external link)
  • Sidebar
    • Search
    • Featured Blog Post
      • Title
      • Excerpt
      • Read More Button
    • Arbitrary Text/HTML Widget
    • Social Media Profile Icons

This will help you during the wireframing stage. You can get approval on these from the client, marketing, and project managers before even starting to sketch wireframes. And they also help the client figure out what content they need to find and/or create. Lastly, annotate the heck out of them! The last thing you want is to have a developer build something based off of what they saw in the wireframe, and just simply read it wrong. Also, you will probably find more elegant solutions by forcing yourself to write out what it is the component actually does.

Tools and Resources

The most common tool used for wireframes is Illustrator. I feel like a lot of designers prefer to do wireframes in Illustrator because that’s what they’re comfortable with. However, seeing how we spend so much time in Illustrator designing things, I think it’s too tempting to mess around with silly things like border radius, color, and even fonts. InDesign can also be a really great tool for wireframes. You can have master pages that include a header, hyperlink elements to other pages in the PDF, and in terms of a design program, it acts the most like HTML/CSS does than any other design program. Mockingbird is another wireframe tool that I like. It’s really not pretty, but it has a ton of prefab elements that you can just drag and drop into your wireframe. It’s a super quick way of creating wireframes, and because it’s so simple, it keeps you from over designing too much during the wireframe stage.

There are many other wireframing tools out there, some very robust, and some more like Mockingbird, aimed to keep you limited in your ability to design. Check out some other tools here.

I hope this was helpful and I invite anyone and everyone to share their own personal experiences or processes for wireframing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: wireframe

item.title: Blogging is Hard: The Ballad of a Developer
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded:
Rarely am I serious. Most anyone who's ever talked to me knows that I don't often give a straight response to a question or say anything that makes one iota of sense. There's a reason for that, and it's that the serious Eric - the real Eric - lives in a world of constant anxious turmoil. Every month I am tasked with writing a blog. I would fathom a guess that of all the blogs I've written, only one has ever been completed when it was supposed to. That includes this one, now over a week late. Usually when it's late I take the typical route of joking about it, which is something I need to work on not doing. In all reality however, blogging takes an unbelievable toll on my mental state. In the week leading up to the blog due date, it's really all I think about, usually to an end result of increased frustration with myself because I can't ever think of what I want to write about. The problem is not so much a lack of topics to write about, it's an issue of what do I actually want to write about. I could rattle off 200 great blog ideas in five minutes, sure. What's wrong with that is that of those 200 ideas, I would feel motivated to write about maybe one. This is something I've dealt with my entire life, if I don't feel passionate about the task before me, my motivation level drops to near zero.

Edison's Inventions

Last night, I was thinking about Thomas Edison and how many inventions he created over the course of his life. It seems as if he invented something every month, and so many of his inventions are fantastic, things we still use today. As I was thinking about this, it occurred to me that he was doing his own thing, at his own pace. I would hazard a guess that's part of what made him so great. I imagined, what if Edison was taking orders from someone who said, “I need an invention every 30 days.” Do you think his inventions would have had the impact they do today? How long did it take him to make the light bulb? Probably not 30 days. Had Edison been tasked with creating something every 30 days, he probably would not have unleashed the amount of great inventions he did. He probably would have just come up with a lot of 'filler inventions' - things he created just to appease the powers that be. Not meaning to compare myself to Edison, I feel the previous point speaks volumes when it comes to blogging. When there is pressure to complete something, oftentimes less is achieved, whether it be in terms of the overall product or the quality of the product. It is only through time and careful thought that I am able to create a blog. It's through this process that the overall blog writing process is streamlined. Consider this: every single one of my previous blog posts took no fewer than 4 hours each. This blog post (something I feel very strongly about) has taken me 7 minutes, as of this sentence. Please don't misconstrue this as meaning that I feel blogs are not important. I get it, they are. It requires no reiteration. That however is precisely why blogging does take such a toll. It's that nagging feeling of knowing that I need to do this, but I can't for the life of me actually complete it because I don't feel strongly about doing it in the slightest.

My Zone of Incompetence

So how do I handle this problem? Like last night, the solution was to go to sleep at 6 pm and stay that way for the next 12 hours after having a full blown panic attack. While that works to put an end to panic attacks, it's not exactly a “solution” when it comes to blogs. Our fearless leader, Tynan, recently gave a lightning talk on something called Satori. In essence, it's understanding where your strengths and weaknesses are in life. There are four Zones: of Incompetence, Competence, Excellence, and Genius. Blogging for me falls into the Zone of Incompetence: the definition of which (per our fearless leader) is as follows:
“The Zone of Incompetence is made up of all the activities we’re not good at. Others can do them a lot better than we can. Surprisingly, many successful people persist in wasting time and energy doing things for which they have no talent. The best way to handle most things in your Zone of Incompetence is to avoid doing them altogether. Delegate them to someone else, or find some other creative way to avoid doing them.”
This rings so true for me as writing in general has never been my forte. According to Satori (and the fact that blogging falls into what I consider my zone of incompetence), I should avoid it altogether. That however not being an option for me, I feel I must take the latter route according to Satori: find a creative way to avoid doing it. What I feel would fit my personal blog style much better is to simply do what I do for a living, what I would say falls in to or between the zones of excellence and genius: programming. Perhaps someday I can be rid of the writing portion of blogs altogether, and just create fun and/or creative programs that help others. Upload a zip file, jot down a quick 2 or 3 sentences about what it does, and that would be that. It doesn't hurt to dream...

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Blogging is Hard: The Ballad of a Developer
blogging is hard
As a developer, Eric doesn't enjoy writing blog posts. It's not so much idea generation, but the actual process of blogging gets him down. Blogging is hard.

item.title: What is Commitment in Scrum?
item.dc:creator: Casey
item.content:encoded:
I’ll come right out and say that I lean as a Scrum traditionalist. I was mentored in a shop where everything revolved around the team’s commitments. Those commitments were canonical. However, they were never clear pictures of what was likely to actually happen. If our estimates were off, we stayed late and got it done. If our internal Product Owner suggested that we make a change during the Sprint (how dare they!) - it was civil war. We did everything and anything to protect that commitment. I spent a lot of time measuring how we did compared to our original commitment. This way of thinking, on the surface, has a lot of upsides. Product Owners know what they’re going to get, and by when.  Development teams want to spend the time digging into the details and tasking items out, as they’re going to be held to the estimate.  Everyone feels warm and fuzzy.  Well, not everyone. The reality of custom development is that it’s close to impossible to perfectly estimate every line of code that you’ll write, API that you’ll integrate with, or view that you’ll generate.  During estimation, we’re talking in the abstract.  We’re making a best guess.  We should feel good if our estimates are within 25% of what that task or story ends up taking.  This reality can leave development teams in a bit of a bind when it comes to true commitment.  Sometimes quality is compromised, and often our sleep suffers.

So, what would be better?

In 2011, The Scrum Guide actually updated the language around commitment to forecasting.  When we forecast, it encourages better behavior, and relieves some of the stress developers feel about committing to something they can’t yet fully understand. We still estimate our Epics and Stories, and then move them over to the Product Backlog.  If you have a fabulous tool like Pivotal Tracker, it will automatically use your velocity to predict what you can get done in a given iteration. The Scrum Master can adjust your team strength when folks go on vacation, and see how the forecast changes.  The Product owner can go in and adjust priorities in the backlog, and see where things are likely to fall.  As long as we haven’t starting working that story yet, we don’t have to worry about the impact to the Sprint Commitment. As we get into development on our stories, and our estimates change, we can adjust them, and then our forecast adjusts. Forecasting (automatic planning) is the default behavior of Pivotal. You can check a box to turn it off, but probably at your own peril. So what, if anything, are we committing to? We’re actually committing to the same things that we did before:
  • understanding the problem we’re trying to solve, and proposing amazing solutions with software
  • breaking the effort down in to estimable chunks, and estimating the effort as accurately as we can
  • working hard every day to on the stories that are likely to have the greatest impact on our client’s businesses
  • being open and transparent as to where we are at with a given task, story, or sprint, including when estimates need to change
Still doing this the old way with hard and fast sprint commitments? Try forecasting, and see if a pretty simple change can make a big impact on your team’s rhythm.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: commitment in scrum
What is Commitment in Scrum?
Casey's a Scrum traditionalist. What does that mean? He likes to manage projects where we stick to the game plan. Here's how to manage commitment in scrum.

item.title: Here's Why I Give
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
Last week a canvasser from the Blue Bench (formerly the Rape Assistance and Awareness Program) came to my door, and while I often politely and nervously tell canvassers to leave, I decided to listen to her spiel and donate some money to the cause. This inspired me to reflect on giving. It's incredibly important to me to contribute to organizations who do good work, and I encourage everyone to give even a small amount. Nonprofits have suffered immensely in the economic downturn, and even as the economy recovers, nonprofits continue to have less money and face increased demand for services. One of Commerce Kitchen's core values is generosity of spirit. For us this means making the effort to give our time, knowledge, assistance, and breakfast burritos to each other, our clients, our business partners, and our community. I incorporate this value into my life, and here are the organizations that I give money to because they probably don't need breakfast burritos:

Black Girls Code

In 2013, only 19.7% of software developers were women. And only 4% of those women were black. If the number of black women devs was directly proportionate to the number of black women in America, there would be at least 36 black women developers for every 300; instead, there are only two. At larger companies, the median income for an experienced software developer is $90,000. In comparison, the median income for black households is around $33,000. Kimberly Bryant, an engineer, founded Black Girls Code in San Francisco after her daughter came home disheartened by her experience at computer science camp. The organization now operates in several cities across the United States, and nearly 75% of its students attend the code school on scholarship. We've written quite a bit on the CK blog about getting more women into tech, but the problem isn't simply a gendered one. It's also about race, economics, and basic access. Black Girls Code aims to give girls of color exposure to great teachers and resources so that they have the knowledge, experience, and confidence to enter into technical fields as adults. I love this organization, and I hope we can convince them to come to Denver.

My neighborhood school

My daughter starts Kindergarten next month. Just writing those words provokes a spasm of terror in my heart. But aside from the reality that my daughter is growing up at a freakishly fast pace, there is also the reality that Colorado spends nearly $1800 less per pupil per year than the national average. Teachers at my neighborhood school don't have the budget to buy items like whiteboards, books, games, and storage bins, so they ask for help on websites like Donors Choose. Even if you don't have children, donating to your neighborhood school benefits everyone. A study conducted in 2011 shows that good public schools create happier communities, even for people without kids:
The researchers discovered a strong correlation between community satisfaction and quality schools. The better the schools (as people perceive them), the more satisfied people are with their communities — and this is true whether they have children attending them or not. This positive relationship holds even after the researchers controlled for other community and individual characteristics, suggesting, they write, that “public school quality uniquely contributes to community satisfaction” above and beyond other common explanations, such as high rates of homeownership or job availability.
I give to my neighborhood school not just for my child (in fact, I gave to it before she started there), but to support the community I'm part of.

Brady Campaign

I've known several people who have died from guns. Many Americans do. I moved to Colorado in 1998, and since then there have been two horrendous mass shootings, at Columbine High School and the Aurora movie theater. Growing up I went to camp for a month every summer in the northern woods of Minnesota. I rode horses, canoed the Boundary Waters and the Crow Wing river, sang cheesy songs around the campfire, and cried when I had to go back home. I was also a pretty good marksman. [caption id="attachment_7119" align="alignleft" width="300"] The author (front row, center, in the black tank top), at Camp Birchwood. Early 1990s.[/caption] I shot my first rifle when I was eleven, and I quickly earned up to the Sharpshooter Bar 4 certificate, through the NRA Marksmanship program. I loved shooting. We were taught to be incredibly careful around guns, and I never once even thought of them as a weapon. I liked shooting paper targets. I liked holding my breath so that I could keep the barrel of the rifle steady. I liked the thrill of seeing the bullet holes in my target. And I liked turning the empty plastic ammo boxes into painted jewelry boxes. My final year at camp, right before I started my sophomore year of high school, they took away the NRA Marksmanship program and replaced it with another. I was disappointed. I'd looked forward to earning my Expert certificate and hanging each badge on my wall next to its corresponding targets. After I came home from camp, I spoke with my parents about it, and I learned what the NRA was becoming, and why so many parents protested against the camp continuing the NRA Marksmanship program. [caption id="attachment_7123" align="alignright" width="300"] Katherine Welles / Shutterstock.com[/caption] Note that the camp didn't get rid of the rifles. We could still access the rifle range, shoot at the same targets we'd always shot at, and enjoy responsible access to guns. Instead, the camp took a stance against an organization that was increasingly becoming less and less about responsible and reasonable gun ownership and more and more about deregulating an industry that has enormous safety implications. This is why I give to the Brady Campaign. Since then, I've known several people who have died from gun violence, including one person killed in a mugging, one person killed while trying to break up a fight between people he didn't even know, and several people who've died from suicide with guns. Consider giving to an organization that helps tackle violence through research, education, direct action, intervention, rehabilitation, or some combination. There are so many great nonprofits out there; give to one that matches your passion.

California WIC Association & Food Bank of the Rockies

[caption id="attachment_7121" align="aligncenter" width="509"] Riding a bike while pregnant. Yes, I did it all.[/caption] I found out I was pregnant during the first month of my final year of graduate school. My partner at the time and I were excited but nervous, as all parents-to-be are. The baby was due June 30th--just a few weeks after I was scheduled to graduate. I would still have health insurance through the university, and I had secured a paid instructor position for the entire school year. However, as many instructors, adjuncts, and TAs know, that pay is pretty slim. My partner wasn't making a ton of money either, and we discovered that we qualified for WIC (Women, Infants, Children). WIC is a government program that provides food assistance to pregnant women, breastfeeding women, and children up to age five. I signed up for the program, and I was given checks every month for cheese, milk, tuna, peanut butter, carrots, cereal, bread, and juice. It was such a great supplement to have, and it really helped us out when we were struggling. I finished my Master's exams, graduated with honors, then my baby was born ten days late on July 10th. I began immediately cobbling together different jobs: I was doing research for a professor, contracting with a company I worked for before grad school, and writing trivia rounds for a pub quiz company based out of Colorado, Geeks Who Drink. When my daughter was four-months-old we moved back to Colorado, and I stopped receiving assistance from WIC. My partner had a much better job, and I secured a great position here at Commerce Kitchen. Since then, I've been giving money to the California WIC Association, and I think that I've more than repaid them for the assistance they gave me when I needed it. Getting access to good food is critical, and it can be especially difficult for children in impoverished communities to be adequately nourished. This is why I also give to the Food Bank of the Rockies. Giving to your local food bank is an incredibly easy and direct way to impact the lives of people in your city, and while it's not necessarily about community empowerment or social justice, it is a service that people depend on and genuinely appreciate.
I also give almost every time a cashier at a grocery store asks me to donate a few bucks for cancer research, children's health, the Red Cross, or any number of organizations. In my monthly budgets I consider giving a non-negotiable, like paying my electricity bill. Even if you don't make much, it's always possible to give. Earlier this month at LAX I found $20 on the ground. Instead of pocketing it, which I seriously considered, I decided to pay for a few strangers' coffees. Not only was that more fun for me than keeping $20, but it also created a tiny bit more joy for several other people. I know I'm being cheesy, but hopefully in turn this helped those people be a little more patient, a little kinder to someone else in their lives. Giving is the gift that keeps on giving.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Why I Give to Nonprofits
Natalie discusses why she gives to Black Girls Code, her neighborhood school, the Brady Campaign, and the California WIC Foundation.

item.title: The Myers Briggs Test is a Lie: How I became a personality hipster and took the OCEAN quiz
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
I'm a Myers Briggs Hater, it's true

Why is the Myers Briggs personality test a lie? The Myers Briggs test uses theories of Carl Jung from 1921 with no empirical evidence to back them up.  People taking the test twice often get different results. Just as bad, the results insist on sorting people into one of two categories, rather than a more realistic spectrum  No one is 100% extraverted or introverted. Also bad:  each of the 16 personality types has only positive descriptions.

The Big Five Personality Model

It turns out psychology has advanced since 1921. The most widely accepted model is the Big Five personality test — Try the online quiz if you have a short attention span. The Big Five test is also known as the OCEAN test, for Openness to experience, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.  Those of you who have taken a Myers Briggs test will notice that exactly one factor made the cut. Here's a summary (from this website)
  • Openness to experience - Appreciation for art, emotion, adventure, and unusual ideas; imaginative and curious.
  • Conscientiousness - A tendency to show self-discipline, act dutifully, and aim for achievement.
  • Extroversion - Energy, surgency (a $25 psychology word for happy: I guess insurgents are very unhappy), and the tendency to seek stimulation and the company of others.
  • Agreeableness - A tendency to be compassionate and cooperative rather than suspicious and antagonistic towards others.
  • Neuroticism - A tendency to easily experience unpleasant emotions such as anxiety, anger, or depression.
[caption id="attachment_7179" align="alignleft" width="228"] Research page of the outofservice.com website, featuring its humorously dated design[/caption] That same website also discusses the weaknesses of the Big Five Model. The way my brain works as a science nerd, talk of limitations and criticisms makes me more likely to trust something, not less. For instance, that site noted that people who are neurotic tend to be less extraverted, so maybe there's an underlying factor explaining both. It also has a page discussing Big Five research results using a font similar but not identical to Comic Sans and a notebook paper background (no really). It's worth it if you like reading about science papers though. Another point worth making: unlike the Myer Briggs test, there can be negative aspects to each personality factor. I found an interesting page discussing each of the Big Five personality factors in more detail, including discussion of some negative aspects that can come from each factor. I think the improved validity of the Big Five personality model makes it a more useful tool for figuring out what job is right for each person than the Myers Briggs, which is sadly used far more often. An artist needs to score high on Openness, but that doesn't always make Openness a good thing. I don't know about you, but I really want the person in the nuclear silo to score low on Openness, and Neuroticism and high on Conscientiousness. A creative artist is great: a creative accountant, not so much.

My Favorite Big Five Quiz

[caption id="attachment_7163" align="alignright" width="217"] Big Five (OCEAN) test website, with its interesting color scheme[/caption] I have taken different online quizzes of the Big Five personality test. My favorite is this quiz on the oddly named outofservice.com website. In addition to being affiliated with a psychologist, it also has a good usability factor, because each question has the Strongly Disagree and Strong Agree right next to each question rather than at top.  Other tests only show it at the top and it scrolls out of site, and if you're like me, you worry that you're forgotten which side is which. Another nice feature is that you can add another person, rate them on the Big Five, and at the end you can compare your scores.

My Personality Results

I have taken the OCEAN test multiple times—and gotten similar results each time. While I'm too neurotic (spoiler alert!) to share my actual numbers, I aways score about the same:  a bit introverted, in the middle on agreeable, low on conscientiousness, and very high on openness and neuroticism.

Takeaways, including political ones

There are all sorts of interesting takeaways from the OCEAN model. To wade into possibly fraught waters, it's been found that politics and some of these dimensions have some correlation. Liberals tend to score high on openness to experience, while conservative tend to score higher on conscientiousness. If you want to meet a liberal, go to an art gallery; if you want to meet a conservative, join the military. Since I've already gone political, I might as well talk about the tech sector. I've noticed that the tech sector skews to the left politically more than other sectors. Given that there's always something new in this business, that makes perfect sense in light of the Openness factor. The 2012 presidential election campaigns reflected this: the Obama campaign's website used an open-source approach using new technologies while Mitt Rommney's ORCA crashed.

So you know your OCEAN numbers.  Now what?

So does the fact that I am a worrywart have a high neuroticism score doom me to a life of worrying? I don't think that needs to be the case. When I work to turn down the worrying and let my Openness lead me to new and interesting things, I am a much happier person. It's worth actively working on any personality factor you don't like, while being realistic enough to acknowledge that can only go so far from your basic setting. For instance, I was supposed to finish this blog post yesterday.  But still, for me, a day late is pretty good, so trying to up my conscientiousness, lower my neuroticism, and embrace my openness seems a worthy goal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/shutterstock_172366430.jpg
myers briggs
The Myers Briggs Test is a Lie | Commerce Kitchen
Chad's not a big fan of the Myers Briggs personality test. What does he prefer instead? It's called the Big Five personality test, and it's more accurate!

item.title: A Road Trip with My Dog
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
It's no secret. Here at Commerce Kitchen we love our dogs.

We love our office dogs

As soon as I chomp on a carrot, Peaches is at my side. She stomps and sighs until I give her carrots. So I feed her lots of carrots. :-) Ripley flies up the office stairs, looking to see who's here, who isn't here, and who's ready to play with a koosh ball. She greets me every morning, and of course, the game of fetch never gets old. Peanut, our newest addition, is part-cat and part-dog. If you aren't paying attention while in a conference room meeting, you may end up with Peanut on your lap or on the table in front of you. He's got the ups of a Jack Russell...I kid you not. And there's my dear old pup. Woodford only makes it to the office occasionally given his hyper tendency to run around and get into everything on all three levels of our firehouse. While I sometimes miss having him by my side, he's simply the perfect productivity time suck since he must be monitored every minute of every day. So I was really thankful to be able to take off work for a few weeks earlier this month, rid him of his separation anxiety and drive to my parents' lake house in South Carolina with Woodford in tow. While the 2-day, 26-hour drive there and the 3-day, 28-hour drive back were not on the top of the "this is what I want to be doing with my time" list, the drives and the subsequent time spent in rural SC forced me to reflect on some things, and appreciate living in the now.

Take breaks

It's so easy to forget sometimes to stop and smell the proverbial roses. But with a dog, you have to. Every four hours or so, Woodford got restless (well, more restless than his usual car pacing) and needed to run around. Plus, Peter and I could only handle driving for about four hours at a time. So we stopped, and enjoyed the beauty of the open fields, and windmills of Hays, KS. And we made some laps around St. Louis' Gateway Arch. On the way back, we ate BBQ in Memphis, and ran around the countryside in Wichita. It was actually quite fun to plan a road trip that centered on dog parks (or slightly illegal, but sometimes more fun, open spaces for off leash gallivanting) and fun, local places to eat.

Make fun your first priority

[caption id="attachment_7200" align="alignleft" width="300"] Before[/caption] As Kevin mentioned in his Vacationing post, taking trips helps you reset and prevent burnout. For me, resetting can only happen when I do something completely different than what I get to do every day. Take a nap at 2pm. Float in the lake and chat with good friends. Hop on a boat and watch the sun set over the water. Enjoy the fireworks with my family. For Woodford, his priorities were a bit different. They mainly involved a ball, and the lake. Ideally they involved swimming to said ball, when it was thrown into the middle of the lake. He put fun first, and worried about everything else second. And by helping him have fun, I found that I was having more fun too.

Be thankful

[caption id="attachment_7201" align="alignright" width="300"] After[/caption] Woodford was just thankful to have a whole house of people to throw the ball for him, to take a dip in the lake when the temps soared, and to greet me after I opened the office door after my conference calls. I have an amazing job that I find joy in every day, but sometimes you just need to get away. I am thankful that I have a team that can support me and cover for me when I do just that. I am thankful for the friends that drove several hours to see me. And I am thankful for all of the time that I got to spend with my family, especially my new niece. Here's to hoping that I can keep this kind of perspective now that I am back at the office, and once again running at 110mph. I can't wait to plan my next trip with Peter and Woodford.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Road Trip with My Dog: How to Put Fun First and Be Thankful
During a multi-week, cross-country road trip, Leslie reflects on her dog's attitude towards life and tries to take some of those lessons to heart.

item.title: Everything Currently Wrong with Facebook
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
I know, I know. "Not another blog post about your issues with Facebook, Jen!" YES! Another! It's pretty apparent that I'm not friends with Facebook anymore. I've written about my roller coaster of emotions on Facebook again and again and again and again. However, I've never truly sat down to write each piece of beef that I have with the social media juggernaut. To be clear: my issues are not with Facebook as a company. In fact, they're performing rather impressively at the moment; their Q2 2014 earnings were the equivalent of the GDP of the country of Guyana. Whether or not that is a good thing, I'll leave the decision up to you. So what's wrong with Facebook as a social media platform? Two things.

It treats brands (especially small businesses) like sh*t.

I basically covered this one like butter on toast in my open letter to Facebook's Advertising Program post, but let me give you the Reader's Digest version of it. For a client's social media profile, we paid for Facebook ads to get Page Likes. We got the Likes; in fact, we got over 6,000 of them. Yet, our posts weren't being seen by those 6,000 people. On the contrary, they were (on average) being seen by less than 800 users per post, and that was while we were still using paid advertising for Page Likes. When we temporarily stopped our campaigns, the numbers dropped to below 200 users per post. Here's what's difficult for me and the rest of our marketing team to understand: we paid to get the Likes, we still have the Likes, so why do we have to pay more to get those users (who have ALREADY LIKED OUR PAGE) to see posts from that page? "Cleaning up News Feed Spam" is one thing. Stealing money from small businesses is another thing entirely.

It makes you, the user, feel like sh*t.

Pretty notoriously, Facebook manipulated the News Feed for almost 700,000 users to see if it could elicit certain emotions. That's right. They made people feel like sh*t on purpose. Who does that? A platform with its priorities out of whack, that's who. Not only that, but they've made addicts out of so many of us that we're starting to result to Facebook detoxes and/or 'quitting' it for 99 days to test our willpower. In truth: I don't like checking Facebook. It annoys me that I rely on it so heavily for communication with my friends and family. Every time I click the Refresh button in my browser to see the latest updates in my News Feed, a little piece of my soul wilts away. Checking Facebook is starting to become a part of our daily routines, and, in my opinion, that's a really bad sign of where we're at on the Internet-level of the general scheme of things. And it's not just me! A recent study showed that people who spend more time on Facebook are less happy than those who spend fewer minutes per day on the social media platform. I'm feeling sad just thinking about that.
Whether you are a user or brand representative, you need to stay educated about all of these not-so-minor issues with Facebook and its ego. In our wide world where 1 billion of us use this social media platform, will there be an end to Facebook's reign? Possibly. I've said it once, and I'll say it again: with more and more of us abandoning Facebook, there is room for another social platform to edge its way into the big leagues. Ello could be that platform, but they haven't started sending out invites to the masses quite yet. As someone who works on social media (Facebook included), my feelings are amplified. I see these wrongs and more on a daily basis, but there's nothing I can do. I would delete my personal profile if I could still manage my client's pages without it. Facebook (and all of its sh*t) is just something that I have to deal with. P.S.: Sorry for all of the swearing.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Everything Currently Wrong with Facebook | Commerce Kitchen
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/shutterstock_141090136.jpg
Jen finally sat down to describe why she has so many issues with Facebook. It's a short list (with some swearing), but it explains a lot.

item.title: I Thought the Pantheon was in Rome?
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.content:encoded:
Besides building high performance custom web software, we also develop customized Wordpress sites for our clients. They want the flexibility and control to manage their content while creating a unique experience for their audience. And the open source framework of Wordpress is an excellent and popular choice for the demand of a content management system. Even though we like creating and building new websites, sometimes, we are asked to inherit a custom one that our client wants to migrated to a new hosting platform. I'm going to share my experience, both good and bad, from the aforementioned scenario, in a two part blog series from working with the platform, Pantheon. I'm not talking about the most imitated and biggest dome in the history of architecture. Pantheon, as some developers know, has been a popular website platform for Drupal the past three years. But early this year, they extended their services to support the Wordpress application framework. This is exciting news because Pantheon isn't like other hosting companies running virtual machines. Instead, it has a container-based infrastructure to provide scalability and better performance. It's the reason they proudly claim, 'Hosting is Dead' on their website. Other examples you might be familiar with that use this architecture are the ubiquitous Google Apps, Salesforce, and Heroku. Web 'hosting' has moved beyond classicism, and the future is now. Here are five reasons I like Pantheon:

1. Intuitive, Easy to Use Dashboard

Once you login to your dashboard, you can easily manage multiple sites from a tab navigation. As a developer, you don't want to spend a lot of time learning a new tool or hunt for details. So the clean layout of the user interface with the intuitive hierarchical menu options made jumping in easy. It's obvious that Pantheon spent a great deal of time to make the user experience a good one.

2. Git Integration

Pantheon uses Git to manage your code and deployments. They conveniently display the commit log for each environment making it a snap to review the history. And once you push a code change, the commit is automagically displayed, prompting you to deploy your code before reviewing it in the environment of your choosing. An added bonus, merging of other environments is also possible from the dashboard.

3. Dev, Test, and Live Environments

One of the more difficult or time consuming steps for a developer is creating the different environments needed to test and review changes. With Pantheon, the dev, test, and production environments are created by default. Plus, you have the option to create cloud development environments that everyone on your team can create for 'local' development or to test feature updates. This is huge because you can create a sandbox environment that is an exact replica of production. And you don't need to worry about creating a local MAMP stack and wonder if your local setup will work differently than on Pantheon.

4. Workflow

Pantheon wants to be a developers best friend. It's apparent from the adoption of Git and the tool their engineers created to make cloning from one environment to another easy. Its flexibility allows you to choose to clone either the files or database or both. Some platforms don't give you that granular control without adding extra steps to your process. Using their workflow to deploy code changes, quickly became one of my favorite aspects to Pantheon.

5. Errors

The PHP error log for each environment is conveniently accessed from the dashboard to give you a quick overview of what is wrong with your code. This is particularly useful when migrating a custom Wordpress theme that might have outdated or errant code. I don't have to necessarily dig into the logs on the file server to understand what's wrong. Instead, I can start debugging the code to find a solution quickly. Next week, I'll discuss some of the things that I found difficult while working on Pantheon.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: pantheon
Developing on Pantheon | Commerce Kitchen
Early this year, Pantheon extended their services to support the Wordpress application framework. Here are the five reasons why Alex likes using Pantheon.

item.title: What Makes Me Better
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: I've been going to the gym a lot lately, and here's one thing I've noticed: CNN does not make me a better person. In fact, I'm pretty sure that the constant barrage of terrifying world events ticking across the screen in front of me raises my heart rate more than sprinting on the treadmill does. I get anxious, sad. I feel helpless and powerless. This does not make me a better person. I try not to look. But there's something about the power of the screen that compels most of us to watch, even when we don't want to. Next time you're in a bar, restaurant, or gym with a TV, try not to look at it even once. It's almost impossible. Worldwide, the past few weeks have been dizzyingly traumatic. Three commercial planes crashed, one of which was shot down out of the sky. 1,000 Palestinians and 50 Israelis have been killed in and around Gaza, and a lasting ceasefire or truce seems impossible. Ebola is spreading in West Africa. I'm sure I'm missing something. Happily there hasn't been a mass shooting in the U.S. for a month or so, but we're all always holding our breath. CNN will let us know as soon as it happens, and there I'll be, on the treadmill, panting and sweating, powerless and sad. There's a fine balance between staying informed and staying sane, but there's also a deluge of real-time information. Facebook used to be a kind of respite. I hid all the stories that bummed me out because I realized I didn't have the emotional fortitude to handle a constant stream of problems that I have no control over. But then Facebook added its Trending Events section, and now when I log in to do client work or to check my own profile, there it is. Murders, mean-spirited celebrity gossip, assaults, racism, war, disease. How are my friends doing today? Did my awesome friend Dan from high school post any more photos of his weird baby snakes? Did everyone else see that stunning double rainbow last night? It was amazing! Oh, also, 1,600 people died in Syria yesterday. There's a war in Tripoli. More girls were kidnapped by Boko Haram. Southern California is turning to dust. How do we stay informed without becoming more and more hopeless? How does this constant assault of information inspire action rather than apathy and feelings of nihilism? I can give as much as I have, but it's not going to stop the honeybee population from dying. It's not going to solve the Israel / Palestine crisis. So what helps, then? If we really are powerless, what can ease the burden of world trauma? For me the answer is poetry. Poetry makes me better.  When the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting happened at the end of 2012 someone on Facebook posted this poem, by Polish poet Adam Zagajewski: Try to praise the mutilated world. Remember June's long days, and wild strawberries, drops of rosé wine. The nettles that methodically overgrow the abandoned homesteads of exiles. You must praise the mutilated world. You watched the stylish yachts and ships; one of them had a long trip ahead of it, while salty oblivion awaited others. You've seen the refugees going nowhere, you've heard the executioners sing joyfully. You should praise the mutilated world. Remember the moments when we were together in a white room and the curtain fluttered. Return in thought to the concert where music flared. You gathered acorns in the park in autumn and leaves eddied over the earth's scars. Praise the mutilated world and the gray feather a thrush lost, and the gentle light that strays and vanishes and returns. The everyday tragedies, which are just a reality of living, have inspired some of the most powerful art. We can sink into despair, or we can use our despair to build something beautiful. While Facebook makes me crazy with its Trending Events section, I may have never learned about poet Adam Zagajewski without it. My friend Brigid posted a portion of a Mary Oliver poem to Facebook this week, and as I read it and re-read it, I felt my heart rate literally slowing down, felt my breathing deepen, felt my shoulders relax. In her poem, Oliver asks us to notice the sun. To remember the pleasure and passion inherent in something as simple as watching the sun rise. There will always be tragedies. We will often be powerless to stop them or to help when they do happen. We can support organizations who do good, but we cannot obsess about how terrible things are and expect to stay remotely sane. We can take a moment to create something out of tragedy. We can take a moment to watch the sun rise above the mutilated world, and we can crawl out of our despair long enough to make beauty out of it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What Makes Me Better
Natalie discusses how the deluge of tragic information makes it difficult to lead a good life. But sometimes poetry makes her better.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/rainbow.jpg
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/07/makes-better/

item.title: All of the Things that Happen When Facebook is Down
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
And to think I wasn't sure what to blog about today... Facebook was down for some users this morning. It doesn't happen very often, but when it does, unusual things begin to happen.

PANIC. Widespread panic.

I mean this in the most dramatic of senses, of course. I sincerely hope that no one is actually panicking right now. It's Facebook, for Pete's sake. Calm down. However, there are certain users (Facebook addicts and social media managers) who take a Facebook outage very seriously. And by that, I mean we hate it. Since managing Facebook pages is part of my job, I don't take kindly to the rare Facebook outage. It's an unforeseen obstacle in my day, but I'm not crying about it. I have other things that I could be doing, like writing this blog post!

Sarcasm and sass take flight.

If you spend two minutes on #facebookdown on Twitter right now, you'll see a little bit of hysteria, but mostly it consists of curious users and sarcasm champions. I applaud you, sassy tweeters. I have a lot of love for you when outages happen.

Twitter traffic skyrockets.

This is what every single person does when a Facebook outage occurs. 1. Attempt to sign into Facebook. 2. Land on this screen: 3. Refresh the browser 2-20 times in a row. 4. Turn to Twitter for solace in your time of need. 5. Spot the trending #facebookdown, followed by everyone's retweets of a Mashable article about the Facebook outage. 6. Tweet about the Facebook outage. 7. Wallow in self pity about your reliance on such a bad site.

Things happen. Work things.

"You mean I can't check Facebook for the millionth time today??" When you can't check your main social network, you turn to the other ones (see above process). After you've finished tweeting about the Facebook outage, you actually get stuff done. *Gasp!* That's right. Productivity increases when Facebook is down. Well, it probably increases. I'm just guessing based on my own productivity right now. Obviously this outage has done wonders for me; I've written this whole blog post in the 20 minutes. And in the 20 minutes that it has taken me to write this, Facebook has mended itself.

The end.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: facebook is down
All of the Things that Happen When Facebook is Down
Facebook was out for some users this morning. It doesn't happen very often, but when it does, unusual things happen, like Jen blogging in 25 minutes.
