item.title: Tynan's Top 5 Things You Need to Know This Week
item.dc:creator: tszvetecz
item.content:encoded:
It’s been an exciting week! Especially when Bitcoin aims to misbehave. These are the top five developments you need to know about:

1. The Lessons Thus Far From the Transition to Digital Patient Records

Snippet:

"No one thinks a modern health care system can cling to paper records. But the policy goal of the federal incentive program was to use digital technology to curb costs and improve care. The legislation was called the Health Information Technology for Economic and Clinical Health Act.

And there are examples of health care providers that use digital patient records effectively — mostly large medical groups, like Kaiser Permanente, the Mayo Clinic, the Cleveland Clinic and the Marshfield Clinic, that have worked with the technology for years.

But Dr. Jha said there was “certainly not yet” evidence of a payoff nationally from the federal incentive program."

Why It Matters:

Over the last six years, the government has moved aggressively to shake-up healthcare. Regardless of your political views, the result is a “blue ocean” of opportunity for digital health startups. This follow-up from the NY Times looks back over the last six years to see whether the digitization of health records has reduced or increased overall healthcare costs. We’ve certainly seen both sides of this at Commerce Kitchen. Organizations that can move nimbly into digitization set themselves up for long-term cost savings and create opportunities for new revenue streams. However, poor planning and under-resourcing of technology teams can drive costs up considerably, and create months or years of code debt to boot.

2. When Wearable Tech Saves Your Life, You Won’t Take it Off

Snippet:

"The problem with wearables is that usually people stop wearing them. According to one recent report, one-third of users of activity-tracking wearables, like the Fitbit and the Jawbone, toss their devices aside after just six months.

To overcome this, a small cadre of companies has been furiously working to develop smaller, sleeker, more discreet devices that monitor health and wellness--in the form of temporary tattoos, band-aids, and ingestible pills."

Why It Matters:

Particularly in the digital health startup space, the wearable tech focus is significant. However, it’s incredibly important to realize the pace of hardware innovation. The level of hardware innovation that companies like MC10 are pushing into the market is going to bury under-engineered digital health startups. Also: this stuff is just fucking cool.

3. Overstock’s Radical Plan to Reinvent the Stock Market With Bitcoin

Snippet:

"In an echo of the bitcoin digital currency, this would be a stock that’s controlled by cryptographic algorithms running across a network of computers owned by people and companies spread across the globe.

In other words, all stock trades would be governed by tools in the hands of the general public rather than by a traditional stock exchange, such as the NASDAQ or the New York Stock Exchange."

Why It Matters:

It remains my position that Bitcoin is a bigger disruptive technology than much of the world realizes at this time. One of the bigger trends I’m watching is Bitcoin’s ability to bypass traditional banks and their fees for international transfers of money. This is going to allow the growing migrant worker populations of the world to save substantial amounts of money, and it will hit big banks hard. The movement of Bitcoin into the stock trading space will similarly be a significant threat to the investment banks and stock exchanges of the world. These are huge centers of revenue centered largely on transaction fees. As this seemingly intractable foundation collapses, there will be dangerous fallout.

4. How the Internet of Things Changes Business Models

Snippet:

"In a connected world, products are no longer one-and-done. Thanks to over-the-air updates, new features and functionality can be pushed to the customer on a regular basis. The ability to track products in use makes it possible to respond to customer behavior.

And of course, products can now be connected with other products, leading to new analytics and new services for more effective forecasting, process optimization, and customer service experiences."

Why It Matters:

Check-out the infographic embedded in the article. This is one of the most accessible, digestible descriptions of how technology business models are shifting. Ask yourself:
  • Is your product addressing real-time and emergent needs in a predictive manner?
  • Are you driving product freshness through over-the-air updates?
  • Are you adding personalization as a feature and leveraging network effects between products?

5. Digital Fitness: Tech Giants Are Moving into Healthcare

Snippet:

"A number of major tech companies have started to take an interest in the healthcare industry. Hardware is rushing to catch up to the innovations in software over the recent years, and will catapult healthy living onto the forefront of innovation.

The digital healthcare world is in dire need of improvements, and here are some of the exciting things coming our way."

Why It Matters:

The major tech companies are going after the “toys” of digital health. It remains to be seen whether they will actively pursue clinical validation for their tools. If they do not pursue clinical validation, technology startups who do will have a significant competitive advantage, despite the big tech company's production power and reach.

That's a wrap, folks! Onward.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Tynan's Top 5 Things You Need to Know This Week
It’s been an exciting week, especially when Bitcoin aims to misbehave. Tynan sums up the top five developments you need to know about.

item.title: Pantheon, Parte Seconda: Mamma Mia, My Frustrations
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_7297" align="alignright" width="334"] The Roman's version of a lie detector.[/caption] Last week, I promised to share some of the difficulties I encountered while working with Pantheon. And since I don't want to renege, or fear losing my hand in La Bocca della Verità for lying, it's time to back up my words. You may recall, Pantheon is a professional website platform which recently added support for running WordPress. I was fortunate enough to migrate a couple of sites owned by our client to test things out before it was available to the public. Hopefully, some of the lessons I learned can help others. I know first hand, that Pantheon is working hard to make the process as painless as possible. But like anything new or customized, it will have its obstacles. And me, I'll have my user operator frustrations or moments. So, in no inglorious order, here are some of my frustrations:

Can't Trust Your Local Environment

Before migrating any of the sites to Pantheon, I created local environments for my own development and debugging purposes. It's know that Pantheon offers cloud development and they encourage developers to use it. But having a local environment is something that I'm accustom to and I enjoy the freedom it provides. I work remotely and there are times when my internet connection isn't reliable. Having my local environment around means I can still work. It's not perfect but, I can also find issues or bugs before even getting to the server environment where the application will ultimately live. And since the first migration I did to Pantheon went off without a hitch, I decided to keep the process the same. “It should be easy,” I thought to myself. That thinking got me in trouble the second time around. Solutions that worked locally, suddenly failed in the dev environment. Feed's were spitting out PHP errors. Images failed to be linked properly. What happened? I discovered the code used to parse the feed's were relying on the short form (<? ?>) of PHP to compile. I can't tell you how long this took me to figure out. It was like a needle in a haystack until I really thought about why it was showing up in my local and not the dev environment. To add insult to injury, I later found, in Pantheon's documentation, the short_open_tag directive isn't allowed. Did you hear that? SMACK! It was the slap of my hand against my forehead.

No Query Checks

Some of the images and links didn't have the correct URL reference. They were using my local domain. I somehow introduced that reference, yet I still don't know how this happened. Why were some references working fine and others found in the content not working? I know Pantheon runs queries to update the database used by the environment. It's the same collections of queries we've all used to migrate WordPress databases.Yet, I still had to make these updates manually to correct HTTP 404 errors for images and pages.

No Plugin Checks

Since Pantheon's platform is not your typical 'host', they handle caching differently. Some plugins like W3 Total Cache, WP Super Cache, and Woo Commerce are not supported and are unnecessary. It just so happened that one of the site's I was migrating used the W3 Total Cache plugin. It wasn't a major issue that recked havoc on the site. But, it would have been nice to have some message from Pantheon warning me about this in the migration. WP Engine, a competitor, actually has a tool that will stop the migration or deployment of code, warning you that it's stopped because the site includes the plugin. Having some sort of checklist or query check would be a great addition to the dashboard.

Support Response Slow and Sometimes Not Helpful

I don't want to sound like an ugly American wanting more features and being ungrateful. I was grateful for the help I got from Pantheon's WordPress engineers. I was even able to have a retro with them to share my experience while they listened with earnest. And they offered to work hand-in-hand for any future migrations to learn from the process. But I knew I would be entering the Mojave desert of support, when I learned only a couple of WordPress engineers were available to handle tickets. The turnaround times were slow and sometimes took until the end of business the next day or two. One time I was sent some log information that only underscored what I already knew, in response to a question and bid for help.

All The Documents Reference Drupal!

Pantheon has a LOT of documentation to create or update since adding WordPress as service. The references in the documentation are incomplete and don't translate directly to WordPress. And even though I kept this in mind while reading it, I still wasn't certain if the same rules applied. I was second guessing my logic and the variations I used from the help didn't clear my test.
Pantheon has made great strides since I first started migrations to their platform. In fact, I see WordPress is being referenced more in their documentation. As they continue to complete their transition to supporting WordPress, I hope they improve the tools developers use to migrate sites onto their platform.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/bocca-della-verita.jpg
pantheon
Pantheon, Parte Seconda: Mamma Mia, My Frustrations
Last week, Alex promised to share some of the difficulties he encountered while developing with Pantheon. Here are some frustrations that he's had.

item.title: National Unsubscribe Day
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded: I hereby declare Monday, August 18th, which also happens to be my birthday, Unsubscribe Day. Every day my inbox is freshly filled with newsletters I don't read, updates I don't care about, and offers I don't even want. Instead of unsubscribing I usually delete these emails, but sometimes I let them build up, creating a wobbling tower of virtual chaos that threatens to collapse and smother me. Overly dramatic? No. I am not. I am appropriately dramatic. Which is why I'm seeking to create a similarly dramatic response to the feeling that too many people / businesses / organizations have my email address and use it. Also, unsubscribing can be a generous thing to do to these organizations because people often pay for more subscribers, and if you're not even opening the emails it doesn't do them any good. In fact, I still have some messages that I've filtered to skip my inbox and go straight to my trash. That's no good. I'll unsubscribe instead. Join me today, August 18th, and unsubscribe. Unsubscribe from at least three lists you're on, then reply to this blog and tell us how good it feels.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: National Unsubscribe Day: August 18th
Natalie hereby declares that August 18th is National Unsubscribe Day. Take time to unsubscribe from at least three email lists that you're sick of getting.

item.title: Compelling Calls to Action
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
You've decided to build a new website. You've set aside your budget dollars. You've hired a smart team. You've corralled internal resources. You've planned out the architecture. And you've seen the mockups for your site. You are excited, and already prepping for how to iterate your brand. But after the design and development are done, weeks go by. Maybe even months. You are stuck in the rut trying to develop hundreds of well-optimized pages and other relevant content to maximize the value of your shiny, new, responsive site. You forget about your sitemap and redirects plan. You forget about the desired funneling and site actions you committed to achieving. And you may even forget why you started this project in the first place. Do not fret. I repeat, DO NOT FRET. Content ruts happen to the best of us, especially when faced with writing a hundred (or a thousand) pages (but if you are in the latter camp, do you really have that many thought provoking and relevant things to say? Probably not.) One of the best ways to break out of a content rut is move backwards. Focus on the intended funneling and end goal of the page, and then write a compelling call-to-action (CTA) that gets you there. And once your CTAs are in place, you can focus on writing the benefit-driven copy to support that CTA.

Write with the End Goal in Mind

While a CTA can be as simple as "click here", they are generally the most impactful if they tie to the content on the page and entice you to click. Let's say we've been struggling to write about a difficult subject like cancer treatment. We know that a patient is most likely to schedule an appointment (end goal) if he learns more about the treatments for his specific kind of cancer. So our intermediary CTA would probably looks something like this: We now know that our lead-in copy prior to the CTA should provide an overview of the cancer treatments that we provide. But the CTAs don't end there. Once we've directed a visitor to the cancer page to learn more, we want him to meet our team, learn why we are different and, if he is ready, schedule an appointment. Done! There are our three CTAs, in order down the page, based on where our visitor is in the sales cycle. All we need to do is work on the relevant action-prompting CTA copy: Our CTA is clear, concise and relevant. And it directs the visitor to our funnel (from the doctors and differentiator pages we ask you to schedule an appointment) to achieve our site goals. And working, we know that the benefit-driven copy leading up to that CTA needs to be about breast cancer treatment specifically.

Be Visually Disruptive and Impactful

CTAs should stand out visually to help break up sections of content. Yet they should be positioned on the page so that they are helpful rather than distracting.

Well-Placed CTAs

You've just told me how you can help me find a mortgage, that your lending services are exactly what I am looking for, and how you stand out from competitors that I might be looking at. Great! Where do I sign? That's exactly what a well-placed CTA should do. Allow someone to take the action that you want them to take as easily and quickly as possible. And if the visitor wasn't ready to click? He could scroll down to read more, or click through to our secondary CTAs to read about our differentiation or call us to learn more. On a page of copy copy with five or six sections, you may want three to four CTAs to direct visitors to content further along the sales funnel.

Color and Wayfinding

In the mortgage example above, we have one site action: requesting a quote. The use of the color red and the clear button copy let the visitor know exactly what he's getting by clicking. The red is only used to prompt action on the site, so it stands out visually from all other content. In the example related to cancers, we use up to five colors and associated icons for the various CTAs. Each CTA type - meeting our team, scheduling an appointment, etc. is tied to a specific color - to allow for easy navigation through a more complicated site. Each color is only used with the appropriate content, and the full-width color floods of the CTAs stand out prominently from the white background. Do you have strong CTAs on your site? Any best practices that you like to follow? Share them with us!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Write Compelling CTAs to Achieve Your Website Objectives
Working backwards with your site goals in mind, guide visitors through the appropriate funnels using color, concise copy and well-placed calls-to-action.
compelling call to action

item.title: Join Us: Clash of the Cocktails is Back!
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Back in January, our Firehouse hosted one of Built-In Colorado's Built-In Brews events. As the overachievers that we are, we didn't want this to be some run-of-the-mill Built-In Brews. No, sir. We tacked on something extra: a battle between alcoholic drinks. Sounds awesome, right? It was. Two file format cocktails - .HTML and .PNG - duked it out throughout the evening to be named champion. Ultimately, .PNG (Peach 'N Ginger) won out over .HTML. Well, it's been a long eight months since that fated battle, and we're bringing Clash of the Cocktails back! That's right: on September 5th at 5:00 PM, we'll be hosting an exclusive, 4-hour, bracketology-style COTC. Working off of the .HTML and .PNG models from our Built-In Brews, we're asking startups that are participating to show off their imaginative side and create their own delicious/fun/funky file format cocktail.

What are the file format options?

Think dot-anything: .gif, .jpeg, .txt, .php, .rb, .js, .psd, .css, .svg, .asp, .cfm, .haml, .erb, .zip, .jsp, .mg, .eps, .gz, .ova, .md, .tar, the list goes on and on. Time to get creative!

What's in it for me and my startup?

  • Four comp'ed tickets for you and your cocktail makers (and other staff) who want to join in on the fun.
  • Endless networking & brand exposure.
  • Entry gets you complete access to all five competing cocktails, Illegal Pete's taco bar, as well as a commemorative Clash of the Cocktails taster glass.
  • Possibly getting spooked by the Firehouse 13 ghost(s).
  • The chance to beat seven other startups with your amazing cocktail creativity.

Can I attend without my startup competing?

Here at Commerce Kitchen, we love making new friends when alcohol (especially wine) is involved. If you're from a non-participating startup or company, or if you just want to hang out with us and our amazing superheroes, then we'd love to have you! General admission tickets for Clash of the Cocktails will be $5.

Call to Arms

We want YOU (Denver startups) to get involved! Ombud, Inversoft, P2Binvestor, Mighteor, and Stack Overflow have already thrown their hats in the ring. We have three spots left for startups who want to participate!

Think your cocktail has what it takes?

Email me - Jen, Clash of the Cocktails Ring Leader - at jen@commercekitchen.com for more details! Flying solo? Click here to RSVP!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: clash of the cocktails
Join Us: Clash of the Cocktails is Back! | Commerce Kitchen
That's right: on September 5th, we'll be hosting an exclusive, 4-hour, bracketology-style Clash of the Cocktails. Think your cocktail has what it takes?

item.title: Social Media Activism: The Tweet is Mightier Than The Gun
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
I've talked a lot about the power of social media. I've discussed how it has changed the Superbowl, the World Cup, and marketing your business. I've complained about Facebook, and I've praised Pinterest. Normally, I'm in a joking mood; I like to keep my posts light and funny, to keep people reading. Right now, I'm not really in a joking mood. In light of recent events, I think it's time I finally discuss how social media has changed 21st century activism. Raising awareness and speaking out about certain issues, illnesses, etc. are at the heart of activism. Martin Luther King Jr. brought 200,000 people to Washington D.C. in 1963 because he believed segregation was fundamentally wrong. Senator Wendy Davis became an overnight political powerhouse when she wouldn't sit down and shut up for 13 hours. Malala Yousafzai became a household name after wrote a book about being gunned down for wanting an education. Talking about these issues - whether they are local, national, or global - has nearly become the norm for the world we live in today, and social media has played a large role in that. To cover my bases here, I'm going to talk about two very different sides of the social media activism coin: the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge, and the current tensions between citizens and the police force in Ferguson, Missouri.

ALS, Ice, and Awareness

The first side of the activism coin is the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge. If you're unaware what this is, it's a phenomenon that is sweeping the Internet. Upon being "challenged" by someone, you either have to donate $100 to the ALS Association, or dump a bucket of ice water on your head. If you take the challenge, you douse yourself in freezing water, and then challenge 3 friends or family members. Sounds like a great idea, right? It was. It has garnered attention - and challenge acceptances - from the likes of Mark Zuckerberg, Bill Gates, Oprah Winfrey, Taylor Swift, the list goes on and on. So what's the problem? Why are people so divided about the Ice Bucket Challenge? I can't answer for everyone, but I can tell you why I'm annoyed: some of the celebrities and public figures who have accepted the challenge and posted their videos on the web & social media don't even mention ALS, what it is, or what it does to the people who have it. I love Lena Dunham, but she didn't even say "ALS" in her challenge video. Neither did Martha Stewart. The ones that do mention it? That's exactly what it is: a mention. "I hereby accept the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge, blah blah blah..." On the other hand, Charlie Sheen surprisingly has given probably the best response to being challenged by a friend. While there are those of us who aren't 100% onboard with the ALS Ice Bucket Challenge, there are many people who know that it's truly making a difference in ALS awareness and funding. The ALS Association has said that the phenomenon has raised nearly $32 million for their research and efforts. Even skeptics like me can't deny that the Ice Bucket Challenge has made a huge impact, and ultimately has changed the activism game. So where does social media fit into this? Well, where do you think celebrities, public figures, and normal people like you and me are sharing videos of dumping ice water all over themselves? That's right: social media. It's how "Ice Bucket Challenge" has remained one of the top trending topics on Facebook for the past several weeks. While the ALS Association most likely has achieved what it set out to do (raise a lot of money), it is important to emphasize the need for education about the disease. It's scary for those who have it or know someone who has it. Dumping water on your head and posting it on Facebook doesn't mean a damn thing if you don't do the research to find out why you're doing it or talk about why you're doing it.

Michael Brown, Ferguson, and Race Relations

On the other side of this activism coin, we have Ferguson, MO. If you need a really amazing, in-depth review of what's going on in this St. Louis suburb and why it's happening, watch John Oliver cover it with class, a little bit of humor, and a whole lot of frustration. As Oliver says, this event is all too familiar. I was a senior in high school in the Bay Area when Oscar Grant was shot and killed by a BART officer in Oakland in 2009. More recently, Trayvon Martin was shot and killed by a neighborhood watch coordinator in Sanford, Flordia. I could name off so many more incidents where white-on-black crime took the life of a young man, but we're here to talk about the shooting of Michael Brown. The chain of events that Brown's murder has caused is nothing short of extraordinary, in the best and worst senses. While the local law enforcements' reactions to protestors need to go under some serious evaluation, many of us have been reexamining how much trust we put in police officers. We've seen more and more news stories about how much riot police in Ferguson look nearly identical to the U.S.'s troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. In my opinion, Mike Brown's death will not be in vain, because it's causing many of us to take a good, hard look at modern-day race relations in the land of the free and home of the brave. How are people being educated? On Twitter, of course. Hashtags (while mildly present on Facebook) are dominant on Twitter, and this fact has led to #Ferguson trending nearly non-stop on this social media platform for days now. As more and more people learn the truth about Brown's death, the peaceful protestors, and the overreaction of local - and now federal - law enforcement in Ferguson, it's becoming a story that won't vanish from headlines easily. Because of #Ferguson (in addition to similar events and their hashtags from around the globe) Twitter users are being educated about the reality of the world that we live in. I'd like to think I'm in-the-know about a lot of things, but I just learned that tear gas was banned from war - on a global scale - in 1993, and yet is used in domestic riot control. That scared the bajeezus out of me. Where did I learn it? My Twitter feed. Activism without education is like the unintelligent leading the blind; just ask the Westboro Baptist Church. Social media has changed the way that we look at - and are exposed to - issues in our world, but until we're educated about what we're fighting for (or against), we're no closer to fixing these issues than when we started.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: social media activism
Social Media Activism: The Tweet is Mightier Than The Gun
In light of recent events, it's time we talk about social media activism and how it has changed the way we are exposed to and educated about certain issues.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/march-on-washington-ftr.jpg

item.title: UX Beyond the Web: 5 Ways to Make Your Staff, Customers, and Family Happy
item.dc:creator: natalie
item.content:encoded:
In the past five years that I've been working at Commerce Kitchen, the company has grown and changed in some really interesting, fantastic, and difficult ways, as all businesses do. With that growth my role has shifted according to company need and business direction. Lately I've taken on the task of figuring out what gives our staff and customers a good experience and improves their happiness index. As mentioned before, it's not as easy as having a kegerator for our employees and sending cupcakes to our clients. Beer and cupcakes are awesome, and they should always be part of the equation. But the bigger and more important pieces of providing a good user experience are ongoing and subtle. As a mom I've realized that these five concepts also help keep my relationship with my daughter positive and healthy, so really what I'm doing here is giving you a simple roadmap to a happier life. Does that make me your self-appointed pseudo guru? Yes. Yes it does. So here are five ways to make your staff, customers, and family happy, beyond beer and cupcakes. 1. Listen to them Seems like a no-brainer, right? Not exactly. We get so stuck in our way of doing things that we often stop listening before we even begin. We don't know how to listen. Put aside your defenses and assumptions and get to the heart of what your staff, customers, and kids are telling you. There are insights into your clients' businesses that you cannot obtain without listening carefully. Likewise, your clients' feedback about your organization can help make you stronger if you're willing to listen with an open mind. Your staff also deserves to be heard. They work hard to keep your company afloat, and they may have observations and feedback about the business that can help you grow better and stronger. Some of your staff's feedback may not be about the fiscal health or processes of the company at all but about how to make it a better place for everyone. Listen to them. They deserve it and your company deserves it. As for your family and non-work-related relationships, listening is crucial. While my daughter definitely has her irrational tantrums, a sentence I always hear from her when she's frustrated is "Mom, listen to me! Listen to me!" She wants to know she's being heard, and it's much easier to talk her down from the ledge of a massive tantrum if she knows I hear her. 2. Don't make everything about you Yes it's your business. It's your family. But unless you're a sole proprietor and owner/operator or a family of one (is that a thing?), then there are other stakeholders. Your staff may not own the company legally, but they own the work they do. They own their time. And they are giving it to you and you reciprocate with a paycheck. But to keep them happy the reciprocation has to be more than just a paycheck.  Ayn Rand would have a fit of rage over what I'm about to say, but your decisions need to be for the good of the many, not just the good of the you. We will always have to cut loose certain staff members and clients who aren't a good fit with our company vision. But if we've done our hiring right, if we've vetted our clients properly, and if we've identified our own strengths and weaknesses, then hopefully we're bringing on people that we want to learn from and share with. With family it's not so easy. We don't get to choose our children or parents. But we can choose how we interact with them every single day. Teenagers and toddlers are the worst at thinking about anyone besides themselves, but the rest of us have the ability to see beyond our needs. I may want to go watch my friend's band play at the museum, but if my daughter has school the next day I know that she'll be exhausted and cranky if we go. I will sacrifice my pleasure to do what's best for her. Ask yourself in what areas can you sacrifice your personal pleasure to create a better environment for everyone overall. 3. Set clear expectations This might be the most difficult of all. We know we need help. We know we want to run our business well, but we forget to set expectations properly. Your staff needs to know precisely what you expect from them so that they can feel successful. We've recently changed our hiring process to reflect this need. Instead of saying, oh, we need to hire a project manager, we now say, we need to hire a project manager who will do this and this and this. Who has this skill and this skill and this skill. With these goals in mind.  One of the most honest and difficult pieces of feedback we've heard from staff in the last year was "I don't know what success looks like here." That's a demoralizing feeling for them, and we're working to change that. Start off with having a set of concrete goals for your staff, then work with them over time to expand those goals so that they know what success looks like every single day, and they can aim for that. For your clients, ensure that you have solid contracts that outline who does what and when, and remind them on a regular basis what you expect for them. Sometimes we wait for a client to do something, and they don't even know that they're expected to do it. Communicate clearly, communicate often, and let people know what you want to accomplish. I have to admit something. One of my biggest faults as a parent is not setting clear expectations for my child. Happily she came into this world a very well-behaved human being, but there are times when it's clear that she doesn't know what I expect from her. Do I expect her to eat all her veggies or do I expect her to stop eating when she's full. Both! This is confusing. Our expectations may change. In fact, it's inevitable. But we need to communicate them all the time so that the people who depend on us--and whom we depend on--feel safe and happy in their relationships with us. 4. Answer questions with patience and love We're not all cut out to be Kindergarten teachers. I love my Kindergartner but have a relatively low tolerance for other Kindergartners. However, in whatever job we've chosen, in whatever family structure we have, we have the choice to respond to questions with patience and compassion or resentment and frustration. My kid asks me frustrating, repetitive, and annoying questions all the time. I love her to pieces, but she's five. There's a lot she doesn't understand yet. The more frustrated I get with her, the more magically frustrating she becomes. It's a vicious cycle. The same goes for staff and clients. Your clients don't know as much about what you do as you know. Duh. If they did they wouldn't hire you. They're going to ask you a lot of questions to try and understand what you're doing. Don't take this the wrong way. They're not questioning your ability to make good decisions; they're not questioning your knowledge of your industry. They're trying to understand, in their own language, what they're paying you for. Your staff will do the same. They may ask you to explain the company's vision, your expectations, their role, or any number of things. They're not attacking you. They're seeking knowledge from  you. It's an honor to have a curious staff who want to get better at what they do, who want to help make your business better. Answer the questions with patience and compassion, and look toward building a solid business with their complete buy-in and commitment. That's a gift. 5. Take things offline How many times have conversations turned sour over email because of misinterpreted innuendo? The internet allows for very little innuendo, even with all the emoticons and exclamation points we can muster!!!! :D :D Serious and important conversations should be had face to face. Talking about difficult things over text and email can seem easier but almost always leads to misunderstanding somewhere. This is true for everyone. Clients, staff, family. I'm not opposed to beginning difficult conversations over email, but it's important to know when to take them offline. This also goes for more positive communication. You can give me as many likes on Facebook as you want, but if you never tell me, to my face, that you appreciate me, then I'll assume something is off. Sometimes clients need to see your face to understand your position, to really grok why you're making the decisions that you're making. We all have stories about email misunderstandings, and the only way to compensate for those is by meeting face to face. Praise and criticism are both crucial, and they both need to be expressed in person. So many of us are terrified of confrontation, so we take to digital media in an effort to avoid having to actually confront a real human being. However, digital confrontation can escalate in such a way that in-person confrontation may not.
What do you do to create a good "UX" for your staff, clients, and family? It's really just about creating healthy relationships by understanding what people need. Emotional intelligence 101.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: UX Beyond the Web: Keeping Your Staff, Clients, and Family Happy
UX off the web is really understanding human emotion and responding well to others' needs. Natalie walks you through 5 steps to healthy UX.
http://www.newwhyweb.com/2014/08/make-staff-customers-happy/

item.title: T-18 Days Until Denver Startup Week
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
I cannot believe it's almost September! Where has this summer gone!? But with fall rapidly approaching come some of my favorite things -- college football, cooler weather and Denver Startup Week! Over the last two years Denver Startup Week has rapidly grown in scope, with 100+ events spanning areas such as business, manufacturing, design and tech. And let's not forget the ever important, and increasingly boozy social events from startup crawls to after parties. Below are some of the events I'm looking forward to the most:
  • Growing Your Business the Colorado Way: Pursuing Passion vs Pursuing Exit Strategy - I can't wait to hear Tynan lead a panel discussion with Chuck Sullivan from Something Independent, and other local CEOs that focuses on the reason we all got into our businesses to begin with, rather than just the financials.
  • Digital Health Challenge - PrIME Health Collaborative's shark tank-style pitch night for burgeoning healthcare startups should prove to be entertaining and inspiring.
  • Don't Be a Jerk: Customer Service and Servant Leadership in the Tech Sector - Led by Jamie, Commerce Kitchen partner and co-founder of Anneal, I think we'll hear some great insight on how to apply servant leadership to all aspects of your business from client management to talent development.
  • Long Distance Relationships: Working with Distributed Teams - Working with teams in different offices and across different timezones can be challenging. It will be great to hear from Anneal, Tynan and our wonderful client Jim Ball of Trip30 (previously of Alpine Access) how to overcome challenges and create a compelling countrywide culture.
I am also really intrigued by some of the events that touch on industries or digital storytelling approaches that Commerce Kitchen is currently working in, or just getting in to: Technology-Driven Behavior Change In Health Care, Entrepreneurship, Technology & Media: How To Tell Your Story And Engage Through Video, Women Who Startup and Spire's Kill The Artist — This Is Business. We'd pitched the idea of doing a Startup Capture the Flag event for the DSW social track, but alas, we didn't make the cut this year. Maybe next year my life will be complete when outdoor sports meet startups in the fall sunshine. In the meantime, sign up for your DSW events, and don't forget to join us for Clash of the Cocktails on 9/5! Which Denver Startup Week events are you most excited about? Any can't miss seminars that I need to add to my calendar?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: denver startup week
Denver Startup Week 2014 | Compelling Events and Networking

item.title: Why Choose a Social Media Consultant?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Here at Commerce Kitchen, we've been doing SEO audits for years. A small fraction of these SEO audits has been social media analysis, where we evaluate how your business has been performing across different social platforms, and suggest how we think your strategy can improve. Why am I talking about this? Well, we recently decided to copy-and-paste that social media analysis part of an SEO audit and morph it into its own audit. Our social media consulting and strategy package is a brand spankin' new feature of the many services that we offer. Sounds like a sales pitch, right? I'm not on the Commerce Kitchen business development team for nothing! In actuality, I know my social media. I've been working the twists and turns of business social media management for about a year and a half now, and it's been a wild roller coaster. I've felt the cold, harsh sting of several Facebook Newsfeed algorithm changes (but let's not dig up the past), and I've been on the receiving end of one too many rants about the uselessness of Pinterest. In other words, I'm a badass social media consultant, and my superhero alter-ego is Queenpin.

So why should we help you deep-dive into your social media past?

1. You shouldn't have to do it yourself.

Truthfully, I could end the list here; it's that important. You're busy. You have your own company to run. What does an office manager know about Facebook Insights? Or Followerwonk? Or industry-specific social media trends? Not much, I'm guessing. You probably don't know why your tweets don't get much engagement, why Instagram isn't quite working for you yet, or if you're supposed to include Google+ into your game plan. We're here to dig into your social media pages and accounts to examine how they have been performing, and cross-reference that data with your direct competitors' pages and accounts. In short: we do all of the research and work that you don't want to do.

2. You don't need deep pockets for our expertise or service excellence.

While SEO audits are lengthy, expensive ($5,000 - $7,500+), and pretty hardcore, social media audits don't require as heavy of a financial commitment. For a one-time fee of $2,500, you get us for two weeks as we shuffle through your social media history and create a new and/or improved social media strategy for you to implement on your own.

3. You'll discover your next steps, and then be on your merry way.

We're here to help you become even better at what you already do. How do we do that? We're a service-oriented company, and that means your business priorities come first. We help you determine what's been going wrong (in this case, on the social media side of things) and direct you to your next steps. In one overview meeting, we walk you through our research and findings, and give you our professional opinions about how your strategy can improve across all social media channels from this point forward. We give you the advice and tools you need to become more successful on social media, and then we set you free.

Think you need help with your social strategy? Let's get started!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: social media consultant
Why Choose a Social Media Consultant? | Commerce Kitchen
Social media consulting is a brand new feature of our services. So why go with the pros? Let's discuss why you should choose a social media consultant.

item.title: Why I Chose to Build My Career in Denver
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Now that I am expecting a bundle of joy at the end of the year, everyone I know has asked me if I plan on moving. Some, like my mother and other extended family, would like to know when I am moving back to my home state of South Carolina. While it's lovely to visit, and I do miss the beach, sorry mom, that's not happening any time soon. Others, such as my well-intentioned colleagues and friends, are wondering if we're going to ditch our home a stone's throw from downtown for a tract home in the burbs, which *supposedly* has better schools. While that decision is at least a few years off, and at least in today's thinking, unlikely, the questions and comments have gotten me thinking about why I chose Denver, and more specifically, why I chose to build my career in Denver, in the first place.

What Got Me to Colorado

Like many Colorado transplants, I was lured with the 300 days of sunshine, the proximity to the mountains (skiing!), my now sister-in-law, and an entry level job at Dish Network. While the job didn't last more than a year or two, I completely fell in love with Denver. Great beer. Powdery snow a short drive away. Tons of parks. Professional sports (and let us not forget, rec league kickball). Really cool people.

Why I've Stayed in Denver

After my nearly ten years (whoa, I guess I am getting older :/) here, I've realized that the lifestyle factors that got me to make the 26-hour drive West aren't the real reasons that I've chosen to stay here, and build my career here. Instead, I've come to value:

Diversity

No matter where you work in Denver, you will find diversity in thought and skill sets. Tech coworking spaces are at home next to mechanics' shops in RiNo. Large banks and investment firms are only a suite away from the next big healthcare startup in LoDo. And they all buy their lunches from the burrito vendor on the corner selling out of her cooler. The list goes on. The business community -- blue collar to white collar -- is thriving. Having so many different kinds of businesses that represent different ways of thinking, and different socioeconomic pockets of our state bring stability to our economy. Similarly, I love that we are currently a purple metro area within a purple state. No one voice is dominating the political conversation. We're all trying to respectfully hash out policies that are in the best interests of our businesses, our children, and our future.

Opportunity

Denver is your oyster, especially if you are entrepreneurially minded. Have a disruptive, market-changing idea and ready to bootstrap (or finance) your way to the top? You may just have the next great startup. Denverites see opportunity and aren't afraid to take the leap to make their dreams come to reality. And fellow Denverites are there to collaborate and help you succeed. Many Coloradans that I know will go out of their way and open their wallets just a little bit more if they can support a local company. By having such great local pride (embodied by wonderful organizations like Something Independent), we're further supporting business development in our own backyards. You may be saying, "hey, this way of thinking applies to all Coloradans and not just Denverites". And while as a blanket statement I agree with you, I've found that Denver in particular seems to attract a more collaborative, pay-it-forward kind of attitude in its local talent and businesses than say a high growth, heavily funded area like Boulder. We pursue passion instead of just exit strategy.

Work-Life Balance

Setting aside the great climate and local topography, the pervasive Denver attitude is work to live, but love what you do. In essence, Denverites are passionate about the things they do both inside and outside the workplace. And because of that dual passion, many employers encourage their teams to find the right balance for them. Whether that's working a non-traditional schedule so you can ski on Wednesdays or catching up on email in the evenings after your kid is in bed so you can take him to soccer at 2pm, Denver companies seem to embrace employees' priorities while still maintaining their bottom line and competitive edge. It also doesn't hurt that many of us have at least three or four easily accessible ways to get to work within the metro area. I take the light rail two or three days each week, drive two days a week, and will be walking to our new office (when it opens next month) one day a week. Having so many options means it's easy to adjust your home or work life to accommodate and hiccups or commitments that come up. So while I love the quintessential, 40+ reasons people give for moving to Colorado, I'll be staying here because of the diversity of thought, the opportunity for growth and the wonderful balance that I have at Commerce Kitchen. I am excited to continue my career and raise my daughter in Denver, and I cannot wait to see what the next decade holds for our cow town.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Why I Chose to Build My Career in Denver, CO
Three hundred days of sunshine aside, I'll continue to build and grow my tech career in Denver because of the diversity, opportunity and work life balance.

item.title: Who's Who at This Year's Clash of the Cocktails?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
We're less than 24 hours away from our first, full-blown Clash of the Cocktails event! We have five startup teams participating in what is sure to be an epic battle between bourbon and tequila; between vodka and whiskey. Let's get to know the participating companies a bit more before we send them into the ring together.

Inversoft

Inversoft is the creator of the CleanSpeak suite of tools for filtering and moderating your online community and provides expert moderation services. They developed CleanSpeak to fill the user-generated content management gap, in industries such as in-gaming chat and social networks.  Inversoft's CEO, Brian Pontarelli, was eager to get involved in Clash of the Cocktails to show off his mad cocktail-mixing skills. Eight members, including Brian, of the Inversoft team will be in attendance here, so they have numbers working in their favor for the battle! Brian and the Inversoft team will be shaking up their .SVG "Pear Programming" cocktail tomorrow night!  

Mighteor 

Mighteor makes great videos that the Internet loves. They combine concepting, production, and promotion/distribution into a brilliant mixture to create videos for their clients. While small in numbers, Mighteor is - for lack of a better word - mighty. Liz Giorgi, founder of Mighteor, is ready to show off her stuff at Clash of the Cocktails, and - with the help of a few friends - will be showing off some of her work at her pouring station! Mighteor's .MOV "Melon Over Vodka" is sure to be a smashing success tomorrow night.

Ombud

Ombud develops a reference network for technology solution decision making so that anyone can research and review software technology. Their goal is to advance business technology decisions. Thad Eby, Co-founder and CEO of Ombud, has wanted to get in on Clash of the Cocktails since we first came up with the idea a year ago. So, of course, he was first on our list of startups to get in touch with when we first brought COTC back. Thad and six others from the Ombud team will here tomorrow night, to make us their killer .JSON Manhattan!

P2Binvestor

P2BInvestor is the first and only platform to offer crowdfunded business loans. They have the capacity to fund multi-million dollar credit lines to companies in all 50 U.S. states in various industries including technology, staffing, natural foods, manufacturing, energy, and more. These guys heard about Clash of the Cocktails through the grapevine - okay, technically it was my blog post from last month announcing COTC's return. Krista Morgan and John Goldschmidt, P2BInvestor's designated mixologists are gearing up to destroy the competition with their .TMP "Tequila Mockingbird Punch!"

Stack Overflow

Last, but certainly not least: Stack Overflow. Stack Overflow, the world's largest forum of software developers, is a question and answer site for professional and enthusiast programmers. It's run by users, and is part of a larger network of Q&A sites under Stack Exchange. Erin Gray - chief mixologist for Stack Overflow - and her team are psyched to be participating in Clash of the Cocktails, and they've thrown the gauntlet down. They're ready to ignite your tastebuds with their .BMP "Bourbon Mint Peach!"
These five teams will be going head-to-head in a round robin-ish event. Attendees will vote for their two favorite cocktails out of the five, and then we'll narrow it down to the top two cocktails. The winner will be chosen with a second round of voting.

It's not too late to RSVP for Clash of the Cocktails!

Register here, because we won't be selling tickets at the door!

item.title: Stay the Course, Change Now
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
Change – I find myself talking about it a lot in my blogs. It's important to recognize change. It drives or at least affects most things in technology and does so at a fast pace. Keeping up with change is one of those topics where your opinion might vary depending on what it is you’re suppose to be keeping up with. The amount of success you’ve already had at keeping up can also influence your opinion. "Join us and make apps that will change the world."  I suspect we've all heard that statement at least a couple of times. Given the number of people and the number of lines of code they write each day to make those apps, is the world changing fast enough or too fast? As software developers in an age where technology pervades so many aspects of our lives and is in such high demand, we have many opportunities to consider the effects of our actions on the things around us. From our choice of programming statements in one line of code affecting its result, to the grander scale of geopolitics and social evolution, the systems we create, enhance and maintain can have a significant impact on the planet and its inhabitants. But for the most part, our software is not making significant social changes in the world at all. It can be useful, entertaining, convenient, enlightening, and so many more things a lot of the daily grind efforts in software development never even get out of QA to be released much less have an impact. There are several reasons why this happens, and a big one is change.

The requirements changed. The product owner changed. The API changed. The operating system changed. Our frameworks changed.

As software relies more and more on other software, which relies on other software, your dependency chain can quickly have a large number of links that expose you to risks. For example, an API has changed, this is the final release where deprecated method Z will be supported, or framework X now has a security flaw. So what can be done to manage these changes? How can you reduce your risk to this type of exposure? The first and best answer is to embrace change. Changes in technology and software are largely driven by us, people. People and people doing business. People doing business often imagine opportunities through software and technology. These people need to collaborate with people in the software business that understand change. They help clients define and understand their current technology needs, find the client's appropriate position on the technology adoption curve (AKA risk management), and advise them how to anticipate and prepare for changes that might bring them opportunities as well as the associated risks. Since software relies more and more on other software, it's a given that the software they provide you will be one of those risks. Everything has an expected lifespan. Cars age and crumble. Bodies wear out. But with a flexible, modular and resilient design, regular maintenance, and a continued awareness of what is likely to be coming next, your software can quickly adapt to change and present you with new opportunities and minimized risks.

Keep your business software well maintained and up to date.

Embrace change!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Stay the Course, Change Now | Commerce Kitchen
As software developers, we work in an industry where change is constant: systems get updates, strategies shift, and the like. Russ says embrace the change!

item.title: Wear Sunscreen, and 8 Other Things You Should Know About Being a Developer
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.content:encoded:
I have friends in various fields who have often considered changing careers to become software devs. Clearly, this is becoming a trend with more and more nontraditional coding schools popping up all around the country. Though their biggest fears seem to stem from some simple misunderstandings about coding and what the job entails.  Many believe that their math skills aren't strong enough [I imagine] because traditional CS programs have so much of a math focus.  Or that they have to be some kind of brilliant hacker-type, like the ridiculous portrayals in the movies of sleep-deprived, over-caffeinated, introverts who (somehow) don't even need a mouse. I really think most people can become software developers; there's not a lot of magic to it, but like most anything, it requires dedication, patience, and a lot of work. Sure, there will always exist some devs who can write code 16 hours a day, work weekends, solve difficult problems with ease and finish projects in 1/3 the time as I do. These devs are the exception, not the rule. I hate that people feel intimidated because they feel like they have to be that kind of developer to be useful to an organization. Being a developer isn't just about writing great code, even though that helps too. It's about all the other non-coding stuff that comes with the job. This is my list of things that I think are of key importance to being a great programmer, and coincidentally almost none of them are code related.

1. Giving yourself enough time to finish something properly is crucial.

It's taken me a long time to learn this one. New devs almost always make the mistake of underestimating tasks; they forget about adding tests, re-factoring, testing, finding technical issues that always arise, and the standard 20% buffer that should always be added.

Even if you're a lightning-fast dev, if you underestimate a task and have to push back the deadline, you're late. You thought giving an aggressive timeline would make you look good in the meeting where you committed to it. Now you've made yourself and your employer look unreliable in the eyes of the client. For what? Just to save face in a planning meeting? Don't do that to yourself!  It's not worth all the stress it creates. I'd much rather have a reliable dev who takes longer to get things done, who gives me estimates and always meets them.

2. Communication with clients is equally as important as the code you write.

Prompt responses to emails go a LONG way to create communicative trust. It's one of the easiest ways to maintain a healthy working relationship. If they ask a question that will require a longer response time, write them back and let them know you're working on it. Don't just disappear for days waiting to get them an answer.

I always thought replying without an answer was just a waste of everyone's time. It's not; just do it! As long as you're always prompt to respond, it keeps the onus on the client to continue prompt responses. Once you start with the delayed responses, clients feel it's ok for them to do the same. It creates an unproductive communication environment. It's way more important than you'd think, just get in the habit of responding quickly.

3. Being really good at one language is much more useful than a mediocre polyglot.

It's easy to jump ship all the time and get into another language, since they seem to come out every week. Make sure you get really good with at least one. You'll be much more marketable and useful.

4. Sleep is good.

There are romanticized notions of devs staying up all night, in a coffee/adderall/soda-fueled bender trying to hammer out some code to meet a deadline, like some kind of nerdy superhero. It's stupid. If you've been writing code for 12 hours, then you're definitely not nearly as productive. Go to bed, get up early, and you'll be WAY more efficient.

5. You should be writing code that is readable.

It's WAY more important than writing code that is 'clever'.

6. Don't be afraid to leave the training wheels on a little longer.

Sometimes it's easy to think you've gotten to the point where you're a great developer and you don't need to work under a senior dev anymore. Enjoy the time where you have someone to ping questions off of, to help you with architecture decisions, can field challenging questions in client meetings, and all the other things that having a senior person brings with it. I left my first dev job (after working for only a year) to go 'freelance' and it was a big wakeup call. I realized how much I didn't know that my senior dev did. I've been at it for ~6 years now, and I spent the last year working under a more senior person. Although losing some autonomy is hard, having access to all that knowledge and experience is invaluable and it's an opportunity you may never have again.

7.) Refactor, refactor, refactor.

You'd never turn in a first draft essay or even an email. Why would you think your first round of code is polished enough?

8.) Be patient with yourself.

It's said that it takes 5-10 years before you'll become a great developer, so keep at it! It's difficult work that requires a lot of knowledge, most of which has to be learned on the job. You're not going to be great out of the gate; accept this. Learn as much as you can. Understand that it's the kind of career that requires a commitment to lifelong learning. Don't become a dinosaur dev. Good lord, I'm starting to sound like an old person, dispensing advice to kids at graduation. Anyway, if you can just remember one piece of my advice, just wear sunscreen.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: being a developer
What You Should Know About Being a Software Developer
There's not a lot of magic to being a developer, but like most anything, it requires dedication, patience, and a lot of work.

item.title: A Denver Startup Week Guide for First-Timers
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Alright, Denver Startup Week folks. It's time to get down to brass tax here. DSW is kind of intimidating for first-timers. It's a week filled with smart people, great ideas, and a whole heck of a lot of beards and beers. So how is a Denver Startup Week newbie supposed to approach this crazy, intense week of startup nerdiness? Take it from someone who attended their first one last year: it's long, tough week, but it's so worth it. Here are my tips on getting through Denver Startup Week alive and in one piece.

1. Put on your thinking cap.

Dust off those ol' brain muscles of yours. You'll be using parts of your brain - like your imagination! - that haven't been stretched in a while. Denver Startup Week is all about listening and sharing ideas with some of the brightest minds in our community. Be alert. Be attentive. You'll be hearing from some of the coolest people in Denver (and sometimes Boulder)'s business community. Getting inspired by these folks will be easy; it's what you take away from them that will determine if DSW was worth it for you.

2. Put on your networking pants.

Leave it to Denver to put on the biggest free entrepreneurial shindig in North America. They're expecting upwards of 7,000 attendees this year, compared to last year's 5,500. That's a shit ton of people to network with. Between all of the panels, sessions, and social events, you're sure to meet plenty of startup enthusiasts who share your passion for entrepreneurship, tech, and/or craft beer.

3. BYOB to the Startup Crawl.

Bring your own BIKE! With 12 stops this year, the startup crawl going to be a blast for everyone involved. I biked between the stops last year, and it was so much easier (and faster!) than walking. However, depending on how great of a bicyclist you are after 10 beers, maybe biking's not the best option. Just be safe, hydrate when you're stopped at a couple of the offices, and don't drive after you're done. Site note: if the map of the crawl is anything like last year's, your tipsy/drunk self might not be able to handle it. Best of luck to ya.

4. Go to a couple of events per day, but don't overload your schedule.

I'm not planning on getting much work done during Denver Startup Week. I've already accepted that fact. Yet, I've limited myself to two or three sessions per day, so I can have some semblance of a productive week. Keep your schedule balanced. Take advantage of the awesomeness of DSW, but don't overdo it.

5. Geek out.

Get excited! Get a little starstruck! Get funky! Denver Startup Week [albeit exhausting and overwhelming] is amazingly fun if you let it take you over. Listen. Learn. Leave feeling inspired and ready to take on the world. It's going to be a great week. I hope to see you out there!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Denver Startup Week Guide for First-Timers
denver startup week
So how is a Denver Startup Week newbie supposed to approach this crazy, intense week of startup nerdiness? It's a long, tough week, but it's worth it.

item.title: What Buffy Taught Me About Being a Young Woman in Tech
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
There are certain leading ladies from pop culture and history who will always occupy that special place in my heart reserved for strong, intelligent, independent women who know how to kick some ass (figuratively or literally). Britain's Queen Victoria, Disney's Pocahontas, and Meryl Streep in basically everything she does are just a few of the ladies I've loved. It wasn't until I started watching Buffy the Vampire Slayer that I discovered what being a heroine is all about. Surprisingly, there are some serious parallels between Buffy's life in Sunnydale and being a young woman in tech. As I spent the past eight months getting through 144 episodes of the show, I started finding some true life lessons to be learned from Buffy's constant endeavors to kill demons and save the world. (Spoilers ahead!)

Roll with the punches.

I've got to hand it to Buffy — she overcame every single obstacle in the battle between good and evil during the series' seven-year run. Of course she had her low points - I personally would like to forget her "I'm not the slayer" period in L.A. between seasons one and two - but she still managed fight every punch that was swung in her direction. In real life, things change just as rapidly for young women, especially if you work at a tech-based startup. Here at Commerce Kitchen in 2014, we've had some big leadership changes and departures. Our company's direction has pivoted to fit the kind of work we want to focus on. Personally, I have had four different titles since I started working here in January 2013. At a startup, you have to learn to deal with change just like Buffy did in Sunnydale.

Follow the leader... until you become one.

When Buffy first became The Slayer, she was introduced to her Watcher and mentor, Mr. Rupert Giles. As British and uptight as he was in the first few years of their relationship, Giles was the perfect leader, father-figure, and punching bag for Buffy in those early days. Day after day, he taught her Slayer strategy and to trust her instincts, until one day, she didn't need him anymore (except for when she actually did in seasons 6 and 7). During my time at Commerce Kitchen, I've had several leaders and mentors who have guided me through the rough terrain of my first job in the business world. Each of them have played a critical role in how I've grown as part of this team and as an individual. I still have a lot to learn, but I am also growing as a leader within our organization, just like Buffy in the Scooby gang.

Surround yourself with awesome people.

If I could, I would give Joss Whedon a huge hug for A) writing and directing such an amazing show with a kickass female lead and B) for surrounding Buffy with amazing friends, family, and allies. Willow, Xander, Giles, Cordelia, Anya, Angel, Spike, Tara, Joyce, and even Dawn brought out the best [and sometimes the worst] in our Slayer. Time and again, the Scooby Gang was the core group of people who helped Buffy slay the demons and save the world. If putting yourself in danger to help out your Slayer-buddy isn't true friendship, then I don't know what is. Just like Buffy, you can't go it alone. You need a solid group of kickass people by your side as you maneuver your career, and it's even better if they're fighting the same good fight as you are. You need your own clever, kindhearted Willow. You need a brave, joke-cracking Xander. You need a wise, once-punk Giles. If you're as lucky as Buffy was, then you'll find friends and allies in the strangest of places (I'm looking at you, Anya and Cordelia).

Make worthy sacrifices.

Demon after demon, apocalypse after apocalypse, Buffy's goal was always to save the world and the people she loves. As the Slayer, it was her responsibility, and that constantly weighed on her. On several occasions, she had to turn her back on her friends, family, and (most memorably) Angel in order to stop an apocalypse from happening. I'm not saying that you'll have to kill your soulmate to be successful in your career, but small sacrifices will have to be made here and there. You might have to skip happy hour with your actual friends in order to attend that big networking event that your boss wants you to make an appearance at. You'll definitely have to figure out how to prioritize your life to incorporate exercise and down-time into your weekly schedule (I'm personally still trying to figure that one out). Not a drinker? Good luck keeping that up in a world where kegerators and Wine Fridays are the norm.

Don't make unnecessary apologies.

If there's one thing Buffy didn't do very often, it was give apologies that were undeserved. She wasn't afraid to make enemies; in fact, she made a lot of those. From her cheerleading, Cordelia-hating days of Sunnydale High, to bringing the young potential slayers into a dangerous fist fight with Caleb and The First, Buffy was rarely the crowd favorite. (Except for when she was given the "Class Protector" award at her senior prom by a soon-to-be-evil Jonathan. I mean, who didn't tear up in that scene?) It's common in our gender to start every question with a "Sorry," like we're apologizing for wanting to learn or for speaking up. That confidence gap is a tough one to overcome as a young woman in a new position or industry. Please don't apologize when you don't have to, and certainly don't be afraid to make a few enemies in your career — it shows that you've got the passion to succeed and you don't care about being everyone's best friend (Willow strayed into that territory often, especially in the early seasons).

Be the leading lady in your own life.

This is quite possibly the most important lesson that Buffy taught me. Strong, resilient, and ever-ready with a witty comeback, Buffy Summers is leading lady legend. Rare was it that she failed to step up to the plate to take down the latest Big Bad, even when it was her best friend Willow (a.k.a.: best Big Bad EVER). Buffy is the strong female character that us millennial ladies have always wanted but didn't know we already had. Ladies, it's 2014. You are a tough, powerful young woman. You are not a damsel in distress. Take charge of your own life. Be your own boss. Become an entrepreneur. Ask for that raise that you definitely deserve. Don't like your job? Move. You are not a tree. Put yourself first every single day of the week and twice on Sundays. Be the leading lady in your own life.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/buffy-1.jpg
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/buffy-1.jpg
young woman in tech
What Buffy Taught Me About Being a Young Woman in Tech
Young women can learn a lot from Buffy the Vampire Slayer, especially those who are seeking careers in technology. Buffy fans, this one's for you.

item.title: Bad clients? Buck up, buttercup.
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Our community engagement associate (and rockstar social media manager) Jen keeps a fabulous list of blog topics to help direct Commerce Kitchen's content strategy. Been to a great conference recently? She'll encourage you to write about that. Learn a new dev skill? Tell the world. For this week, I was coming up dry. But given that I've had some ups and downs recently in client management, Jen suggested that I focus on "how to treat clients who treat you poorly". Clients who treat me poorly...really, just "bad clients". Queue steam coming out of my ears, and my nose pinched between my fingers. My first written response?
  • Sarcasm
  • Disdain
  • Public ridicule
Although writing that down made me chuckle, clearly those ideas are not helpful, and would probably do more harm than good. So once I got through my internal therapy session, I spent some time reflecting on the situation.

What causes bad clients?

Obviously, we always set out to work with the best, brightest and most inspired folks. And almost all of the time, we do. Unfortunately good clients can become bad clients if the right set of circumstances forces their hand. In my recent experience, that evolution has been driven by:

  • Too many cooks in the client's kitchen.

    It's hard to know who to listen to or how to solve a problem when there are 15 different people clamoring to be heard and put their stamp on a project. And this doesn't just affect the vendors...I think our main client contact is suffering right alongside us.

  • A once neutral environment turns political.

    Despite the best intentions, if your client's team starts to get an agenda that runs counter to the project, or there's a hostile takeover of a team's project by their boss' boss, trouble is sure to ensue.

  • Communication breakdowns.

    If you aren't communicating effectively, confusion and frustration can quickly downward spiral into finger pointing, incongruous expectations and a lack of quality output.

How can you overcome bad clients?

  • Empathy

    While it may sometimes be difficult to put yourself in your clients' shoes, take a deep breath. Now reflect on how the client's environment has been evolving. Have you been clear enough in your communications? What new challenges are your clients facing internally? You won't know unless you ask, and reframing your perspective may help you see your bad clients in a new light.

  • Honesty

    Sometimes your clients just don't get it. They can get so focused on what you've done, that they can no longer hear you explaining why you've done it, or they frankly don't care. They can't see the forest for the trees. Being honest and open, and reinforcing the rationale for your decision making will keep the conversation going and, at the very least, get you on the same page. Admit when you are wrong, yet also acknowledge when there may be another way to look at a problem or potential solution. Your client may still push back and choose to not take your advice, but then that's their purposeful decision making (bad or otherwise). You have to let go at this point...they are paying for your services and advice, but it's also their prerogative to go their own way.

  • Integrity

    You make decisions for a reason, and need to stand by them. Be kind, yet firm if you are getting pushback from a client. Refer back to your research or documentation (a brief, a wireframe, or whatever other jointly approved project plan you have). Apply every ounce of gentle authority that you have in you to lead the conversation, but again, know when to say enough is enough. In extreme cases, you may have to walk away from a bad client, and the associated project, but most times, you can figure out another path forward.
Good luck. With humility, patience and a whole lot of communication, you have the potential to turn your once good, bad client back into a long-term partner. Side note, is it "buck up, buttercup" or "suck it up, buttercup"? Urban dictionary says the latter, but my family, in their infinite ability to f*** up idioms, have ingrained the former into my psyche.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: bad clients
Bad clients? Reflect, empathize and move forward.
Empathy, honesty, and integrity along with good communication can help overcome bad clients, get a project back on track, and start a productive partnership.

item.title: 20 Definite Signs You Attended Denver Startup Week
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Dearest Denver Startup Week, I love you, but I think it's time we spent some time apart. You know, maybe a year from now, I'll probably feel differently, and I'll be ready for you. It's not you, it's me. We had a whirlwind romance, but I just need some time to reflect on our relationship. I promise we can still stay friends. Best wishes, Jen I can't be alone in this, right? Here are 20 signs that you had a Denver Startup Week very similar to mine. 1. You've had to restock your business card holder at least once in the past 5 days. 2. You now have a collection of schwag (t-shirts, stickers, koozies, lip balms, boomerangs...) from many different startups, and you don't know what to do with any of it. 3. You've shaken so many hands this week that you feel like you could write a book on all of the kinds of crappy handshakes. 4. Because of all of those handshakes, you feel like you're coming down with something: a cold, the flu, an allergy to the question "So, what do you do?", etc. 5. Speaking of... you've got your answer memorized. You'll probably it recite over and over again in your sleep sometime over the weekend, forcing your partner to kick you in the shins at 2AM. 6. You're currently trying to figure out if there's a Denver Startup Week version of PTSD. PDSWD? 7. Unlike last week, you can now accurately describe the last time you were forced to sit on the floor, which of course caused your leg to fall asleep, like it was the first day of 1st grade all over again. Feld forbid you show up to a session within five minutes of its starting time... 8. Your Twitter follower count increased by 10+ in the past few days. 9. You've already received and/or sent multiple LinkedIn invitations to connect. 10. You've felt the cold, harsh sting of getting cut in line by someone who just had to talk to Rand Fishkin before you did. 11. You've been surviving on a diet of beer, wine, espresso, granola bars, and event appetizers. 12. You've regretted driving to Chase Basecamp, mainly because trying to find parking around there is more stressful than trying to figure out what your exit strategy will be. 13. You're so fucking sick of the phrase "exit strategy." 14. At one point, you seriously considered making a drinking game out of hearing "exit strategy," or another startup-related word or phrase. 15. You discovered that there aren't many Denver natives in the startup community. 16. You've questioned the purpose of the #DENStartupWeek wristbands. 17. You didn't get much work done in the past few days, and are trying to figure out if you should be working over the weekend. 18. You feel like you could've gone to more sessions and events. 19. At the same time, you're really glad you didn't go to more sessions and events. 20. You're so incredibly happy that you get to return to your normal schedule next week.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: denver startup week
20 Definite Signs You Attended Denver Startup Week
Denver Startup Week, while fun and full of insight, was (as always) exhausting. Here are 20 signs that you lived through it like Jen did.
