item.title: Lorem Ipsum: Why You Shouldn’t Use it, But Sometimes Should
item.dc:creator: Casey
item.content:encoded:
Like many of you, at various companies and on numerous teams, I’ve experimented with methods of presenting design comps to clients.

In an ideal world, we would stop using dummy content, and design with the actual point in mind: the content. It’s illogical to create a look and feel (particularly messaging and callouts), when we don’t know what the content will be. This can put designers in a precarious position, and potentially prevent them from solving the real problem at hand: "How can I use my design skills to best get THIS MESSAGE (or these messages) across, not a message that I’ll find out about later…?"

Unfortunately, with tight turnarounds and the need to overlap functions to hit deadlines, we often need to get going on design and copy at the same time, and meet somewhere down the road. Hopefully, we check in with each other frequently along the way.

Here are some lessons learned, annoyances, and suggestions for both methods.

If you are able to write the content in your comps, make sure that it’s the final version, and has already been approved by all decision makers. Often we end up with timeline reasons for producing our comps with incomplete or unapproved content. This can backfire in a few ways, and probably isn’t much better than using dummy content.

  • As the content changes, your design may need to change along with it. This can be a risky approach, as you get approval, then need to go back and make tweaks to fit the content. Add another callout here, a lightbox there, another round of approval, etc.
  • You can very easily get stuck in a loop of content changes in your design comps, which are really best taken care of in a development or storytelling exercise. Understandably, stakeholders have a hard time ignoring the content in a comp. You can end up with revisions that aren’t design revisions, at all.
  • You can actually completely lose the focus of the exercise, which is an approved look and feel that can be used with many types of pages and content. If a stakeholder is trying to make the content perfect, they may completely ignore whether or not they like the look and feel.

If you decide to [or have no choice but to] use Lorem Ipsum in your designs, here are a few things to consider:
  • Make sure there is a solid creative brief that gets the designer as close to what the messaging will be, as possible. This will allow the designer to understand whether he/she is trying to help drive downloads for a new mobile application, or generate leads for a sales organization.
  • Make sure you have approved wireframes. These should be well-annotated wireframes that show approved content areas and functionality.
  • Make sure that copywriters understand the wireframes (and their flexibility) while they develop copy.
  • Make sure that content hierarchy is considered. This can be a big risk if Design and Copywriting aren’t joined at the hip, as the final content may not fit the approved designs otherwise.
  • Make sure that what your designing isn’t so rigid that seemingly innocuous content changes will have a crazy impact on the design. The content is certainly going to flex during the live of what you are developing, so consider this.  Work with a developer (if you aren’t one…you probably should be one) to talk about how to make this happen.

My most successful projects have been those where the content is final before starting design, but I’ve had more success with Lorem Ipsum than with incomplete content.

Here are some of my favorite Lorem Ipsum generators, including a few that we’ve created here at Commerce Kitchen!

  • Startup Ipsum (Beards)
  • Whedon Ipsum (Buffy)
  • Bacon Ipsum (Bacon!)
  • Lebowski Ipsum (The Dude Abides)
  • Hodor Ipsum (Hodor)
  • Hipster Ipsum (Comes with Can of PBR)
What’s working for you?  What’s not working? Share your thoughts below!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: lorem ipsum
Lorem Ipsum: Why You Shouldn’t Use it, But Sometimes Should
In an ideal world, we would stop using dummy content, and design with the actual point in mind: the content. Unfortunately, lorem ipsum is the old standby.

item.title: Accountability and the Remote Worker
item.dc:creator: shelly
item.content:encoded:
Last week, one of my favorite CK clients, Merrily from over at EEO Legal Solutions, reached out and asked for some help brainstorming on a tricky issue. I won't get into the legal details - in large part because they seem horribly confusing and I don't really understand them - but the gist is that she's working on putting together a webinar to help employers make smart "reasonable accommodation" for pregnant workers. She was curious if I had any suggestions from a technological perspective. ***Note: All stock photos that come up for the search "pregnant worker" make the experience look really unpleasant. 

Realizing We're the Exception

[caption id="attachment_7803" align="alignleft" width="199"] Why so much misery?![/caption] The challenges that face a shop like Commerce Kitchen aren't the same as those that face a lot of employers, it turns out.  CK's experience with pregnant employees is minimal, but happily for us, our employees are some of the most engaged people I know, and they hold themselves to high accountability standards without our oversight. But what happens when your pregnant employee isn't as engaged? How do you provide her with reasonable accommodation and hold her accountable to still complete the work assigned to her? At CK accountability and engagement is a given in our staff, but it's not that way for all employers. Of course, in creative and white collar work, most jobs are measured by deliverables: managing client relationships through meetings, emails, and calls; delivering creative briefs; research and reporting. This is all work that can be done remotely, which jibes with a common request of the pregnant employee: the freedom to work from home or make up time during non-business hours. Other kinds of work are not nearly as flexible like manufacturing or cashiering at a fast food joint. Even a receptionist in a busy office is tied to being at a certain place at a certain time, so remote work would probably not be an alternative for her. But for those of us in thought-work positions, allowing remote work can be a great way to offer pregnant employees some flexibility over the course of a pregnancy, so long as you manage to get it right from the beginning. At CK we have a few developers that don't live in Denver (damned snowboarders!), so working with remote teams is part of our bread and butter.  Below are some suggestions on how to offer your staff the opportunity to shift some of their time to working out of the office.

Set Expectations

[caption id="attachment_7805" align="alignleft" width="199"] Someone get this woman a pile of ibuprofen, stat![/caption] This is not a tech solution, of course, but it's critical to success. Your remote team member needs to know what she's expected to do during the time that she's not in the office. If you're lucky, she already knows her job so well that she'll be telling you what to expect. If that's not the case, review with her the kind of work that she does in a given week, identify what pieces are the easiest to take home, and set deadlines and expectations around that work on a regular basis. It's super easy to tell when an in-office employee is out of things to do. It's a lot harder to tell when a remote worker is idle. Laying out what kind of work and how much of it needs to get accomplished from home is essential to success.

Get Face to Face, Virtually

Meetings are a regular part of almost any job, and you should make sure not to exclude your remote worker from those meetings. You may think you can just catch people up over email/or instant message, but intentions and details often get lost over non-spoken channels. If you have an employee who is remote for more than a day or two - say, the bedrest scenario I suggested above - make a point of having morning, face-to-face checkin in meetings daily. Just 10-15 minutes to review progress and layout goals for the new day will go a long way to making sure that the expectations above are understood and met.

Tools to Consider

  • Google Hangouts Free via Gmail, and included in any Google Apps integration, Hangouts allow you to see your remote team members, share screens, and have face to face conversations, so long as all computers involved have a webcam and microphone
  • WebEx and Go To Meeting These tools are massive, and often expensive, and so are only usually used by big companies. Is yours one of those companies?
  • Facetime The iPhone video phone call system would work if everyone has an iOS device. Which also reminds me: providing a worker on bedrest with an iPad or laptop really doesn't seem like too much to ask, does it?

Use a Task Management or Project Management Tool or Track Time

This dovetails with setting expectations, but if your team isn't using any task management tools, the day you agree to let a team member work remotely is the day you should implement one. There are tons of different tools available with varying degrees of complexity. What works for your team will depend on the kind of work you do, the number of people involved, and how much you want to pay. That said, below are some of my favorites.

Tools to Consider

  • LeanKit LeanKit is an online Kanban board - a system that allows you to list out tasks, assign them to team members, and then let those team members move those tasks across "To Do," "Doing," and "Done" columns. LeanKit sends email updates in real time, so if your team is good about maintaining the board, you'll get updates as the work is being done, which gives you the ability to stay out of it if things are going well, or check in if you're not seeing any movement across the board.
  • Basecamp or Asana Basecamp and Asana are much more complex, comprehensive project management tools. Clients as well as team members can be invited to join a project through them, allowing all stakeholders to see progress, ask questions, and track and contribute to project-related conversations. Asana boasts that they promote "teamwork without email," so if that sounds doubly appealing, definitely check it out!
  • Freckle or Toggl Freckle and Toggl both do one thing really well: Time tracking. You're not using them to plan out someone's week in anticipation of them being gone from the office, but if you've got a team member who will be out for a while, who knows what she's got to do, and you just want to keep tabs on what she's up to, these tools are great. They're often used to track billable hours, but you can use them as you see fit.
There are, of course, tons of other considerations for making reasonable accommodations for pregnant workers, and tons more for managing remote teams, but these tools and tactics have my vote for managing the space where those needs intersect. Any other ideas on keeping remote team members on track? Leave 'em in the comments below!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: remote worker
Accountability and the Remote Worker | Commerce Kitchen
What happens when your pregnant employee isn't around? How do you hold her accountable to complete her work? Michelle tackles the remote worker conundrum.

item.title: Denver Does NOT Get 300 Days of Sunshine.
item.dc:creator: Chad
item.content:encoded:
Lies, Damned Lies, and Days of Sunshine

In damn near every tourist article about Denver, the tired old stat of "Denver gets 300 days of sunshine" gets trotted out. It is sometimes qualified with "almost", but not nearly often enough. There's just one problem. It's not true. Denver has pretty nice weather and does get a good amount of sunshine, just not 300 days, not even by a generous definition including partly cloudy days. So how much sunshine does Denver have? According to my source:  245 Clear AND partly cloudy days. Only 115 officially clear days. That doesn't sound like "300 days of sunshine" to me. Here's a link to the Colorado data on the Currents Results website. A few definitions. This data this covers daylight hours only. Clear denotes zero to 3/10 average sky cover. Partly cloudy denotes 4/10 to 7/10 average sky cover. Cloudy denotes 8/10 to 10/10 average sky cover. Albuquerque, where I used to live, comes a lot closer to 300 days of sunshine -- 278 clear and partly cloudy days. The only place that actually gets more than 300 days of sunshine (again, party cloudy is included) is Yuma, Arizona, which weighs in with a whopping 313 days. Even the infamously hot Phoenix has only 296 days. Looking at the month-to-month data, you see that some weather stereotypes are true: Seattle gets a whopping 3 clear days in the average January, while Denver gets three times as many, at 10.

Forget Days: What about Percentages?

A more useful way of looking at it: what percentage of the possible sunshine does the city get in a year? Here are some numbers:
  • Albuquerque: 76%
  • Denver: 69%
  • Seattle: 43%
  • The lowest: Juneau, Alaska: 30%
  • The highest: Yuma again, with a crazy 90%. It's apparently the driest city in the United States, which I believe with that number.

How cold is Denver though?

While we are talking about weather, let me clear up something else: whether Denver is one of the coldest major cities in the US depends on whether you are talking morning or afternoon average winter temperatures.  Denver ranks fairly high on coldest major cities in the morning at 18 degrees Fahrenheit (sorry, Celsius fans, no love from me), but doesn't doesn't even crack the top ten on coldest daily maximum temperature. Why? Higher altitude and drier places have a wider temperature swing. Denver is obviously high, but it's also a bit drier compared to a lot of places. In other words, it's cold all day in Minnesota: most days in Denver it gets up to a more reasonable temperature by afternoon.  But what is that temperature, I wondered?

I went and generated the numbers for average winter highs in Denver myself. What? Some people like fantasy football: I like weather geekery. I picked Denver Stapleton airport, since that covers more of the time period. The average high in winter (December, January, and Februar) is a relatively balmy 45 degrees F.

That should keep the tourist bureaus a bit happier than my "300 days of sunshine is a lie" rant.

Original data sources

From National Climatic Data Center, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
  • Sunshine as a percentage, most to least
  • NOAA's 1981-2010 Climate Normals
  • Denver Stapleton Airport weather records

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: a:3:{s:20:"restored_revision_id";i:7841;s:16:"restored_by_user";i:9;s:13:"restored_time";i:1411505932;}
300 days of sunshine
Denver Does NOT Get 300 Days of Sunshine
In nearly every tourist article about Denver, the tired old stat of "Denver gets 300 days of sunshine" gets trotted out. But is it true? Chad investigates.

item.title: "I Attended Denver Startup Week. Now What?"
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
In case you've been living under a rock, Denver Startup Week has come and gone. It was a long, fun week filled with informative sessions and alcohol-rich social events. Now that it's over, what are we supposed to do? Yes, getting back to our normal lives has been a huge relief, but if you're still looking to scratch that startup itch you got last week, then you've come to the right place.

1. Built-In Colorado

[caption id="attachment_7856" align="alignright" width="350"] Photo: 23rd Studios.[/caption] Built-In Colorado is a great resource for all things startup in the Centennial State. One of the added perks of joining the BIC crew is Built-In Brews: a monthly hangout at a different startup. I've been to my fair share of Built-In Brews, and I meet at least a few new people at every one. The BIB organizers are trying this new thing out where attendees must purchase a $5 ticket deposit to save their spot at the event (and to ensure that Built-In Colorado keeps their attendee numbers up). You get refunded the $5 upon arrival to the Built-In Brews venue (because the event is actually FREE), so don't let that deter you from checking out the scene. Startups like ReadyTalk, SolidFire, and Craftsy are in the hosting queue for the next few events.

2. Women Who Startup

I have a lot of love for Women Who Startup. Not only did Lizelle organize a great panel for Women Who Startup's headline event, but she actually does that every month. Okay, technically she doesn't have eight kickass panelists at every Women Who Startup meetup, but she does bring in one amazing leader from the Denver/Boulder community each month to talk about her experiences as a businesswoman and/or female entrepreneur. While it is a female-specific meetup, men are often welcomed as guest speakers or attendees!

3. Startups Drink Local

Shameless plug time, folks! Commerce Kitchen is kicking off Startups Drink Local next month, on October 16. What is it? After the hilarity of Clash of the Cocktails was over, we decided to continue helping build the camaraderie that is so present in our Denver startup community. Startups Drink Local was born from the idea that every startup has its own neighborhood hangout. For us, it's Adrift on South Broadway. Every month, we'll be co-hosting a meetup with a different startup at their neighborhood bar, pub, brewery, etc. to support local businesses. Want your startup (and your favorite neighborhood bar) to get some love from the Denver startup community? Email me at jen[at]commercekitchen[dot]com!
Denver's startup community is exactly that: a community. If last week's shenanigans weren't proof enough that we have something very special here in the Mile High City, then I hope you take advantage of these opportunities!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/2014-09-24_1453.png
"I Attended Denver Startup Week. Now What?"
Denver Startup Week
Getting back to our normal lives has been a huge relief, but we bet you're still looking to scratch that startup itch you got during Denver Startup Week.

item.title: New Award, New Location
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
The last few weeks at the firehouse have been kind of nuts, but in a good way!

CWCC Small Company of the Year

On September 25th, we were honored and humbled to have received the Colorado Women's Chamber Small Company of the Year Award for 2014. The award "recognizes a company that creates a workplace culture that supports the highest levels of personal and professional accomplishment for their employees who are women." As a company with 75% female partners, and an organization that strives to encourage and support women in tech, we hope to encourage businesses throughout Colorado to respect and promote diversity in their workforce. Of course we asked Tynan, our lone male partner, to accept the honor because, as CEO, he's been leading our vision for an equitable tech workplace for the last 11 years. He immediately endeared himself to the audience, and gave some heartfelt words about the challenges of women in tech to the assembled lunch crowd. And shout out to our partner, Jamie, who was nominated for this year's Young Professional of the Year for her work with Anneal!

A Second Office at INDUSTRY

As we continue growing the Commerce Kitchen business in the digital health industry, we've found that the networking at INDUSTRY's coworking space has been invaluable for connecting with our clients, and movers and shakers in the healthcare scene. We're excited to announce that we're opening a second, satellite office this month. Don't worry -- the firehouse isn't going anywhere! Most of our team will office at 600 South Broadway, but several of our CK superheroes will be regularly rotating through and working from our new office at 3001 Brighton Boulevard, just a few doors down from our partners at Anneal! If you are in the River North area, come stop by and check out Tynan's Tavern -- a wine tasting conference room, complete with wine barrel furniture and a fully stocked bar. Meetings will never be the same.
You may have heard rumblings about some other big office news at CK. Shssh, we can't say anything yet, but stay tuned for an official announcement in the coming weeks.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: We're Opening a New Office and Celebrating Our Award
It's been a big month at the firehouse. We won 2014 CWCC Small Company of the Year, and are opening a second office at INDUSTRY!

item.title: Giving Marketing and WordPress a New Why
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded: At Commerce Kitchen, we've been blessed to wear a lot of hats, and assemble a diverse team of talent -- from brand strategists and social media managers to full stack developers and triple Magento-certified experts, we have them all. But as our business has grown and we've solicited feedback from our clients, vendors, and prospects, we've realized that we really have two distinct, but equally important, core competencies: custom software development, especially in the healthcare space, and marketing site development / inbound marketing management. To better support each business vertical, and provide the best customer service possible for all of our clients, we're happy to announce that we've decided to migrate marketing and WordPress projects to a new sister brand, New Why. Michelle and Natalie will be heading up that business venture to help clients redefine and perfect their web presence. They will continue providing great customer service, marketing insights and WordPress development for clients of all budgets, shapes and sizes. Read their back story, ask them about their name, and drop them a line at their new email addresses to say congrats! Tynan and Jamie will continue to head up the custom software and app development at Commerce Kitchen, especially for enterprise level clients in healthcare and technology. We've got some really great projects in the hopper, and are especially excited for reveal an immersive and interactive web project that tells the story of digital health in Colorado early next year! Stay tuned as we refine Commerce Kitchen's brand messaging to reflect our focus on the healthcare scene. Exciting stuff all around! Thank you to all of our clients, friends, mentors and peers for helping us make these amazing changes. We couldn't have done it without you! We're excited about the opportunity to better serve our diverse set of clients, and appreciate your support of our family of companies at the Firehouse -- Commerce Kitchen, New Why, Lark IT and Anneal.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: New Why and Commerce Kitchen | Websites and Apps for All
We're excited to announce New Why, a sister brand focused on marketing websites. At CK, we'll continue to build custom apps and software for healthcare.

item.title: Mine is 6 Terrabytes. How Big is Yours?
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
What exactly is Big Data anyway?

According to the internet, Big Data is:
  • Any collection of data sets so large and complex that it becomes difficult to process using traditional data processing applications.
  • Any amount of data that's too big to be handled by one computer.
  • An easily scalable system of unstructured data with accompanying tools that can efficiently pull structured datasets.
  • [Big Data is] what happened when the cost of storing information became less than the cost of making the decision to throw it away.
  • [Big Data is] when the size of the data becomes part of the problem.
There you have it. Big Data defined. Are you feeling well informed now? The term definitely has a moving target as a definition, so here are some thoughts that will hopefully help to improve your aim. Big Data can certainly involve a galactic scale in it's definition, but if we step away from the data science group and toward the business applications people, here are two definitions that help bring it down to Earth:

Big Data is...

1) When the volume, velocity and variety of data exceeds an organization's storage or compute capacity for accurate and timely decision making. 2) Who cares? It's what you're doing with it that matters.

These statements imply a simple, time-honored use of two words to help clear the confusion: data vs. information. Data is disparate facts, quantities or characters of raw content: individual items you purchase, each GPS coordinate your phone logs, each step you take, and so on. Information is organized data providing some insight or answer to a question. It is data made useful.

For example, DATA: The distance from the earth to the moon is 238,900 miles. A dollar bill has a thickness of 0.0043 inches

INFORMATION: It would require 3.53 trillion one dollar bills to make a stack that would reach the moon.

The usefulness of that information might be debatable, but it does relate two disparate pieces of data and provide an answer to a question. Scale, perspective, and context are three similar and often-used words when considering or discussing Big Data. It's important to understand the scale or scope or size of Big, what the context of a problem might be, and the perspective of an audience with regard to the problem/answer.

Appreciation of scale: Item #1: With Warren Buffet's vast wealth, it would require 71 of his fortunes to build a stack of dollar bills to the moon.

Item #2: The US Debt Clock reports 2.95 trillion as the current US Tax Revenue.

Thus, even Mr. Buffet's vast wealth can't even begin to solve the problem of building the money stack to the moon, but the 316 million "contributing" US citizens would nearly complete the stack to the moon right now. This illustrates a scalable solution to a problem. One extraordinary contributor to a solution falls far short of the goal, but a large number of ordinary contributors achieves the solution quickly. Having a truly vast amount of data and applying a scalable solution is the quantum leap in problem solving that the data science groups are working on. Using the daily contributions of billions of people's lives as input data to be organized into informed answers to problems of previously unimagined scale (ex: cancer, disease, genomics, why people like that TV show or that hair style). When moving from the galactic to the more earthly scale of quantum leaps, businesses of all sizes, as well as individuals, will be using similar tools and applying similar techniques to discover answers to their larger questions. These scalable techniques and the benefits of previously related data sets will certainly find their way into our daily use. But if your organization's storage or compute capacity for accurate and timely decision making centers around spreadsheets, Word documents and static web pages, you will likely have difficulty trying to find some good questions, much less any answers. Start or accelerate your pace toward taming Big Data. And remember to Make It Useful.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/shutterstock_143575819.jpg
big data
Mine is 6 Terrabytes. How Big is Yours? | Commerce Kitchen
Big Data can certainly involve a galactic scale in it's definition. In this post, Russ discusses what Big Data means in a business application setting.

item.title: From Chemistry to Digital Strategy: A Winding Road to Tech
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
Last month we had the opportunity to meet hundreds of job seekers in the tech space at the Denver Startup Week job fair. From newly minted gSchool grads looking to land their first RoR development gig to seasoned product managers looking for a new opportunity to take a product to market, we met them all. Since then we've been following up with promising individuals to chat more, or at least let them know that we're not hiring for their desired position now, but when that changes, we'll be back in touch. The job seeking process: exciting, yet stressful. Filled with opportunity, yet fraught with closed doors along the way. Reflecting on that process, I want to share a bit of my story of how I've gotten where I am today in digital strategy, and what job seekers, especially in the startup scene, should be thinking about as they start chatting with potential employers:

Be Passionate

Or at least be really interested in what you are learning while you are in school. It's more interesting to talk to, and get to know, a passionate religious studies major who minored in music about how her skills could transition to marketing, than it is to talk to a business major that doesn't really care about his major and "just wants a job". (Sorry, but that's not a good reason for me to consider hiring you.) For most of my childhood, I wanted to become a doctor and work at the CDC. I thought that being on the front lines of clinical care and research on deadly diseases like ebola would be fascinating and rewarding. And like more than half of my entering class at college, I declared pre-med. But unlike most pre-med dropouts I didn't drop out because of organic chemistry. I decided I like chemistry more than the rest of my pre-med classes, and majored in it. Similarly, I really enjoyed my Spanish-language classes such as Spanish film pre- and post-Franco, and before I knew it, I had majored in romance languages as well. So if an employer says that they are only looking for CS or business majors, that company is probably a bit shortsighted and is not the right fit for you anyhow. Make sure you know the fundamentals of any job you are applying for. And be self aware so you can articulate how your skill set converts to a business setting, Don't let anyone tell you otherwise -- you are relevant, and you have a unique perspective to bring to the table that may just become your company's competitive advantage.

Be Flexible

College recruiting landed me at Dish Network in a sales and marketing management of online retailers. It was nothing like I'd done before, but it gave me hands on training in account management, Spanish translation (I translated legal language in my free time - ha!), product management of a order entry platform, and marketing campaign execution. When I was no longer being challenged, I parlayed that experience to an advertising agency that was niched in telecom. I started with account and project management of print work and TV before moving to brand strategy and digital tactics. My client base slowly shifted from telecommunications companies to healthcare companies, giving me experience in a broader set of industries. Wanting to focus on more digital tactics in the healthcare space, I took a leap to join a startup with my current job at Commerce Kitchen. Within the last two years alone, my role has evolved from event management, marcomm, SEO, and account management to brand strategy, analytics, UX and IA, and art direction. Long story long, while it's easy to look back and see the evolution of my roles and the common thread that weaves them together, at the time, it wasn't as clear. I had a vision, but it was an attainable one that focused two steps ahead instead of ten. Be flexible, take chances and seek new learning opportunities. You'll probably end up somewhere you never could have imagined, and it will be better than the path you thought you wanted to be on. And learn to speak up. None of my professional evolution would have been possible if I'd stayed quiet. Instead, each time I saw an opportunity to learn or try something new, I gave it a go. Speak up and tell people what you want to do; your managers and peers will often help you move in a new direction.

Be Present

As you start out in your career, it's easy to think, "Oh, I'll remember so and so. I work with her every day." And then two jobs later, you cannot remember her name and haven't made an effort to stay in touch even though she was critical to your success at the time. I am as guilty as the next gal in this department. And while LinkedIn and Twitter have made the process of staying top of mind with colleagues, peers and friends easier than ever, that doesn't replace a real human connection and taking the time to get together and listen to what that person has been up to recently. Be present and get to know your colleagues and clients across all of your networks. Find out what makes them tick. Learn how you can help support their career growth. And then care enough to stay in touch when you no longer work with those folks. Check in via email. Go to coffee or lunch from time to time. I am where I am today through a combination of persistence, risk taking, openness to change and sheer dumb luck, and can't wait to see where the next five years take me. Future CKers, put yourselves out there, and I'm sure we'll be working together soon. What approaches have helped you get where you are today in your career?

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How I Got Into Tech: Chemistry to Digital Strategy
Be passionate, be flexible, and be present to learn the skills you need to make an impact and kickstart your career in Denver's tech and startup scene.

item.title: Sales: It's Got a Bad Reputation. Let's Change It.
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Writer's note: suggested music for this post is obviously Joan Jett. It's time to talk about the "S" word. Indeed, I'm here to talk about that dirty, disgusting word that has such a bad reputation in our world today.

SALES.

When did "sales" become an unutterable word in our community? After a recent discussion that Tynan and I had with Jeremiah Fellows, the VP of Sales and Marketing from Aspenware, I decided to look more into this anti-"sales" phenomenon.

It's all in the family.

Immediately, when I think of sales, I think of my parents. My dad has been in sales for over 25 years, working in one industry to build business and obtain new clients for the various companies he has worked for. He's a conservative, friendly, respectable man, who has worked extremely hard to where he has gotten to today. He doesn't like to bring his work home with him, so he keeps his answers to "How's work?" pretty brief. My mother, on the other hand, works in retail sales, and has worked for the same major department store for the past 30 years. My mom is unlike anyone I've ever met, in that she takes serious pride in her profession, while others in similar positions (i.e.: me, when I worked there with her) do not. She loves people, loves her customers, and loves helping them find clothes that make them feel fabulous. She doesn't always come home with a smile on her face, but I can tell she wouldn't want to be doing anything else. And then there's me: I've had my history of [retail] sales experience, but only recently did "sales" become part of my work here at Commerce Kitchen. I'm just getting started, and I have a lot to learn. Hence, I'm doing my homework and writing this post.

Sales and Business Development: Same diff, right?

Oftentimes, "sales" and "business development" are used interchangeably, and until I started doing my homework (read: 10 minutes ago), I thought they meant the same thing. I was under the assumption that sales = new clients & projects = business development.  As it turns out, business development means almost something else entirely. In fact, business development has a much friendlier tone to its definition:

"Business development is the creation of long-term value for an organization from customers, markets, and relationships." -Scott Pollack, Forbes.

For the visual learners out there, the most fantastic source that I found to show the difference between sales and business development was a graph by Andrew Dumont, shown here: In short, the main difference between sales and business development is the partner: the person who connects you to the people you want to talk to. It's about a relationship: while sales focuses on direct contact with whoever you want to buy your shit, business development takes the time to establish a connection.

Shitty Salespeople and their Shitty Sales Techniques

So how exactly did sales become such a dirty word? Over time, many sales managers and representatives formed bad habits that have isolated them from their audiences. Too many dull, pitch-y conversations between sales reps and potential clients have given "sales" a bad reputation. For too long, the mindset of sales reps has been "What can I sell this person today?" or "How can I turn this connection into a sale for my business?" To those people, I say, "You suck." Sales, when it comes down to it, has always been about making money. The problem is that many in sales make the mistake of internally focusing on how a sale is benefitting their own organization, rather than their customer's. But it's not about you; it's about how the service or product that you're providing improves the life of your customer or their business. Intrinsically, we're all selfish and driven by success (a.k.a.: money). It's time to reframe how we talk about what we're selling. On the other hand, there are those who say that it isn't a dirty word, simply because if it's something that you're passionate about, then you shouldn't feel ashamed to say it. Personally, I think those people are just a bunch of bullshitters trying to kid themselves.

Literally Changing the Conversation

I know, I know. It's tacky to talk about "changing the conversation." In this case, we quite literally need to change the conversation. We're living in a different world, filled with startup execs and VPs of technology who don't want to be given the ol' song and dance of their 20th century counterparts. Traditional sales techniques aren't going to cut it. During our conversation about how "sales" has been transforming in the past decade, Jeremiah from Aspenware suggested that Tynan and I read Let's Get Real or Let's Not Play: Transforming the Buyer/Seller Relationship. It focuses on getting the conversations between buyer and seller down to brass tax. As a person whose nemesis is ambiguity, I'm really psyched to get my hands on this book. So what can we do to get rid of sales' bad reputation? Be genuine. Stop trying to sell people a product or service. Instead, sell them a lifestyle, a change, an idea. It's not about you. It's about them. What value are you adding to their life or business? Why should they give a damn about you? What can you give them that the others can't? Bottom line: I don't care about sales' bad reputation. I care more about what we're doing at Commerce Kitchen to diverge from the standard sales routine, to make sure that we're not playing by 20th-century, corporate sales rules. We're not corporate in any way. We're nerds who like Whedon and beer and puns, and how we get to know people - even in a sales situation - reflects that.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sales: It's Got a Bad Reputation. Let's Change It.
sales
When did "sales" become an unutterable word in our community? After some recent experiences, Jen decided to look more into this anti-"sales" phenomenon.

item.title: Wedgies, and 4 Other Things I Can't Live Without Right Now
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Things have been changing here at Commerce Kitchen, and, consequently, my role has shifted as well. Like any lean, agile startup, we've been working on being more efficient. Getting there, however, has been a journey worthy of a fellowship carrying a shiny, precious little ring. That journey, however, has been greatly improved by the discovery of specific tools that are making my job - and my life - a hell of a lot easier and, quite frankly, more fun. These are a few of my favorite things:

1. Rapportive

This #1 on my list because it's #1 in my heart. I found out about Rapportive last month thanks to this 2012 post from Distilled's Rob Ousbey. It has changed my life and everything that I do. It connects to LinkedIn through your GMail account, and allows you to send an invitation to connect with that person without even leaving the email thread you have going with them. That's one way to use Rapportive. However, Rob mostly talked about how you can use it to find someone's email address. In the moment when I was reading his post, the heavens opened up, Rob's wisdom shone down on me, and I felt like one of his disciples. You know something is important when I make a Christianity reference.

2. Sendbloom

Sendbloom is the the cheese to Rapportive's macaroni. It's been a huge influence as we tweak our business development tactics. I won't go too much into it, because I think the website can explain it better than I can.

3. Google Calendar

I was very hesitant to adopt anything in the Google family for much too long. I had a YMail - yes, that's part of the Yahoo! family - account, and it was my only email account up until about three years ago. Even when I switched from YMail to GMail, I was still wary of Google's charms. I liked having a real life notebook, filled with paper from trees and the whole shebang. Then, about three months ago, without even realizing it had happened, my whole mentality shifted and I was a Google Calendar addict. I cannot live without it these days.

4. Wedgies

I love Wedgie polls. They help me quickly poll our Commerce Kitchen staff and the rest of the Firehouse inhabitants. I use them to figure out what beer we want in the kegerator next, what movie we should watch during movie night, and so on. Basically, anything that involves office logistics that should be crowdsourced is discovered by using Wedgie polls. Side note: our nerdy devs have hacked them once or twice to get what they want.

5. Soundrown

I think I spent too much time writing papers at coffee shops in college, because I've been conditioned to be more productive when I have noise in the background. More specifically, I'm partial to noise that resembles conversations while baristas make lattes with extra foam in the background. Soundrown helps me with that. Now that we've opened up a satellite office at INDUSTRY, we have a few less superheroes around our Firehouse on a daily basis. Hence, less people-noise. Hence, I had to find a tool that tricks me into thinking that people are around when actually they're not. Soundrown has a mix of different audio tracks of rain, fire, waves, birds, etc., but the one I use the most is obviously the coffee shop track. Take advantage of these amazing tools, and go rock it!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/oIpwxeeSPy1cnwYpqJ1w_Dufer-Collateral-test.jpg
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/oIpwxeeSPy1cnwYpqJ1w_Dufer-Collateral-test.jpg
Wedgies, and 4 Other Things I Can't Live Without Right Now
Like any lean, agile startup, we've been working on being more efficient. Getting there, however, has been a journey worthy of a fellowship carrying a ring.

item.title: I Want To Go, But I Actually I Don't: The Tale of an Outgoing Introvert
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
"Hi, I'm Jen, and I'm an introvert." "Hi, Jen." "It's so great to meet you all. Let's talk about stuff, exchange business cards, and then let me retreat into my apartment for the next 48 hours. Sound good?" That's me, in a nutshell. I'm an introvert with an outgoing personality. For my entire life, I thought I just wavered back and forth between being extroverted and introverted on any given day. It wasn't until I read a life-changing Thought Catalog article (I know, I know. I'm a cliché: a twenty-something white girl who reads Thought Catalog) that I realized being an outgoing introvert is a real thing. How does someone like me even come into existence? I'm the only child of two very outgoing, extroverted parents, that's how. My parents, God love 'em, are people people. They're both in sales, both from families with many aunts, uncles, and cousins whom they grew up with, and both two of the friendliest and most genuine people you'll ever meet. But I'm not biased, right? And then there's me: their one and only child. While I was fortunate enough to spend much of my childhood with cousins, I still had my alone time; not especially lonely, but alone nevertheless. Fast forward 23 years, and here I am: a full-fledged introvert with an outgoing personality. Sounds wonderful, right? To not have to feed off other peoples' energy in order to thrive? To be comfortable enough when I'm alone with my thoughts that I'm not pushed into a downward spiral? To enjoy being surrounded by friends or strangers, but also truly love being by myself? Doesn't that all sound great? Well, it's not. Take last night, for example. It was just another Thursday night. I was at Built-In Brews, chatting it up with strangers, acquaintances, and friends alike. I was enjoying myself. And then I hit the two-hour mark. Not only was my parking meter expired, but I was personally ready to leave. There's only so much networking and conversation that an outgoing introvert can take before she's ready to go home, curl up in bed, and dive head-first into a Netflix binge session. Thus, at that two-hour mark, I practically left a Jen-shaped hole in the Craftsy doors. Now, you can imagine that, as our company's Communications Manager, my introverted tendencies are not ideal for someone in my position. I'm in charge of events like Clash of the Cocktails and Startups Drink Local. I go networking events like Built In Brews and Women Who Startup in order to make sure we're being active in the Denver startup sphere. I've been spending time meeting new people alongside Tynan as we build our client base and community connections. And at the end of all of it, I breathe a sigh of relief as I enter my apartment and close the door behind me, because there's nothing I love more than being home and watching movies or reading books. Don't get me wrong — I love my job and I love what I do. I love meeting new people and I love being able to be as active as I am in the Denver startup community. It's something that I fell into, and it's been a fun ride getting to where I am today. Of course, I am still an introverted hermit by nature who somehow grew up to be very outgoing, so I'll always struggle between the two extremes of my personality. It's something that I'll constantly be working on to find balance, and I'm definitely willing to have conversations with people in similar situations. But can we discuss it tomorrow? I have a date with my couch and season 7 of Buffy the Vampire Slayer that I simply cannot miss.
Like this post? You'll love this one by our friends at Anneal!

http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/1898228_10152782419799588_545435478474472922_n1.jpg
outgoing introvert
I Want To Go, But I Don't: The Tale of an Outgoing Introvert
For my entire life, I thought I just wavered between being extroverted and introverted. Turns out, being an outgoing introvert is a real thing.

item.title: Parenthood and Prioritization
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
At countless conferences in the past, I've heard women in executive leadership positions discuss how motherhood forced them to fundamentally reassess their careers and their individual management styles. Delegate more. Trust your team. Ask for help. Find balance. While all of those maxims ring true to a certain extent, for me, the biggest challenge of being a working mom has been time management. Up until my stint as a NICU mom (28 days and counting!), I'd never really procrastinated. Sure, I'd had last minute proposal deadlines. And I'd put off some difficult tasks while starting with the easier tasks. But I'd never had a last-minute, crunch time "it's got to get done" moment for deliverable that I agreed to do. Fast forward to present and I feel like my whole existence is keeping time at warp speed and I don't have enough time to do anything. I've been trying to stay on top of things, but the more I chase my deliverables, the harder they seem to achieve. The last few weeks have been painful. But last night at 8pm I had a mini meltdown before making another trip back to the hospital. Fighting through tears of anguish that I wasn't doing a very good job as an employee or a mom, I had a mini epiphany: I need to prioritize my time better. You see, I've been stuck in a period of stasis because I only have 30 minutes to an hour and a half between every baby task. That's been enough time to reflect on the big items that I should be doing, but it hasn't been enough time to actually accomplish any of my larger work tasks. And while I cherish my twice daily kangaroo care with my daughter, and feel like I am contributing to her success when I hook myself back up to the pump every three hours (ah!), I wasn't able to make measurable progress against some of my bigger tasks such as storyboarding the intro for an immersive web project. So what am I now going to do differently you ask?

  1. Recognize and publicly acknowledge the difficulties I am facing.

    I am going to have good days where I feel great about my ability to get things done, and bad days where nothing seems to go right. But it's okay because my team understands, and I know that even if a day is difficult, I can strive to do better next time. And no one is a harsher critic than yourself.

  2. Micro-plan and micro-delegate my tasks.

    Instead of looking at the big picture and focusing on everything that needs to get done, I am going to focus on what I can get done in the dedicated work sessions that I have throughout the day. Instead of reading all of Jamie's research in one go as I would have done in the past over a four to five hour period, I will focus on three articles and then plan how those fit into my forever evolving plan. I'll write a blog to help support CK's content strategies. I'll schedule hangouts or office time to catch up with my team.

  3. Get out of the house.

    While sometimes it makes the most sense to stay home so I can maximize the use my scant 30 minutes of free time, that can also keep me in a rut if I haven't planned out my tasks well enough. So even though it may seem silly to drive into the office, I have to recognize that my extroverted self needs the company and stimulation of others to be at my best. And even if I can only spare an hour of time before I have to punctuate my day with another baby task, I know that my work will be better when I'm back in my element.
With my game plan in place, I'd also like to give a shout out to CK for their flexibility in letting me wrap up my open projects and tasks while Clara's in the NICU. Here's to our next adventure!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Parenthood and Prioritization: Micro-Delegation of Tasks
To make my new working mom gig successful, I have to prioritize and delegate manageable tasks that can be completed in 30 minutes or less.

item.title: Education in Tech: Why a Piece of Paper Doesn't Really Mean Anything
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded:
I live in a very interesting world filled with very educated individuals.

Clearly, I'm in the tech industry. Most of my co-workers - past and present - have degrees, diplomas, certifications, etc. For the longest time, that actually really irked me because I have no formal education in web development - or anything else in that area for that matter. In fact, I'm simply a high school dropout who just happened to have some weird hobbies as a child. Don't worry — I got my GED many years ago, but does any of that formal education even matter in the tech world?

I was about 10 or 11 years old when I began programming. In school, we took a computer course which involved playing with Adobe Flash (formerly Macromedia Flash). Our task was to create a scene of... something, I can't honestly remember what now. Like most kids, I played around with the "tweening" of keyframes, a.k.a.: learning how to animate shapes on a screen.

It was during that course that I noticed something called ActionScript, the code behind Flash. Slowly, I learned that I could achieve even better animations by just writing what I wanted to do. No longer was I limited by static frames of content. However, that wasn't the most interesting part to me. Sure, I could move a ball around on a screen or have something follow my mouse. Booorrring! To me, the fun stuff had nothing to do with the visuals; it was all about what you couldn't see. I loved building Flash applications that would save and store information that was entered, or load in data from a remote site.

Over the course of the next few months, I taught myself ActionScript using nothing more than Google, the ActionScript.org forums, and my own trials/failures. You'd be surprised what you can learn from an error message if you really think about it.

The next few years became a sort of evolution of programming for me. ActionScript led me to PHP and Javascript, which led to C#, Visual Basic, .NET, C++, MySQL, CSS, so on and so forth. I'd even admit that (for a few minutes), Cold Fusion was a part of that learning as well. I let that go very quickly after realizing that the authors of Cold Fusion were probably strung out on hard drugs and pixie sticks when they wrote that language.

While I was teaching myself these languages, I was also in school, and doing... let's say not well. Not to venture off on a rant about the American public school system, but I wasn't absorbing things at school the same way I was in front of a computer. I've always felt that I learn best by doing, not watching, and it seemed that (at the time) most schools did the latter. "Watch this. Memorize it. Tests on Wednesdays."

Programming on my own offered something most schools couldn't: the opportunity to get my hands dirty.

When talking about why self-taught programming has advantages over instruction-led learning, I like to refer to the often-cited but almost always mis-quoted Thomas Edison. When asked how it felt to fail 1,000 times to create the incandescent lightbulb,  Edison said, "I didn't fail. I found out 1,000 ways how not to make a lightbulb." This is exactly how I feel about being a self-taught programmer. Sure, I didn't know the "rules" of programming from the beginning, but I probably learned even more by discovering all the errors along the way. If you don't ever fail, how can you see what's wrong?

The other distinct advantage of self-taught programming is that schools produce, in essence, cloned brains. Put 200 people in a room and teach them all the exact same thing and what you get is 200 people who - for the most part - will think the exact same way. Of course that isn't entirely true, as students are not robots and every person is unique — like a snowflake! Yet, those students understand the fundamentals in similar ways.

Not having ever gone through traditional higher education, you could argue that I don't fully understand the fundamentals of programming. However, I'm also not bound by many of the limitations that fundamental thinking brings. After almost 20 years of programming, I think have the fundamentals down.

When I was 14 or 15 I was discovered (not unlike a child star) on ActionScript.org helping others and posing questions. I spent a lot of time on that site, and it was without question one of the most beneficial tools in my learning arsenal. After a few years doing contract work while I continued to go to school, I was hired on full time. And for the vast majority of the last 10+ years I have spent working in the industry, I have loved (mostly) every minute of it.

It's especially nice to think about the fact that, even though I may not have a piece of paper to show for it, I already had ~10 years of experience in a variety of programming languages before most graduates could tell you what HTTP stands for. In the end, that's the primary reason why I feel that a fancy piece of paper and a square hat doesn't exactly mean anything when it comes to being in a certain tech field.

I'm not trying to go all Timothy Leary on everyone and advocate for dropping out of school or other nefarious activities — because I do think school is important. What I'd like those who read this to take from it is that a formal education isn't always your golden ticket to the working world. What is important is that - whatever you do - learn it in a way that suits you and learn it the best you can. Don't limit yourself to an education on a blackboard.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Education in Tech: A Piece of Paper Doesn't Mean Anything
education in tech
Unconventional paths to tech are common at Commerce Kitchen. Eric's personal education is unique, and it's also one the things that makes him so great.
