item.title: Clear Out the Cobwebs: Maintenance Checklist for 2015
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded:
maintenance |ˈmānt(ə)nəns, ˈmāntn-əns|

1 the process of maintaining or preserving someone or something: to keep in an existing state: to preserve from failure or decline 2 to sustain against opposition or danger: uphold and defend 3 the provision of financial support for someone’s living expenses

For most of us, maintenance is one of those massively uninteresting topics of daily existence. I’m stopping short of describing it as something akin to Rodney Dangerfield, because many of us do have respect for what regular maintenance can bring. We know that our cars would last longer with regular and frequent oil changes. We know that our bodies would be much better with frequent exercise. We know tires would last longer with regular rotation, portfolios would perform better with regular evaluation and adjustments, and the oven would smell less with frequent cleanings. But armed with this knowledge - maybe even an annual resolution - we often ignore, postpone, forget about, and often abandon continuous, regular maintenance. It doesn’t take much consideration before one realizes the vast size of the list of possible things that can be placed into regular maintenance. And to that list, you should definitely add your digital devices and the software that makes them run, as well as the software applications that do things for you. Your home computer and it’s operating system. Your phone and it’s operating system. Your favorite apps, games, virus and security scanners. The list does seem to go on and on. Feeling a bit overwhelmed? It’s a lot to do. It needs to be done, and there’s no time like the present. Plus, it is that time of year for new beginnings. A time to adopt new behaviors even if for a 'trial' period. Software maintenance is definitely a topic worthy of such a trial. A new beginning that will lead you through a maze of acronyms and jargon, but should provide you with a better understanding of risk and responsibilities. Take stock in the hardware, software, and software services you use. Note the current versions of software, models of hardware (with related software versions) and determine if your products are up to date. What is your password policy? If it’s more appropriate, establish a password policy. Start using a password manager service. If this is your first step on this path, choose one that offers the basics for free. Investigate the service and upgrade or switch when you’re familiar with the features you want. If your web security software only scans for viruses, it’s time to upgrade. There are long-established malware strategies and new ones discovered too often. Get a malware product for your operating system that can be run automatically and by user command. And just like backup software, let’s hope the precautionary steps are the only way it ever gets used. In quick review, the three-statement definition for maintenance at the beginning of this blog progresses in severity. Although it can be annoying and repetitious, step one surely has the fewest negative repercussions. May everyone have a happy, well-maintained, and productive 2015!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: maintenance checklist
Clear Out the Cobwebs: Maintenance Checklist for 2015
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/SplitShire-6881.jpg
For most of us, maintenance is one of those massively uninteresting topics of daily existence. Yet, it's a necessary annoyance that we all must endure.

item.title: Employee Handbook Hilarity, and Other Lessons on Culture
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
I recently rewrote the Commerce Kitchen employee handbook. It took a lot of research, many discussions with our company leadership and staff, and nearly a dozen separate writing sessions to finish it. Even after two years of working here, I still have much to learn about our business and people. Just like any organization, Commerce Kitchen has grown and changed since my first day. And just like any healthy long-term relationship, we've grown and changed together, all the while having to adjust to how that growth and change has affected us.  I knew writing our handbook would be something I could do, but I was unsure how well-equipped I was to get the job done. It was like sitting down to write the biography of a dear friend. I had to get it right.

"Where do I start?"

Just like the thousands (not really) of papers I had to write during my undergrad years, I started by researching. I read article upon article about how to construct an employee handbook, what company culture is all about, how to create an orientation structure that works, and so on. I read many strangers' thoughts on how to onboard a new employee, how to make newcomers feel welcome, and how to incorporate an organization's culture and values into every single action along the way. And I took notes. Copious amounts of notes. On real paper. When it came time for me to start writing, I had two terrible cart-before-the-horse conundrums in front of me.
  • We had too many company values — twelve, to be exact.
  • We didn't have a clear-cut process or checklist for what happened when we brought on new folks.
How the hell was I supposed to sit down and introduce Commerce Kitchen to a new employee via our handbook when I had these two potentially problematic issues to resolve? The value problem needed to be dealt with immediately. I polled the entire staff and we narrowed our original twelve down to three core values that best embodied our beliefs and mission: Generosity of Spirit, Gentle Authority, and Ownership. The orientation process was an entirely different animal to deal with. First of all, we're not the traditional 'orientation' kind of people. We find it monotonous and boring and somewhat unnecessary. Most often, it is by working and playing alongside our peers that we truly begin to understand our company and our people. With that said, we needed something that would help us as we start to grow our company in 2015 and beyond. For this particular conundrum, I chose to work on both our handbook and onboarding process simultaneously. One could not be born without incorporating the other, so as I wrote and made edits to the handbook, I wrote and made edits to the onboarding process. The former would be for our staff's use, and the latter would be for our leadership.

Content is Key, But Language is Lovely

Once I had resolved my cart-before-the-horse conundrums, I realized that I actually had to sit down and start to write the damn thing. One of my biggest concerns going into this was how to make sure the Commerce Kitchen voice - the smart, funny, conversational office language I'd loved for two years - shone through in our handbook. How do you get hours upon hours of sci-fi references and dad jokes and technology rants to express themselves on paper, while also communicating general business ideologies and operational practices in a non-boring way? I had my work cut out for me. When it came down to it, my North Star was the Valve Company Handbook. Valve, a software and gaming company in Bellevue, really knocked it out of the park with their handbook for new employees. Their company culture is truly admirable, and I used their handbook as a guiding light as I wrote ours. I also used Tribal Leadership and Delivering Happiness as additional reference points for the types of language I wanted to incorporate.

Leave No Stone Unturned

One of the main goals behind rewriting our company handbook was to make sure that we answered any and all questions that a new Commerce Kitchen employee might have before, on, or after their first day here. However, as someone who spent four years of my undergraduate career studying the bland storytelling of history's biggest moments, I wanted to make sure that whatever we produced as our handbook was concise, informative, and, above all things, fun. In the final, thirteen page-copy, we cover everything from nearly every corner of who we are and what we do: process, values, getting feedback, security policies, professional development, office dynamics and desk setup, payroll, health insurance, dress code (or lack thereof), and more. I even snuck in some Calvin & Hobbes cartoon strips in the security policy section because hello, snooze. Contrary to what online articles told me to create, our handbook is not snack-sized. It is a full meal to be digested with a nice glass of wine, whiskey, or water at your side.

Learn from the Process

A black pencil skirt, a white blouse, black flats, and a purple blazer. That's the extremely corporate-like outfit that I wore on my first day at Commerce Kitchen. I had much to learn back then, and I'm still learning to this very day. These incredibly intelligent and hilarious people I call my coworkers and friends have taught me many things about business, communication, pop culture, and life. Yet, nothing could have prepared me for what I'd learn while writing our employee handbook. In order to talk about how we work, I had to take a closer look under the hood. In doing so, I began to understand our company operations, values, and overall culture much more than I had previously. Then, I solicited feedback from the entire Commerce Kitchen staff in order to make sure I accurately covered everything. They were as much a part of writing it as I was.  They also laughed at my jokes in the handbook, which was very nice of them. I'm very proud of the new and improved Commerce Kitchen handbook. Mostly because it feels like my child and I'm watching it become beloved amongst our staff. I'm like a weird pageant mom. Is that weird? Oh well.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: employee handbook
Employee Handbook Hilarity, and Other Lessons on Culture
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/14929512628_138679d966_b.jpg
We recently rewrote our employee handbook. It was a tough process that did not come without its lessons. Here are some of the highlights.

item.title: Building a Culture of Assistance
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded: Business is hard. It's tough to build, tough to maintain, and tough to grow. And none of us can go it alone. This week, I saw some old friends, caught up with recent acquaintances, and made new connections. While I was spending time with all of these fantastic folks, I realized that I was hearing similar language being used by all of them. When you surround yourself with people from different industries and backgrounds who share similar business ideals, the conversations that take place are like familiar music to your ears. In many ways, the business community that Commerce Kitchen is part of is built on a culture of assistance. The Denver and Boulder business communities are chockerbock full of software and web development shops. Of course, there is a bit of friendly competition amongst these like-minded businesses, yet we seem to thrive most when we work alongside our peers and partners to provide better service to our clients. Much of that success is due to transparency and mutual trust. Being transparent in business is so en vogue these days that when we come across folks who play their cards close to the chest, we're taken aback. In those situations, lack of transparency is a huge red flag (or yellow light, if you've read Let's Get Real or Let's Not Play) of larger internal issues in that organization. At the end of the day, any information that we can get about anyone - partner or client - will help us help them. Yet, if that information isn't being shared by one party, then there's a misalignment of culture fit. From there, we reevaluate our relationship with that partner or client. Trust is a huge part of this culture of assistance. I trust you with this piece of information, and you trust me that the information is valid. I trust you with my credit card number, and you trust me that the number isn't fraudulent. I trust you with my imaginary dog, and you trust me that payment will be received for that imaginary dog's care while I'm in Aruba, and so on and so forth. Without trust, the relationship between Business A and Business B sits on a throne lies. Yes. A THRONE OF LIES. When businesses are functioning in a culture of assistance, they have no qualms discussing their strategies and operations with other businesses, competitors or otherwise. Last week during Startups Drink Local, I was swapping business stories with Krista Morgan, CEO of P2Binvestor. I caught her up on the changes that we've been undergoing at Commerce Kitchen, and she gave me some insight into how P2Binvestor has been growing and thriving. Granted, P2Binvestor and Commerce Kitchen are very different businesses with very different missions, which means there isn't much of a competition between our organizations. Nevertheless, in that conversation, I realized that Krista and I function on the same level of the culture of assistance. We were open and honest with each other, giving each other a different perspective in which to approach this operational conundrum or that business development question. My conversation with Krista is hardly unusual. The culture of assistance that Commerce Kitchen operates in is contagious. One of our company values, Generosity of Spirit, explains that we need to share our goodness with each other and spread it out into the community. When you help out one person without having an agenda or needing a favor in return, it quickly turns into a "pay it forward" situation. In short, being a good person, speaking honestly, and helping out people who need it makes you not a jerk! Mind-blowing stuff, I know. There's a lot of bullshit that floats around business communities, which makes it difficult to determine friends from foes. However, if we all begin to subscribe to the idea of a culture of assistance, our world would be a much nicer place to live.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/shutterstock_149301761.jpg
culture of assistance
Building a Culture of Assistance
People helping people: that's the foundation for a culture of assistance. But what does that mean for businesses? We'll dig deeper in this post.

item.title: 5 Essential Skills Any Web Developer Should Have
item.dc:creator: abrink
item.content:encoded:
The full landscape of web development skills can be overwhelming, especially for new web developers.  If we distill all of this knowledge into five essential skills that are needed to be a professional web developer, regardless of your framework and toolset of choice, what would they be?

1. Security

Every web developer needs to know about security.  The best place to start is the OWASP top ten, which should be required reading.  Web developers should take time to go through the list.  Learn about each vulnerability and how it can be avoided. Think about any of your own code that might be vulnerable. Revisit the list frequently. Good frameworks make it easier for the developer to be secure by default.  For example, in Ruby on Rails, Active Record by default will perform parameterized database queries, helping to remove SQL injection vulnerabilities.  Ruby on Rails also helps with CSRF protection when using the built-in form helpers, by placing a hidden input field in your form that the server recognizes and must receive in order to submit the form. In addition to the OWASP top ten, take some time to learn about the hashing and salting technique to encrypt user passwords.  Though you hopefully aren't writing your own authentication, hashing and salting is a common technique and it's worthwhile to spend some time understanding how it works. Finally, think about what information you shouldn't be collecting.  Do you really need to store that credit card number?  Think about what information shouldn't be persisted to logs, as that is an easy area to overlook.

2. Performance

It goes without saying that users prefer fast websites over slow websites. Every web developer should learn the basic techniques for running a fast website. On the client-side, learn how to concatenate and minify your JavaScript and CSS. A good web framework should help you with this task.  In Ruby on Rails, the asset pipeline makes concatenation and minification a trivial issue.  Even if your framework doesn't perform this step automatically, there are plenty of tools such as Grunt that can perform this step and help speed up the delivery of your pages. One great tool for checking how your site is performing on the client side is the Page Speed Insights tool from Google. On the server side, learn about the big performance offenders.  In Ruby on Rails, two of the biggest performance bottlenecks are N+1 queries and blocking processes.  Rails developers should learn how to recognize, then rewrite N+1 queries in a more performant way.  Rails developers should also learn how to push blocking processes off to a background job. As far as tooling goes, New Relic has great tools for identifying server-side issues for many of the popular frameworks.

3. Understand the Plumbing

In the early days of building websites, there wasn't much choice but to understand how HTTP worked.  Later on, certain web frameworks, such as Microsoft's Web Forms, and certain protocols, such as SOAP, hid much of the underlying plumbing.  Today we've swung back toward embracing HTTP.  Ruby on Rails for example, provides a ton of convenience on top of HTTP, while fully embracing the protocol.  For example, by default, Rails uses the correct HTTP verbs and response status codes, and working with resources is done in a RESTful manner. As a web developer it's important to learn HTTP. Learn the different request headers, response codes, HTTP verbs, and how your framework makes use of them. Learn how caching makes use of the headers, and how they can be tweaked for performance. Tools such as Chrome Developer Tools web inspector make it easy to dive in and learn what is going on at the HTTP layer, and is time well spent.

4. Ability to Use the Appropriate Technology for the Job

There are so many tools and technologies available for web developers, and more appear every single day.  One of the essential skills of any web developer, is to navigate the new tool ecosystem. Before you know if a tool can help you, you need to know that it exists.  There are great newsletters, podcasts, Twitter feeds, and conference videos to help you stay on top of the latest news.  Find the news source that best fits into your schedule, style, and technology stack, and stay on top of it. Once you know about the new and shiny thing, have a methodology to determine whether a new tool will really improve your workflow as a developer, or if the new tool is simply trendy.  This skill comes with experience, practice, and thinking about real-world needs.

5. Ability to Consume APIs

As web developers we plug into all kinds of external services to help us build compelling products.  It's hard to imagine an interesting web application that doesn't make use of some type of API.  Developers often use payment providers like Stripe, error monitoring services like New Relic, or Honeybadger, SMS services like Twilio, even authentication providers like Facebook or Twitter.  Or, perhaps you need to pull in interesting data for analysis from a government or third party data source. As web developers, it is essential that we learn to consume web services in all of their various formats.  Some services provide a language-specific library to wrap the web service calls, some rely purely on REST, or even SOAP. Some services provide web hooks to communicate back when specific events occur.  Being comfortable in whatever method of communication the service uses is an essential skill. In addition it's important to learn how to properly test the pieces of our application that rely on a given web service.  What happens when a given web service is down or failing?  Having a backup plan for critical services, and the ability to test those plans is part of this essential skill.
There is an overwhelming amount of knowledge needed to be a web developer today.  Knowing what skills are essential can be very tricky and isn't obvious.  Hopefully this list provided insight into skills that web developers should have, or be working to acquire.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: 5 Essential Skills Any Web Developer Should Have
The full landscape of web development skills can be overwhelming, especially for new developers. So what are the top ones that a new engineer should have?
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/SplitShire_IMG_7374.jpg

item.title: The Joys of Working Parents
item.dc:creator: Leslie
item.content:encoded:
After a couple months of maternity leave, I cautiously dipped my toes back into the working world at Commerce Kitchen earlier this month... Who am I kidding?! I let out my war cry and sprinted back to the office as fast as my feet could take me. Even though my daughter had only been waking up once or twice per night, working mostly remotely, part-time, while mommying full-time was not something I was going to be able to sustain. Bouncing a screaming four month old while on a hangout to discuss technical specs, or trying to plan out a complex brand strategy at 10pm when I finally had a break for the day just weren't going to cut it. So thankfully we were able to enroll her in a wonderful daycare that we love, and I was able to start back full time. I thought, I've got this. I had made it through the dual-duty, stay-at-home working mom phase, and things could go back to being a bit more balanced. Boy, was I wrong.

Our Adjustment Period

The Plague on No Sleep

I had heard that your kid would get sick at daycare. I'd even heard that I would be sicker than I'd ever been for the first few months after my daughter started school. I did not, however, anticipate strep throat, two colds, and pinkeye in the first two weeks. And the saga is just beginning now that Peter has pinkeye. And I knew that we'd have some adjustments to Clara's nap and eating routine. I was not prepared for her to revert back to her newborn sleep routine of round-the-clock eating and sleeping all day in an epic "reverse cycling" episode. Needless to say, I got even less work done in my first few days of full time work than I had while working from home.

Mommy Guilt

On Clara's first full day of daycare I'd gotten her settled in her room. She had plenty of bottles, plenty of diapers, and plenty of hugs from the school staff. I closed the door, and felt relief. I was light as air. My child was cared for and I could get back into the adult world of work. I was so giddy that I actually skipped down the hallway, and was beaming as I stepped outside. My euphoria lasted throughout most of the morning, and then the guilt started to set in. It started with, "Why am I so happy to not be with my daughter? Am I a bad mom? But I love my job." And then later progressed to, "I miss Clara. Why am I still at work?" I felt conflicted. I felt guilty to want to be at work, and I felt equally guilty to want to be with my daughter.

Our New Normal

We are now three weeks in. We've found a workable sleep routine with occasional full nights of sleep (such a blessing!). And although I have less time to spend after-hours socializing with coworkers, I try to balance my day with actual client work and adult social interactions so I feel like I'm still part of the team. I'm getting back into the swing of things, and if I do say so myself, I am actually more productive than I was before just because I don't have the luxury of staying late. And although I sometimes want to be with Clara while I am at work, and sometimes want to be at work when I am home with a sick baby, I am actively trying to feel less guilty as I vacillate between the two. Reading some funny and empowering articles from friends has also helped. I am also getting better at being more present during our get-ready-for-the-day periods each morning, and the magical (and frantic) hour and a half between daycare pick up and bed time. I get to focus entirely on her, breathe her in and make her smile. Moral of the story from one new mom to another? Invest in truckloads of vitamin C, recognize that it's going to be hard (and that's okay), and cherish the moments that you have both at work and with baby.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Joys of Working Parents - Surviving Your First Month Back
Overcoming the plague and rising above my guilt at wanting to be at work and with baby at the same time, I'm learning what my new normal looks like.
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/shutterstock_170355020.jpg

item.title: An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 1
item.dc:creator: corey
item.content:encoded: My intention here is to develop a description of my perspectives; one based on a marriage of my knowledge and experience in education, the other rooted in my passion for (and ideas on) technology. Over time, I have developed a unique understanding of our current position as a race and culture in America and how it is related to our system of learning. I have designed this through a convergence of experiences and skills, spanning three careers in four fields: engineering, science, teaching, and technology. I have the unlikely benefit of holding four higher education degrees, earned across a broad spectrum of subjects and applied to a variety of situations. And lastly I believe strongly that our current system and ideas are not just flawed, but rather completely broken and well beyond repair. We need to completely rethink our approach to learning, what we are learning, and what we provide opportunity for learning in order to progress. I like to avoid politics and policy when I think on these things. I find bureaucracy to be a short leash that limits potential. Instead, my faith lies in practice: discussing it, understanding it, and re-inventing it. A future for young learners will thrive based on the application of new practice, and it starts with structure. The current structure(s) of our educational system are not keeping up with the modern world, or the modern learner within it. As a nation we are continually applying patches to a foundation that is no longer sound; it continues of fail, yet no one has the guts to just say, "Lets tear it down, burn it to ash and build something new!" Developing a new horizon for how education - and the related practice of instruction are applied - has the potential to skyrocket our nation to a position of leadership based on progress, innovation, and fresh perspective. As I see it, there are two key issues that need to be addressed. The first is “old folks” and their “old school." Now while this may cause a bit of gasping, I encourage you to hang on. This idea of “old school / old folks” is intended to describe the current methodologies which thrive on the continued use of outdated practices. Current systems put policy and politics before practice. Teachers are still trained based on a pedagogy that was developed 50 years ago. The result of this is teachers who rely on old-world ideas while trying to keep up with new-world students. Schools are constantly in a futile scramble trying to throw tactics at the classroom in an attempt to update curriculum. The unfortunate result is a “meet you in the middle” experience that falls pathetically short of expectations and demand. Additionally, this old school approach has created a separate profession out of teaching, which is just dumb. If we stop and take half a second to look at history in the long term, the greatest growth periods are seen in times with practicing experts provide mentorship to growing professionals. The second key issue is the single model approach. We wouldn’t build software using a single model, so why do we pretend like there is only needs to be one type of teaching model? We need to look beyond the two-dimensional education, push past three-dimensional education, and invent a four-dimensional education. Currently our teaching is constrained to this 2-D ideal: x vs y (Rigor vs. Time). The school of thought is that we can go slower if we have more time, but as time becomes more and more limited, we need to crank up the rigor to compensate and maintain trajectory. What we really need is to apply a z-axis to our model, and consider yearly progressions as more than just a testable funding metric. This would allow us to create a series of stacked iterations (like a deck of cards). Each card is a year, with it’s own dimensions; that when added together create a superstructure that is flexible and able to form a non-linear spiral for learners. I could sit here and type about what’s wrong for months on end, and it would never result in progress. (Please do note that I will continue to use the term “progress" instead of “solutions." Solutions are for repair; progress is for moving forward.) So from here forth I will work to keep focus on a plan, a series of ideas, innovations, and perspectives that I do believe could offer fuel, and even flame to what should be the form of our conversations about this topic. I am not a genius, I am not correct, and I am not the “one with the answer.” However, I am working very hard to think about it in a new way, break paradigms, and throw caution into the wind. The safe path in this will keep us right where we are, which is miles behind, while not gaining any reasonable ground. So let’s begin this plan with a set of useable ideas that could be applied to the school as a system. We need to consider redesigning the entire system to meet a new world’s demands — not the current world’s, but the world of tomorrow. A tomorrow that comes faster and faster every day. Timing is everything to a learner, and it requires a completely new structure within the schools. We need an integration of mentorship which sets it’s roots in the development of a platform for buy in. It's time to treat learners as growing professionals from day one, discarding the imaginary perception of the “student’s job is to learn”, and instead give them a real job to do with real risks and real consequences. From there, we can develop an agile approach to learning, with a system that sees teaching as a second profession that is pursued by experts who are active members of their fields. Next time, I'll talk about useable ideas for a new school model, and start the discussion of what a reinvented school could look like.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/8743593650_1f17470d83_c.jpg
agile approach to learning
An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 1
The way in which our society currently sees education and learning is very one-dimensional. It's time to shake things up with an agile approach to learning.

item.title: Circadian Rhythms
item.dc:creator: Russ
item.content:encoded: What is improvisation? The question likely provokes several answers with varying degrees of detail. Most initial responses will likely center around some version of music, be it jazz, JS Bach, Mozart, or many current professionals. Actors and comedians will probably have a strong showing also. Note, they’re all performers. But is improvisation really a talent that belongs only to those on the stage? Maybe. But I’d also go to Shakespeare and counter with “All the world’s stage, and all the men and women merely players.” This is a blog post on my company’s website. It’s only available in the somewhat modern Internet age through a computer or other e-device using layers of complex software and communication networks to present you with words to read. So, I feel safe in saying, yes, you the reader are a player on a stage, and you do improvise. It’s a part of modern life for most of us. So many options causing us to make so many choices and adjustments in what we want, how to get what we want, and the rules, obstacles, and tools we need to actually obtain what we want — unless we want for something different along the way. We’re constantly adapting our lives to include more. We want the richest life experience we can make and it’s not an oratory. There are millions of players on the stage who are all working with the script until something happens and we need to improvise. At times, life is one big group improv. We're used to it, right? So, how do you make a difference? You can speak your lines with confidence and project your voice to the back of the theater. But when you’re forced to improvise, your confidence in creating something to say from absolutely nothing might be rather low. To gain high confidence, you need to get better at improvising. To get better, you practice. You do it. Again and again. The faster you can make good choices in situations where the script is vague or absent the better the performance of the play will be on a given night. My friend Art Lande is a Jedi Master of improvisation. He is an extraordinary musician and he has an uncanny ability to create high quality prose, poetry, and witticisms, as well as insightful inferences into a wide variety of topics in the moment in any situation. It is a talent he had early and a skill he honed and perfected. It’s his role in the grand play and he is happy doing it. Have you found your role? Whether you have or have not, keep doing the adventurous auditions. Keep exploring and stumbling, and basking in successes. Curtain’s up. Enter stage right. Hit your mark and say it, or wing it. Be ready to make them both work. It’s a great play.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Circadian Rhythms | Commerce Kitchen
The art of improvisation in life is not lost on our senior developer, Russ. All the world's a stage, and adaption is key to your success on that stage.

item.title: An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 2
item.dc:creator: corey
item.content:encoded:
A New School Model: Architecture for the future of now

Last time, I spoke to the shortcomings of current education as I see them. I briefly discussed a landscape of ideas for a new system, one that changes the paradigms. Adding dimension to the learning experience through a culture of mentorship, professional practice, and agility. This time, let's start to dig into some of the details, take a look below the surface, and begin to understand the structure of this new model. I like to refer to this model as Agile Education. I take this name from the world of engineering, most specifically software engineering. In a nutshell, agile means just what one might think: if your work is agile it means it is well planned, but executed with flexibility. Nothing is set in stone, allowing members of team to work along a well planned track, while being well equipped to “roll with the punches,” so to speak. Agile work is done is short measured iterations, “sprints” as they are often called, allowing for a short executable plan to be taken on, quickly reviewed for success, and then adjusted for the next sprint. Before I start to dig too deep let me quickly define a couple of ideas:
  • Systemic architecture: this is the over-body structure that defines how the school pattern works;
    • Daily schedules
    • Content blocking
    • Yearly articulation
  • Application architecture: this is the pedagogy structure that governs daily interactions
    • Mentor student interactions
    • Assessments / metrics
    • Learn / apply / retro / advance cycle

Blending Modalities

Education has started to look as more intelligent designs, unfortunately in the current system these are just road patches being applied to a rusting hulk. That is not to say however that we can’t take some of those fresh ideas and bring them forward. So lets begin our discussion with blending modalities. And from this idea I would take two methods, and apply one to the system and the other to application:

Spiraling Curriculum Model (systemic architecture)

This model is based on advancing recursion. If we take the timeline of a students education and “twist it” to develop a spiral, we create a landscape that continually keeps it history within reach, ideas are continually revisited, but at a constantly developing level. In this model, students constantly look at existing knowledge, and apply it forward to building learning. It keeps concepts fresh, and inherently answers the question of “why should we learn this”. It also forms a standard that easily allows individuals to drop down and review ideas that are challenging or points of struggle. They can do this time and again, as ideas mature, become more relevant, or even as our knowledge as a society evolves. Each learner has an intrinsic connection to their path of learning, it is not a straight line, and they are required to exercise control within it progression(s). Where we have failed in the implementation of this model historically is that we assure each circling of the spiral should be one year in length. This means that a student potentially won’t pass through an important zone of revisitation for as long as a year. The circles need to be much much tighter: as small as two months in duration, with as many as five or six cycles per year. I will talk about a revamping of the academic calendar in more detail later, but in this moment it is important to recognize more chances to repeatedly apply skills and ideas, refine understanding, and experiment for greater success or differing outcome will always lead to depth of understanding vs. the more current reliance of persisting memory of facts in the hopes of garnering skills.

Parallel Curriculum Model (application architecture)

The old school idea of content isolation is ludicrous to say the least. Think simply of your professional life: at what point have you ever done ONLY biology, or ONLY construction? The application and development of mastery within a craft in the real world is only achieved through the amalgamation of multiple skills. Scientists have to be writers, politicians, communicators, inventors, mathematicians, and yes biologist (or other). The parallel model believes that all content has both established and un-established parallels with other content areas. It allows us to blur the lines of isolated content delivery, and introduce a system that teaches cross-content skills, application of craft specific knowledge, and whole professional mastery and acquisition. The applied practice of “teaching” is no longer about one classroom one skill set, instead it all becomes a series of exercises in doing and thinking. Where we currently fail in the application of this model is in putting content first and finding parallels after. Trying to affix or “mine” out parallels between bodies of content that have a long standing history of isolation is an exercise in futility. If you want some first hand experience with this, stop by a school and tell a math teacher that you need them to find language arts parallels within their content that will aid students in learning the mechanics of writing, and then work to support those parallels within their daily teaching. If you really want some fireworks, follow that up by telling the whole staff that your school's goals for the year are focussed on improving student scores in writing and that each of them will be expected to support that by seeking parallels and daily content support. The potential for explosion here will not be the teachers fault, but more the fault of the system which has required them to isolate their expertise. By applying these models to the inception of the idea we are able to immediately the system. First off the whole of the system becomes aligned, at the top level we spiral in a way that has continual relevance. Telling a student that they need to learn something because they will need to apply it over and over and over in short windows of time, and furthermore that they are societally expected to get better at it each time chances the importance of the process. Blurring the lines of content removes barriers to learning, and furthermore has the critical effect of all content equal measure of importance. Lastly, it allows us to update the cognitive model; we can discard the old-school Piaget philosophy, which seems to emphasize the limitations set by cognitive staging. And instead turn more whole faced to Gardner’s ideals which look more specifically at cognitive maturation as a process of thought facilitation and complex strategy application by the learner. “Genius is not born, it is built; through very hard practice, appropriate reinforcement, and immediate balanced feedback…” -- me Next time: breaking down the physical structure of education for the New School Model; redesigning the learning environment from the ground up.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 2
In this post, Corey will dig into some of the details, take a look below the surface, and begin to understand the structure of this new model of learning.

item.title: Commerce Kitchen Wins Best Places to Work, Colorado Companies to Watch
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Commerce Kitchen is growing and evolving. We've experienced quite a few changes in the past year, and we couldn't be more excited about where we're headed this year and beyond. Apparently, there are other folks that agree with us. We have some exciting announcements to make!

Denver Business Journal's Best Places to Work

We work hard to take care of our people. When we found out we had placed third as Denver's Best Place to Work in the Small Company category, we were over the moon. DBJ honors companies with teams ranging from 10 employees to over 100 from around Denver, all with qualities that show they've invested the time and energy to invest in their people. We don't believe that culture comes from the top. What makes Commerce Kitchen a great place to work is our people. We invest in each other every single day. Here are just a few of the perks of being one of us:
  • Unlimited PTO
  • Off-site Education Days spent learning about something cool and interesting
  • On-site, trainer-led yoga classes and bootcamp sessions
  • Access to both private and open office spaces
  • "Fireside Chats" with the CEO to give open and honest feedback
  • Equal opportunity for individual growth and professional development in our flat-structured organization
We're so excited about being one of Denver's Best Places to Work. And in third place, we feel pretty good about it.

Colorado Companies to Watch 2015 Winners

In May, we found out that - in our third consecutive year being nominated - we were one of 50 Colorado Companies to Watch winners. We've had to keep quiet about our win until last Friday's Winners Gala, but now we can finally shout from the mountaintops about it! Each year, Colorado Companies to Watch honors "second-stage companies for the critical role they play in our state and community economies." In its seventh year, Colorado Companies to Watch received over 1,200 nominations of organizations and businesses from around the state. We're so excited to be one of the 50 winners of such a wonderful award! We're proud of where we've been, and we're just getting started. Me thinks you'll be seeing much more of us in the future.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/cctw_05194627_4979-L.jpg
colorado companies to watch
CK Wins Best Places to Work, Colorado Companies to Watch
We've been busy, and people around Colorado are starting to notice! Here's some exciting news about us.

item.title: Is the Résumé Still Relevant?
item.dc:creator: jackson
item.content:encoded:
My résumé did not lead me to my current position at Commerce Kitchen. In reality, my résumé has done nothing for me. Two years ago, I envisioned a game plan to transition from arts nonprofit fundraising to tech for-profit business development. My hunch at the time was that in order for me to successfully land a biz dev position in the tech field, I was going to have to find a champion to go to bat for me during the hiring process. Now, speaking from experience, I found that hunch to be accurate.

Exhibit A

Last year, in a moment of unshakable dissatisfaction with my current job, I decided to send my newly polished résumé to an ERP consultancy, where at the time I had a friend on staff. The human resources director obtained the document highlighting my accomplishments and expertise and quickly shuffled it to the back of the pile. I know this because the HR director told me so. It was only after my friend paid him a visit that he decided to call me. The HR director did not make the connection and assumed that a mistake had been made. I fielded all of the predicted questions. “How does your current experience translate?” “Why are you looking to do this?” “What do you currently make?” Alas, the company decided to go another direction. And I am glad they did.

“You’re Not What We’re Looking For.”

More recently, during yet another sour period at work, I decided to send my résumé to a booming startup that had recently opened an office in Denver. Much to my disappointment (but unsurprisingly), I received no word. A couple of months passed, and I ran into the startup’s internal recruiter at a meetup. I inquired regarding sales/biz dev openings and expressed my interest. She quickly - and only somewhat politely - dismissed me as not having relevant experience. It seemed as though she had a clear vision of what she was looking for, and an arts fundraiser was not it.

Jackpot

So how did I find myself as an account executive for Commerce Kitchen? Authentic networking. It all started with humbly asking questions. What does the tech landscape look like, and how was I to find myself in it? Here is what I have done, could that translate into something relevant? With good fortune, and with the help of a great friend, I found the right people to answer these questions. The initial conversation contained no ‘hire me’ pitch, yet it ultimately lead to that effect. They say that 70-80% of jobs go unadvertised. Whether or not that figure is accurate, we can all agree that a large chunk of job opportunities go unposted. The reason I love authentic networking–where the intent is to connect on a human level, not the utilitarian level–is because over time it will reveal the path of best fit, and lend these hidden job opportunities to you. It certainly did for me. And I know it has for others. A résumé would not have done the same. Although it may be an easy focus to have the most polished résumé and the firmest handshake, meeting people and sharing your curiosities can be much more rewarding. I would postulate that this will continue to be universally true in the job market. In fact, I would wager that I will never have to polish my résumé again.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Is the Résumé Still Relevant? | Commerce Kitchen
résumé
Jackson's resume did not get him his job at Commerce Kitchen. So in the age of networking and forming business relationships, where do resumes fit in?

item.title: Are Millennials Loyal to their Jobs?
item.dc:creator: jen
item.content:encoded:
Millennials, millennials, millennials. We're all anyone can talk about theses days. As our generation starts to flood the workforce (because *gasp!* that's what happens when a group of people reach the standard working age), Gen X-ers and Baby Boomers are trying to figure out what we want, how to relate to us, and why we buy the products that we do. I've even talked about marketing to millennials, which is a big deal because I'm notorious for rolling my eyes whenever someone even utters the word "millennial." We're an extremely relevant demographic right now. We're the prettiest girl at the dance, but no one will buck up the courage to talk to us. In my last blog post about millennials, I said that we're extremely loyal to brands that we love. Oftentimes I'll hear my friends talk about buying here vs. buying there because Company A supports local businesses while Company B operates out of sweatshops in Eastern Asia. But what about our jobs, our careers? Are we loyal to businesses who hire us? How long do we stay there? Let's talk millennial loyalty to our places of work.

Papa Told Us to Be Rolling Stones

First things first, what were we told to do? When each of us started to have panic attacks as we finished getting our [expensive] degrees, what did we hear from our parents, our mentors, our counselors? My parents told me that having many different kinds of work experiences would be valuable, which is hilarious because they've been in the same industries for the past three decades. My career counselor told me that I should work at my first job for a few years and then move on to a new adventure. When you try to find out what to do by reading articles online, you get confused. Some folks say that the ideal period of time at any given job is about four years, and if you stay longer than that (i.e.: closer to six years), you're actually hurting yourself. But it's hard to argue with numbers. Specifically, a study was published last year that said that staying at the same company for more than two years makes you earn 50% less during your career. Other folks are in agreement that working for one company for less than a year makes you look like a drifter. However, according to a report called Gen Y on the Job, over a quarter of millennials believe that workers should stay in a role for less than a year before moving on. So what is the truth??

The Stepping Stone Conundrum

The many pieces of advice we were given contradict each other. You need to have lots of different kinds of work experiences. You need to have 3-5 years of work experience in a field in order to be considered for a position. But don't stay at a company for more than two years, otherwise you'll earn less. Thus, the Stepping Stone Conundrum was born. "Stepping Stones" are what we millennials call the jobs we think will get us places. They're the positions we think will help us in the future. We say to ourselves, "Hey, if I do a stint at [insert prestigious company name here], then I'll definitely have a better chance of ending up somewhere better in a year or two!" This flawed logic brings us to the main question here: Are millennials loyal to their jobs?

Dreaming Big

Our parents told us that we were special one too many times. They told us that we can do anything we want to do and be anything we want to be. While supportive parents aren't anything to be ashamed of, it has caused millennials to dream big. So when I question our loyalty to our jobs, I'm really questioning where our heads are at on a day-to-day basis. My friends, for example, are all very driven. They have their personal and career goals that they strive for each day, yet I'm also seeing a new trend. They talk about 'the next step.' They're uncertain how long they're going to be at their current jobs, because they're anticipating something better to come along that will be more in line with their dreams. Why are our perceptions of work and the reality of work so different? Do we have higher expectations for finding fulfilling jobs than our Gen X and Baby Boomer predecessors? Why won't we settle for good? Why are we so determined to achieve greatness?

How to Keep Us Around

I won't be the first person to say this, and I won't be the last one. It all comes down to culture. Millennials want more out of their jobs. We want an experience. We want benefits and perks. We want coworkers who will become our friends and mentors. Why do we know we want these things? Because our friends are working at great companies where people and culture are valued. We've seen how spending time and money on people and culture can have a positive impact on employee retention and overall happiness, and we don't want to work for organizations who don't value their people. Easier said than done, I suppose, but we're worth the investment.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Are Millennials Loyal to their Jobs? | Commerce Kitchen
Millennials are hard to pin down. Are they loyal to businesses who hire them? How long do they stay there? Let's talk millennial loyalty.

item.title: An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 3
item.dc:creator: corey
item.content:encoded:
Part 1 of this blog series can be found here. And Part 2 can be found here.

Putting Bricks in the Wall

In the last episode of An Agile Approach to Learning, I discussed the inception of a new school model, the idea of agile education, and the importance of the duality that exists between the Systemic Architecture and the Application Architecture. This time I will start to lay the bricks and mortar of the "New School." The primary focus of this portion of my discussion will be on Systemic Architecture, as it acts as the foundation. One does not construct a home without a thoughtfully laid foundation. Within this, I abstract a bit from the more traditional model of Agile workflow, and take some liberties with definitions. But, that in and of itself is agile application, so maybe the departure is not all that notable. None the less, I will begin again with some definitions.
  • Sections: Each is three years in length. These are used for designating time periods for umbrella concepts, designed to develop cognition throughout the greater learning process. They are not curriculum specific, but instead tied closely into developmental understanding. They are highly elastic and extensible, and have not metric based assessment tied to them.
  • Iterations: Each is one year in length. They are designed to flow seamlessly, as such the overall timeline of each year needs to change. Furthermore this is no need for grandiose final assessments, because retro-assessment becomes a built-in
  • Blocks: Each block is 45 days in length. Blocks act as the foundation for the articulation spiral. This means that the spiral repeats and elevates 3 times per-year(iteration), as opposed to the more standard 1 year circle.
  • Sprints: Each sprint is 3 weeks in length, this is where the learning happens. They are well planned, rigorous, and in depth. Sprints can and should in fact spiral within the block. Offering an even greater emphasis of revisitation, application, and elevation of ideas, skills, and novel topics.
Note: the underlying timeline of this structure is based on the currently used balanced calendar year. This structure allows for some very positive systemic changes. First, students no longer are segmented into grades. The total number of Iterations a student completes may range from twelve to fifteen or even sixteen. The idea that every human has to learn everything in twelve years is medieval at best. It is comes for archaic conjurings of capability, limitations, and down right stupidity. To limit a person's potential to twelve poorly designed years is laughable. This improved designs allows us to make a simple statement to all students. “Come here, work hard, and learn all that you can. If you do this, we will not give up on you, we will not turn you away, and we will grow along with you. Your efforts matter, each and every one, each and every day.” This all means shorter cycles, less downtime, more engagement, greater growth. There is an overlying architecture however that is applied to each Section. The following flow demonstrates the detail of how this functions:
  • Section One { Iterations 1 → 3 } (Creative interaction with artistic ideas and thinking)
    • Making useful ideas into useful things
    • How the art(s) sculpt our world and our interactions
    • Broadening the definition of art beyond the fine
  • Section Two { Iterations 4 → 6 } (Thinking outside the box of beliefs, problem solving with artistic creativity)
    • Introduction to complex / multi-facet problems
    • Spontaneous thinking
      • Changing terms of success / completion
      • Dealing with frustration constructively
      • Assessing unknowns
    • Seeing art within algorithms
  • Section Three { Iterations 7 → 9 } (Solving problems through technology, utilizing complex systems)
    • Entry level coding (yes for each and every student)
    • Complex mathematics, thinking, and logic systems
    • Solving multi-layer / multi-outcome problems
    • Dynamic solutions and theoretical thinking patterns
  • Section Four { Iterations 10 → ?? } (Globalism, professionalism, mastery)
    • Development and application of professional skills
    • Integration into global perspectives
      • application of skills to meaningful global contributions
    • Professional menteeship
  • At all levels
    • Developing thinkers, everyday, every Fundamental Parallel
    • Problem solving
    • Collaboration
      • Paradigms successful of collaboration
      • Dealing with collaborative frustration
      • Abstracting personal from professional in the collaborative environment
      • Resolution of conflict without walking away from the collaborative table
    • Subscribing to standard(s) of personal resilience
    • Adoption of the 3 keys to lifelong learning addiction
      • CHOOSE TO HAVE FUN
        • not all things are inherently fun, you have the power to manage your mindset / mindfulness
      • VALIDATION THROUGH HARD WORK
        • measure yourself and others through their deeds and accomplishments, strip away the imposition of perceived expectations
      • DO THINGS THAT ARE WORTHWHILE
        • all collaborative members should understand why we do what we do and be able to state its importance to the individual and the culture
The final piece of the structure is the Fundamental Parallels, this is where the true integrity of the system is established. These parallels break down the curricular walls and require that students apply a wealth of skills across perceived borders of understanding. They must exist at every level in every sprint, iteration, block, and section. It is through these that we may discard the “core subject model” [Language Arts, Math, Social Studies, Science].

The Fundamental Parallels:

  • Parallel 1: Art, Architecture, and Creativity . . . (Fine Arts)
  • Parallel 2: Articulation and Communication . . . (Linguistics)
  • Parallel 3: Logic, Accuracy, Design . . . (Sciences [Mathematics])
  • Parallel 4: Global Interest, Humanism, Meaningful Contribution . . . (Humanities)
Does this change everything? You bet it does, which is why it’s hard, but nothing worth doing was ever easy, at least not in my opinion! It immediately changes the definitions of what makes a lesson, what makes a teacher, and what makes a student. The classroom becomes a collaborative table. The grading system goes out the window (my fury on that will come in time). The whole system becomes a network of scaffolds, that create expert thinkers, who understand technical ideas and are intrinsic parts of society. Currently, school is the social queue. Students are allowed to participate in the greater social structure until they go through the motions. The New School sees students as what they are, the future of society, a future that needs immediate integration, and needs to be empowered to do meaningful things in that society from day one. Next time: attacking the Application Architecture, creating a platform for buy in, and redefining meaningful roles within the community.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/shutterstock_249910381.jpg
An Agile Approach to Learning: Part 3 | Commerce Kitchen
Corey's talked about how an agile approach to learning could improve the way in which our society is educated. In this post, he intros the 'New School.'

item.title: A Fresh Take On Networking
item.dc:creator: jackson
item.content:encoded: In my previous blog post, I mentioned that my golden ticket into Commerce Kitchen was authentic networking. But what the hell does "authentic networking" mean? Whenever we hear “networking,” we have to actively suppress our reactionary groans. Why? It’s because we paint this picture in our heads of the scenario that is all too familiar: a happy hour (misnomer) in a bland venue with a bunch of strangers uncomfortably buttoned-up in business casual, mindlessly trading business cards while trying to recall any buzzwords to recite in order to sound business-y. It has become a meme in its own right. And nobody likes it. You might as well have a Business Card Bazooka (patent pending), where you show up and fire away hundreds of business cards into a crowd. At least in this case, chances are you would be more memorable. So what about authentic networking? Here, we move from the soundbites of our LinkedIn pages and stumble onto something deeper. We express passion and demonstrate curiosity. We try to find a link that reminds us that we are human beings first, not associates. This is how the right path is revealed to us. And if your aim is to land a new job, this is how you will test the culture of the prospective company. It’s much harder to test the culture solely based on business metrics. Expressing interest in someone as a human being goes a long way. This is how people will remember you, too. Odds are a business pitch will be forgotten in a matter of hours, but the gut feeling you left someone can last forever. Ask about what really matters to them, whether that be a side project, their family, or their salsa lessons. This isn’t to say that business won’t matter to individuals - quite the opposite, in fact - but this is the point that fifteen other people just belabored. Authentic networking is truly a skill, and like any skill it takes practice to become good at it. Practice this in any conversation you are experiencing – after all, listening is the most important part. Search through dialogue for what people really care about and highlight those passions. I encourage everyone to work on authentic networking. Being a flashy, slick networker will continue to go out of style. Make a human connection. Who knows? You may just like it.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A Fresh Take On Networking | Commerce Kitchen
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/shutterstock_296179508.jpg
Whenever we hear “networking,” we have to actively suppress our reactionary groans. So what if we tried something different when trying to make connections?

item.title: A Developer's Take on Agile Development
item.dc:creator: eric
item.content:encoded:
2:22 AM Ramblings on Agile Development

I am currently unable to sleep, nerdily enough because my pre-dream thoughts tonight (and 99.9% of every other night ever) are largely composed of thoughts on development. Tonight, however, my thoughts have centered their focus on Agile development, specifically how it relates to current/past on-goings, and how I've come to a few of my own realizations about it. About two weeks ago I watched a video that has since had an unusually profound effect on how I think about Agile. Go watch it, and then read on.

Challenges with Creativity

When watching the video, it really struck me how such a trivial thing - something everyone sees at least once every day of their life - was at one time an absolute complete unknown. While that may be a "Wow! - total mind blower" moment for some, that alone isn't what fascinated me. What I was truly drawn to was the story of how Bell Labs went about solving the problem of: "What button layout do we put on phones now that we can make buttons?" In the video, the presenter mentions that, when the opportunity arose to switch from the standard rotary dial to buttons, the natural go-to layout would be to place the buttons in the same place the "holes" were on a rotary dial. Seems logical, right? Put the number buttons where everyone is already used to seeing them, in a counter-clockwise circle starting in the top right. Done. But then she says probably the most important thing one can say when doing Agile development: "There's no reason it has to be that way." Thank you! Everything I've ever thought condensed down to a single sentence that couldn't be clearer. Repeat that to yourself: "There is no reason it has to be that way." Now you're probably thinking, "Well duh, I'm a developer/designer/project manager/scrum master/what-have-you. I'm creative. I always think that way." Maybe not as much as you think, turbo thunder. I've been thinking that creativity - as it relates to agile development - can be very much hindered by those calling the shots, a.k.a. "clients." *gasp!* Do I think clients are at fault for hindering creativity? No, absolutely not. Clients know what they know. They know their product. They know their process. It's not their responsibility to know what will work. It's their responsibility to make sure that what will work actually works for them. So how do you tell a client that your creative idea will work for them? How do you tell a straight straw it can bend? The answer is more than likely: you don't. Instead, you show.

Prototyping

This gets me to another thought on Agile development: it has less to do with being "flexible" (in terms of what you develop) so that it can accommodate what might come along, and more about getting clients something substantial, faster. Rapid prototyping. In my personal experience, trying to explain my creative ideas to clients goes off about as well as a papaya explaining quantum theory to a dog. Not that the client isn't capable or willing to understand what I'm saying, but I'm a papaya, they are a dog. Both speak their own language and understand things in completely different ways; the problem of misunderstanding is very much a two-way street. Rapid prototyping would be my preferred solution to overcoming this communication barrier. As they say, a picture is worth a thousand words. It may then hold true that a rough example of a feature is worth a two hour meeting. If communication is not working after 10-15 minutes, then perhaps a non-styled, quick and dirty marked-up form with next to no error handling on the backend can help convey an idea — provided it can be done in any where from 10 minutes to a couple hours. Spending 5+ hours on a prototype makes it almost exactly the opposite, so don't do that.

Compromise Leads to Greatness

Another, maybe more subtle part of the video is the end result. Throughout the video, the presenter points out a few layouts that people had a favorable opinion of, was fastest to dial, or was the most accurate. You may have also noticed that the phone number layout we have today looks nothing like any of those layouts. That brings me to my second point of Agile development: the compromises. Some folks might think Agile means taking X number of things the client would like to have and shaping that into priorities and discarding the rest. While that is to a certain extent true, it's not necessarily wise to take ten requests and whittle that down to one or two that you can do 100% according to what the client requested. Provided a little agile-ness and flexibility, it might be possible to get even more out of those ten requests by tweaking them just a little bit. If you were given the choice of eating one whole slice of pie just because you can't have ten, or eating 90% of four slices of pie, which would you choose? It's a matter of compromise that falls squarely on that of the client. However, remember that clients aren't the ones responsible for thinking what 90% of their pie looks like, or how that could potentially tie in to a few other 90% slices of pie. Again, the key is to show them. This means options. This means creating every possible phone button layout you can think of. It also means my last point on Agile: knowing what's possible ahead of time.

Getting to the Moon

Too often, I worry that everyday problems in the development process are chocked up to, "Well, that's Agile for you." Quite frankly, I think that's a poor excuse for something that's not necessarily avoidable, but preventable. The specific problem I refer to is the constant potential of lacking information, but it goes even deeper than that. I'd like to think I understand that no one can know everything at any given moment. Yet, the problem with that arises when you try to work with that by building for everything. The fact of the matter is you probably shouldn't build for everything. Perhaps rapid prototyping is a possible answer, since the alternative of building for everything will yield really crappy code/functionality in the end. This problem of "building for everything" is probably one of, if not the biggest pain point for me as it relates to Agile. Imagine if you will that I ask you to build a rocket. What are some questions you might ask?

"How many crew do we need to account for?

Where does the rocket need to travel to?

Does it need to return to Earth?

What's our payload?"

Now imagine my answer is: *shoulder shrug* "I don't know." The "building for everything" process means you now need to design a rocket that goes... somewhere, with some... people? And return... maybe? This right here is the example of why Agile can't mean being open to anything that might come along. Your rocket failed. Agile should mean being flexible based one what you know. Now forget the above answers and pretend I said this instead:

"At least 4 crew members.

Going to the moon, but unsure if landing or just orbiting.

Payload, if any, won't be bigger than 200 lbs."

I intentionally left out one answer there, to the question about returning to Earth. Thinking logically, what would you presume the answer would be based on what I was able to provide? If you said yes it needs to return to Earth because we're taking people to the moon, then pat yourself on the back because you are a deducer of things, and also not a sociopath. Who leaves 4 people in space?! So what does building your rocket look like? Well, it'll probably a couple stages since we're going to the moon. And the crew cabin should be pretty large: 4 comfortable = 7 cozy? It should also have a payload bay of medium-large size. Remember people? Yeah, they eat food — another thing I failed to mention. So up to a 200 lb object + food for 4 people. How about a lander? Well, since I didn't say one way or another that we'd be landing on the moon maybe the best option is to just go ahead and account for it. If we decide to land, great! We're done already. If not, aside from being a bummer, it's not terribly difficult to remove a lander. You'll just have a larger payload bay. That's a little bit more refined idea of a rocket than we had before, isn't it? I didn't even provide very clear information. It's a similar concept as it relates to Agile. No, you don't need to know everything up front, but even a rough guess as to what you might need is better than just saying, "We don't know. Let's check with the clients on that one." Usually only two possible results come from an idea like that. Either the client doesn't know and you spend several days seeking answers, or the client thinks they know and are actually wrong. Either way, a best guess on the part of the team knowing what they know about the clients product and/or process could be the most "Agile" solution. While opinions vary greatly as to what Agile means, for me Agile means not being too agile. Taking a step back, saying no, and doing only what is reasonable when you have the resources to do so is my approach to Agile development. Always keeping in mind the difference between who you're building for and who you're building it to work for is also critical. When Bell Labs was designing phones with buttons instead of rotary dials, they were building for everyone aged 3 to 103, not for their engineers. Had they not built for the user, phones as we know it would be a heck of a lot different. Sometimes in Agile, the answer you're looking for may be the one that no one notices. As part of a dev studio, it is our job to find all of the answers, and maybe even throw them all away in favor of the right one. Or something like that.

A Developer's Take on Agile Development
http://www.commercekitchen.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/shutterstock_86356015.jpg
What can we learn from the development of modern-day phone dial pad? There are some lessons that we can apply to agile development here.

item.title: B2B Market Segmentation: Diffusion of Innovators
item.dc:creator: jackson
item.content:encoded: Regardless if you are selling B2B or B2C, market segmentation is always a good idea. Properly defining your target market segment will allow you to know to whom you are selling, and that will allow you to discover why a particular segment should buy from you rather than any of your competitors. Everyone knows this. Typically in the B2B landscape, businesses will look at factors like geography, firmographics, behavior, and needs to get a sense of their target market segment. Increasingly, businesses are finding that these qualifications fall short in providing a meaningful or powerful target sale profile. In response, there has been an upward trend of taking deeper dives into the psychological archetypes and personas of market segments, to better obtain a holistic understanding of the buyer. Let’s propose a new and perhaps helpful qualification. Everett Rogers theorized on the rate of new ideas and technology spreading through cultures in 1962. This is known as diffusion of innovations. He carefully defined five categories: innovators, early adopters, early majority, late majority, and laggards. In reality, very few are innovators (and you can meditate on whether or not you fall in that category for as long as you’d like). What if we were to take this curve and convert it into an x-axis? And what if we were to duplicate this curve, rotate it 90º and convert it into an y-axis? Imagine the x-axis as the target decision maker and the y-axis as the industry of the target sale. This will reveal interesting trends regarding your target market segments. Are you primarily selling to innovators in laggard industries? Are you primarily selling to innovators in innovator verticals? Which quadrant do you find yourself selling in? Are your competitors in your quadrant or another? The beauty of this exercise is it provides flexibility. Are you only selling in one industry? Could you change the y-axis to reflect something more meaningful for your sales strategy? Finding out about where your sales exist in the realm of innovation is important, and will soon be paramount as the Internet of Things becomes the standard for innovators, laggards, and everyone in between.

There has been an upward trend of taking deeper dives into the psychological archetypes and personas of market segments. So what about innovators?
